faqs.question: I broke both bones in my forearm (the radius and ulna). My doctor says I absolutely need surgery. Why?
faqs.answer: The forearm is a complex, rotating joint. The radius and ulna bones work together to let you turn your palm up and down (supination and pronation). If both bones are broken in an adult, they are extremely unstable and will not heal in the perfect alignment needed for this rotation. Adult both-bone forearm fractures are almost always treated with surgery (plates and screws) to restore the precise length and alignment.

faqs.question: What is a nightstick fracture?
faqs.answer: This is a specific, isolated fracture of the ulna (the bone on your pinky-side of the forearm). It gets its name from being a defensive injury, where a person raises their arm to block a blow from an object (like a nightstick). Since the radius bone is not broken, it often just needs to be treated with a cast or a brace.

faqs.question: I broke my elbow (olecranon fracture) and my doctor says the pieces are distracted. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: An olecranon fracture is a break of the pointy bone of your elbow, which is where your powerful triceps muscle attaches. When it breaks, the triceps muscle pulls the broken piece away from the rest of the bone—this is called a distracted or displaced fracture. Because the muscle is constantly pulling it apart, this fracture cannot heal on its own and will require surgery (usually with wires or a plate) to pull the pieces back together.

faqs.question: My doctor is worried about radial nerve palsy with my humerus fracture. What would I notice?
faqs.answer: The radial nerve runs in a groove right against the back of the humerus bone, making it very vulnerable in a fracture. This nerve controls the muscles that lift your wrist and fingers. The classic sign of radial nerve palsy is wrist drop—you would be completely unable to extend your wrist or straighten your fingers. It would just hang limply. The good news is that in 90% of cases, this is just a stretch injury (neuropraxia) and the nerve function will slowly return over several months.

faqs.question: I have a big, squishy, swollen lump on my elbow (Popeye elbow). It doesn't really hurt. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of olecranon bursitis. You have a bursa—a thin, fluid-filled sac—that acts as a cushion between your pointy elbow bone and your skin. If you rest your elbow on a hard surface too much (student's elbow) or bang it hard, that sac gets inflamed and fills up with a lot of extra fluid, creating that squishy lump.

faqs.question: My hip hurts when I lie on my side at night and when I get up from a chair. Is this arthritis?
faqs.answer: It's much more likely to be trochanteric bursitis. You have a large bursa on the outside point of your hip (the greater trochanter). When this gets inflamed (often from weak gluteal muscles or a tight IT band), it causes a deep, aching pain right on the side of your hip. It's famously painful when you lie on that side (which puts direct pressure on it) or when you use the gluteal muscles to stand up from a seated position.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to give me a cortisone shot for my shoulder bursitis. Is that safe? Will it wear away my joint?
faqs.answer: Cortisone (a corticosteroid) is a powerful anti-inflammatory. When injected directly into the inflamed bursa, it is very effective at putting out the fire and giving you rapid pain relief. This is very safe. The concern about wearing away tissue is related to multiple, frequent injections into a tendon or the joint cartilage itself. A single, well-placed injection into a bursa is a standard, low-risk, and highly effective treatment.

faqs.question: My elbow bursitis is now hot, red, and I have a fever. What's happening?
faqs.answer: You need to be seen by a doctor immediately. This is the major warning sign that your bursitis has become infected. This is called septic bursitis. It can happen if a small scrape or bug bite over the bursa allows bacteria (like staph) to get inside the fluid sac. This is a serious infection. You will need to have the fluid drained with a needle (aspirated) and sent to a lab, and you will require strong antibiotics.

faqs.question: What's the difference between bursitis and tendinitis? My doctor said I have both in my shoulder.
faqs.answer: They are neighbors and are often inflamed together, which is part of impingement syndrome. The tendons (like your rotator cuff) are the ropes that attach your muscles to your bones. Tendinitis is when these ropes get frayed and inflamed. The bursa is the cushion sac that sits on top of those tendons to protect them from the bone above (the acromion). Bursitis is when this cushion gets inflamed. In your shoulder, when you lift your arm, the inflamed tendon and the inflamed bursa both get pinched, causing pain.

faqs.question: My mouth is on fire, but my doctor and dentist say they can't see anything wrong. Am I imagining this?
faqs.answer: You are absolutely not imagining it. This is the classic, and very frustrating, presentation of Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS). It is a neuropathic (nerve) pain condition. This means the problem isn't with the tissues of your mouth (like an infection, sore, or burn), but with the nerves that send taste and sensation signals to your brain. Your mouth looks normal, but the nerves are misfiring and sending constant pain signals.

faqs.question: Why did this start right after menopause? Is there a connection?
faqs.answer: This is a very strong link. The vast majority of primary BMS sufferers are postmenopausal women. While the exact mechanism isn't proven, it's strongly believed that the sharp decline in estrogen and progesterone has a direct effect on the tiny nerve fibers (especially those related to taste) in the oral cavity. This hormonal change may make the nerves dysfunctional or over-sensitive, triggering the chronic burning sensation.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to give me an anti-seizure drug (like gabapentin) or an antidepressant for my mouth. Why?
faqs.answer: It sounds strange, but this is a standard treatment for neuropathic pain. Medications like gabapentin (an anti-seizure drug) or amitriptyline (an antidepressant) are used in low doses to treat nerve pain. They work by calming down the overactive, misfiring nerves. They aren't treating seizures or depression in this case; they are treating the dysfunctional nerves that are causing the burning pain signal.

faqs.question: I also have a bitter or metallic taste in my mouth all the time. Is that related?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is another classic symptom. The nerves responsible for taste (the chorda tympani nerve) and the nerves for sensation (the trigeminal nerve) are closely intertwined. In BMS, the dysfunction often affects both. This results in dysgeusia (a distorted taste, often metallic or bitter) and xerostomia (a persistent feeling of a dry mouth, even if you are producing saliva).

faqs.question: Are there any home remedies that actually work? Spicy food makes it so much worse.
faqs.answer: You're right that avoiding triggers is key. Triggers often include acidic foods (tomatoes, citrus), spicy foods (capsaicin), and strong mints or cinnamon. Many people find temporary relief from symptomatic treatments: sucking on ice chips, sipping cold water, or chewing sugar-free gum (which stimulates saliva and distracts the nerves). Some people also find relief from alpha-lipoic acid (a supplement) or topical clonazepam (a mouthwash prescribed by a doctor that numbs the nerves locally).

faqs.question: Why did my blistering (second-degree) burn hurt so much, but the doctor is more worried about my deep (third-degree) burn that feels numb?
faqs.answer: This is a key diagnostic sign. A second-degree burn is excruciatingly painful because it has destroyed the top layer of skin and is irritating the nerve-rich dermal layer below. A full-thickness, third-degree burn is often painless or just feels like dull pressure because it has completely destroyed all skin layers, including the nerves themselves. The nerves are too damaged to send any pain signals. This indicates a much deeper, more severe injury.

faqs.question: The hospital is giving me massive amounts of IV fluids for burn shock. What is that?
faqs.answer: Burn shock is a specific type of hypovolemic (low volume) shock. A major burn causes a massive, body-wide inflammatory reaction. This makes your blood vessels become leaky, allowing huge amounts of fluid (plasma) to seep out of your bloodstream and into your tissues. This causes massive swelling and, more dangerously, a severe drop in your circulating blood volume. This leads to low blood pressure and organ failure. The IV fluids are to resuscitate you by replacing this lost volume.

faqs.question: Why is the risk of infection so high? I'm in a clean hospital room.
faqs.answer: Your skin is your single most important barrier against infection. A burn has completely destroyed this barrier, leaving a warm, moist, nutrient-rich environment (dead tissue) that is the perfect breeding ground for bacteria (like pseudomonas) that are always present in the hospital environment. Furthermore, a major burn triggers a massive immune suppression, making your own body less able to fight off these infections.

faqs.question: What's the difference between an autograft and an allograft for my skin graft?
faqs.answer: An autograft (from the Greek auto for self) is the gold standard. This is your own healthy skin, taken from an unburned area (like your thigh) with a tool called a dermatome. Your body will accept this as your own. An allograft (from allo for other) is temporary skin from a human donor (a cadaver). It's used as a biological dressing to temporarily cover a massive burn when there isn't enough healthy skin to take. Your body will reject it after 1-2 weeks.

faqs.question: Why is my scar so thick, tight, and itchy? The burn healed months ago.
faqs.answer: This is a hypertrophic scar. In a deep burn, the healing process is prolonged and disorganized. Your body panics and produces a massive amount of collagen to fill the wound. This collagen is laid down in a haphazard, thick, and raised pattern instead of the normal, flat basket-weave pattern of skin. This excess, disorganized collagen is what makes the scar thick, inflexible (a contracture), and often very itchy as the nerves heal.

faqs.question: How did this cancer grow so fast? My son was fine two weeks ago and now has a huge tumor.
faqs.answer: Burkitt lymphoma is one of the fastest-growing human cancers, with a doubling time of less than 24 hours. This means the number of cancer cells can literally double every single day. This rapid proliferation is its defining feature, which is why it can appear and grow to a large size in just days. The good news is that this same rapid growth makes it extremely sensitive and responsive to chemotherapy.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned a c-MYC translocation. What does that gene have to do with this?
faqs.answer: The c-MYC translocation is the defining genetic event of Burkitt lymphoma. In almost all cases, a genetic accident (translocation) happens where the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 breaks off and attaches to a gene on chromosome 14 (or 2 or 22). The c-MYC gene is a master regulator that tells cells to divide. When it moves to its new spot, it gets stuck in the on position, constantly screaming at the B-cells to divide, divide, divide, which is what causes the explosive growth.

faqs.question: What is tumor lysis syndrome and why is it a major risk during treatment?
faqs.answer: Because Burkitt lymphoma grows so fast, it also dies just as fast when hit with chemotherapy. Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS) is a medical emergency caused by the massive, rapid death of cancer cells all at once. When these cells burst, they release their contents (potassium, phosphate, and uric acid) into the bloodstream. This flood can overwhelm the kidneys, causing kidney failure and life-threatening heart rhythm problems. Patients are given aggressive IV fluids and medications before chemo even starts to prevent this.

faqs.question: I read this is linked to malaria and EBV in Africa. My son grew up in the US. How did he get it?
faqs.answer: You are referring to endemic Burkitt lymphoma, which is linked to EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) and chronic malaria in Africa. Your son has sporadic Burkitt lymphoma, the type seen in North America and Europe. While the cause is unknown, it's not linked to malaria. About 20-30% of sporadic cases are associated with EBV, but the majority are not. The underlying c-MYC translocation is the same in both types, but the initial trigger is different.

faqs.question: Why does the chemotherapy have to be given intrathecally (into his spine)?
faqs.answer: This is for CNS prophylaxis. Burkitt lymphoma is notorious for hiding in the Central Nervous System (CNS)—the brain and spinal fluid. Most standard IV chemotherapy drugs cannot cross the protective blood-brain barrier to reach these hidden cells. By injecting chemotherapy (like methotrexate) directly into the spinal fluid via a lumbar puncture (spinal tap), doctors can ensure the medication kills any cancer cells in the CNS and prevents a relapse in the brain.

faqs.question: I thought my high heels caused my bunion, but my doctor says it's my foot structure. Which is it?
faqs.answer: It's both, but your doctor is right about the primary cause. You don't get bunions from shoes; you inherit a foot type (like flat feet or a flexible hypermobile foot) that is biomechanically unstable. This predisposes you to forming a bunion. Then, wearing narrow, pointed, or high-heeled shoes for years puts immense pressure on that unstable joint, accelerating the deformity and making it worse, faster.

faqs.question: Can I fix my bunion with those splints, toe spacers, or exercises I see online?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, no. A bunion (hallux valgus) is a progressive bone and joint deformity. These devices cannot reverse or cure the underlying bone misalignment. Splints and spacers may provide temporary pain relief by stretching the tight soft tissues, but the moment you take them off, the toe will go back to its position. They are tools for managing symptoms, not a fix.

faqs.question: My doctor is talking about an osteotomy for surgery. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Simply shaving the bump (a bunionectomy) is an outdated procedure with a high failure rate. A modern bunion surgery almost always involves an osteotomy, which means the surgeon cuts the bone (the metatarsal) to realign it. They shift the bone back into its correct position and then fix it in place with small screws. This corrects the underlying cause of the bunion (the angular deformity) and is much more durable.

faqs.question: What is a Lapidus procedure? Why is that a much bigger surgery?
faqs.answer: A Lapidus bunionectomy is for people with a very large or very unstable bunion that starts further back in the midfoot. This procedure involves fusing (making solid) the joint at the base of the metatarsal bone (the TMT joint). By fusing this unstable joint, the surgeon creates a solid, stable beam so the bone can't drift out of place ever again. It's a more powerful correction but has a longer recovery, often requiring 6-8 weeks of no weight-bearing.

faqs.question: If I have surgery, won't the bunion just come back?
faqs.answer: This is a major concern. The recurrence rate is highly dependent on choosing the right procedure. If you have a large, unstable bunion and you get a small procedure (like just shaving the bump), it will almost certainly come back. But if an experienced surgeon correctly identifies your foot type and performs the right corrective procedure (like an osteotomy or Lapidus), the long-term success rates are very high.

faqs.question: My EKG report says I have a right bundle branch block (RBBB) but I feel fine. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: In most cases, no. A bundle branch block is an electrical issue. Think of your heart's signal splitting into two wires (bundles) to make the bottom chambers squeeze. An RBBB means the right wire is slow. In a young, healthy person with no symptoms, an RBBB is often found by chance and is considered a normal variant or a benign finding. Your doctor will likely just note it.

faqs.question: I was just diagnosed with a NEW left bundle branch block (LBBB) and the doctors seem very concerned. Why is this one different?
faqs.answer: A new LBBB is taken much more seriously than an RBBB. The left wire (the left bundle) is responsible for signaling the left ventricle, the heart's main powerhouse. A new LBBB is rarely found in healthy hearts. It often implies a new, underlying structural heart problem, such as long-standing high blood pressure, weak heart muscle (cardiomyopathy), or even an ongoing heart attack. It's a sign that the powerhouse muscle is sick.

faqs.question: How can an LBBB make my heart failure worse? What is dyssynchrony?
faqs.answer: This is a key mechanical problem. With an LBBB, the electrical signal is slow, so the walls of your left ventricle don't squeeze at the same time. The septal wall and the lateral wall contract at different times. This uncoordinated, wobbling motion is a very inefficient way to pump blood. This dyssynchrony wastes a huge amount of energy and can significantly worsen your heart failure symptoms and your ejection fraction.

faqs.question: My doctor is recommending a biventricular pacemaker (CRT) for my LBBB and heart failure. How does that help?
faqs.answer: This is Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT). A normal pacemaker just prevents a slow heart rate. A CRT device has a third wire (lead) that is carefully placed on the outside of the slow-moving lateral wall of your left ventricle. The pacemaker then sends signals to both the right and left ventricles at the exact same time, forcing them to resynchronize their squeeze. This corrects the dyssynchrony, makes the pump more efficient, and can dramatically improve heart failure symptoms.

faqs.question: I'm a runner and was just told I have an RBBB. Can I still exercise?
faqs.answer: If you have an isolated RBBB (meaning an echocardiogram and other tests show your heart is structurally normal), you can absolutely continue to exercise. The RBBB is just an EKG finding and does not affect your heart's performance or put you at risk. It's a common finding in endurance athletes. Your doctor will just want to get a baseline echo to confirm your heart's structure is healthy.

faqs.question: I'm 70 and I've suddenly developed large, tight, intensely itchy blisters all over my body. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds like a classic case of bullous pemphigoid. This is an autoimmune blistering disease, most common in the elderly. It's not an infection or an allergy. Your own immune system has mistakenly created antibodies that attack the glue (the basement membrane) that holds the top layer of your skin (epidermis) onto the bottom layer (dermis). This attack causes the layers to separate and fill with fluid, forming large, tense blisters (bullae).

faqs.question: How did my doctor diagnose this? They took a biopsy of the skin next to a blister.
faqs.answer: This is the gold standard for diagnosis. A simple biopsy of the blister isn't enough. Your doctor takes a sample of normal-looking skin right next to a blister and sends it for direct immunofluorescence (DIF). This special test uses fluorescent dye to look for the autoantibodies. In bullous pemphigoid, the test will show a linear band of antibodies glowing along the basement membrane, confirming the diagnosis.

faqs.question: My doctor started me on a high dose of prednisone. I'm worried about the side effects.
faqs.answer: High-dose oral steroids (like prednisone) are the first-line treatment because they work quickly to shut down the overactive immune system and stop new blisters from forming. You are right to be concerned about side effects (like high blood sugar, bone loss, and mood changes). The goal is to get the disease into remission and then slowly taper you off the prednisone, often by adding a steroid-sparing drug (like methotrexate or mycophenolate) to keep the immune system quiet with fewer side effects.

faqs.question: Is this related to a pemphigus disease? My doctor said this was pemphigoid and that it's better.
faqs.answer: They are both autoimmune blistering diseases, but they are very different. Pemphigus is often more severe. In pemphigus, the blisters are flaccid (limp and fragile) because the attack is within the top layer of skin, and it always involves the mouth. In pemphigoid (your condition), the blisters are tense (strong and hard to pop) because the split is deeper, and mouth involvement is less common. Pemphigoid generally has a better prognosis and is less dangerous than pemphigus.

faqs.question: Why is the itching so unbearable, even on skin that doesn't have blisters?
faqs.answer: The intense, urticarial itching (called pruritus) is the hallmark symptom and often starts weeks or months before the blisters ever appear. The autoimmune attack and inflammation are already happening in the skin, irritating the nerve endings and causing this severe itch, even before the skin layers have fully separated to form a visible blister.

faqs.question: I'm stuck in a binge-and-purge cycle. Why can't I just stop? I feel so out of control.
faqs.answer: This loss of control is the defining feature of bulimia. It's not a failure of willpower. The cycle is a powerful, compulsive loop. The binge is often triggered by restrictive dieting, stress, or difficult emotions. This leads to a feeling of dissociation and a loss of control. The binge is then followed by intense feelings of guilt and panic, which trigger the purge (vomiting, laxative use, etc.) as a desperate attempt to undo the binge. This purge provides temporary relief, but reinforces the cycle.

faqs.question: My dentist is the one who asked if I was okay. How could they tell?
faqs.answer: Dentists are often the first to see the physical signs. Chronic, self-induced vomiting repeatedly exposes your teeth to powerful stomach acid. This acid erodes the enamel on the inside surface (the lingual side) of your teeth, particularly the upper front teeth. This causes a perimolysis, where the teeth look glassy, smooth, and scooped out. They may also see swelling of the salivary (parotid) glands, which causes puffy cheeks.

faqs.question: What is Russell's sign?
faqs.answer: Russell's sign is a callus or scar on the back of the knuckles. It's caused by repeatedly using the fingers to induce vomiting. The skin of the knuckles gets scraped against the upper teeth (incisors), leading to a characteristic mark. It's a physical sign that a provider might look for, but not everyone who purges will have it.

faqs.question: Why is my doctor so worried about my electrolytes? I feel fine, just tired.
faqs.answer: This is the most medically dangerous part of bulimia. Purging (especially vomiting and laxative abuse) flushes critical electrolytes out of your body. The most dangerous is the loss of potassium (hypokalemia). Your heart requires a precise balance of potassium to beat correctly. Low potassium can cause severe muscle weakness, cramping, and most dangerously, a life-threatening cardiac arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat) or sudden cardiac arrest. This is a silent danger.

faqs.question: What is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) for bulimia? How does it work?
faqs.answer: CBT-E (Enhanced CBT for Eating Disorders) is the gold-standard treatment. It doesn't just focus on your past. It's a practical, present-focused therapy that helps you: 1) Break the cycle by helping you eat regular meals (regularization of eating) to prevent the extreme hunger that triggers a binge. 2) Identify your triggers (thoughts, feelings, or events) that lead to a binge. 3) Learn new coping skills (distress tolerance) so that when you feel an urge, you have a different tool to use besides binging and purging.

faqs.question: I rolled my ankle badly. How do I know if it's a high ankle sprain or a broken ankle?
faqs.answer: This is what the Ottawa Ankle Rules are for. In general, you need an X-ray if you have pain in the malleolar zone (the bony bumps on the sides of your ankle) and you cannot bear weight on it for 4 steps. A high ankle sprain (syndesmosis injury) involves the ligaments above the ankle that hold the two leg bones together, and it often takes even longer to heal than a simple fracture. A fracture means the bone itself (the malleolus) is broken.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a bimalleolar fracture and need surgery. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is an unstable ankle fracture. Your ankle joint is a ring formed by three bones/parts: the medial malleolus (inside bump), the lateral malleolus (outside bump), and the posterior malleolus (back of the shin bone). A bimalleolar fracture means two of those parts are broken (usually the inside and outside). This makes the entire ankle joint unstable, and the talus bone (the main ankle bone) can shift out of place. Surgery with plates and screws is needed to put the ring back together so it heals perfectly.

faqs.question: What's a trimalleolar fracture?
faqs.answer: This is even more unstable. It means all three parts of the ankle ring are broken: the medial (inside), lateral (outside), and posterior (the back) malleoli. This is a severe injury that almost always requires surgical fixation with plates and screws to restore the joint's stability.

faqs.question: I have a non-displaced lateral malleolus fracture (just the outside bone). Why can I just be in a boot?
faqs.answer: This is a stable ankle fracture. Because only the outside bone is broken and the pieces are still in a perfect position (non-displaced), the ring of the ankle is still intact. The strong deltoid ligament on the inside of your ankle is holding everything in place. This can be treated non-surgically, with a walking boot or cast to protect it while the bone heals, which usually takes 6 weeks.

faqs.question: Why do I have to be non-weight-bearing for 6 weeks after my surgery? The plate is in!
faqs.answer: The plate and screws are just internal splints—their job is to hold the broken pieces together in the right position. They are not strong enough to support your entire body weight. The bone itself is what needs to heal, and that process of knitting together takes 6-8 weeks. If you put your full weight on it too early, you could bend or break the screws, or cause the bone to collapse before it's healed, which would be a disaster. You must let the bone do its job.

faqs.question: My breasts get really sore, heavy, and lumpy for a week every month before my period. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the most common type of breast pain, known as cyclical mastalgia. It's directly linked to your menstrual cycle. The normal surge in hormones, especially estrogen, causes your breast tissue to retain fluid and swell, making it feel tender and dense. The pain and lumpiness almost always get better as soon as your period starts.

faqs.question: I have a sharp, stabbing pain in one spot in my left breast that comes and goes. It's not related to my period. What could it be?
faqs.answer: This is non-cyclical breast pain. It's not related to hormones and is often felt in just one spot. The most common cause isn't actually the breast, but the chest wall underneath it. It's often costochondritis (inflammation of the rib cartilage), a pulled muscle, or a benign breast cyst. Even though it's almost never cancer, any new, focal (one-spot) pain should be checked by your doctor.

faqs.question: Can the underwire in my bra be causing my breast pain?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. An ill-fitting bra is a very common cause of non-cyclical breast pain. If the underwire is digging in, it can put constant pressure on your breast tissue or, more commonly, on your ribs underneath the breast, causing costochondritis. Getting a professional bra fitting to ensure you have the right size and support can solve this.

faqs.question: I'm terrified my breast pain is cancer. How can my doctor be so sure it's not?
faqs.answer: This is a very common fear, but it's important to know that pain is very rarely the first symptom of breast cancer. Most breast cancers present as a painless lump. Your doctor is confident after doing a clinical breast exam and, if appropriate for your age, ordering a mammogram and/or ultrasound. If those imaging tests are clear, it confirms the pain is from a benign (non-cancerous) cause.

faqs.question: What can I do to relieve my cyclical breast pain? It really bothers me.
faqs.answer: Many women find relief from simple changes. You can try reducing your caffeine and salt intake, as both can make swelling worse. Some studies show that taking evening primrose oil capsules (a fatty acid supplement) can help. For severe pain, wearing a well-fitted sports bra for extra support (even at night) and using over-the-counter anti-inflammatories like ibuprofen can help significantly.

faqs.question: I found a lump in my breast that's smooth, round, and moves when I push it. I'm terrified. What is it?
faqs.answer: While any new lump needs to be checked, what you're describing is the classic presentation of a simple breast cyst. Cysts are fluid-filled sacs, like tiny water balloons, that are extremely common and benign (not cancer). They are most common in women in their 30s, 40s, and 50s (pre-menopause) and are related to hormone fluctuations. They often feel tender.

faqs.question: How will my doctor know if it's a cyst or something serious?
faqs.answer: Your doctor will likely order a diagnostic ultrasound. This is the best test to tell a cyst from a solid lump. On an ultrasound, a simple cyst shows up as a perfectly round or oval black hole (black means fluid) with thin, smooth walls. A solid lump, by contrast, would look gray and have different features.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to drain the cyst with a needle. Is that necessary? Does it hurt?
faqs.answer: This is called a fine-needle aspiration (FNA). It's done for two reasons: 1) If the cyst is large and painful, draining it provides immediate relief, and 2) It confirms the diagnosis. The doctor will numb your skin, guide a tiny needle into the cyst, and draw out the fluid (which is usually straw-colored or greenish). If the lump disappears completely, it's confirmed to be a cyst. It's a very quick, minimally painful procedure.

faqs.question: Can breast cysts turn into cancer?
faqs.answer: Simple breast cysts do not turn into cancer. They are a benign finding and do not increase your risk of breast cancer. The only (very rare) exception is a complex cyst, which has solid bits or a thick wall seen on ultrasound. These are managed more carefully and are often biopsied just to be safe, but a simple cyst is not a pre-cancerous condition.

faqs.question: My cyst went away after my period. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is very common. Cysts are hormone-sensitive. They often get larger and more tender in the week or two before your period (due to estrogen) and then can shrink or even disappear completely once your period starts and your hormone levels drop. They may then reappear in the next cycle.

faqs.question: My mammogram report says I have dense breasts. Does this mean I have cancer?
faqs.answer: No, it does not mean you have cancer. Dense breasts means you have more fibrous and glandular tissue and less fatty tissue. It's very common (especially in younger women). However, it's important for two reasons: 1) It makes mammograms harder to read, as both dense tissue and tumors look white. 2) It is an independent risk factor, meaning having dense breasts by itself slightly increases your risk of developing breast cancer. Your doctor may recommend a 3D mammogram or supplemental screening, like an ultrasound.

faqs.question: I was diagnosed with DCIS. My doctor said it's Stage 0 cancer, but I still need surgery. Why?
faqs.answer: DCIS stands for Ductal Carcinoma In Situ. In Situ means in its original place. This means abnormal, cancerous-looking cells are found inside a milk duct, but they have not broken out of the duct into the surrounding breast tissue. It's non-invasive, so it can't spread to other parts of your body. However, if left untreated, a significant percentage of DCIS cases will eventually break out and become an invasive cancer. Surgery (like a lumpectomy, often followed by radiation) is done to remove the duct and prevent this from happening.

faqs.question: My tumor is ER/PR positive and HER2 negative. What does this mean for my treatment?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and important finding. ER/PR positive (Estrogen/Progesterone Receptor positive) means your cancer cells use your body's own hormones (estrogen and progesterone) as fuel to grow. This is actually good news, as it means your cancer can be treated very effectively with hormone therapy (like tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor). These pills block the hormones, essentially starving the cancer cells. HER2 negative means your cancer does not have an excess of the HER2 protein, so you would not need targeted HER2-blocking drugs (like Herceptin).

faqs.question: What's the difference between a lumpectomy and a mastectomy?
faqs.answer: A lumpectomy (or breast-conserving surgery) is an operation to remove only the tumor and a small margin of healthy tissue around it, leaving the rest of the breast intact. It is almost always followed by radiation therapy. A mastectomy is the surgical removal of the entire breast. For most early-stage breast cancers, studies show that a lumpectomy plus radiation has the exact same long-term survival rate as a mastectomy.

faqs.question: What does it mean to check the sentinel lymph node?
faqs.answer: Lymph nodes in your armpit are the first place breast cancer is likely to spread. The sentinel node is the first lymph node (or group of 2-3 nodes) that drains fluid directly from the tumor. During surgery, the surgeon injects a blue dye or a tiny radioactive particle near the tumor. They then use a probe to find the first node that lights up or turns blue. They remove only this node and send it to the lab. If the sentinel node is clear of cancer, it's highly likely the rest of the nodes are clear too, and no more need to be removed.

faqs.question: I've had a headache that's worse in the morning for a few weeks, and now my hand feels clumsy. Could this be a brain tumor?
faqs.answer: This combination of symptoms is very concerning and should be evaluated immediately. A classic brain tumor headache is one that is new, persistent, and often worse upon waking, as pressure can build in the skull while lying flat. When combined with a new neurological focal deficit—like clumsiness (motor weakness), speech difficulty, or vision changes—it raises suspicion for a mass in the brain (like a tumor or an abscess) that is pressing on the specific part of the brain that controls that function.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a meningioma and that it's benign. Does this mean I don't need to worry about it?
faqs.answer: A meningioma is a tumor that grows from the meninges—the protective lining around the brain, not from the brain tissue itself. The vast majority are benign (Grade 1), meaning they are not cancer, grow very slowly, and don't spread. However, they can still cause serious problems by mass effect—as they grow, they compress and squish the normal brain. If it's small and not causing symptoms, it's often just watched with serial MRIs. If it's large or causing symptoms, it is treated with surgery or focused radiation.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a primary brain tumor and a metastatic one?
faqs.answer: A primary brain tumor (like a meningioma or a glioma) originates from the cells within the brain or its lining. A metastatic brain tumor (or brain met) is a cancer that started somewhere else in the body (like lung cancer, breast cancer, or melanoma) and spread to the brain through the bloodstream. Metastatic brain tumors are actually much more common than primary ones.

faqs.question: What is a glioblastoma (GBM)? Why does it have such a bad prognosis?
faqs.answer: A glioblastoma (also called a Grade 4 astrocytoma) is the most common and most aggressive primary brain tumor. It's malignant (cancerous) and it arises from the brain's supportive glial cells. It has a poor prognosis because it's highly infiltrative—it doesn't grow as a neat ball that can be easily removed. Instead, its cancerous tentacles spread deep into the normal brain tissue, making it impossible to remove completely with surgery. It is also very resistant to traditional chemotherapy and radiation.

faqs.question: Why did my doctor give me steroids (dexamethasone) before I even have a diagnosis?
faqs.answer: A brain tumor causes two problems: the tumor itself, and the massive swelling (vasogenic edema) in the healthy brain tissue around it. This swelling is what causes many of the symptoms, like headaches and weakness. High-dose steroids (like dexamethasone) are incredibly effective at rapidly shrinking this swelling. This can relieve your symptoms and reduce the pressure in your head before surgery, making the operation safer.

faqs.question: I have lung cancer, and now my doctor says it has spread to my brain. How did it get there?
faqs.answer: This is called metastasis. Cancer cells from your lung tumor (the primary site) can break off, enter your bloodstream, and travel throughout your body. The brain is a common place for these cells to land and take root, as it receives a very large portion of the body's blood supply. Once in the brain, they can multiply and form new tumors.

faqs.question: I have multiple tumors in my brain. Does this mean I need whole-brain radiation?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. This used to be the standard treatment, but we now have a much more targeted option called Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS), often using a Gamma Knife or CyberKnife. This is not actual surgery. It's a highly focused radiation technique that delivers a single, very powerful dose of radiation only to the tumors, sparing the surrounding healthy brain. SRS is now the preferred treatment for patients with a limited number (e.g., 1-10) of brain metastases.

faqs.question: What's the difference between Gamma Knife and Whole Brain Radiation Therapy (WBRT)?
faqs.answer: A: Gamma Knife (SRS) is a precision, scalpel-like treatment that hits only the specific tumors with a very high dose, usually in a single 1-day session. Its goal is to kill the tumors while protecting your normal brain. WBRT is a shotgun approach. It delivers a lower dose of radiation to your entire brain over 10-15 sessions. It's very effective at killing tumors (even microscopic ones we can't see), but it has a much higher risk of long-term side effects, like memory loss and cognitive decline, because it damages healthy brain tissue.

faqs.question: My doctor says I have leptomeningeal disease. Why is this more serious than a regular brain met?
faqs.answer: Leptomeningeal disease (or carcinomatous meningitis) is a different, more diffuse form of metastasis. Instead of forming a solid ball (a tumor), the cancer cells have spread into the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)—the fluid that bathes your brain and spinal cord. These free-floating cells coat the surface of your brain and nerves. This is very difficult to treat because it's not a single target for radiation, and most IV chemotherapy can't get into the CSF.

faqs.question: I have a single brain metastasis. Should I have it surgically removed?
faqs.answer: This is often the best approach, especially if the tumor is large (e.g., >3 cm) and is causing significant symptoms (like weakness or seizures). Removing the bulk of the tumor provides a quick decompression and relieves pressure on the brain. The surgical bed (the area where the tumor was) is then often treated with SRS radiation to clean up any microscopic cells left behind.

faqs.question: My doctor found a brain aneurysm on an MRI I had for headaches. I feel fine. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: This is called an incidental or unruptured aneurysm. It's a small blister or weak spot on a blood vessel in your brain. The vast majority of these, especially if they are small (<7mm), never rupture. However, a rupture (a subarachnoid hemorrhage) is a life-threatening brain bleed. The decision to treat it versus watchful waiting with more scans depends on its size, its location, its shape, and your personal risk factors (like smoking and high blood pressure).

faqs.question: What's the difference between clipping and coiling to treat an aneurysm?
faqs.answer: These are the two main treatment options. Clipping is an open brain surgery. A neurosurgeon removes a piece of your skull, finds the aneurysm, and places a tiny metal (titanium) clip across the neck of the aneurysm, sealing it off from the outside. Coiling is a minimally invasive endovascular procedure. A neuroradiologist inserts a tiny catheter in your groin, navigates it up to your brain, and then packs the inside of the aneurysm bubble with soft platinum coils, causing the blood inside it to clot and seal it off.

faqs.question: I had the worst headache of my life and now I'm in the ICU. They said my aneurysm ruptured.
faqs.answer: You have had a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). That sudden, thunderclap headache is the classic sign of blood bursting from the aneurysm and flooding the space around your brain. This is a medical emergency. The immediate priority is to secure the aneurysm (with coiling or clipping) to prevent it from re-bleeding, which is often fatal.

faqs.question: The rupture was three days ago. Why is the doctor now worried about something called vasospasm?
faqs.answer: This is the most dangerous delayed complication of an SAH. The blood that spilled around your brain is very irritating. In 3 to 14 days after the bleed, it can cause the other healthy blood vessels in your brain to spasm and narrow. This vasospasm can cut off blood flow to parts of your brain, causing a new stroke. You are kept in the ICU and given medication (nimodipine) to try to prevent this.

faqs.question: I'm a smoker with high blood pressure. Did I cause this?
faqs.answer: You didn't cause the weak spot, as that can be genetic. However, smoking and uncontrolled high blood pressure are the two biggest modifiable risk factors that cause an existing aneurysm to grow and rupture. Quitting smoking and managing your blood pressure are the most important things you can do to protect your other blood vessels.

faqs.question: My fitness tracker says my resting heart rate is 45 bpm. Is this dangerously low?
faqs.answer: It depends entirely on your situation. If you are a young, very physically fit person or an endurance athlete, a resting heart rate in the 40s can be completely normal. Your heart is so strong and efficient it doesn't need to beat often at rest. However, if you are not an athlete and you are having symptoms like dizziness, fatigue, or fainting, then a rate of 45 is considered symptomatic bradycardia and is a serious problem.

faqs.question: I get really dizzy and lightheaded, and my doctor says I have sick sinus syndrome. What is that?
faqs.answer: Sick Sinus Syndrome (or sinus node dysfunction) is a common cause of bradycardia. Your heart's sinus node is its natural pacemaker; it's what tells your heart to beat. When this node gets sick (usually due to age-related scarring), it stops firing properly. It can fire too slowly (sinus bradycardia) or just randomly stop firing for a few seconds (a sinus pause), which is what makes you feel dizzy or faint.

faqs.question: What is heart block and how is it different from sick sinus syndrome?
faqs.answer: If the sinus node is the pacemaker at the top, the AV node is the wire that carries the signal from the top chambers (atria) to the bottom chambers (ventricles). Heart block is a problem with this wire. The signal from the top is either slowed down (1st degree), partially blocked (2nd degree), or completely blocked (3rd degree). In 3rd-degree complete heart block, the top and bottom chambers beat completely out of sync, which is a life-threatening emergency.

faqs.question: My doctor said I need a pacemaker. How does that work?
faqs.answer: A pacemaker is a small device implanted under the skin of your chest with one or two flexible wires (leads) that are guided into your heart. Its job is to listen. It constantly monitors your heart. If it hears that your natural pacemaker has failed to fire or that your heart rate has dropped below a set level (e.g., 60 bpm), it will instantly deliver a tiny, painless electrical pacing impulse that tells your heart to beat. It's a safety net that prevents your heart from ever going too slow.

faqs.question: Can my medications be causing my slow heart rate?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. This is a very common cause. Two of the most common culprits are beta-blockers (like metoprolol or atenolol) and calcium channel blockers (like diltiazem or verapamil). These drugs are designed to slow your heart rate to treat high blood pressure or other heart issues. Sometimes, the dose is too high or your body is too sensitive, leading to symptomatic bradycardia.

faqs.question: My son had a seizure, and an MRI found a tangled bunch of blood vessels in his brain. What is a Brain AVM?
faqs.answer: An AVM (Arteriovenous Malformation) is a rare, abnormal tangle of blood vessels that you are born with. In a normal brain, high-pressure arteries feed into a capillary bed (which slows blood down), which then feeds into low-pressure veins. In an AVM, this middle-man capillary bed is missing. High-pressure arterial blood bypasses it and shunts directly into the weaker veins. This nidus (the tangle) is a high-flow, high-pressure, and unstable connection.

faqs.question: Why is an AVM so dangerous? My son felt fine before this.
faqs.answer: The AVM is dangerous for two main reasons. 1) Rupture: The veins in the tangle are not built to handle high-pressure arterial flow. They can weaken and blow out, causing a devastating brain hemorrhage (a type of stroke). 2) Seizures: The AVM steals blood from the normal brain tissue around it (vascular steal) and the abnormal vessels can irritate the brain, triggering seizures.

faqs.question: My doctor said my AVM has a high Spetzler-Martin grade. What does that mean for my treatment?
faqs.answer: The Spetzler-Martin grade (I-V) is a scoring system neurosurgeons use to measure how difficult and dangerous an AVM is to treat. It's not a cancer stage. It's a risk assessment. It's based on three things: 1) Size (small is easier), 2) Location (is it in eloquent brain tissue, like speech or motor areas?), and 3) Veins (does it drain into deep or superficial veins?). A high grade (like IV or V) means the AVM is large, in a critical area, and the risk of treatment may be higher than the risk of leaving it alone.

faqs.question: What are my treatment options? I've heard of surgery, radiation, and embolization.
faqs.answer: These are the three main tools. 1) Surgical Resection: This is open brain surgery to physically remove the entire AVM nidus. This offers an immediate cure. 2) Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS/Gamma Knife): This is a single, high dose of focused radiation aimed at the nidus. It's non-invasive, but it's not a quick fix—it causes the AVM to slowly clot off and disappear over 2-3 years. 3) Embolization: This is an endovascular procedure where a catheter is used to inject glue into the AVM to block off its arteries. This is rarely a cure on its own but is often used to shrink the AVM before surgery or radiation to make them safer.

faqs.question: If the AVM is unruptured, is it safer to just leave it alone?
faqs.answer: This is the most difficult question in neurosurgery, and the answer is complex. The ARUBA trial (A Randomized trial of Unruptured Brain AVMs) famously found that for unruptured AVMs, medical management (just treating symptoms like headaches/seizures) was safer in the short term than treatment. However, the lifetime risk of rupture is still there. The decision is highly individualized and depends on your age, the AVM's grade, and your personal risk tolerance.

faqs.question: I was in a bad motorcycle accident and now I can't move my arm at all. The doctor says I injured my brachial plexus. What is that?
faqs.answer: The brachial plexus is not a single thing—it's a complex, fuse box like network of nerves that runs from your spinal cord in your neck, across your chest, and into your armpit. All the nerves that control your entire shoulder, arm, and hand (motor and sensation) pass through this plexus. A severe, high-speed stretch injury (like in a motorcycle crash) can pull these nerves, stretch them, or even rip them completely out of the spinal cord.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned a nerve root avulsion. Is that the worst type?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the most severe type of injury. It means the nerve root has been pulled completely off of the spinal cord. This is a spinal cord level injury, and the nerve cannot be sewn back on to the spine. It will not heal on its own. This results in a flail arm (a completely paralyzed and numb arm).

faqs.question: I just had my baby, and his arm is limp. The doctor said it's Erb's palsy from the birth.
faqs.answer: This is a brachial plexus birth palsy. It can happen during a difficult delivery if the baby's shoulder gets stuck. The stretching of the neck to free the shoulder can injure the brachial plexus. Erb's palsy is the most common type, affecting the upper nerves (C5-C6). This causes the classic waiter's tip posture: the arm hangs by the side, rotated inward, but the hand can still move.

faqs.question: What's the difference between Erb's palsy and Klumpke's palsy?
faqs.answer: It's all about which nerves in the plexus are injured. Erb's palsy is an upper plexus injury (C5, C6) that affects the shoulder and elbow muscles. Klumpke's palsy is a rare lower plexus injury (C8, T1) that affects the hand and forearm muscles, resulting in a claw hand with a functional shoulder and elbow.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to do a nerve transfer surgery. How does that work?
faqs.answer: In an avulsion injury where the nerve is dead, a nerve transfer is a highly specialized surgery. A surgeon will sacrifice a less important healthy nerve (or a small branch of one) and re-wire it to the dead end of the more important nerve. For example, they might take a nerve that helps with breathing (the phrenic nerve) or a nerve from the other side of your neck and plug it into the nerve that controls your bicep. The healthy nerve then grows down the new pipe, slowly re-powering the paralyzed muscle.

faqs.question: I ate some home-canned beans that tasted fine, but now I have double vision and my muscles feel weak. Could this be botulism?
faqs.answer: Yes. You need to go to an emergency room immediately. Botulism is a rare but life-threatening paralytic illness. It's not an infection. It's an intoxication caused by swallowing the botulinum toxin, one of the most potent poisons on Earth. It's produced by Clostridium botulinum bacteria, which thrive in low-acid, airless environments like improperly canned (especially home-canned) foods. The toxin causes a descending paralysis: it starts at the top (double vision, drooping eyelids, slurred speech) and moves down, causing muscle weakness and, most dangerously, respiratory failure when it paralyzes your diaphragm.

faqs.question: How is infant botulism different? My baby is limp and constipated after I gave him honey.
faqs.answer: This is a completely different mechanism. In infant botulism, the baby swallows the bacterial spores (which are harmless to adults but can be found in honey or soil). In a baby's immature gut, these spores can grow and produce the toxin inside their body. The toxin is then absorbed and causes paralysis. The first signs are constipation, a weak cry, poor feeding (floppy baby syndrome), and loss of head control. Honey is the classic avoidable cause, which is why you never give it to a child under 1 year old.

faqs.question: What is wound botulism?
faqs.answer: This is another rare form. It's not from food. This is when the Clostridium botulinum spores get into a dirty wound or, more commonly, into a skin-popping injection site in someone who uses black tar heroin. The spores germinate in the wound's low-oxygen environment and produce the toxin, which is then absorbed into the bloodstream.

faqs.question: What is the antitoxin and how does it work?
faqs.answer: The botulism antitoxin (or Botulism Immune Globulin - BIG-IV for infants) is the only treatment. It's a life-saving medication. It does not reverse the paralysis that has already happened. The toxin locks onto your nerve endings, and that damage is done. The antitoxin is a mop—it circulates in your blood and mops up any free-floating toxin that hasn't yet attached to a nerve. This stops the paralysis from getting worse and allows your body to slowly begin the 2-8 week process of growing new nerve endings.

faqs.question: I thought botulism was Botox. How can a poison be a cosmetic?
faqs.answer: It's the exact same toxin. Botox is a tiny, highly purified, and extremely diluted dose of botulinum toxin type A. When it's injected into a facial muscle for cosmetic reasons (or into a neck muscle for dystonia), it intentionally paralyzes that specific muscle, which stops it from pulling on the skin and creating a wrinkle. The dose is so small it doesn't spread systemically.

faqs.question: How is BPD different from Bipolar Disorder? They both sound like intense mood swings.
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction. The mood swings in Bipolar Disorder are sustained episodes of depression or mania that last for days, weeks, or even months. The mood swings in BPD (known as emotional dysregulation) are rapid, intense, and often last for only a few hours or even minutes. They are almost always a reaction to an interpersonal trigger, like a perceived slight or fear of abandonment.

faqs.question: What does the fear of abandonment actually look like in day-to-day life?
faqs.answer: It's an intense, often frantic panic at the thought of being left alone (even temporarily). This can manifest as: 1) Repeatedly calling or texting someone to check in, 2) Becoming very angry or distressed if someone is a few minutes late, 3) Testing the relationship by pushing the other person away to see if they'll stay, or 4) Preemptively ending a relationship to avoid the pain of being dumped first.

faqs.question: Why is Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) always recommended for BPD?
faqs.answer: DBT is considered the gold-standard treatment because it was specifically designed to treat the core symptoms of BPD. It's built on a dialectic—the idea of balancing acceptance (validating that the emotional pain is real) with change (learning new skills). It has four key modules: 1) Mindfulness, 2) Distress Tolerance (how to survive a crisis without making it worse), 3) Emotion Regulation, and 4) Interpersonal Effectiveness (how to ask for things and set boundaries).

faqs.question: My loved one with BPD sees me as all good one day and all bad the next. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a defense mechanism called splitting (or black-and-white thinking). It stems from the identity disturbance symptom. It's difficult to hold two conflicting thoughts at once (e.g., I love this person, but they hurt my feelings). So, the brain simplifies it: the person is either perfect and idealized or evil and devalued. This view can switch instantly based on a single action or perceived slight.

faqs.question: Is the self-harm (like cutting) a suicide attempt?
faqs.answer: Not usually, though the risk of suicide is very high in BPD. This is often non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI). People with BPD often experience an emotional pain so intense it's unbearable, or a profound feeling of emptiness or dissociation (feeling numb and unreal). The physical pain from self-injury can act as a release for the emotional pain, or it can be the only thing that makes them feel something real, grounding them back in their body.

faqs.question: I thought bone spurs were from an injury, but my doctor says it's just from my arthritis. How?
faqs.answer: They are a result of arthritis. In osteoarthritis, the smooth cartilage that cushions your joint wears away. As the bone ends rub against each other, your body tries to repair the damage by growing new bone along the edges of the joint. These bony projections are osteophytes, or bone spurs. They are a sign of the joint trying to stabilize itself, but they often end up causing more pain and stiffness.

faqs.question: Why am I getting a bone spur on my heel? My doctor said it's related to plantar fasciitis.
faqs.answer: This is a perfect example of a traction spur. Your plantar fascia is the long, tight band of tissue under your foot. When it's inflamed (plantar fasciitis), it constantly pulls and tugs on the spot where it attaches to your heel bone. In response to this chronic pulling, the body lays down new bone at that spot, creating a heel spur. Often, the spur itself isn't the cause of the pain; the inflamed fascia is.

faqs.question: I have bone spurs in my neck. What kind of symptoms can that cause?
faqs.answer: This is cervical spondylosis. The spurs can be silent, or they can cause problems by pinching things. 1) If they grow into the small holes where the nerves exit (the foramina), they can pinch a nerve root. This is cervical radiculopathy, and it causes pain, numbness, or weakness that shoots down your arm. 2) If they grow into the main spinal canal, they can press on the spinal cord itself, which is myelopathy and can cause balance problems, clumsiness, and weakness in both your arms and legs.

faqs.question: Can I get rid of my bone spurs with diet, supplements, or exercise?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, no. Diet and supplements (like calcium) cannot dissolve a bone spur that has already formed. However, physical therapy and exercise are critical for managing the symptoms. By strengthening the muscles around the arthritic joint, you improve its stability and take the pressure off, which can significantly reduce the pain.

faqs.question: When do you actually need surgery to remove a bone spur?
faqs.answer: Surgery (an osteophytectomy) is a last resort. It's only done if the spur is causing a clear mechanical problem that non-surgical treatments can't fix. This includes: 1) A pinched nerve (radiculopathy) causing progressive weakness, 2) Spinal cord compression (myelopathy), or 3) A spur in a joint (like the shoulder) that is physically shredding a tendon.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have primary bone cancer, not cancer in the bone. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: This is a critical difference. Primary bone cancer (like osteosarcoma or Ewing sarcoma) is a rare cancer that starts in the bone cells themselves. Metastatic cancer in the bone (which is what most people mean when they say bone cancer) is a cancer that started somewhere else (like the breast, lung, or prostate) and spread to the bones. They are two totally different diseases, treated in completely different ways.

faqs.question: I'm a teenager and my knee hurts at night. My parents say it's growing pains. When should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Growing pains are common, but they are typically in the muscles (like the shins or calves), not in one specific joint, and they come and go. The classic symptom of osteosarcoma (the most common primary bone cancer in teens) is night pain—a deep, boring pain in one spot (often around the knee or shoulder) that is not relieved by rest and may be worse at night. Any new, persistent lump or swelling on a bone should also be checked immediately.

faqs.question: What is Ewing sarcoma and how is it different from osteosarcoma?
faqs.answer: Ewing sarcoma is the second most common bone cancer in children. Unlike osteosarcoma (which makes abnormal bone), Ewing sarcoma is a small round blue cell tumor. It's often found in the shaft (middle) of long bones or in the pelvis. It's also known for causing systemic symptoms like fever, weight loss, and fatigue, which can make it mimic an infection (like osteomyelitis), sometimes delaying the diagnosis.

faqs.question: My pathologist report mentions an EWS-FLI1 translocation. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is the defining genetic signature of Ewing sarcoma, found in about 85% of cases. It's a translocation, where a piece of chromosome 22 (the EWS gene) breaks off and fuses with a piece of chromosome 11 (the FLI1 gene). This new, abnormal fusion gene (EWS-FLI1) acts as a master-switch that drives the cancer's growth. Finding this in a biopsy is how the diagnosis is confirmed.

faqs.question: I'm an adult diagnosed with chondrosarcoma. Is that related?
faqs.answer: This is another type of primary bone cancer, but it's most common in older adults. Unlike osteosarcoma (from bone-forming cells), chondrosarcoma arises from cartilage cells. It's most common in the pelvis, hip, and shoulder. It's known for being very resistant to chemotherapy and radiation. Surgery (a wide, complete removal of the tumor) is the single most important treatment.

faqs.question: I have breast cancer, and now my doctor says I have bone mets. Does this mean I have bone cancer?
faqs.answer: This is a common point of confusion. You do not have bone cancer. You have breast cancer that has spread to the bones. The cells in your bones are still breast cancer cells. This is metastatic or Stage 4 breast cancer. This is important because it's treated as breast cancer (with hormone therapy, chemo, etc.), not as a primary bone cancer (like osteosarcoma).

faqs.question: Why did my cancer spread to my bones? What makes them a target?
faqs.answer: Your bones, especially your spine, pelvis, and ribs, have a very rich blood supply because they are where your bone marrow is. Cancer cells that break off from the primary tumor (like in your breast or lung) travel through the bloodstream. They can get stuck in the tiny blood vessels of the bone marrow, which is a fertile environment where they can easily start to grow.

faqs.question: My doctor says I have lytic lesions from my lung cancer. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This describes what the cancer is doing to the bone. Lytic (or osteolytic) lesions destroy bone, making it weaker and eating holes in it. This is common with lung cancer and myeloma. The opposite is blastic (or osteoblastic) lesions, where the cancer cells stimulate the body to build weak, disorganized new bone. This is classic for prostate cancer. Breast cancer can often be mixed, doing both.

faqs.question: I have a pathologic fracture. What is that?
faqs.answer: A pathologic fracture is a broken bone that is not caused by a major trauma (like a car crash). It's a bone that breaks from a minor fall or even just from normal, everyday activity. This happens because a metastatic tumor (especially a lytic one) has eaten away so much of the bone that it has become weak and hollow, and it snaps under normal stress. This often requires surgery to stabilize the bone with a rod or plate.

faqs.question: What is palliative radiation for bone mets? Is it like a cure?
faqs.answer: This is not a curative treatment, but it is extremely effective for pain. If you have one or two spots (lesions) that are causing severe pain, a radiation oncologist can aim a precise beam of radiation at that spot. This radiation kills the cancer cells in that area, which stops them from irritating the nerves and causing pain. It's one of the best treatments we have for localized bone pain from cancer, and it often works very quickly.

faqs.question: I get these painful red bumps in my armpits and groin all the time. Are they just boils?
faqs.answer: If you get recurrent boils in those specific areas (armpits, groin, under the breasts), it may not be just a boil. It could be Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS). This is a chronic, inflammatory skin condition of the hair follicles in apocrine gland-bearing skin. It's very different from a simple, one-off boil and requires long-term management by a dermatologist.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a boil and a carbuncle?
faqs.answer: A boil (or furuncle) is a single, deep infection of a single hair follicle. It forms a red, painful lump with a head of pus. A carbuncle is much worse. It's a cluster of multiple boils that are all connected under the skin, forming a larger, deeper, and more painful infected mass. Carbuncles are more likely to cause a fever and make you feel sick, and they almost always require medical treatment.

faqs.question: Why do I keep getting boils? Am I dirty?
faqs.answer: It's not about being dirty. The most common cause is the bacteria Staphylococcus aureus (Staph), which many people (about 30%) carry harmlessly on their skin or in their nose. A boil forms when these bacteria get into a hair follicle through a tiny scrape or cut. You may be a Staph carrier, or you may have risk factors like diabetes, obesity, or a weakened immune system that make you more prone to them.

faqs.question: I have a boil that's getting huge and throbbing. Should I squeeze it?
faqs.answer: No, please do not squeeze it! Squeezing a boil can force the infected pus deeper into your tissue, or even into your bloodstream, causing a much more dangerous infection called cellulitis or sepsis. The best home care is to apply a hot, wet compress for 10-15 minutes, several times a day. This will help the boil come to a head and drain on its own.

faqs.question: When does a boil need to be drained by a doctor?
faqs.answer: You need to see a doctor if the boil is: 1) Extremely large and painful, 2) On your face, near your spine, or in your groin, 3) You have a fever or feel sick, or 4) It hasn't drained on its own after a week of hot compresses. The doctor will perform an Incision and Drainage (I&D) by numbing the area, making a small cut with a scalpel to release the pus, and then packing the abscess cavity so it can heal from the inside out.

faqs.question: I can see bright red blood in my urine, but it doesn't hurt. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. Any visible blood in the urine (gross hematuria) needs to be evaluated immediately, especially if it's painless. Painless gross hematuria is the classic warning sign for bladder cancer or kidney cancer until proven otherwise. While it can be from something benign, you must get it checked out by a urologist.

faqs.question: My urine is pink and it burns badly when I pee. Is this still cancer?
faqs.answer: This is much less likely to be cancer. Painful hematuria, especially with burning (dysuria), frequency, and urgency, is the classic presentation of a Urinary Tract Infection (UTI), also known as hemorrhagic cystitis. The infection in your bladder has become so inflamed that the bladder lining is bleeding. This is treated with antibiotics.

faqs.question: My routine urine test found microscopic blood. I can't see it. Is that still a big deal?
faqs.answer: Microscopic hematuria (where blood is only visible under a microscope) is also a big deal and needs a full workup. The big three causes that doctors need to rule out are: 1) Cancer (bladder, kidney), 2) Kidney stones, and 3) Kidney disease (glomerulonephritis). You will likely need a CT scan (or ultrasound) and a cystoscopy (a camera in the bladder) to find the cause.

faqs.question: I'm a long-distance runner, and I sometimes have blood in my urine after a marathon. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: This is a known phenomenon called exercise-induced hematuria. It's common in endurance athletes. We don't know the exact cause, but it's thought to be from either the repetitive jostling of the kidneys or the bladder walls rubbing together. It should always go away within 48-72 hours. If it doesn't, or if you're not an elite athlete, it should be worked up as a new problem.

faqs.question: What is a cystoscopy? It sounds awful.
faqs.answer: A cystoscopy is the only way for a doctor to look directly inside your bladder. A urologist uses a cystoscope—a very thin, flexible tube with a camera and a light on the end. They numb your urethra with jelly, and then gently guide the scope into your bladder. It allows them to visually inspect the entire bladder lining for any tumors, polyps, or stones. It's a quick (5-minute) office procedure and is the gold standard for ruling out bladder cancer.

faqs.question: How are body lice different from head lice?
faqs.answer: They are biologically different species, though related. The key difference is their habitat. Head lice live on the scalp and lay their eggs (nits) on the hair shaft. Body lice do not live on your skin. They live and lay their eggs in the seams of your clothing. They only crawl onto your skin to feed (take a blood meal) and then return to your clothes.

faqs.question: I'm not homeless, but I am a refugee. Why am I getting body lice?
faqs.answer: Body lice are not a problem of poor hygiene itself. They are a problem of circumstance. They spread in crowded living conditions where people cannot regularly change and launder their clothes in hot water. This is common in refugee camps, homeless shelters, or during natural disasters, regardless of personal cleanliness. You get them from close contact with an infested person or their bedding.

faqs.question: Can body lice spread diseases? I heard they were a problem in wars.
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the main medical danger of body lice. Unlike head lice (which are just a nuisance), body lice are vectors for serious diseases. They are famous for spreading Trench Fever (Bartonella quintana), Louse-Borne Relapsing Fever, and most dangerously, Epidemic Typhus. This is why they are a massive public health problem in crowded, unhygienic conditions.

faqs.question: What's the best way to get rid of them? Do I need a special shampoo?
faqs.answer: Shampoo and lotions (like permethrin) are not the primary treatment, because the lice aren't living on you. The only effective treatment is to address the clothing and bedding. All infested clothing and linens must be laundered in very hot water (at least 130°F or 55°C) and then dried in a hot dryer. Items that can't be washed can be sealed in a plastic bag for two weeks, or must be destroyed.

faqs.question: What do the bites look like? I'm so itchy.
faqs.answer: The itching is an allergic reaction to the louse saliva. The bites are often clustered in areas where clothing seams would be tight against the skin—the waistline, armpits, and neck/shoulders. The skin in these areas often becomes thickened, darkened, and severely scratched from the chronic irritation, a condition called vagabond's disease.

faqs.question: I spend 3-4 hours a day obsessing over my nose. I know it's not that bad, but I can't stop. Is this BDD?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). It's not vanity. It's an obsessive-compulsive related disorder. The key features are: 1) A preoccupation with a perceived (or very minor) flaw in your appearance, and 2) Performing compulsive or repetitive behaviors (like mirror-checking, skin-picking, seeking reassurance, or camouflaging the flaw) that take up a significant amount of time (e.g., more than an hour a day) and cause you major distress.

faqs.question: How is BDD different from just having low self-esteem or being insecure?
faqs.answer: It's a matter of degree. A person with low self-esteem might think I don't like my thighs and feel bad about it. A person with BDD will obsess over their thighs for hours, be convinced they are deformed or grotesque, and may refuse to leave the house, wear shorts, or believe that everyone is staring at them. The preoccupation and compulsive behaviors are what elevate it from insecurity to a clinical disorder.

faqs.question: I had plastic surgery to fix my flaw, but now I'm just obsessing over a different one. Why didn't the surgery help?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and tragic outcome. BDD is a psychiatric disorder, not a physical one. The flaw is in the brain's perception, not on the body. Cosmetic procedures do not fix the underlying obsessive-compulsive process. The preoccupation simply latches on to a new body part, or the person becomes convinced the surgery was botched. This is why reputable plastic surgeons will screen for BDD and refuse to operate.

faqs.question: What is muscle dysmorphia?
faqs.answer: This is a specific subtype of BDD, found almost exclusively in men. It's an obsession with the idea that one's body is too small, skinny, or puny, even when the person is often very muscular. This leads to compulsive behaviors like excessive time in the gym, obsessive dieting, and often, the dangerous use of anabolic steroids.

faqs.question: What kind of therapy actually works for BDD?
faqs.answer: The most effective treatment is a combination of medication and therapy. The medications are SSRIs (like Prozac or Zoloft), usually at a much higher dose than is used for depression. The therapy is a specific type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) that includes Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP). This involves gradually facing the fear (e.g., going out without camouflaging) and resisting the compulsion (e.g., not checking the mirror). This retrains the brain to stop the obsessive loop.

faqs.question: My newborn baby's eye is always watery and has yellow gunk in it. Is it infected?
faqs.answer: This is the most common presentation of a congenital blocked tear duct (nasolacrimal duct obstruction). It's rarely a true infection. What's happening is that the tiny membrane at the end of the tear duct (down by the nose) hasn't opened properly yet. Tears can't drain, so they well up in the eye and spill over. The gunk is just mucus and normal debris that can't get flushed away. It's very common and over 90% of cases resolve on their own by age 1.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to massage the duct. How does that help?
faqs.answer: This is called the Crigler massage. The goal is to build up hydrostatic pressure in the tear sac to pop open that little membrane at the end. You'd place your finger on the side of the nose (at the corner of the eye) and press firmly downward and inward, milking the duct toward the nose. Doing this a few times a day can help it open sooner.

faqs.question: What is dacryocystitis?
faqs.answer: This is when a blocked tear duct does get infected. Because the tears are just sitting in the tear sac and not draining, it becomes a stagnant pond for bacteria. You will see a new, red, swollen, tender lump at the inner corner of the eye, by the nose. The eye will be very goopy, and the baby may have a fever. This is a true infection (dacryocystitis) and needs to be treated with antibiotics.

faqs.question: My baby is 1 year old and his eye is still watering. What's the next step?
faqs.answer: If it hasn't resolved by 12 months, the next step is usually a tear duct probing. This is a minor, 10-minute surgical procedure. An ophthalmologist will pass a tiny, blunt metal probe through the tear duct's natural opening in the eyelid and push it down through the blockage, opening the membrane. This is highly successful.

faqs.question: I'm an adult and my eye just started watering all the time. What caused this?
faqs.answer: This is acquired nasolacrimal duct obstruction. In adults, it's not from a membrane. It's usually from chronic inflammation, scarring (from repeat infections or sinus issues), or just age-related narrowing of the duct. This will not get better on its own. The treatment is a surgery called a DCR (dacryocystorhinostomy), which creates a new pathway for the tears to drain directly into your nose, bypassing the blockage.

faqs.question: My eyelids are always red, itchy, and I have crust in my eyelashes when I wake up. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of blepharitis. It's a chronic (long-term) inflammation of the eyelids, right at the base of the eyelashes. It's not a pink eye infection, but a persistent condition. It's often compared to dandruff of the eyelids. It can be very annoying and persistent, but it's not contagious.

faqs.question: What's the difference between anterior and posterior blepharitis?
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction. Anterior blepharitis affects the outside front edge of the eyelid, where the eyelashes attach. It's often caused by bacteria (Staph) or seborrheic dermatitis (dandruff). Posterior blepharitis is a problem with the inner eyelid. It's caused by Meibomian Gland Dysfunction (MGD). These are tiny oil glands in your eyelid that get clogged, like pimples on the eyelid margin. This is the more common and problematic type.

faqs.question: Why does my eye doctor keep telling me to use warm compresses and lid scrubs?
faqs.answer: This is the cornerstone of all blepharitis treatment. The warm compress (a warm, wet washcloth held on the closed eyes for 5-10 minutes) works to melt the thick, waxy oil that is clogging your meibomian glands. The lid scrub (gently scrubbing the lash line with a baby shampoo solution or a special lid wipe) is to exfoliate the crust, bacteria, and debris from the base of the eyelashes. You must do this every day to manage the condition.

faqs.question: I have blepharitis, and my eyes are always dry and gritty. Are these related?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. This is the main complication. Your tear film has three layers: a mucus layer, a water layer, and an oil layer on top. That oil layer (which comes from your meibomian glands) is crucial; it stops your tears from evaporating. In posterior blepharitis (MGD), your glands are clogged, so you don't get that oil layer. Your tears evaporate too quickly, leading to evaporative dry eye, which feels gritty and sandy.

faqs.question: I keep getting styes. Is this because of my blepharitis?
faqs.answer: Yes. A stye (or hordeolum) is an acute infection of one of those tiny meibomian glands, usually by Staph bacteria. Having chronic blepharitis means your eyelid margins are already inflamed and full of bacteria, making it much easier for one of these glands to get blocked and infected, forming a painful red bump.

faqs.question: How are bladder stones different from kidney stones? I thought they were the same.
faqs.answer: They are very different. A kidney stone forms in your kidney from concentrated minerals in your urine (like calcium oxalate) and then travels down into the bladder. If it's small, it gets passed. A bladder stone forms inside the bladder. It's almost always caused by urinary stasis—the inability to empty your bladder completely. Stagnant urine sits in your bladder, and the minerals in it crystallize and form a stone in place.

faqs.question: My doctor said my enlarged prostate (BPH) caused my bladder stone. How?
faqs.answer: This is the #1 cause of bladder stones in men. Your enlarged prostate (BPH) kinks or pinches your urethra (the exit tube). This makes it very difficult for your bladder to push all the urine out. You are left with post-void residual (stagnant urine) sitting in your bladder all the time. This swamp of old urine is the perfect environment for minerals to crystallize and form a stone.

faqs.question: I have a neurogenic bladder from a spinal cord injury. Is that why I get stones?
