Your immune system sees this as abnormal and sends cells (macrophages) to eat the cholesterol, forming foam cells. Over time, this mixture of cholesterol, foam cells, dead cells, calcium, and scar tissue forms a plaque, often covered by a thin fibrous cap. It's this cap rupturing that causes most heart attacks.

faqs.question: I get chest pain (angina) when I walk uphill, but it goes away when I rest. Why?
faqs.answer: This is stable angina. It means your coronary artery is narrowed by plaque (e.g., 70% blocked). At rest, your heart muscle gets just enough blood flow. When you exert yourself (walk uphill), your heart needs more oxygen, but the blockage limits the flow. This supply-demand mismatch causes the heart muscle to cramp, which you feel as chest pain or pressure. It goes away when you rest because the demand decreases.

faqs.question: What's the difference between stable angina and a heart attack (myocardial infarction)?
faqs.answer: It's all about plaque rupture. In stable angina, the plaque is there, but it's stable and just narrowing the artery. In a heart attack (MI), the thin fibrous cap covering the plaque suddenly ruptures or tears. This exposes the guts of the plaque to your blood, causing a blood clot to form instantly at that spot. This clot completely blocks the artery (100% blockage), cutting off all blood flow. The heart muscle downstream starts to die from lack of oxygen.

faqs.question: My EKG showed ST elevation. Why was everyone rushing around?
faqs.answer: That's an ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI). It's the most dangerous type of heart attack. The ST elevation on the EKG is a sign that a major coronary artery is completely blocked and a large amount of heart muscle is actively dying right now. This is a Code Red emergency. The only treatment is to get that artery opened immediately (reperfusion)—either with clot-busting drugs (thrombolysis) or, ideally, by rushing you to the cath lab for an emergency angioplasty and stent.

faqs.question: What's the difference between an angioplasty/stent and bypass surgery (CABG)?
faqs.answer: Angioplasty/Stent is a minimally invasive plumbing fix. A cardiologist threads a wire through the blockage, inflates a balloon (angioplasty) to squish the plaque, and then deploys a stent (a tiny metal mesh scaffold) to prop the artery open from the inside. Bypass Surgery (CABG) is open-heart surgery. A surgeon takes a healthy blood vessel (from your leg or chest wall) and creates a detour or bypass graft that goes around the blockage, restoring blood flow downstream.

faqs.question: I have this hard, painful bump on the top of my pinky toe. What is it?
faqs.answer: That sounds like a corn (heloma durum). Corns are small, concentrated areas of very hard, thick skin. They form on bony prominences (like the tops or tips of your toes) in response to direct, focal pressure or friction, usually from ill-fitting shoes rubbing on that spot. They often have a hard central core that presses inward, causing pain.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a corn and a callus?
faqs.answer: They are both made of the same thing (thick, dead skin - hyperkeratosis), but they differ in location and cause. A corn is small, deep, has a central core, and forms on a bony part of the toe due to direct pressure. A callus (tyloma) is a larger, flatter, more diffuse area of thick skin, usually found on the sole of the foot (like the ball or heel) due to repeated friction or pressure over a wider area.

faqs.question: I have a soft corn between my toes that's always damp and white. Is this different?
faqs.answer: Yes, that's a soft corn (heloma molle). It forms between the toes (usually the 4th and 5th) where the bony parts of the toes rub against each other. Because it's in a moist environment, the thick skin doesn't get hard; it stays soft, white, and macerated. These can be very painful and are prone to getting infected.

faqs.question: Are those medicated corn pads from the drugstore safe to use?
faqs.answer: They should be used with extreme caution, especially if you have diabetes or peripheral artery disease (PAD). These pads contain salicylic acid, which is designed to eat away the thick skin. However, the acid doesn't know where to stop. If you have poor circulation or sensation (like with diabetes), you could easily create a deep chemical burn or ulcer that you can't feel, leading to a serious infection. It's much safer to have them shaved down by a podiatrist.

faqs.question: How do I get rid of them for good?
faqs.answer: You have to remove the source of the pressure or friction. 1) Shoes: Get shoes with a wider toe box that doesn't rub. 2) Padding: Use non-medicated pads (like moleskin or silicone sleeves) to cushion the area. 3) Debridement: Have a podiatrist safely shave down the thick skin. 4) Orthotics: If calluses are due to foot mechanics (like flat feet), custom orthotics can redistribute the pressure. 5) Surgery: For severe corns caused by underlying bone spurs or hammertoes, surgery to correct the bone deformity may be needed.

faqs.question: My dad has COPD. Is it the same as emphysema or chronic bronchitis?
faqs.answer: COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) is the umbrella term. It includes both emphysema AND chronic bronchitis. Most people with COPD have elements of both. Emphysema is damage to the tiny air sacs (alveoli) in your lungs; they lose their elasticity and merge into big, floppy sacs that can't push air out. Chronic bronchitis is inflammation and narrowing of the airways (bronchial tubes), causing a chronic cough with mucus.

faqs.question: I smoked for 30 years and quit 10 years ago. Can I still get COPD?
faqs.answer: Yes. Unfortunately, the damage from smoking is often irreversible and progressive. While quitting smoking is the single most important thing you can do to slow down the progression, the underlying damage may already be done. Many people develop COPD symptoms years or even decades after they quit.

faqs.question: What does FEV1 mean on my breathing test (spirometry)? Mine is 50%.
faqs.answer: FEV1 stands for Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second. It's the most important number for diagnosing and staging COPD. It measures how much air you can forcefully blow out of your lungs in the first second. A low FEV1 (like yours, which is 50% of what's predicted for your age/height) means you have airflow obstruction—air is getting trapped in your lungs because your airways are narrowed or your air sacs are floppy. This FEV1 value indicates moderate COPD.

faqs.question: My doctor gave me two inhalers: Albuterol and Tiotropium (Spiriva). How are they different?
faqs.answer: They work in different ways to open your airways. Albuterol is a SABA (Short-Acting Beta-Agonist). It's a rescue inhaler. It works fast (in minutes) to relax the muscles around your airways, providing quick relief when you feel short of breath. Tiotropium (Spiriva) is a LAMA (Long-Acting Muscarinic Antagonist). It's a maintenance inhaler. You take it every day (whether you feel bad or not). It works slowly but keeps your airways open for 24 hours, preventing symptoms and reducing flare-ups.

faqs.question: What is a COPD exacerbation or flare-up?
faqs.answer: An exacerbation is a sudden worsening of your COPD symptoms—more shortness of breath, more coughing, and often a change in your mucus (thicker, more yellow/green). It's usually triggered by a respiratory infection (like a cold or the flu) or sometimes by air pollution. These flare-ups are dangerous; they cause further lung damage and are the main reason people with COPD get hospitalized. Preventing them (with inhalers, vaccines, and avoiding triggers) is a key goal of treatment.

faqs.question: I wore a new necklace, and now I have an itchy, red rash exactly where it touched my skin. What happened?
faqs.answer: This is almost certainly allergic contact dermatitis (ACD). Your skin has developed an allergic reaction to something in the necklace, most likely nickel, which is a very common metal allergen found in costume jewelry. It's a delayed-type hypersensitivity—it takes 12-72 hours after contact for the rash (redness, itching, tiny blisters) to appear.

faqs.question: My hands are dry, cracked, and itchy from washing them so much at work. Is this the same thing?
faqs.answer: No, this is irritant contact dermatitis (ICD). It's not an allergy. It's caused by substances that directly damage your skin barrier through repeated exposure. Common culprits are soaps, detergents, solvents, and even just frequent water exposure (wet work). It causes dryness, redness, cracking, and burning, but usually not the intense poison ivy type blisters seen in ACD.

faqs.question: I got into poison ivy. How long will this rash last, and can I spread it by scratching?
faqs.answer: Poison ivy rash is a classic example of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) caused by the oil urushiol. The rash itself usually lasts 1 to 3 weeks. You cannot spread the rash by scratching the blisters. The fluid in the blisters does not contain urushiol. You only spread it if you still have the original oil on your skin, clothes, or under your fingernails. The rash appears to spread because areas that got less oil take longer to react.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to do patch testing. What is that?
faqs.answer: Patch testing is the gold standard for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis (ACD). It's not the same as allergy scratch testing for hay fever. Tiny amounts of common allergens (like nickel, fragrances, preservatives) are applied to patches taped onto your back. You wear them for 48 hours. The doctor then removes them and checks your back at 48 hours and again at 72-96 hours to see if you developed a small, itchy red spot under any of the patches, identifying your specific allergen.

faqs.question: How do I treat this itchy rash?
faqs.answer: The most important step is to identify and avoid the trigger (the allergen or irritant). For the rash itself: 1) Topical corticosteroids: Prescription-strength steroid creams or ointments are the mainstay to reduce inflammation and itching. 2) Antihistamines: Oral antihistamines (like Benadryl or Zyrtec) can help with the itching, especially at night. 3) Cool compresses and oatmeal baths can soothe the skin. For severe, widespread rashes (like bad poison ivy), your doctor might prescribe oral prednisone.

faqs.question: My 4-year-old only poops once a week, and it's huge and painful. He cries when he goes. What's wrong?
faqs.answer: This is the classic picture of functional constipation in childhood, often leading to encopresis (stool leakage). What usually happens is the child has one painful bowel movement (maybe from a change in diet or routine). They then become afraid to poop because it hurts. They start withholding—clenching their muscles to avoid going. This causes the stool to sit in the rectum, get larger, harder, and drier, making the next poop even more painful. It's a vicious cycle.

faqs.question: He has these skid marks in his underwear. I thought he had diarrhea, but the doctor says it's from constipation?
faqs.answer: This is encopresis, or overflow incontinence. It seems counterintuitive, but it's the hallmark of severe constipation. The child's rectum is so impacted with a large mass of hard stool that the liquid stool from higher up leaks around the blockage and soils their underwear. It's not diarrhea; it's leakage around a blockage. The child often can't even feel it happening.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to do a clean-out with Miralax. What does that involve?
faqs.answer: The first step in treating severe constipation/encopresis is to get rid of the blockage (the impaction). This is the clean-out. It usually involves giving the child very high doses of an osmotic laxative like Miralax (polyethylene glycol) mixed in a large volume of liquid over 1-3 days. The goal is to induce a bowel prep like for a colonoscopy—to completely flush out all the hard stool until they are passing only liquid.

faqs.question: After the clean-out, do we stop the Miralax?
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. This is the most common mistake. The clean-out just empties the rectum; it doesn't fix the underlying fear or the stretched-out rectum. You must continue with a daily maintenance dose of Miralax (a much smaller dose) for several months (often 6-12 months). The goal is to keep the stool consistently soft (like toothpaste) every single day so the child has no fear of pooping, and the stretched rectum has time to shrink back to its normal size.

faqs.question: Is Miralax safe to take long-term? I've heard bad things online.
faqs.answer: Miralax (polyethylene glycol 3350) is considered very safe and is the standard of care for childhood constipation. It is not absorbed into the bloodstream. It works simply by drawing water into the colon (osmosis), which softens the stool. Decades of research and clinical experience support its safety and efficacy. The bad things online are largely based on misinformation and are not supported by scientific evidence. It is far safer than leaving severe constipation untreated.

faqs.question: I only have a bowel movement every 3 days. Is this technically constipation?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Normal bowel frequency varies hugely—anywhere from 3 times a day to 3 times a week can be normal for you, as long as the stool is soft and easy to pass. Constipation is defined more by symptoms: straining more than 25% of the time, having hard or lumpy stools, feeling like you haven't completely emptied, or needing to use your fingers to help (digital evacuation).

faqs.question: I started taking an iron supplement, and now I'm terribly constipated. Why?
faqs.answer: Iron supplements are a notorious cause of constipation. They tend to slow down the motility (the muscular contractions) of your colon and can also make the stool harder and darker. Other common medication culprits include opioid pain medications (like oxycodone), some blood pressure pills (like calcium channel blockers), and some antidepressants.

faqs.question: What's the difference between fiber supplements like Metamucil and laxatives like Miralax?
faqs.answer: Fiber (like Metamucil/psyllium) is a bulking agent. It absorbs water and adds bulk to your stool, which stimulates your colon to contract. It's great for prevention but requires drinking lots of water. Miralax (polyethylene glycol) is an osmotic laxative. It's a large molecule that stays in your colon and pulls water in via osmosis, softening the stool. Stimulant laxatives (like Senna or Dulcolax) are different—they directly irritate the colon wall, forcing it to contract. They work fast but can cause cramping and shouldn't be used long-term.

faqs.question: I've been constipated my whole life, and laxatives don't work well. My doctor mentioned slow transit constipation. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is a specific motility disorder. It means the nerves or muscles of your colon itself are not working properly. The transit time—how long it takes for stool to move through your colon—is abnormally slow. This is diagnosed with a special X-ray test called a sitz marker study (you swallow a capsule of tiny rings, and X-rays track how fast they move). This type often requires prescription medications that stimulate motility (like Linzess or Motegrity).

faqs.question: When should I be worried about my constipation? Are there red flag signs?
faqs.answer: You should see a doctor immediately if you have constipation plus any of these red flags: 1) Blood in your stool (bright red or black), 2) Unexplained weight loss, 3) Severe abdominal pain, 4) Inability to pass gas, or 5) A sudden, new onset of severe constipation if you've always been regular (this could be a sign of a blockage, like from colon cancer).

faqs.question: How does this even happen? Is it two babies fused together?
faqs.answer: It's the other way around. It starts as a single fertilized egg that is meant to become one baby. For identical twins to form, this egg must split completely in two, usually within the first 8-12 days after conception. If this splitting process starts late (e.g., after day 13) and is incomplete, the resulting identical twins remain partially joined.

faqs.question: My ultrasound showed conjoined twins. What's the most important factor for their survival?
faqs.answer: The single most critical factor is whether or not they share a heart, and how complex that shared circulation is. Twins joined at the chest (thoracopagus, the most common type) often share a heart or major vessels. If they share a single, complex heart, surgical separation is usually impossible, and the prognosis is very poor.

faqs.question: What are the different ways twins can be joined?
faqs.answer: They are classified by the point of fusion: Thoracopagus (chest-to-chest, often sharing a heart - most common), Omphalopagus (belly-to-belly, often sharing a liver or intestine), Pygopagus (back-to-back at the pelvis/buttocks), Ischiopagus (hip-to-hip), and Craniopagus (joined at the head - rarest).

faqs.question: Can they always be separated surgically?
faqs.answer: No. The decision is incredibly complex and depends entirely on which organs are shared and how feasible it is to reconstruct those organs for both twins. Separation surgery is one of the most complex operations performed, requiring massive teams and months of planning. Often, it involves sacrificing less critical shared organs or performing complex reconstructions. Sometimes, separation carries such a high risk that it's deemed safer not to attempt it.

faqs.question: If one twin dies, does the other automatically die?
faqs.answer: If they share vital circulation (like a heart or major blood vessels), then yes, the death of one twin will lead to the death of the other very quickly due to circulatory collapse or sepsis. This is why emergency separation surgery is sometimes attempted in dire circumstances, even if it means sacrificing one twin to save the other.

faqs.question: My baby is floppy and has droopy eyelids. The doctors ruled out Myasthenia Gravis and say it's Congenital Myasthenic Syndrome. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction. Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disease that usually starts in adulthood; your own immune system attacks the communication point between nerve and muscle. Congenital Myasthenic Syndromes (CMS) are genetic disorders you are born with. The problem isn't autoimmune; it's a faulty part—a broken gene—that affects one of the many proteins needed for that nerve-muscle communication to work properly. The symptoms (weakness, fatigue, droopy eyelids) look the same, but the cause and treatment are different.

faqs.question: The doctor mentioned a specific gene, like DOK7 or COLQ. Why are there so many different types?
faqs.answer: The neuromuscular junction (where nerve meets muscle) is incredibly complex, involving dozens of specialized proteins. CMS occurs when the gene for any one of these proteins is broken. There are now over 30 known CMS genes. They are grouped based on where the faulty protein is: Presynaptic (nerve side), Synaptic (the gap), or Postsynaptic (muscle side). Knowing the specific gene is crucial because the treatments are often gene-specific.

faqs.question: Why doesn't the standard Myasthenia Gravis drug (Mestinon/pyridostigmine) work for all types of CMS?
faqs.answer: Pyridostigmine works by boosting the levels of the neurotransmitter (acetylcholine) in the gap. This helps overcome the autoimmune blockage in MG. It does work for some types of CMS (like those affecting the acetylcholine receptor itself). However, for other types (like COLQ or slow-channel CMS), pyridostigmine can actually make the weakness worse. This is why genetic diagnosis is critical.

faqs.question: My child has COLQ-CMS. What treatments might help?
faqs.answer: CMS caused by mutations in the COLQ gene affects the enzyme (acetylcholinesterase) that breaks down acetylcholine. Treatment often involves ephedrine or albuterol/salbutamol (asthma medications!), which are thought to help compensate for the signaling defect in a different way. Pyridostigmine is generally avoided.

faqs.question: My child has Slow-Channel CMS. Why is Quinidine used?
faqs.answer: Slow-Channel CMS is caused by mutations in the acetylcholine receptor itself, making the channel stay open too long. This leads to over-excitation of the muscle. Quinidine (an old heart rhythm drug) or fluoxetine (Prozac!) can act as channel blockers, helping the receptor close more normally. Pyridostigmine would make this type much worse.

faqs.question: My baby was diagnosed with a heart murmur, and the echo showed a mitral valve anomaly. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: The mitral valve is the door between the top left chamber (left atrium) and the bottom left chamber (left ventricle) of the heart. Congenital anomaly means your baby was born with a mitral valve that didn't form perfectly. There are many variations, but the valve might be too narrow (stenosis), leaky (regurgitation), have abnormally shaped leaflets, or have problems with the ropes (chordae tendineae) that support it.

faqs.question: What is a parachute mitral valve?
faqs.answer: This is a specific, rare anomaly. Normally, the mitral valve leaflets are attached by many ropes (chordae) to two distinct papillary muscles inside the ventricle. In a parachute valve, all the ropes converge and attach to just one papillary muscle. This restricts the valve's opening, often causing mitral stenosis (narrowing).

faqs.question: The doctor mentioned a double-outlet left ventricle or mitral arcade. What are these?
faqs.answer: These are other rare structural abnormalities. A double-outlet left ventricle means the valve leaflets' support structures (papillary muscles) are too close together or fused, restricting motion. A mitral arcade involves abnormal bridging tissue or fused papillary muscles creating a narrowing just below the valve. Both can lead to mitral stenosis.

faqs.question: My baby's valve is leaky (regurgitation). Will this need surgery?
faqs.answer: It depends on the severity. Mild or moderate mitral regurgitation is often monitored with regular echocardiograms. If the leak is severe, it causes the left atrium and ventricle to enlarge and work harder. Over time, this can lead to heart failure symptoms (poor feeding, rapid breathing, failure to thrive). Severe, symptomatic regurgitation usually requires surgical repair or replacement of the valve.

faqs.question: Can they repair the valve, or does it always need to be replaced?
faqs.answer: Whenever possible, surgeons prefer to repair a child's native valve rather than replace it. Replacement often requires a mechanical valve (needing lifelong blood thinners) or a tissue valve (which wears out and needs re-replacement). Repair techniques are complex but aim to reshape the leaflets or fix the supporting structures to make the valve function better. The success of repair depends heavily on the specific valve anatomy.

faqs.question: I had surgery for a hole in my heart (ASD) as a kid. Do I still need to see a cardiologist?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Even after a successful childhood repair, you need lifelong follow-up with a cardiologist specializing in Adult Congenital Heart Disease (ACHD). While your ASD is fixed, your heart grew up with abnormal blood flow patterns. You remain at higher risk for certain long-term complications, like arrhythmias (especially atrial fibrillation or flutter), pulmonary hypertension (high pressure in the lungs), or problems with your heart valves.

faqs.question: I was born with Tetralogy of Fallot and had a repair. What problems should I watch out for now as an adult?
faqs.answer: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is complex. Even after a great repair, the most common long-term issue is pulmonary valve regurgitation (leakiness). The repair often involved cutting across the pulmonary valve, and it becomes very leaky over decades. This leak causes the right ventricle (the chamber pumping to the lungs) to enlarge and fail. You also have a high risk of ventricular arrhythmias and need regular monitoring with echoes and MRIs.

faqs.question: I had a coarctation repair as a baby. Why do I still have high blood pressure?
faqs.answer: This is very common. Even after fixing the kink in the aorta, the blood vessels in the upper body often remain somewhat stiff or abnormal from having seen high pressure for years. Hypertension is a major long-term risk after coarctation repair and must be treated aggressively to prevent aneurysms and premature coronary artery disease.

faqs.question: Can I get pregnant if I have congenital heart disease?
faqs.answer: This requires careful planning with your ACHD cardiologist and a high-risk obstetrician. For many women with simple defects (like a repaired ASD or VSD) and good heart function, pregnancy is safe. However, for women with complex conditions (like unrepaired defects, pulmonary hypertension, or weakened heart muscle), pregnancy carries significant risks to both mother and baby. You need a personalized risk assessment before conceiving.

faqs.question: Why is endocarditis prophylaxis (antibiotics before dental work) not always needed anymore?
faqs.answer: The guidelines changed significantly. We realized the risk of endocarditis (a heart valve infection) from routine dental work is much lower than previously thought, and the risks/costs of antibiotics are not zero. Now, prophylaxis is only recommended for the highest risk ACHD patients: those with prosthetic (artificial) valves, those with a history of previous endocarditis, or those with unrepaired cyanotic (blue) heart disease.

faqs.question: My baby was born blue. The doctors said it's a cyanotic heart defect. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Cyanosis (blueness) means there isn't enough oxygen in the baby's blood. In a cyanotic heart defect, there's a structural problem that allows oxygen-poor (blue) blood from the right side of the heart to mix with oxygen-rich (red) blood from the left side before it goes out to the body. This mixing lowers the overall oxygen level. Examples include Tetralogy of Fallot, Transposition of the Great Arteries, and Truncus Arteriosus.

faqs.question: What's the difference between an ASD and a VSD?
faqs.answer: They are both holes in the heart, but in different places. An ASD (Atrial Septal Defect) is a hole in the wall between the two top chambers (the atria). A VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect) is a hole in the wall between the two bottom chambers (the ventricles). VSDs are more common and often cause symptoms earlier because the pressure difference between the ventricles is much higher, causing more blood to shunt across the hole.

faqs.question: My baby has a PDA. Is that serious?
faqs.answer: A PDA (Patent Ductus Arteriosus) is a connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery that is normal in a fetus but is supposed to close shortly after birth. If it stays patent (open), it allows extra blood to flow into the lungs. In premature babies, a large PDA can be very serious, causing breathing problems. In full-term babies, a small PDA might just cause a murmur and can often be closed later with a minimally invasive catheter procedure.

faqs.question: What is hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS)? It sounds very bad.
faqs.answer: HLHS is one of the most complex and severe defects. Hypoplastic means underdeveloped. The entire left side of the heart (mitral valve, left ventricle, aortic valve, and ascending aorta) is too small and non-functional. The right ventricle has to do all the work, pumping blood to both the lungs and the body. Babies with HLHS cannot survive without a series of three complex open-heart surgeries performed over the first few years of life (the Norwood, Glenn, and Fontan procedures).

faqs.question: My baby gets tired and sweaty just from drinking her bottle. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a classic sign of Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) in an infant. Her heart defect (like a large VSD or severe valve problem) is making her heart work so hard just to pump blood that she doesn't have enough energy left for anything else. Feeding is like exercise for a baby. If she gets sweaty, breathes fast, or falls asleep after only drinking a small amount, it's a sign her heart is struggling. She may need medication (like diuretics) or earlier surgery.

faqs.question: My ultrasound showed the baby's stomach is up in its chest. What is a CDH?
faqs.answer: A Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH) is a birth defect where the diaphragm—the flat muscle separating the chest from the abdomen—has a hole in it. This hole allows the abdominal organs (like the stomach, intestines, and sometimes liver) to herniate or move up into the chest cavity during fetal development.

faqs.question: Why is this so dangerous? Is it just that the organs are in the wrong place?
faqs.answer: The location is part of it, but the real danger is pulmonary hypoplasia. Because the abdominal organs are taking up space in the chest while the baby's lungs are supposed to be growing, the lungs (especially on the side of the hernia, usually the left) are severely underdeveloped or hypoplastic. The baby is born with lungs that are too small to support breathing.

faqs.question: What is pulmonary hypertension in CDH?
faqs.answer: This is the other major life-threatening problem. Not only are the lungs small, but the blood vessels within those lungs are also abnormal—they are thick-walled and constricted. This causes extremely high blood pressure in the lung arteries (pulmonary hypertension), making it very hard for the heart to pump blood to the lungs to pick up oxygen. This is often the hardest part to manage after birth.

faqs.question: What is ECMO and why might my baby need it?
faqs.answer: ECMO (Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation) is the highest form of life support. It's essentially an artificial heart-lung machine used for babies who are too sick for a ventilator. Blood is drained from the baby, run through an external lung (oxygenator), and then pumped back into the baby. This allows the baby's own lungs and heart to rest completely and hopefully recover, giving time for the pulmonary hypertension to improve before surgery.

faqs.question: When do they do the surgery to fix the hole?
faqs.answer: The surgery is not done immediately at birth. The priority is to stabilize the baby's breathing and pulmonary hypertension first. Once the baby is stable on the ventilator (or off ECMO), usually after several days or even weeks, the surgeon will perform the operation to move the abdominal organs back down into the belly and repair the hole in the diaphragm, often using a patch.

faqs.question: My newborn baby girl has ambiguous genitalia. The doctors mentioned CAH. What is this?
faqs.answer: Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of genetic disorders affecting the adrenal glands. The most common type (95%) is 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Your adrenal glands are supposed to make three hormones: cortisol, aldosterone, and androgens (male hormones). In CAH, there's a block in the assembly line—the enzyme needed to make cortisol and aldosterone is broken. The raw materials back up and get shunted sideways into making excess androgens instead.

faqs.question: Why does the excess androgen affect my baby girl?
faqs.answer: During fetal development, external genitalia form based on hormone signals. In a genetic female (XX) with CAH, her adrenal glands produce so much excess androgen (testosterone) that it virilizes her external genitalia. This can cause the clitoris to enlarge (looking like a small penis) and the labia to fuse (looking like a scrotum). Her internal organs (uterus, ovaries) are normal female.

faqs.question: The doctor said my baby could have a salt-wasting crisis. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is the life-threatening emergency in severe CAH. Because the enzyme to make aldosterone is also blocked, the baby cannot retain salt. Aldosterone's job is to tell the kidneys to keep salt. Without it, the baby pees out massive amounts of salt and water, leading to dehydration, low blood pressure, high potassium, shock, and death within the first few weeks of life if not recognized and treated immediately with fluids and steroids.

faqs.question: How is this treated? Will my child need hormones for life?
faqs.answer: Yes. Treatment is lifelong. It involves hormone replacement: 1) Glucocorticoids (like hydrocortisone): This replaces the missing cortisol. Giving cortisol also tricks the pituitary gland into stopping the signal (ACTH) that was driving the adrenal overgrowth, thus reducing the excess androgen production. 2) Mineralocorticoids (like fludrocortisone): This replaces the missing aldosterone to prevent salt-wasting. Doses need to be carefully monitored and adjusted, especially during times of illness (stress dosing).

faqs.question: What is non-classic CAH? My teenage daughter has early puberty and severe acne.
faqs.answer: Non-classic CAH (NCAH) is a much milder form of 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The enzyme isn't completely broken, just sluggish. These individuals do not have ambiguous genitalia at birth and do not have salt-wasting. Instead, they present later in childhood or puberty with signs of mild androgen excess: early pubic hair (premature adrenarche), severe acne, irregular periods (in girls), and sometimes rapid growth. It's often mistaken for PCOS.

faqs.question: I hit my head playing soccer, saw stars, and felt foggy. I didn't pass out. Was it still a concussion?
faqs.answer: Yes. Loss of consciousness is NOT required for a concussion diagnosis. A concussion is a functional brain injury, not structural. It's caused by a blow to the head (or body) that makes the brain slosh inside the skull, stretching and shearing nerve fibers. This disrupts normal brain signaling, causing symptoms like headache, dizziness, fogginess, confusion, nausea, or seeing stars (visual disturbance).

faqs.question: How long will this last? It's been 3 days and I still have a headache and feel off.
faqs.answer: The typical recovery time for a sports-related concussion is 7 to 14 days. However, about 10-20% of people experience Persistent Post-Concussive Symptoms (PPCS), where symptoms like headache, dizziness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating last for weeks or months. Recovery is highly variable.

faqs.question: My son got a concussion playing football. When can he go back to playing?
faqs.answer: He cannot return to play until he has completed a formal, stepwise Return-to-Play (RTP) protocol supervised by a healthcare provider. This involves gradually increasing physical activity only after he is completely symptom-free at rest and back to normal cognitive function (school). Each step (light aerobics, sport-specific drills, non-contact practice, full practice) must be symptom-free for 24 hours before moving to the next. Returning too soon significantly increases the risk of a second, more severe injury.

faqs.question: What is second impact syndrome?
faqs.answer: Second Impact Syndrome (SIS) is a rare but catastrophic event. It occurs when an athlete suffers a second head impact before they have fully recovered from a previous concussion. The brain, still vulnerable, loses its ability to regulate blood flow, leading to massive, rapid brain swelling, herniation, and often death within minutes. This is why the Return-to-Play protocol is so strict—you never return an athlete with any concussion symptoms.

faqs.question: Should I just rest in a dark room until I feel better?
faqs.answer: This is outdated advice. While relative rest (avoiding strenuous activity and symptom-provoking situations) is crucial in the first 24-48 hours, prolonged, strict rest (cocoon therapy) is now known to delay recovery. After the first couple of days, the recommendation is gradual reintegration into light cognitive and physical activity as tolerated, staying below the level that makes symptoms significantly worse.

faqs.question: I spend hours every day looking at porn, even when I know I should stop. It's hurting my relationship and my job. Is this an addiction?
faqs.answer: The term sex addiction is controversial, but the behavior you're describing fits Compulsive Sexual Behavior Disorder (CSBD). The key features are: 1) Recurrent, intense sexual urges or behaviors that feel out of control. 2) Spending excessive time on these activities. 3) Continuing the behavior despite negative consequences (relationship problems, job loss, financial issues, STIs). 4) Using sex as a primary way to cope with stress, anxiety, or depression.

faqs.question: How is this different from just having a high sex drive?
faqs.answer: A high sex drive (libido) isn't inherently problematic. CSBD is about the loss of control and the negative impact on your life. Someone with a high libido enjoys sex but can still manage their responsibilities and relationships. Someone with CSBD feels compelled to engage in sexual behavior, often in ways that feel shameful or risky, and they can't stop even when it's causing harm.

faqs.question: Could this be related to my Bipolar Disorder?
faqs.answer: Yes, it's very important to rule out other conditions. Hypersexuality (an increase in sexual drive and risky behavior) is a classic symptom of a manic or hypomanic episode in Bipolar Disorder. This is different from CSBD, which is a persistent pattern regardless of mood state. Some medications (like dopamine agonists used for Parkinson's) can also trigger compulsive behaviors.

faqs.question: What kind of treatment helps? I feel so ashamed.
faqs.answer: Shame is a huge barrier, but treatment is available and effective. The main approaches are: 1) Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps identify triggers and develop coping skills. Therapy often focuses on underlying issues like trauma, anxiety, or depression. 2) Support Groups: 12-step groups (like Sex Addicts Anonymous) provide peer support and accountability. 3) Medication: Sometimes medications like SSRIs (antidepressants) or naltrexone (used for alcohol/opioid addiction) can help reduce the compulsive urges, especially if there's an underlying mood or anxiety disorder.

faqs.question: Is online porn the main problem? Or does it include other behaviors?
faqs.answer: CSBD can involve any type of sexual behavior that becomes compulsive and problematic. This can include excessive pornography use, compulsive masturbation, multiple affairs, anonymous sex, paying for sex, exhibitionism, or cybersex. The specific behavior matters less than the pattern of loss of control and negative consequences.

faqs.question: I keep gambling even though I know I'm losing money I can't afford. I lie to my family about it. Do I have a problem?
faqs.answer: Yes, this sounds like Gambling Disorder (also known as compulsive gambling or gambling addiction). Key signs include: 1) Needing to gamble with increasing amounts of money to get the same thrill (tolerance). 2) Feeling restless or irritable when trying to cut back (withdrawal). 3) Lying to hide the extent of your gambling. 4) Gambling to escape problems or relieve bad moods. 5) Chasing losses (trying to win back money you lost). 6) Jeopardizing relationships, jobs, or finances due to gambling.

faqs.question: How is this an addiction? It's not like a drug.
faqs.answer: It's considered a behavioral addiction. The brain pathways involved are very similar to drug addiction. Gambling triggers the release of dopamine (the reward chemical) in your brain's pleasure center. This creates a powerful high and reinforcement loop. Over time, the brain adapts, requiring bigger risks (larger bets) to get the same dopamine release, leading to the compulsive cycle.

faqs.question: Is online sports betting or stock market day trading considered gambling?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Gambling Disorder isn't just about casinos. It can involve any behavior where you are risking something of value on an uncertain outcome. This definitely includes sports betting, online poker, lottery tickets, and even highly speculative stock market trading if it becomes compulsive and causes negative consequences.

faqs.question: What kind of help is available? I feel trapped.
faqs.answer: There is very effective help available. 1) Gamblers Anonymous (GA): A 12-step program providing crucial peer support and structure. 2) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Helps identify gambling triggers, challenge irrational thoughts (I'm due for a win), and develop coping strategies. 3) Medication: While no specific gambling pill exists, medications for underlying conditions like depression, anxiety, or ADHD can sometimes help reduce gambling urges. 4) Financial Counseling: Crucial for managing the debt and financial chaos caused by the addiction.

faqs.question: My husband refuses to admit he has a problem. What can I do?
faqs.answer: This is incredibly difficult. You cannot force someone into recovery. Focus on what you can control. 1) Set boundaries: Refuse to enable the gambling (e.g., no bailouts). 2) Protect finances: Separate bank accounts if possible. 3) Seek support for yourself: Groups like Gam-Anon are specifically for family members affected by gambling addiction. 4) Encourage treatment, but recognize you can't make him go.

faqs.question: My husband died a year ago, and I still feel like it happened yesterday. I can't accept it, and I have no interest in life. Is this normal grief?
faqs.answer: While grief has no timeline, what you're describing sounds like it could be Complicated Grief, now formally called Prolonged Grief Disorder (PGD). Normal (integrated) grief gradually lessens in intensity over time, allowing you to re-engage with life while still remembering your loved one. PGD is when the acute stage of grief remains stuck—intense yearning, disbelief, anger, and an inability to function persist for an extended period (typically defined as >1 year for adults, >6 months for children) and significantly impair your life.

faqs.question: How is PGD different from depression?
faqs.answer: They can overlap, but the focus is different. Depression is characterized by pervasive low mood, loss of interest in everything, feelings of worthlessness, and often, suicidal thoughts unrelated to the loss. Prolonged Grief Disorder is centered specifically on the loss. The intense pain, yearning, and preoccupation are all focused on the deceased person. You might be able to experience moments of happiness in other areas, but the grief itself remains debilitating.

faqs.question: Why did this happen to me? Other people seem to handle loss better.
faqs.answer: PGD is not a sign of weakness. Certain factors increase the risk: 1) Circumstances of the death: Sudden, violent, or traumatic deaths (like accidents, suicide, homicide) are much harder to process. 2) Relationship to the deceased: Loss of a child or a spouse/partner you were highly dependent on. 3) Lack of social support: Feeling isolated after the loss. 4) Pre-existing mental health issues: History of depression or anxiety.

faqs.question: What kind of therapy helps? Talking about it just makes me feel worse.
faqs.answer: A specific type of therapy, Complicated Grief Treatment (CGT), now often adapted as Prolonged Grief Disorder Therapy (PGDT), is highly effective. It's different from general grief counseling. It uses techniques from CBT and interpersonal therapy to help you: 1) Understand and accept the reality of the loss. 2) Work through avoided memories and reminders. 3) Restore a sense of purpose and plan for the future while still maintaining a connection to the deceased. It focuses on integrating the loss into your ongoing life.

faqs.question: Will antidepressants help?
faqs.answer: If you also have Major Depressive Disorder co-occurring with PGD, then yes, antidepressants can help lift the depressive symptoms. However, antidepressants do not specifically treat the core symptoms of grief itself (the yearning, the disbelief). Therapy is the primary treatment for PGD, although medication may be a helpful adjunct if depression is present.

faqs.question: I sprained my wrist 3 months ago, but the pain is now worse than ever, burning and constant. My skin is shiny and swollen. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds very much like Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS), previously known as Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD). It's a mysterious and debilitating chronic pain condition that usually develops after a minor injury (like a sprain, fracture, or surgery) to a limb. The hallmark is pain that is out of proportion to the initial injury and persists long after the injury should have healed.

faqs.question: Why is my hand also changing color (red or bluish) and temperature (cold)?
faqs.answer: These are classic autonomic signs of CRPS. The injury seems to trigger a malfunction in your autonomic nervous system (which controls blood flow, temperature, and sweating) and your central nervous system. This causes abnormal nerve signals that lead to: 1) Vasomotor changes: Blood vessels constrict or dilate abnormally, causing color and temperature changes. 2) Sudomotor changes: Abnormal sweating (too much or too little). 3) Trophic changes: Changes in skin (shiny, thin), hair (loss or increased growth), and nails (brittle).

faqs.question: Just lightly touching my skin is excruciating (allodynia). Why is normal touch so painful?
faqs.answer: Allodynia (pain from a non-painful stimulus) is a key feature of CRPS and neuropathic pain. It's a sign of central sensitization. The injury has rewired your pain pathways in your spinal cord and brain. Your nervous system is now stuck in a high-alert state, interpreting all signals from that limb—even light touch—as danger or pain.

faqs.question: Is this all in my head? My doctor seems skeptical.
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. CRPS is a very real, physiological disease of the nervous system. Unfortunately, because the initial injury is often minor and the symptoms are bizarre (and X-rays are normal), patients are sometimes dismissed. Diagnosis is made using the Budapest Criteria, which rely on a specific combination of symptoms (disproportionate pain) and objective signs (color/temperature changes, swelling, motor changes) observed by the doctor.

faqs.question: How is CRPS treated? It feels hopeless.
faqs.answer: Treatment is challenging and requires a multidisciplinary approach, starting early. Key components include: 1) Physical/Occupational Therapy: This is CRUCIAL. Techniques like mirror therapy and graded motor imagery help retrain the brain. Gentle movement prevents stiffness. 2) Medications: Nerve pain medications (like gabapentin, amitriptyline), NSAIDs, and sometimes low-dose naltrexone. Opioids are generally not effective long-term. 3) Nerve Blocks: Sympathetic nerve blocks can sometimes provide temporary relief and aid therapy. 4) Neuromodulation: For severe cases, spinal cord stimulators may be considered.

faqs.question: I have these rough, bumpy growths on my fingers. Are they contagious?
faqs.answer: Yes, common warts (verruca vulgaris) are contagious. They are caused by the Human Papillomavirus (HPV). You get them when the virus enters your skin through a tiny cut or scrape. You can spread them to other parts of your own body (autoinoculation) by picking or scratching, or to other people through direct skin contact or by sharing things like towels.

faqs.question: Why do some people get warts and others don't, even in the same family?
faqs.answer: It's all about your individual immune system. Some people's immune systems are very good at recognizing and fighting off the HPV virus, so they never get warts or they go away quickly. Other people's immune systems don't mount a strong response, allowing the virus to establish itself and cause the warty growth. Children and people with weakened immune systems are more susceptible.

faqs.question: What are those tiny black dots inside the wart?
faqs.answer: Those are thrombosed capillaries (clotted blood vessels). Warts induce the growth of their own tiny blood supply to feed themselves. These vessels often look like little black seeds or dots within the wart tissue. Their presence is a good sign that the growth is indeed a wart.

faqs.question: Will warts go away on their own?
faqs.answer: Often, yes, especially in children. About 60-70% of warts in children will resolve spontaneously (without treatment) within 2 years as their immune system eventually recognizes and clears the virus. In adults, they can be much more persistent and often require treatment.

faqs.question: What's the best way to treat them? I tried the drugstore freeze spray and it didn't work.
faqs.answer: Wart treatment can be frustrating. Common options include: 1) Salicylic Acid: Over-the-counter liquids or pads applied daily work slowly by peeling away the infected skin (requires persistence). 2) Cryotherapy: Freezing with liquid nitrogen by a doctor. This is often painful and may require multiple sessions. 3) Cantharidin (Blister Beetle Juice): Applied by a doctor, causes a blister to form under the wart, lifting it off. 4) Prescription creams (like imiquimod) or injections (like Candida antigen) to stimulate the immune system. There's no single best treatment; it often takes trial and error.

faqs.question: My 3-month-old has a stuffy nose and a slight cough. How can I help him breathe?
faqs.answer: Babies under 6 months are obligate nose breathers, meaning they must breathe through their nose. A stuffy nose is therefore miserable for them, especially during feeding. The most important thing you can do is saline and suction. Put 1-2 drops of saline nasal spray (saltwater) in each nostril to loosen the mucus, wait a minute, and then use a bulb syringe or nasal aspirator (like a NoseFrida) to suck the mucus out. Do this especially before feeds and sleep.

faqs.question: Can I give my baby over-the-counter cold medicine?
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. OTC cough and cold medications (decongestants, antihistamines, cough suppressants) are unsafe and ineffective for children under 4 years old (and especially dangerous under age 2). They can cause serious side effects like rapid heart rate, drowsiness, or even seizures. Do not use them.

faqs.question: Why does my baby seem so much fussier and sleep worse with just a cold?
faqs.answer: Even a mild cold is tough on a baby. They can't breathe through their nose easily, which makes it hard to drink their bottle or breastfeed (they have to keep stopping to breathe). This leads to frustration, less intake, and dehydration. The stuffiness also makes it hard to sleep comfortably. Plus, they just feel generally unwell.

faqs.question: When should I worry and call the doctor?
faqs.answer: Call your pediatrician if your baby: 1) Has a fever (rectal temp >100.4°F or 38°C), especially if under 3 months old. 2) Shows signs of respiratory distress: fast breathing (>60 breaths/min), nasal flaring, retractions (skin sucking in around ribs/neck). 3) Is refusing to feed or showing signs of dehydration (fewer wet diapers). 4) Has a cough that sounds barky (croup) or is getting progressively worse. 5) Is unusually lethargic or difficult to wake.

faqs.question: What else can I do besides saline/suction?
faqs.answer: Use a cool-mist humidifier in the baby's room, especially at night, to help keep nasal passages moist. Keep the baby hydrated by offering breastmilk or formula frequently, even if they only take small amounts. Elevating the head of the crib slightly (by placing a thin towel under the mattress, NOT pillows in the crib) may help with drainage, but check with your pediatrician first.

faqs.question: I get sinus infections and pneumonia constantly. My doctor tested my immunoglobulins and said they're low. What is CVID?
faqs.answer: Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) is the most common primary immunodeficiency (an inherited immune system problem) diagnosed in adults. Variable means it presents differently in everyone. The core issue is that your B-cells (a type of white blood cell) fail to produce enough functional antibodies (immunoglobulins - IgG, IgA, IgM). Antibodies are crucial for fighting off bacterial infections, especially in your respiratory tract.

faqs.question: If my B-cells aren't working, why does the doctor need to check my T-cells too?
faqs.answer: While the main problem in CVID is antibody production (a B-cell function), some people with CVID also have subtle defects in their T-cells (another type of immune cell). This is important because T-cell problems can increase the risk of certain opportunistic infections or autoimmune complications. Ruling out a combined immunodeficiency is part of the workup.

faqs.question: How is this treated? My doctor mentioned infusions.
faqs.answer: The cornerstone of CVID treatment is Immunoglobulin Replacement Therapy (IRT). Since your body can't make enough antibodies, you receive infusions of purified antibodies (IgG) collected from thousands of healthy blood donors. This gives your immune system the ammunition it needs. IRT can be given either intravenously (IVIG) in a clinic every 3-4 weeks, or subcutaneously (SCIG) under the skin at home, usually once a week.

faqs.question: Besides infections, what other problems can CVID cause?
faqs.answer: CVID is tricky because the immune dysregulation can cause problems beyond just infections. Patients are at higher risk for: 1) Autoimmune diseases: The faulty immune system can attack the body's own tissues (like ITP, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, or arthritis). 2) Lung disease: Chronic infections can lead to permanent lung damage (bronchiectasis). 3) Gastrointestinal problems: Chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and inflammatory bowel disease-like symptoms. 4) Increased risk of certain cancers: Especially lymphoma.

faqs.question: I had normal immunity as a child. How could I develop this now as an adult?
faqs.answer: This is the variable part. CVID most commonly presents in young adulthood (20s-40s), even though the underlying genetic defect was present from birth. We don't know why the immune system functions adequately for years and then fails. It's thought that some environmental trigger or secondary factor might contribute to the eventual loss of antibody production in genetically susceptible individuals.

faqs.question: My husband played pro football for years, and now in his 50s, he has terrible mood swings, memory problems, and flies into rages. Could this be CTE?
faqs.answer: This constellation of symptoms—mood changes (depression, irritability, rage), cognitive impairment (memory loss, executive dysfunction), and behavioral changes (impulsivity, aggression)—developing years after a history of repetitive head impacts is highly suggestive of Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE). It's a progressive neurodegenerative disease linked to repeated concussions and, importantly, subconcussive blows (hits that don't cause symptoms).

faqs.question: What actually happens in the brain with CTE?
faqs.answer: CTE is a tauopathy, similar to Alzheimer's disease. The repetitive trauma is thought to trigger the abnormal misfolding and clumping of a protein called tau within brain cells. These neurofibrillary tangles first accumulate in specific areas (often deep in the sulci of the cortex) and then spread, disrupting communication between brain cells and eventually killing them. The pattern of tau accumulation is unique to CTE.

faqs.question: Can CTE be diagnosed while someone is alive?
faqs.answer: Currently, no. A definitive diagnosis of CTE can only be made by examining the brain tissue after death (at autopsy) and seeing that characteristic pattern of tau tangles. While doctors can have a strong clinical suspicion based on the symptoms and exposure history (Traumatic Encephalopathy Syndrome), there is currently no reliable blood test, brain scan, or clinical exam that can definitively diagnose CTE in a living person.

faqs.question: Is it just football players? What about boxers or military veterans?
faqs.answer: CTE is associated with any activity involving repetitive head impacts. It was first described in boxers (dementia pugilistica). It is definitely seen in American football, ice hockey, soccer (from heading), rugby, and military veterans exposed to blast injuries or repeated concussive events.

faqs.question: If you can't diagnose it, can you treat it?
faqs.answer: There is no cure for CTE and no treatment that can reverse the underlying brain degeneration. Treatment focuses entirely on managing the symptoms. This involves medications for mood disorders (antidepressants, mood stabilizers), therapy for behavioral issues (anger management, impulse control), and strategies to cope with cognitive decline (memory aids, structured routines). Prevention—reducing exposure to head impacts—is the only way to stop CTE.

faqs.question: I feel like I always have a stuffy nose, sinus pressure, and post-nasal drip. It never fully goes away. Is this chronic sinusitis?
faqs.answer: That sounds like it. Chronic Rhinosinusitis (CRS) is defined as inflammation of the nose and sinuses lasting for 12 weeks or longer, despite attempts at treatment. The key symptoms are: 1) Nasal blockage/congestion, 2) Nasal discharge (runny nose or post-nasal drip), 3) Facial pain or pressure, and 4) Reduced sense of smell. You need at least two of these for diagnosis.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have CRS with nasal polyps. What are polyps?
faqs.answer: Nasal polyps are benign (non-cancerous), grape-like inflammatory growths that can form inside the nasal cavity and sinuses in some people with CRS. They physically block the sinuses, worsening congestion and often causing a complete loss of smell. CRS with polyps is often driven by a specific type of inflammation (Type 2 inflammation, involving eosinophils) and is frequently associated with asthma and aspirin sensitivity (Aspirin Exacerbated Respiratory Disease - AERD).

faqs.question: Why do I need a CT scan? Can't the doctor just tell?
faqs.answer: While the symptoms suggest CRS, a CT scan of the sinuses is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis and assessing the extent of the disease. It allows the doctor to: 1) See if the sinuses are truly blocked with thickened lining or fluid. 2) Look for anatomical problems (like a deviated septum) that might be contributing. 3) See if there are polyps. 4) Rule out other rare causes (like tumors).

faqs.question: My doctor keeps telling me to use nasal steroid sprays (like Flonase) and sinus rinses. Do they really work?
faqs.answer: Yes. They are the cornerstone of CRS management. Nasal steroid sprays are powerful anti-inflammatories that directly target the swelling in your nasal lining. They must be used every single day to be effective. Saline sinus rinses (like with a Neti Pot or squeeze bottle) are crucial for washing out thick mucus, allergens, and inflammatory debris, allowing the steroid spray to work better. They are the one-two punch against the inflammation.

faqs.question: When is sinus surgery necessary?
faqs.answer: Surgery (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery - FESS) is reserved for patients who fail maximal medical therapy (daily steroids, rinses, possibly antibiotics). Surgery does not cure the inflammation. Its goal is mechanical: to open up the blocked sinus drainage pathways by removing polyps, bone partitions, and diseased tissue. This allows mucus to drain properly and, just as importantly, allows your medicated rinses and sprays to actually reach the diseased sinus lining.

faqs.question: My routine blood test showed a super high white blood cell count. My doctor mentioned CML and the Philadelphia chromosome. What is that?
faqs.answer: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML) is a type of cancer of the bone marrow. The Philadelphia chromosome is the defining genetic abnormality. It's a translocation—a specific accident where part of chromosome 9 breaks off and fuses with part of chromosome 22. This creates a new, abnormal fusion gene called BCR-ABL. This bad gene produces a protein that acts like a stuck accelerator, telling your bone marrow to produce massive amounts of abnormal white blood cells (granulocytes).

faqs.question: My doctor prescribed a pill called Gleevec (imatinib). How can a pill treat leukemia?
faqs.answer: Gleevec was a revolutionary breakthrough. It's a Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor (TKI). Remember that BCR-ABL protein? It's a tyrosine kinase—an enzyme that signals cells to grow. Gleevec is a smart drug specifically designed to fit into the BCR-ABL protein and block its activity. It turns off the stuck accelerator. This stops the overproduction of leukemia cells and allows your normal bone marrow cells to return. It turned a deadly leukemia into a manageable chronic condition, taken as a daily pill.

faqs.question: What are the phases of CML? My doctor said I'm in the chronic phase.
faqs.answer: CML typically progresses through three phases if untreated: 1) Chronic Phase: This is the early stage where most people are diagnosed (often incidentally). The white count is high, but the cells are still relatively mature. People often feel fine or just have mild fatigue or spleen enlargement. Treatment with TKIs is highly effective here. 2) Accelerated Phase: The leukemia becomes less stable, with more immature cells (blasts) in the blood/marrow, worsening symptoms, and less response to treatment. 3) Blast Crisis: This is the final, deadly phase. The leukemia transforms into an acute leukemia, with >20% blasts. It behaves like AML or ALL and is very difficult to treat.

faqs.question: How do doctors monitor if the Gleevec is working?
faqs.answer: They monitor your molecular response using a very sensitive blood test called PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). This test doesn't just count your white cells; it directly measures the amount of the BCR-ABL fusion gene in your blood. The goal is to achieve a Major Molecular Response (MMR) or even a Complete Molecular Response (CMR), meaning the level of the leukemia gene is extremely low or undetectable. This indicates the TKI is working effectively.

faqs.question: My leukemia developed a T315I mutation and Gleevec stopped working. What now?
faqs.answer: This is a known mechanism of resistance. The T315I mutation is a change in the BCR-ABL protein itself that prevents Gleevec (and some other TKIs like dasatinib and nilotinib) from binding to it. It's like changing the lock so the key doesn't fit. Thankfully, there are newer TKIs specifically designed to overcome this resistance. Ponatinib is one TKI effective against T315I. A stem cell transplant might also be considered.

faqs.question: I feel fine, but my routine blood test showed a high lymphocyte count. My doctor says I have CLL but wants to watch and wait. Why no treatment?
faqs.answer: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is a slow-growing (indolent) cancer of mature B-lymphocytes. For asymptomatic, early-stage CLL (diagnosed by chance on a blood count), watch and wait (or active surveillance) is the worldwide standard of care. Studies have shown that starting treatment before you have symptoms does not make you live longer, but does expose you to the side effects of chemotherapy or targeted drugs. Treatment is saved for when the disease starts causing problems.

faqs.question: What problems (indications) would make my doctor decide to start treatment?
faqs.answer: Treatment is usually started when you develop: 1) Significant B symptoms: Drenching night sweats, fevers, unexplained weight loss. 2) Troublesome lymph node swelling (lymphadenopathy) or spleen enlargement (splenomegaly). 3) Worsening anemia (low red blood cells) or thrombocytopenia (low platelets) because the CLL cells are crowding out your normal bone marrow.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned 17p deletion and TP53 mutation. Why are these bad?
faqs.answer: These are high-risk genetic markers found within the CLL cells. 17p deletion means a piece of chromosome 17, which contains the crucial TP53 tumor suppressor gene, is missing. A TP53 mutation means the gene is there but broken. TP53 is the guardian of the genome. Without it, the CLL cells are much more aggressive, respond poorly to traditional chemotherapy (like FCR), and progress faster. Patients with these markers are usually treated upfront with newer targeted agents.

faqs.question: What are these targeted agents like Ibrutinib or Venetoclax? How are they different from chemo?
faqs.answer: These are revolutionary pills that target specific pathways the CLL cells depend on to survive. Ibrutinib (and similar drugs like Acalabrutinib, Zanubrutinib) is a BTK inhibitor. It blocks a key signaling protein (BTK) that tells the CLL cells to grow and stay alive. Venetoclax is a BCL-2 inhibitor. BCL-2 is a protein that stops cancer cells from dying (apoptosis). Venetoclax blocks BCL-2, essentially telling the CLL cells to commit suicide. These targeted drugs are often more effective and less toxic than traditional chemo, especially for high-risk CLL.

faqs.question: I keep getting infections, even though my white count is high. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a paradox of CLL. Even though your total white blood cell count (specifically lymphocytes) is high, the CLL cells are abnormal and don't function properly as immune cells. Furthermore, they suppress your normal, healthy B-cells, leading to hypogammaglobulinemia (low levels of infection-fighting antibodies). This makes you highly susceptible to bacterial infections, especially pneumonia and sinus infections. Some patients need IVIG (antibody infusions) to prevent infections.

faqs.question: My blood test showed my eGFR is 50. My doctor says I have Stage 3 CKD. What does this mean?
faqs.answer: CKD (Chronic Kidney Disease) means your kidneys have been damaged and aren't filtering your blood as well as they should for 3 months or longer. The eGFR (estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate) is the best measure of your kidney function—it's a percentage of how well your kidneys are working compared to normal (which is >90). CKD is staged 1-5 based on eGFR. Stage 3 (eGFR 30-59) means you have mild to moderate kidney damage. You likely feel fine, but the damage is present.

faqs.question: What caused this? I have high blood pressure and diabetes.
faqs.answer: You've named the two biggest causes of CKD worldwide. Both diabetes (diabetic nephropathy) and high blood pressure (hypertensive nephrosclerosis) damage the tiny, delicate filtering units (glomeruli) in your kidneys over many years. High blood sugar makes the filters leaky and scarred. High blood pressure pounds against the filters, causing damage. Controlling your blood sugar and blood pressure aggressively is the most important thing you can do to slow down the progression of CKD.

faqs.question: Can my kidneys get better? Or is the damage permanent?
faqs.answer: Chronic kidney disease, by definition, implies damage that has been present for months and is generally considered irreversible. Unlike acute kidney injury (which can sometimes recover), the scarring in CKD doesn't heal. The goal of treatment is not to cure it, but to slow down the rate of decline as much as possible, preserving the kidney function you still have for as long as possible, and preventing complications.

faqs.question: My doctor started me on an ACE inhibitor (like Lisinopril) even though my blood pressure isn't that high. Why?
faqs.answer: ACE inhibitors (and related drugs called ARBs) are critically important in CKD, especially if you have diabetes or protein in your urine (proteinuria). They do more than just lower blood pressure. They have a specific kidney-protective effect. They reduce the pressure inside the tiny filtering units (glomeruli), which decreases leakiness (proteinuria) and slows down the scarring process. They are standard care even with normal blood pressure.

faqs.question: What happens if it gets worse? My doctor mentioned dialysis.
faqs.answer: If CKD progresses despite treatment, you eventually reach Stage 5 CKD, also called End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), which is usually an eGFR below 15. At this point, your kidneys have failed, and toxic waste products build up in your blood. You need renal replacement therapy to survive. The options are: 1) Dialysis (either hemodialysis, using a machine to filter your blood 3 times/week, or peritoneal dialysis, using fluid in your belly), or 2) Kidney transplant.

faqs.question: I've had pain down there for over 6 months. My GYN says my exam and ultrasound are normal. What could be causing this?
faqs.answer: Chronic Pelvic Pain (CPP) is defined as non-cyclical pain perceived in the pelvic region, lasting 6 months or longer, and causing functional disability. It's often a diagnosis of exclusion after common gynecologic causes (like endometriosis, fibroids, PID) are ruled out. CPP is frequently multifactorial, involving not just the pelvic organs but also the muscles, nerves, and even psychological factors.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned pelvic floor dysfunction. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is a very common contributor to CPP. Your pelvic floor muscles form a sling or hammock supporting your pelvic organs. In response to chronic pain or inflammation, these muscles can become chronically tight, spasmed, and weak (hypertonicity). This muscle spasm itself becomes a source of pain, often felt as deep aching, pain with intercourse (dyspareunia), or pain with bowel movements. Pelvic floor physical therapy is a key treatment.

faqs.question: Could it be interstitial cystitis (Painful Bladder Syndrome)? I have pain and frequency.
faqs.answer: Yes, Interstitial Cystitis/Painful Bladder Syndrome (IC/PBS) is frequently overlooked. It causes chronic bladder pain, urgency, and frequency, without a urinary tract infection. The pain often feels like pressure or spasms in the bladder area and gets worse as the bladder fills. It's considered a primary bladder disorder but often overlaps significantly with other CPP conditions.

faqs.question: What about nerve pain? Sometimes I get sharp, shooting pains.
faqs.answer: Neuropathic pain is another major component. Chronic inflammation or prior surgeries (like C-sections or hysterectomies) can damage or entrap the small nerves in the pelvis (like the pudendal, ilioinguinal, or genitofemoral nerves). This can cause burning, stabbing, or shooting pains in specific nerve distributions. Treatments often involve nerve pain medications (like gabapentin or amitriptyline) or nerve blocks.

faqs.question: This pain is affecting my mood and relationships. Is that common?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Living with chronic pain, especially in such a sensitive area, takes a huge toll. Depression, anxiety, sleep disturbance, and sexual dysfunction are extremely common and are considered part of the syndrome, not just a reaction to it. The brain's pain pathways are closely linked to mood centers. A multidisciplinary approach involving pain management specialists, physical therapists, and mental health professionals is crucial for treating the whole picture of CPP.

faqs.question: I've been getting itchy hives (wheals) almost every day for 3 months. My doctor says it's chronic. What causes this?
faqs.answer: This is Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria (CSU), previously called Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria. Chronic means lasting >6 weeks. Spontaneous or Idiopathic means there is no identifiable external trigger (like an allergy). For the vast majority of CSU patients, it is not caused by food, detergents, or anything you are doing. It's an autoimmune process—your own immune system is mistakenly activating your mast cells, causing them to release histamine and create hives.

faqs.question: How can it be autoimmune? My autoimmune blood tests were negative.
faqs.answer: It's a specific type of autoimmunity. In about 40-50% of CSU patients, the body makes autoantibodies that directly attack either the IgE receptor or IgE itself on the surface of mast cells. This cross-linking tricks the mast cell into thinking it's seeing an allergen, causing it to degranulate and release histamine. Standard autoimmune tests (like ANA) are usually negative.

faqs.question: Will allergy testing help? Should I avoid certain foods?
faqs.answer: For Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria (CSU), allergy testing is almost never helpful. Remember, CSU is not caused by an external allergic trigger. Extensive food avoidance diets are also generally not recommended and can lead to nutritional deficiencies without helping the hives. The problem is internal.

faqs.question: The antihistamines (like Zyrtec, Allegra) aren't working, even when I take four times the normal dose! What now?
faqs.answer: This is very common. High-dose, second-generation antihistamines are the first-line treatment, but they only control symptoms in about 50% of people. The next step, and the most effective treatment for antihistamine-resistant CSU, is Omalizumab (Xolair). This is a biologic medication (an injection given every 4 weeks) that specifically targets and neutralizes IgE, preventing it from activating the mast cells. It works extremely well for the majority of patients.

faqs.question: Sometimes my lips or eyelids swell up too (angioedema). Is that related?
faqs.answer: Yes. Angioedema (deep tissue swelling) occurs along with hives in about 40% of CSU patients. It's caused by the same mast cell activation, but the histamine release happens in the deeper layers of the skin. While often alarming, angioedema in CSU is histamine-mediated and almost never affects the airway (unlike ACE-inhibitor induced angioedema). It responds to the same treatments as the hives (antihistamines, Xolair).

faqs.question: My son keeps getting severe infections—pneumonia, skin abscesses, infected lymph nodes. The doctor mentioned CGD. What is it?
faqs.answer: Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a rare, inherited primary immunodeficiency. It affects a specific type of white blood cell called phagocytes (neutrophils and macrophages). These cells are supposed to eat and kill bacteria and fungi. In CGD, there's a genetic defect in an enzyme complex called NADPH oxidase. This enzyme is crucial for producing bleach-like reactive oxygen species (like superoxide) that the phagocytes use to kill the germs they eat. Without this killing power, the germs survive inside the cells.

faqs.question: Why does he get granulomas? Isn't that like TB?
faqs.answer: The granulomas are a direct result of the immune defect. Because the phagocytes can eat the germs but can't kill them, the immune system tries to wall off the infected cells by forming granulomas—collections of immune cells packed tightly together. These granulomas can become large and act like tumors, obstructing organs like the bowel or urinary tract. It's inflammation gone wrong, not necessarily an active infection like TB (though TB can also form granulomas).

faqs.question: What kinds of infections are most common?
faqs.answer: People with CGD are susceptible to specific types of bacteria and fungi—those that are catalase-positive. These germs produce an enzyme (catalase) that breaks down the small amount of hydrogen peroxide the faulty cells can make, protecting themselves. Classic CGD culprits include: Staphylococcus aureus (skin/bone infections), Aspergillus (fungal pneumonia/abscesses), Serratia, Burkholderia, and Nocardia.

faqs.question: How is this diagnosed? My son's white count is normal.
faqs.answer: The white blood cell count is normal, but their function is broken. The gold standard diagnostic test is the Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test (or the older NBT test). This is a flow cytometry test that directly measures whether the patient's neutrophils can produce that bleach (reactive oxygen species) when stimulated. In CGD, the cells fail to light up in the test.

faqs.question: How is CGD treated? Is it curable?
faqs.answer: Treatment involves lifelong prophylaxis (prevention): 1) Daily antibiotics (usually Bactrim/TMP-SMX) to prevent bacterial infections. 2) Daily antifungals (usually itraconazole) to prevent Aspergillus infections. 3) Gamma-interferon injections: This drug helps boost the killing power of the phagocytes. Despite prophylaxis, severe infections still occur and require aggressive treatment. The only curative option is a hematopoietic stem cell transplant (bone marrow transplant), which replaces the faulty immune system with a healthy one.

faqs.question: I've had a dry, hacking cough for 3 months. My chest X-ray is normal. What could be causing this?
faqs.answer: Chronic cough is defined as a cough lasting 8 weeks or longer. In adults who don't smoke and have a normal chest X-ray, the vast majority (>90%) of cases are caused by one (or a combination) of the Big Three: 1) Upper Airway Cough Syndrome (UACS), previously known as post-nasal drip. 2) Asthma (specifically cough-variant asthma). 3) Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD).

faqs.question: What is Upper Airway Cough Syndrome? I don't feel like I have post-nasal drip.
faqs.answer: UACS is the most common cause. It's irritation in the back of your throat triggering the cough reflex. It can be caused by obvious post-nasal drip (from allergies or sinusitis), but sometimes it's silent—you don't feel the drip, but the inflammation or sensitivity is still there. Treatment involves nasal steroid sprays and sometimes antihistamines to treat the underlying sinus/nasal inflammation.

faqs.question: Could it be asthma if I don't wheeze?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is called cough-variant asthma. The only symptom is a chronic, dry cough. The underlying mechanism is the same as regular asthma (airway inflammation and hyperresponsiveness), but instead of wheezing, the main reflex is coughing. It often gets worse at night, with exercise, or exposure to cold air or irritants. Diagnosis is confirmed if the cough gets better with asthma inhalers (like albuterol or inhaled steroids).

faqs.question: How can acid reflux (GERD) cause a cough? The acid isn't going into my lungs.
faqs.answer: There are two main theories: 1) Microaspiration: Tiny, microscopic droplets of stomach acid do reflux high enough to get into your airway, directly irritating your larynx and triggering a cough. 2) Reflex Arc: Acid irritating the lower esophagus triggers a nerve reflex (via the vagus nerve) that causes the cough center in your brain to fire, even without anything touching the airway. Treating the GERD aggressively (with PPIs like omeprazole, often at high doses for months) is the only way to see if this is the cause.

faqs.question: I take an ACE inhibitor (like Lisinopril) for blood pressure. Could that be the cause?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. ACE inhibitors are notorious for causing a chronic, dry, annoying cough in about 10-15% of people who take them. It's caused by a buildup of a substance called bradykinin. The cough can start weeks or even months after starting the drug. The only treatment is to stop the ACE inhibitor and switch to a different class of blood pressure medication (like an ARB). The cough should resolve within 1-4 weeks of stopping.

faqs.question: I have a headache literally every single day, or at least most days. What is going on?
faqs.answer: Chronic Daily Headache (CDH) isn't a specific diagnosis itself, but an umbrella term. It's defined as having a headache on 15 or more days per month for at least 3 months. The most common underlying cause of CDH is Chronic Migraine. Other causes include Chronic Tension-Type Headache, Hemicrania Continua, and Medication Overuse Headache.

faqs.question: How do I know if it's Chronic Migraine?
