Major culprits include: Antihistamines, Decongestants, Antidepressants (especially tricyclics), Blood pressure medications (diuretics, beta-blockers), Pain medications (opioids), Muscle relaxants, and Anticholinergic drugs used for overactive bladder or Parkinson's.

faqs.question: I have Sjogren's syndrome. Is the dry mouth related?
faqs.answer: Yes, Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks the body's moisture-producing glands, primarily the salivary glands (causing severe dry mouth) and the lacrimal glands (causing severe dry eyes). Dry mouth is a hallmark symptom.

faqs.question: I had radiation therapy for head and neck cancer. Why is my mouth so dry now?
faqs.answer: Radiation therapy to the head and neck area can directly damage the salivary glands within the radiation field. This damage is often permanent and severe, leading to chronic, profound xerostomia that significantly impacts quality of life.

faqs.question: What can I do to relieve the dryness? Sipping water only helps for a minute.
faqs.answer: Management involves symptomatic relief and prevention of complications: 1) Sip water frequently throughout the day. 2) Chew sugar-free gum or suck on sugar-free hard candies (especially those with xylitol) to stimulate saliva flow. 3) Use saliva substitutes: Over-the-counter sprays, gels, or rinses provide temporary lubrication. 4) Avoid caffeine, alcohol, and tobacco, which worsen dryness. 5) Use humidifiers at night. 6) Practice meticulous oral hygiene (fluoride toothpaste/rinses) to prevent cavities. 7) Prescription saliva stimulants (pilocarpine, cevimeline) may help if some gland function remains.

faqs.question: My central vision seems blurry, and straight lines (like door frames) look wavy. My eye doctor said dry AMD. What is that?
faqs.answer: Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of vision loss in older adults. It affects the macula, the small central part of your retina responsible for sharp, detailed, straight-ahead vision. Dry AMD is the most common form (80-90%). It involves the gradual breakdown of light-sensitive cells in the macula and the accumulation of tiny yellow deposits called drusen underneath the retina. This causes slowly progressive blurring or distortion of central vision.

faqs.question: What are drusen? Are they dangerous?
faqs.answer: Drusen are small deposits of lipids (fats) and proteins that build up between the retina and the layer beneath it (the choroid). Small, hard drusen are common with aging and carry low risk. Large, soft, confluent drusen are characteristic of AMD and indicate a higher risk of disease progression (either worsening dry AMD or conversion to wet AMD).

faqs.question: How is dry AMD different from wet AMD?
faqs.answer: Dry AMD involves slow atrophy (thinning) and drusen buildup. Wet AMD (Neovascular AMD) is less common (~10-15%) but more severe and rapid. It occurs when abnormal, leaky blood vessels start to grow underneath the retina (choroidal neovascularization - CNV). These vessels leak fluid and blood, causing sudden, significant distortion and scarring of the macula, leading to rapid central vision loss. Dry AMD can convert to Wet AMD at any time.

faqs.question: Is there any treatment for Dry AMD?
faqs.answer: Currently, there is no cure for dry AMD and no treatment to reverse the atrophy. However, for people with intermediate dry AMD (many medium-sized or one large drusen), taking a specific high-dose formulation of antioxidant vitamins and minerals (AREDS2 formula) has been proven to significantly slow down the progression to advanced AMD (both late dry and wet forms). These supplements do not prevent early AMD or help those who already have advanced AMD.

faqs.question: How can I monitor my vision at home? My doctor gave me an Amsler grid.
faqs.answer: The Amsler grid is a crucial tool for home monitoring, especially for detecting the conversion from dry to wet AMD. It's a grid of straight lines with a central dot. You cover one eye, look at the dot, and check if any lines appear wavy, distorted, broken, or missing. Any new change on the Amsler grid could signify the start of wet AMD and requires an urgent eye exam.

faqs.question: My eyes feel gritty, sandy, and burn, especially by the end of the day or when I use the computer. What causes this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of Dry Eye Disease (DED). It's extremely common. Your eyes need a stable layer of tears (the tear film) to stay lubricated and clear. Dry eye occurs either because you don't produce enough tears (aqueous deficiency - less common) or, more often, because your tears evaporate too quickly (evaporative dry eye). Activities like computer use reduce your blink rate, worsening evaporation.

faqs.question: My eye doctor said I have MGD. What is that and how does it cause dry eye?
faqs.answer: Meibomian Gland Dysfunction (MGD) is the leading cause of evaporative dry eye. You have tiny oil glands (meibomian glands) lining your upper and lower eyelids. These glands secrete the crucial oily top layer of your tear film, which prevents the watery layer from evaporating. In MGD, these glands get clogged with thick, waxy oil (like blepharitis). Without that oil layer, your tears evaporate rapidly, leaving your eyes dry and gritty.

faqs.question: Artificial tears only help for a few minutes. What else can I do?
faqs.answer: If you have MGD (which is likely), simply adding watery tears isn't enough. Treatment focuses on improving oil gland function: 1) Warm compresses: Applying a warm mask/cloth to closed eyelids for 5-10 minutes melts the clogged oil. 2) Lid massage/scrubs: Gently massaging the lids helps express the melted oil. Lid scrubs remove debris. 3) Lipid-based artificial tears: These contain oil droplets (e.g., Systane Complete, Refresh Optive Mega-3) to supplement the missing oil layer. 4) Prescription drops: Drugs like Restasis/Cequa (cyclosporine) or Xiidra (lifitegrast) reduce the underlying inflammation.

faqs.question: Could my Sjogren's syndrome be causing my severe dry eyes?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease that attacks moisture-producing glands. It's a major cause of aqueous deficient dry eye (not making enough watery tears) because it damages the lacrimal glands (which produce the watery part of tears). Patients with Sjogren's often have severe dry eye and dry mouth.

faqs.question: What are punctal plugs?
faqs.answer: Punctal plugs are tiny, biocompatible plugs inserted into the puncta—the small openings at the inner corners of your eyelids where tears normally drain away into your nose. By partially blocking this drainage, the plugs keep your natural tears (and any artificial tears you add) on the eye surface for longer, providing relief for aqueous deficient dry eye. They are easily inserted in the doctor's office.

faqs.question: I took penicillin, and an hour later I broke out in itchy hives all over. Is this an allergy?
faqs.answer: Yes, hives (urticaria) appearing shortly after taking a new medication are a classic sign of an IgE-mediated drug allergy. Your immune system has mistakenly identified the drug (or its breakdown product) as a threat and produced IgE antibodies against it. When you took the drug again, these antibodies triggered mast cells to release histamine, causing the hives. Penicillins and related antibiotics are the most common culprits.

faqs.question: How is a drug allergy different from a side effect like nausea?
faqs.answer: A side effect is a known, predictable, non-immunological reaction to a drug's normal action (e.g., nausea from chemotherapy, drowsiness from antihistamines). An allergy is an unpredictable immune system response that is specific to that individual. Allergic reactions involve immune cells and antibodies (like IgE) and can range from mild rashes to life-threatening anaphylaxis, often occurring even with tiny doses.

faqs.question: I had hives from penicillin as a kid. Does that mean I'm allergic to cephalosporins (like Keflex) too?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily, especially if the original reaction was mild. While penicillins and cephalosporins are chemically related (beta-lactams), the risk of cross-reactivity is much lower than previously thought (probably less than 1-2%). Many people labeled penicillin allergic based on childhood history aren't truly allergic. Allergy testing (skin testing) can clarify your true status. Never assume cross-reactivity without testing or specialist advice.

faqs.question: What is Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS)? My doctor warned me about a rash with my new seizure medicine.
faqs.answer: SJS (and its more severe form, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis - TEN) is a rare but life-threatening severe cutaneous adverse reaction (SCAR). It's not an IgE-mediated allergy. It's a delayed, T-cell mediated reaction that causes widespread blistering and sloughing of the skin and mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, genitals), resembling a severe burn. Certain drugs (like allopurinol, sulfa antibiotics, certain anticonvulsants - lamotrigine, carbamazepine) carry a higher risk. Any widespread blistering rash starting 1-3 weeks after a new drug needs immediate ER evaluation.

faqs.question: How do allergists test for drug allergies?
faqs.answer: For immediate (IgE-mediated) allergies like penicillin allergy, the gold standard is skin testing. Tiny amounts of the drug are pricked onto the skin, then injected just under the skin (intradermal). A positive reaction (a hive) indicates allergy. If skin testing is negative, a graded drug challenge may be done under supervision, where you take small, increasing doses of the drug to confirm you can tolerate it safely. There are fewer validated tests for delayed reactions like SJS.

faqs.question: I can't seem to stop using opioids, even though it's ruining my life. Why does my brain keep craving them?
faqs.answer: Addiction (Substance Use Disorder - SUD) is a chronic, relapsing brain disease. Drugs like opioids hijack the brain's natural reward pathway (primarily involving dopamine). They cause a massive surge of dopamine, creating intense pleasure and reinforcing the drug-taking behavior. Over time, this fundamentally changes brain circuits involved in reward, stress, self-control, and judgment. The brain adapts to the drug's presence (tolerance, dependence), leading to intense cravings and withdrawal symptoms when the drug is stopped, making it incredibly difficult to quit despite negative consequences.

faqs.question: Is addiction a matter of willpower? Why can't I just stop?
faqs.answer: No, it's not a failure of willpower or morality. The drug-induced changes in brain structure and function impair executive functions like impulse control and decision-making. The compulsive drive to seek and use the drug overrides rational thought and the ability to just stop. It requires treatment, similar to other chronic diseases like diabetes or heart disease.

faqs.question: What's the difference between dependence and addiction?
faqs.answer: Physical dependence means your body has adapted to the drug, and you will experience withdrawal symptoms if you stop abruptly (e.g., tremors from alcohol withdrawal, flu-like symptoms from opioid withdrawal). You can be dependent on a medication (like a painkiller taken as prescribed) without being addicted. Addiction (SUD) involves dependence plus compulsive drug seeking and use despite harmful consequences, loss of control, and preoccupation with the drug.

faqs.question: What are Medications for Addiction Treatment (MAT) like Suboxone or Methadone?
faqs.answer: MAT is the gold standard for treating Opioid Use Disorder (OUD). Methadone and Buprenorphine (Suboxone) are opioid agonists or partial agonists. They bind to the same opioid receptors in the brain, preventing withdrawal symptoms and reducing cravings, but without producing the same intense high (especially buprenorphine). Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist; it blocks the effects of opioids. MAT helps stabilize brain chemistry, allowing individuals to engage in counseling and rebuild their lives.

faqs.question: Does treatment work? Relapse seems so common.
faqs.answer: Yes, treatment works, but relapse is common, just like with other chronic diseases. SUD requires long-term management, not just a short detox. Effective treatment combines MAT (for opioid or alcohol use disorder), behavioral therapies (CBT, contingency management), counseling, and peer support (like NA or AA). Relapse is seen as part of the recovery process, not a failure, requiring treatment adjustment rather than termination.

faqs.question: I had a heart attack 3 weeks ago, and now I have sharp chest pain that's worse when I lie down or breathe deep. I also have a fever. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds very much like Dressler syndrome, also known as post-myocardial infarction syndrome or post-cardiac injury syndrome. It's a type of pericarditis (inflammation of the sac surrounding the heart) that occurs weeks to months after damage to the heart muscle or pericardium, most commonly a heart attack, but also after heart surgery or trauma.

faqs.question: What causes it? Is it another heart attack?
faqs.answer: No, it's not another heart attack. It's believed to be an autoimmune inflammatory response. The initial damage (heart attack, surgery) releases heart muscle antigens into the bloodstream. Weeks later, the immune system mistakenly forms antibodies against these antigens, which then attack the pericardium (and sometimes the pleura, the lining of the lungs), causing inflammation.

faqs.question: Why does the pain get better when I sit up and lean forward?
faqs.answer: This is the classic posture that relieves the pain of pericarditis. When you lie back, the inflamed pericardial sac rubs against the heart more. Sitting up and leaning forward pulls the heart slightly away from the back of the pericardial sac, reducing the friction and pain.

faqs.question: How is Dressler syndrome diagnosed?
faqs.answer: Diagnosis is based on the clinical picture (recent cardiac injury + characteristic chest pain) plus supporting findings: 1) Pericardial friction rub: A scratchy sound heard with a stethoscope. 2) EKG changes: Widespread ST segment elevation or PR depression (different from heart attack changes). 3) Echocardiogram: May show inflammation or fluid around the heart (pericardial effusion). 4) Elevated inflammatory markers in blood tests (CRP, ESR).

faqs.question: How is it treated?
faqs.answer: Treatment focuses on reducing inflammation: 1) High-dose NSAIDs (like ibuprofen or indomethacin) are the first-line treatment. 2) Colchicine is often added to NSAIDs to help resolve the inflammation faster and prevent recurrence. 3) Corticosteroids (prednisone) are reserved for severe cases or if NSAIDs/colchicine fail, as steroids might potentially impair healing of the original heart attack scar.

faqs.question: My prenatal screening test came back high-risk for Down syndrome. What exactly is it?
faqs.answer: Down syndrome (also known as Trisomy 21) is the most common chromosomal condition. Normally, a person has two copies of each chromosome. People with Down syndrome have three copies of chromosome 21 instead of two. This extra genetic material alters the course of development and causes the physical characteristics and intellectual disabilities associated with the syndrome.

faqs.question: How does this happen? Is it inherited?
faqs.answer: Usually, no, it's not directly inherited. About 95% of cases are Trisomy 21, caused by a random error in cell division called nondisjunction during the formation of the egg or sperm, resulting in a reproductive cell with an extra copy of chromosome 21. Less common types include Translocation Down syndrome (where the extra chromosome 21 material is attached to another chromosome - this can be inherited) and Mosaic Down syndrome (where only some cells have the extra chromosome).

faqs.question: What are the common physical features?
faqs.answer: While individuals vary greatly, common features include: Flattened facial profile, especially the bridge of the nose; Upslanting eyes; Small ears; A single deep crease across the palm (simian crease); Short neck; Poor muscle tone (hypotonia) in infancy; Often short stature.

faqs.question: What health problems are associated with Down syndrome?
faqs.answer: People with Down syndrome have an increased risk for certain medical conditions, including: Congenital heart defects (very common, ~50%), Hearing and vision problems, Thyroid disease (hypothyroidism), Gastrointestinal issues (like celiac disease, duodenal atresia), Increased susceptibility to infections, Obstructive sleep apnea, Higher risk of leukemia (especially in childhood), and Earlier onset of Alzheimer's disease.

faqs.question: What is the life expectancy and quality of life?
faqs.answer: Life expectancy has dramatically increased, now averaging around 60 years due to better medical care (especially heart defect repairs). With early intervention services (physical, occupational, speech therapy), inclusive education, and supportive environments, individuals with Down syndrome can lead fulfilling lives, achieve milestones, hold jobs, and participate actively in their communities. Intellectual disability ranges from mild to moderate, but capabilities vary widely.

faqs.question: My baby was diagnosed with DORV. What does double outlet mean?
faqs.answer: Double-Outlet Right Ventricle (DORV) is a complex congenital heart defect where both of the heart's great arteries—the aorta (to the body) and the pulmonary artery (to the lungs)—arise primarily or completely from the right ventricle (the bottom right chamber). Normally, the aorta arises from the left ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the right.

faqs.question: If both arteries come from the right side, how does oxygenated blood get to the body?
faqs.answer: That's the key problem. For survival, there must be another defect present: a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)—a hole between the right and left ventricles. Oxygenated blood returning from the lungs to the left ventricle can only get out to the body by crossing through this VSD into the right ventricle and then going up the aorta.

faqs.question: My doctor keeps talking about the location of the VSD. Why does that matter so much?
faqs.answer: The location of the VSD relative to the great arteries is the most critical factor in determining the type of DORV, the baby's symptoms (blue or pink), and the surgical repair strategy. Common VSD locations include: Subaortic (under the aorta - often behaves like Tetralogy of Fallot), Subpulmonary (under the pulmonary artery - often behaves like Transposition/Taussig-Bing), Doubly Committed (under both), or Remote (far from both).

faqs.question: Are there often other heart defects too?
faqs.answer: Yes, DORV frequently occurs with other defects, such as pulmonary stenosis (narrowing of the pulmonary artery/valve), coarctation of the aorta, or mitral valve abnormalities. These associated defects significantly influence the physiology and surgical plan.

faqs.question: How is DORV repaired? Is it open-heart surgery?
faqs.answer: Yes, repair requires open-heart surgery, usually within the first few months of life. The surgical goal depends on the specific anatomy, but it typically involves: 1) Closing the VSD in a specific way using a patch to baffle (direct) the oxygenated blood from the left ventricle through the VSD and out the aorta. 2) Addressing any associated lesions (like relieving pulmonary stenosis or repairing coarctation). Sometimes, more complex repairs like an arterial switch operation (similar to transposition repair) are needed, especially for Taussig-Bing type DORV.

faqs.question: My doctor said my ultrasound shows a double uterus (uterus didelphys). How is this possible?
faqs.answer: Uterus didelphys is a rare congenital anomaly. During fetal development, the uterus normally forms from two small tubes (Müllerian ducts) fusing together into one organ. In uterus didelphys, these tubes fail to fuse completely, resulting in two separate uterine horns, often each with its own cervix, and sometimes even a septum (wall) dividing the vagina into two canals.

faqs.question: I never knew I had this! Does it cause symptoms?
faqs.answer: Often, no. Many women with uterus didelphys have no symptoms and are unaware of the condition until they become pregnant or have imaging for another reason. Potential symptoms can include unusually heavy or painful periods (dysmenorrhea) or pain during intercourse (dyspareunia), especially if there's also a vaginal septum.

faqs.question: Can I still get pregnant and have a baby?
faqs.answer: Yes, women with uterus didelphys can get pregnant and often carry pregnancies successfully. However, they are considered high-risk pregnancies due to an increased chance of: Miscarriage, Preterm labor and delivery, Breech presentation (requiring C-section), and Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). This is because each uterine horn is smaller than a normal uterus and may have altered blood flow.

faqs.question: Do I need surgery to fix it?
faqs.answer: Surgery (metroplasty) to unify the two uterine horns is rarely performed and generally not recommended. It's a complex surgery with significant risks (scarring, bleeding) and doesn't clearly improve pregnancy outcomes. Management focuses on close monitoring during pregnancy by a high-risk obstetrician.

faqs.question: Are there other types of Müllerian duct anomalies?
faqs.answer: Yes, uterus didelphys is just one type. Other common anomalies resulting from incomplete fusion include: Bicornuate uterus (heart-shaped uterus with a deep indentation at the top), Septate uterus (a normal-shaped uterus on the outside but with a wall/septum dividing the inside - associated with highest risk of miscarriage), and Unicornuate uterus (only one side/tube developed).

faqs.question: I keep feeling dizzy, but the room isn't spinning. It's more like I feel lightheaded or might faint. What could cause this?
faqs.answer: This type of dizziness is called presyncope (pre-fainting) or lightheadedness. It's usually caused by a temporary decrease in blood flow or oxygen to the brain. Common causes include: Orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure dropping when you stand up), Dehydration, Anemia, Low blood sugar, Anxiety/Panic attacks (hyperventilation), Heart rhythm problems (arrhythmias), or Medication side effects.

faqs.question: When I stand up quickly, I feel like I'm going to pass out for a few seconds.
faqs.answer: This is likely orthostatic hypotension. When you stand up, gravity pulls blood down into your legs. Your body normally compensates instantly by constricting blood vessels and increasing heart rate to maintain blood pressure to the brain. If this reflex is slow or inadequate (common with dehydration, certain medications, or autonomic nervous system problems), your blood pressure drops briefly, causing that lightheaded, head rush feeling.

faqs.question: Sometimes the room suddenly starts spinning violently for about 30 seconds when I roll over in bed.
faqs.answer: This is vertigo, the illusion of movement. This specific pattern—brief, intense spinning triggered by head position changes—is the classic symptom of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). It's caused by tiny crystals becoming dislodged in your inner ear. It's harmless and treatable with specific head maneuvers (like the Epley maneuver).

faqs.question: I had a bad cold, and now I have constant vertigo (spinning) that's lasted for days, plus nausea.
faqs.answer: This sounds like vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis. It's caused by a viral infection inflaming the vestibular nerve (which sends balance signals from the inner ear to the brain) or the inner ear itself (labyrinthitis, which also causes hearing loss). This causes continuous, severe vertigo that lasts for days to weeks and gradually improves as the inflammation resolves. Medications for nausea and vestibular suppressant drugs (like meclizine) are used initially, followed by vestibular rehabilitation therapy.

faqs.question: When is dizziness an emergency? What are the red flags?
faqs.answer: Dizziness is usually benign, but seek immediate medical attention if it's accompanied by any central neurological signs suggesting a stroke or brain problem: Sudden severe headache (thunderclap), Double vision, Slurred speech, Facial droop, One-sided weakness or numbness, Difficulty walking (ataxia), or Loss of consciousness. Dizziness plus these signs is an emergency.

faqs.question: I have sudden, severe pain in my lower left belly, plus fever and chills. My doctor thinks it's diverticulitis. What are diverticula?
faqs.answer: Diverticula are small, bulging pouches that can form in the lining of your digestive system, most commonly in the colon (large intestine). They are like tiny blowouts or herniations through weak spots in the colon wall, often related to increased pressure (like from chronic constipation). Having these pouches is called diverticulosis, which is very common and usually causes no symptoms.

faqs.question: So what is diverticulitis?
faqs.answer: Diverticulitis occurs when one or more of these pouches becomes inflamed or infected. It's thought to happen when a tiny piece of stool (fecalith) gets trapped in a pouch, obstructing it and allowing bacteria to overgrow, or when the thin wall of the pouch erodes. This causes the characteristic left lower quadrant abdominal pain (where the sigmoid colon is most affected), fever, nausea, and changes in bowel habits.

faqs.question: Do I have to avoid nuts and seeds? I heard they get stuck in the pouches.
faqs.answer: This is an old myth that has been disproven. Eating nuts, seeds, corn, or popcorn does not increase the risk of developing diverticulitis. In fact, a high-fiber diet, which often includes these foods, is actually recommended to help prevent diverticulosis and potentially diverticulitis by keeping stool soft and reducing pressure in the colon.

faqs.question: How is diverticulitis treated? Do I need surgery?
faqs.answer: Treatment depends on severity. Uncomplicated diverticulitis (mild symptoms, no signs of perforation) is often treated outpatient with clear liquids initially, followed by oral antibiotics (though antibiotics aren't always needed for very mild cases). Complicated diverticulitis (severe pain, high fever, signs of an abscess or perforation on CT scan) requires hospitalization, IV antibiotics, bowel rest (NPO), and sometimes percutaneous drainage of an abscess or emergency surgery if there's a perforation (hole) or widespread infection (peritonitis).

faqs.question: I keep getting attacks of diverticulitis. When is elective surgery recommended?
faqs.answer: Elective surgery (a sigmoid colectomy, removing the affected part of the colon) is considered for patients with recurrent episodes of uncomplicated diverticulitis that significantly impact quality of life, or after recovery from a single episode of complicated diverticulitis (like a contained perforation or abscess) to prevent future, potentially more dangerous episodes.

faqs.question: Sometimes I feel disconnected from my body or like I'm watching myself in a movie. Things don't feel real. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds like Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder. It's a type of dissociative disorder. Depersonalization is the feeling of being detached from oneself (thoughts, feelings, body), like an outside observer. Derealization is the feeling that one's surroundings are unreal, dreamlike, foggy, or distorted. These episodes can be brief or persistent and are often triggered by severe stress or trauma, but can occur spontaneously.

faqs.question: I have big gaps in my memory, especially about traumatic events from my childhood. Is this dissociative amnesia?
faqs.answer: Dissociative Amnesia involves an inability to recall important personal information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature, that is too extensive to be explained by ordinary forgetfulness. It's not due to a head injury or medical condition. The memory loss is often localized (forgetting a specific event) or selective (forgetting only parts of an event). In rare cases, it involves dissociative fugue, where a person travels away from home and forgets their identity.

faqs.question: What is Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID)? Is it the same as multiple personalities?
faqs.answer: Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID), previously known as Multiple Personality Disorder, is the most complex dissociative disorder. It's characterized by the presence of two or more distinct personality states (or alters) that recurrently take control of the individual's behavior, accompanied by extensive memory gaps for everyday events, personal information, or traumatic experiences. DID is almost always associated with severe, chronic childhood trauma (often abuse).

faqs.question: What causes dissociative disorders? Why do people dissociate?
faqs.answer: Dissociation is generally understood as a defense mechanism or coping strategy in response to overwhelming trauma or stress. When faced with an unbearable situation (especially in childhood when the brain is still developing), the mind disconnects or detaches from the experience to survive it emotionally. This can involve detaching from one's body (depersonalization), surroundings (derealization), memory (amnesia), or even identity (DID). It becomes a disorder when this pattern persists and causes distress or impairment long after the trauma is over.

faqs.question: How are dissociative disorders treated?
faqs.answer: Treatment typically involves long-term psychotherapy, often specialized forms focused on trauma. Goals include: 1) Stabilization: Managing symptoms and ensuring safety. 2) Processing Trauma: Working through traumatic memories in a safe, contained way (techniques like EMDR are sometimes used). 3) Integration: For DID, the goal is not necessarily to eliminate alters, but to foster communication and cooperation between them, working towards a more unified sense of self. Medications may be used to treat co-occurring conditions like depression or anxiety, but they don't treat the dissociation itself.

faqs.question: My shoulder popped out of place during a fall. It looks deformed and hurts terribly. What should I do?
faqs.answer: You likely have an anterior shoulder dislocation (the most common type, where the ball - humeral head - pops out the front of the socket - glenoid). This is an emergency requiring prompt reduction (putting it back in place). Do NOT try to pop it back in yourself. Keep your arm still (often supported by your other arm), apply ice if possible, and get to an Emergency Room immediately. Delaying reduction increases muscle spasm, making it harder to put back, and risks nerve or blood vessel damage.

faqs.question: How do they put it back in the ER?
faqs.answer: The procedure is called a closed reduction. You'll be given pain medication and often sedation (conscious sedation) to relax your muscles. The doctor will then use specific maneuvers involving gentle traction and rotation of your arm to guide the humeral head back into the socket. They will confirm it's back in place with an X-ray and then immobilize your arm in a sling.

faqs.question: The doctor said I might have a Bankart lesion or a Hill-Sachs lesion. What are those?
faqs.answer: These are common injuries that occur during the dislocation: A Bankart lesion is a tear of the labrum (the cartilage rim around the socket) at the front of the shoulder. This happens as the ball pops out, ripping the labrum off the bone. A Hill-Sachs lesion is a dent or compression fracture on the back of the humeral head (ball). This happens as the soft ball crashes against the hard front edge of the socket during the dislocation.

faqs.question: Why is my shoulder likely to dislocate again?
faqs.answer: The main reason is the damage done during the first dislocation, especially the Bankart tear. The labrum acts like a bumper helping to keep the ball in the socket. Once it's torn, the shoulder loses this crucial stabilizer, making it much easier for the ball to pop out again, especially in young, active individuals. The risk of recurrent instability after a first-time traumatic dislocation in someone under 25 is very high (>50-80%).

faqs.question: When is surgery needed?
faqs.answer: Surgery (Bankart repair) is often recommended, especially for young athletes after a first-time traumatic dislocation, to repair the torn labrum and tighten the stretched ligaments, significantly reducing the risk of recurrence. Surgery is also needed for recurrent instability (multiple dislocations) or if there are associated injuries like large bone fractures.

faqs.question: I heard about a diphtheria outbreak. What are the symptoms? Is it just a sore throat?
faqs.answer: Diphtheria is a serious bacterial infection (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) that primarily affects the throat and upper airways. It starts with a sore throat, fever, and swollen neck glands (bull neck). The defining feature is the formation of a thick, gray, adherent pseudomembrane covering the tonsils, pharynx, and sometimes larynx. This membrane can obstruct the airway, causing suffocation. It's much more than just a sore throat.

faqs.question: What causes the pseudomembrane?
faqs.answer: The C. diphtheriae bacteria produce a powerful exotoxin (diphtheria toxin). This toxin kills the surface cells of the throat lining. The dead cells, along with bacteria, fibrin, and white blood cells, form that thick, leathery gray membrane. Trying to scrape it off causes bleeding.

faqs.question: Is the airway blockage the only danger?
faqs.answer: No. The diphtheria toxin is absorbed into the bloodstream and can travel throughout the body, causing severe damage to other organs, typically 1-2 weeks after the throat symptoms start. The most serious complications are: Myocarditis (inflammation/damage to the heart muscle, leading to heart failure or arrhythmias) and Neuropathy (nerve damage, often causing paralysis of the palate, eye muscles, or even limbs and diaphragm).

faqs.question: How is diphtheria treated? Do antibiotics work?
faqs.answer: Treatment requires two things immediately: 1) Diphtheria Antitoxin: This is the most critical treatment. It's given IV and contains antibodies that neutralize the circulating toxin, preventing further organ damage. It must be given early. 2) Antibiotics (like penicillin or erythromycin): These kill the bacteria to stop further toxin production and prevent spread, but they do not neutralize the toxin that's already been released. Patients also need close monitoring for airway obstruction and heart complications.

faqs.question: How can I prevent this? I thought we were all vaccinated.
faqs.answer: Vaccination is highly effective. The DTaP/Tdap/Td vaccines contain diphtheria toxoid, which teaches your immune system to make antibodies against the toxin, not the bacteria. Protection wanes over time, which is why booster shots (Tdap or Td) are crucial every 10 years throughout adulthood. Outbreaks occur in populations with low vaccination rates or waning immunity.

faqs.question: My echo showed my heart is weak and enlarged. The doctor said I have dilated cardiomyopathy. What caused this?
faqs.answer: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common type of cardiomyopathy (heart muscle disease). It means the heart's main pumping chamber (the left ventricle) has become enlarged (dilated), thin-walled, and weakened (systolic dysfunction), so it can't pump blood effectively (low ejection fraction). Causes are numerous and often hard to pinpoint: Idiopathic (unknown) is common (~50%). Other causes include: Viral infections (viral myocarditis aftermath), Alcohol abuse (toxic effect), Genetic/familial causes (mutations in heart muscle proteins), Chemotherapy drugs, Pregnancy-related (peripartum), Severe uncontrolled high blood pressure, or advanced Coronary artery disease (ischemic cardiomyopathy).

faqs.question: What are the symptoms? I've been feeling short of breath and tired.
faqs.answer: The symptoms are those of congestive heart failure (CHF), caused by the weak pump: Shortness of breath (dyspnea), especially with exertion or when lying flat (orthopnea); Fatigue and weakness; Swelling (edema) in the legs, ankles, and feet; Rapid or irregular heartbeat (palpitations); Sometimes chest pain or dizziness.

faqs.question: What does ejection fraction (EF) mean? Mine is 30%.
faqs.answer: Ejection Fraction (EF) is the percentage of blood that the left ventricle pumps out with each heartbeat. A normal EF is around 55-70%. An EF of 30% indicates moderate to severely reduced systolic function—your heart is only pumping out 30% of the blood available in its main chamber with each beat. This is a key measure of the severity of DCM and heart failure.

faqs.question: How is DCM treated? My doctor started me on several heart pills.
faqs.answer: Treatment focuses on managing heart failure symptoms, improving heart function, and preventing complications. The cornerstone is Guideline-Directed Medical Therapy (GDMT) for heart failure with reduced EF. This includes a combination of several life-prolonging drug classes: 1) ACE inhibitors/ARBs/ARNIs (like Entresto), 2) Beta-blockers (like metoprolol succinate, carvedilol), 3) Aldosterone antagonists (spironolactone/eplerenone), and 4) SGLT2 inhibitors (like Farxiga/Jardiance). Diuretics (water pills) are used for symptom relief (swelling).

faqs.question: What about pacemakers or defibrillators? Do I need one?
faqs.answer: Maybe. An Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD) is often recommended if your EF remains ≤35% despite optimal medical therapy. A weak, enlarged heart is prone to dangerous ventricular arrhythmias; the ICD acts as a safety net to shock the heart back to normal rhythm if needed. Some patients with specific EKG patterns (like LBBB) may also benefit from a special pacemaker called Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT) to improve pumping efficiency.

faqs.question: My baby was born with a heart defect and has unusual facial features. Genetic testing showed 22q11.2 deletion. What is DiGeorge syndrome?
faqs.answer: DiGeorge syndrome, now more commonly called 22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a small missing piece (microdeletion) on chromosome 22. This deleted region contains dozens of genes important for development. Because multiple genes are missing, the syndrome can affect many different parts of the body, but the combination varies greatly (variable expressivity).

faqs.question: What are the most common features? The doctor mentioned CATCH-22.
faqs.answer: CATCH-22 is an old acronym highlighting some (but not all) common features: Cardiac defects (especially conotruncal defects like Tetralogy of Fallot, Truncus Arteriosus), Abnormal facies (facial features like small chin, low-set ears, hooded eyes), Thymic hypoplasia (underdeveloped thymus gland), Cleft palate (often submucous), Hypocalcemia/Hypoparathyroidism (low calcium due to underdeveloped parathyroid glands), all related to chromosome 22. Other common issues include feeding problems, developmental delays, and immune deficiencies.

faqs.question: Why is the thymus gland important? My baby has T-cell problems.
faqs.answer: The thymus gland (located behind the breastbone) is where T-lymphocytes (T-cells) mature. T-cells are crucial for fighting certain infections (viruses, fungi) and regulating the immune system. Because the thymus is often underdeveloped (thymic hypoplasia or aplasia) in 22q11.2 deletion, T-cell production is impaired, leading to immunodeficiency. This can range from mild (partial DiGeorge) to severe (complete DiGeorge, requiring a thymus transplant).

faqs.question: My baby also has low calcium levels (hypocalcemia). How is that related?
faqs.answer: The tiny parathyroid glands, located near the thyroid in the neck, are responsible for making Parathyroid Hormone (PTH), which regulates calcium levels in the blood. These glands develop from the same embryonic structures affected by the 22q11.2 deletion. Underdeveloped parathyroids (hypoparathyroidism) lead to low PTH, causing low blood calcium (hypocalcemia), which can cause seizures (hypocalcemic seizures) in newborns if not treated.

faqs.question: Is this inherited? We don't have this in our family.
faqs.answer: About 90% of 22q11.2 deletions occur de novo, meaning the deletion happened randomly as a new event in the egg or sperm that formed the baby; the parents do not have the deletion. However, about 10% of cases are inherited from a parent who also has the deletion (often undiagnosed because their symptoms were mild). It's inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern (50% chance of passing it on).

faqs.question: My child was just diagnosed with a brain tumor called Diffuse Midline Glioma, H3 K27-altered. What does this mean? It sounds bad.
faqs.answer: Yes, unfortunately, Diffuse Midline Glioma (DMG), which includes the entity previously known as DIPG (Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma) when located in the brainstem, is a highly aggressive, malignant (Grade 4) brain tumor primarily affecting children. Diffuse means it infiltrates and spreads throughout the tissue (not a distinct lump). Midline refers to its location in critical central brain structures (pons, thalamus, spinal cord). The H3 K27-altered refers to a specific mutation in a histone gene (usually H3F3A or HIST1H3B) that is the defining molecular feature and drives the tumor's aggressiveness.

faqs.question: The tumor is in the pons (DIPG). Why can't they just do surgery to remove it?
faqs.answer: The pons is a vital part of the brainstem that controls essential functions like breathing, heart rate, swallowing, and eye movements. Because DIPG/DMG is diffuse and intrinsic, the tumor cells are completely intertwined with the normal, critical nerve fibers of the pons. There is no safe way to surgically remove the tumor without causing catastrophic neurological damage or death. Surgery is not an option for typical DIPG.

faqs.question: Why don't they even do a biopsy sometimes?
faqs.answer: For tumors located in the classic location within the pons (DIPG), the characteristic appearance on MRI is often so specific that it is considered diagnostic. Historically, biopsy carried significant risks due to the sensitive location and provided little information to change treatment. However, with the advent of molecularly targeted therapies, biopsy is increasingly being performed (often using stereotactic techniques) to confirm the H3 K27 alteration and identify other potential mutations for clinical trials.

faqs.question: What is the standard treatment if surgery isn't possible?
faqs.answer: The only standard treatment that provides temporary benefit is radiation therapy. A course of focused radiation to the tumor provides significant symptom relief (improving neurological function) for several months in most children. However, the tumor inevitably regrows. Chemotherapy has unfortunately proven largely ineffective against typical H3 K27-altered DMG.

faqs.question: What is the prognosis? Are there any new treatments?
faqs.answer: Tragically, the prognosis for H3 K27-altered DMG (including DIPG) remains extremely poor. Median survival, even with radiation, is typically only around 9-12 months from diagnosis. This is an area of intense research. Clinical trials are actively investigating newer approaches, including targeted therapies aimed at the H3 K27 mutation's downstream effects (e.g., epigenetic modulators like ONC201) and various immunotherapy strategies, offering hope for the future.

faqs.question: I was just diagnosed with DLBCL. My doctor says it's aggressive but curable. How can it be both?
faqs.answer: Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is aggressive, meaning it grows quickly and will cause serious problems rapidly if not treated. However, this same rapid growth makes it highly sensitive to chemotherapy. Because the cells are dividing quickly, they are more vulnerable to chemo drugs that target cell division. The standard treatment (R-CHOP) aims for cure in a significant proportion of patients (perhaps 60-70%).

faqs.question: What is R-CHOP? That sounds like alphabet soup.
faqs.answer: R-CHOP is the acronym for the standard first-line chemo-immunotherapy regimen: R (Rituximab - an antibody targeting B-cells), C (Cyclophosphamide - chemo), H (Hydroxydaunorubicin/Doxorubicin - chemo), O (Oncovin/Vincristine - chemo), P (Prednisone - steroid). It's typically given in cycles every 3 weeks.

faqs.question: My pathology report mentions cell of origin (GCB vs ABC). Why does this matter?
faqs.answer: Gene expression studies show that DLBCL isn't one disease. It can be broadly divided into subtypes based on its cell of origin: GCB (Germinal Center B-cell like) and ABC (Activated B-cell like). This distinction has prognostic importance. GCB-type DLBCL generally has a better prognosis and responds well to standard R-CHOP. ABC-type DLBCL is often more aggressive, has a poorer response to R-CHOP, and may benefit from adding newer targeted agents in clinical trials.

faqs.question: What about double-hit or triple-hit lymphoma? My doctor seemed concerned.
faqs.answer: Double-hit or triple-hit lymphoma (now formally called High-Grade B-cell Lymphoma with MYC and BCL2 and/or BCL6 rearrangements) is a particularly aggressive subtype of DLBCL (or sometimes Burkitt-like lymphoma). It's defined by having genetic rearrangements (translocations) involving the MYC gene plus rearrangements of the BCL2 gene and/or the BCL6 gene. These lymphomas grow very rapidly, often resist standard R-CHOP, and require more intensive chemotherapy regimens. They have a poorer prognosis.

faqs.question: What happens if the R-CHOP doesn't work or the lymphoma comes back (relapses)?
faqs.answer: This is called relapsed or refractory (R/R) DLBCL. The next step depends on the timing of relapse and patient fitness. Options include: 1) Salvage Chemotherapy followed by Autologous Stem Cell Transplant: High-dose chemo followed by rescue with the patient's own stem cells offers a chance for cure in some. 2) CAR T-cell Therapy: A revolutionary immunotherapy where the patient's T-cells are genetically engineered to attack the lymphoma cells; highly effective for R/R DLBCL. 3) Other Novel Agents: Antibody-drug conjugates (Polatuzumab), bispecific antibodies, or other targeted drugs in clinical trials.

faqs.question: I've had watery diarrhea for 2 days after eating out. Is this food poisoning?
faqs.answer: It's very likely acute infectious gastroenteritis, often loosely called food poisoning or stomach flu. Most cases are caused by viruses (like Norovirus, Rotavirus) or sometimes bacteria (like Salmonella, Campylobacter, E. coli) or their toxins, acquired from contaminated food, water, or surfaces. It typically causes sudden onset of watery diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and cramps, and usually resolves on its own within 1-3 days.

faqs.question: What's the best treatment? Should I take Imodium?
faqs.answer: For typical viral or mild bacterial diarrhea, the most important treatment is oral rehydration—drinking plenty of fluids (water, broth, electrolyte solutions like Pedialyte or sports drinks) to prevent dehydration. Anti-diarrheal medications like loperamide (Imodium) can reduce the frequency of stools but should be used cautiously. They should NOT be used if you have high fever or bloody diarrhea, as they could potentially worsen certain bacterial infections (like C. diff or invasive E. coli) by keeping the toxins in your system longer.

faqs.question: My diarrhea is bloody and I have a high fever. What could this be?
faqs.answer: Bloody diarrhea (dysentery) plus high fever suggests an invasive bacterial infection. This means bacteria (like Shigella, Salmonella, Campylobacter, E. coli O157:H7) are actually invading the lining of your colon, causing inflammation and bleeding. This type of diarrhea usually does require medical evaluation and often treatment with antibiotics.

faqs.question: I had diarrhea after taking antibiotics. Could it be C. diff?
faqs.answer: Yes, antibiotic-associated diarrhea is common. Most cases are mild, but Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection is a major concern, especially after certain antibiotics (like clindamycin, fluoroquinolones). C. diff causes severe, watery diarrhea, cramps, and sometimes fever. If you develop significant diarrhea within weeks of taking antibiotics, you must be tested for C. diff.

faqs.question: I've had loose stools off and on for months, often with bloating and gas. What could cause chronic diarrhea?
faqs.answer: Chronic diarrhea (lasting >4 weeks) has a very different set of causes than acute diarrhea. Common possibilities include: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS-D), Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's, Ulcerative Colitis), Celiac Disease (gluten intolerance), Microscopic Colitis, Lactose intolerance, Chronic infections (like Giardia), Medication side effects, or problems with absorption (malabsorption). This requires a thorough workup by a doctor.

faqs.question: I have type 2 diabetes, and my eye doctor said I have background retinopathy. What does that mean? My vision is fine.
faqs.answer: This is the earliest stage, also called Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR). High blood sugar damages the tiny blood vessels (capillaries) in your retina (the light-sensitive layer at the back of your eye). In background/NPDR, these damaged vessels start to leak small amounts of fluid or blood, creating microaneurysms (tiny bulges), dot-and-blot hemorrhages (small bleeds), and hard exudates (fatty deposits). At this stage, vision is usually unaffected, but it's a crucial warning sign that damage is occurring.

faqs.question: What is macular edema? My vision has become blurry.
faqs.answer: Diabetic Macular Edema (DME) is the most common cause of vision loss in NPDR. The macula is the central part of the retina responsible for sharp, detailed vision. When the damaged retinal capillaries become very leaky, fluid (edema) accumulates within the layers of the macula, causing it to swell. This swelling blurs and distorts central vision. DME can occur even in mild NPDR.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have proliferative retinopathy (PDR). Why is this stage so dangerous?
faqs.answer: Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) is the advanced, high-risk stage. The ongoing damage causes widespread closure of retinal capillaries, leading to retinal ischemia (lack of oxygen). In response, the desperate retina releases signals (like VEGF) that trigger the growth of new, abnormal, fragile blood vessels (neovascularization) on the surface of the retina or optic nerve. These vessels are bad news: they bleed easily (causing vitreous hemorrhage - blood filling the eye jelly) and can form scar tissue that pulls on the retina, causing retinal detachment and blindness.

faqs.question: How is diabetic eye disease treated? My doctor mentioned injections.
faqs.answer: Treatment depends on the stage: 1) NPDR: Strict blood sugar, blood pressure, and cholesterol control is crucial to slow progression. 2) DME: The standard treatment is intravitreal injections (injections directly into the eye) of anti-VEGF drugs (like Avastin, Lucentis, Eylea). These drugs block the signal causing leakage and swelling. Laser treatment is sometimes used. 3) PDR: Treatment aims to stop the abnormal vessel growth. This involves pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP)—laser burns applied to the peripheral retina to reduce oxygen demand—and often anti-VEGF injections to shrink the new vessels and treat bleeding.

faqs.question: How often do I need eye exams if I have diabetes?
faqs.answer: Annual dilated eye exams are essential for everyone with diabetes (Type 1 or Type 2), starting at diagnosis (for Type 2) or within 5 years of diagnosis (for Type 1). Retinopathy often has no symptoms in its early, treatable stages. Regular exams allow the eye doctor to detect changes early and initiate sight-saving treatment before vision loss occurs.

faqs.question: My baby's bottom is bright red and sore right where the diaper sits. What's the best way to treat this?
faqs.answer: This sounds like typical irritant diaper dermatitis, the most common type of diaper rash. It's essentially a contact dermatitis caused by prolonged exposure of the skin to moisture, friction, and irritants (urine and feces). The key to treatment is protecting the skin barrier: 1) Frequent diaper changes: Change immediately when wet or soiled. 2) Gentle cleaning: Use plain water and a soft cloth or fragrance-free/alcohol-free wipes. Pat dry gently. 3) Air time: Let the baby go diaper-free for short periods to air out the skin. 4) Barrier cream: Apply a thick layer of a zinc oxide or petrolatum-based ointment (like Desitin, A+D, Vaseline) with every diaper change to create a protective seal.

faqs.question: The rash is bright red with little red satellite spots spreading out. Is this yeast?
faqs.answer: Yes, that description—beefy red rash often in the skin folds, with satellite lesions (small red bumps or pustules extending beyond the main rash)—is the classic sign of a Candida (yeast) diaper rash. Yeast loves warm, moist environments. This often starts as an irritant rash, but the broken-down skin allows Candida to overgrow. Treatment requires an antifungal cream (like nystatin or clotrimazole), often used in combination with a barrier cream.

faqs.question: Could it be an allergy to the diapers or wipes?
faqs.answer: Allergic contact dermatitis in the diaper area is less common than irritant or yeast rashes. If it is an allergy, the rash often looks more like eczema (red, itchy, possibly blistering) and might occur specifically where dyes, fragrances (in wipes), or elastic bands touch the skin. Patch testing might be needed if suspected.

faqs.question: What about using baby powder or cornstarch?
faqs.answer: These are generally not recommended. Powders, especially talcum powder, can be easily inhaled by the baby, causing respiratory problems. Cornstarch can potentially worsen a yeast infection (yeast feeds on it). Thick barrier ointments are much safer and more effective at protecting the skin.

faqs.question: When should I call the doctor about a diaper rash?
faqs.answer: Call your pediatrician if the rash: 1) Looks like yeast (beefy red with satellites). 2) Has blisters, open sores, or pus. 3) Is not improving after 2-3 days of home care with barrier creams. 4) Is causing the baby significant pain. 5) Is accompanied by fever.

faqs.question: I have type 2 diabetes, and my feet burn and tingle, especially at night. Is this neuropathy?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic symptom of Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy (DPN), specifically Distal Symmetric Polyneuropathy, the most common type. High blood sugar over time damages the peripheral nerves, typically starting in the longest nerves first—those going to your feet. This damage causes sensory symptoms: burning, tingling (pins and needles), numbness, or sharp, shooting pains. Symptoms are often worse at night.

faqs.question: Why is the numbness dangerous? It doesn't hurt.
faqs.answer: The numbness (loss of protective sensation) is the most dangerous part. Because you can't feel pain, pressure, or temperature normally in your feet, you can develop a blister, cut, ulcer, or infection (e.g., from stepping on something sharp or wearing ill-fitting shoes) and not even realize it. This can lead to severe infections, gangrene, and ultimately, amputation. This is why daily foot inspection and proper foot care are absolutely critical for diabetics.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned autonomic neuropathy. How does diabetes affect those nerves?
faqs.answer: Diabetic Autonomic Neuropathy (DAN) involves damage to the nerves that control involuntary body functions. This can cause a wide range of problems: Gastroparesis (delayed stomach emptying causing nausea/vomiting), Orthostatic hypotension (dizziness upon standing), Erectile dysfunction, Bladder problems (incontinence or retention), and Abnormal sweating. DAN significantly impacts quality of life.

faqs.question: Can diabetic neuropathy be reversed?
faqs.answer: Currently, there is no treatment to reverse the nerve damage once it has occurred. However, tight blood glucose control is the most important factor in preventing neuropathy or slowing its progression significantly. Once symptoms develop, treatment focuses on: 1) Pain management: Medications specifically for nerve pain (like gabapentin, pregabalin, duloxetine, amitriptyline). 2) Foot care: Preventing complications like ulcers and amputations.

faqs.question: What kind of foot care is needed?
faqs.answer: Essential foot care includes: 1) Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, redness, swelling. Use a mirror if needed. 2) Wash feet daily with lukewarm water and mild soap; dry thoroughly, especially between toes. 3) Moisturize feet (but not between toes) to prevent cracking. 4) Wear well-fitting shoes and socks at all times; never go barefoot. 5) Trim toenails straight across. 6) Have feet examined by a doctor or podiatrist at every visit (at least annually).

faqs.question: My urine test showed microalbuminuria. My doctor says it's the first sign of kidney damage from my diabetes. How?
faqs.answer: Diabetic nephropathy is kidney damage caused by diabetes. Microalbuminuria (small amounts of a protein called albumin leaking into the urine) is the earliest detectable sign. High blood sugar damages the tiny filtering units (glomeruli) in your kidneys, making them leaky. Albumin is one of the first proteins to leak through. Finding microalbuminuria is a crucial warning sign that allows for early intervention to protect your kidneys.

faqs.question: What causes the kidney damage? Is it just high blood sugar?
faqs.answer: High blood sugar (hyperglycemia) is the primary driver, but high blood pressure (hypertension) plays a huge synergistic role. Hyperglycemia damages the glomeruli directly and causes them to work harder (hyperfiltration). Hypertension increases the pressure within the glomeruli, forcing more protein through and accelerating the damage. Aggressive control of both blood sugar and blood pressure is essential to prevent or slow diabetic kidney disease.

faqs.question: How do ACE inhibitors (like Lisinopril) or ARBs (like Losartan) help the kidneys?
faqs.answer: These medications (ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers) are critically important for kidney protection in diabetes, even if blood pressure is normal. They work by reducing the pressure inside the glomeruli. They preferentially relax the efferent arteriole (the vessel leaving the filter), lowering the filtration pressure, reducing the amount of protein leaking (albuminuria), and slowing down the progression of kidney damage.

faqs.question: My kidney function (eGFR) is starting to decline. Can this be stopped?
faqs.answer: While the damage may not be fully reversible, progression can be significantly slowed. Key strategies include: 1) Intensive blood glucose control (target A1c usually <7%). 2) Strict blood pressure control (target usually <130/80 mmHg). 3) Using ACE inhibitors or ARBs. 4) Newer diabetes drugs like SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., Farxiga, Jardiance) and GLP-1 receptor agonists (e.g., Ozempic, Trulicity) have also shown significant kidney-protective benefits beyond glucose lowering. 5) Dietary changes (protein restriction may be needed in later stages).

faqs.question: What happens if my kidneys fail completely?
faqs.answer: If diabetic nephropathy progresses despite treatment, it can lead to End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), where the kidneys fail (eGFR <15). At this point, renal replacement therapy is needed for survival. Options include dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis) or a kidney transplant (often combined with a pancreas transplant in Type 1 diabetes).

faqs.question: I have Type 1 diabetes and I've been vomiting, breathing fast, and my breath smells fruity. Am I in DKA?
faqs.answer: Yes, these are classic signs of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). You need to go to the Emergency Room immediately. DKA is a life-threatening complication, primarily of Type 1 diabetes, caused by a severe lack of insulin. Without insulin, your body cannot use glucose (sugar) for energy, even though blood sugar levels are very high. Instead, it starts breaking down fat for fuel.

faqs.question: Why does breaking down fat cause so many problems?
faqs.answer: The breakdown of fat produces ketones as a byproduct. Ketones are acidic. When they build up rapidly in the bloodstream, they make the blood dangerously acidic (metabolic acidosis). This acidosis, combined with extremely high blood sugar (which causes severe dehydration) and electrolyte imbalances (especially potassium), leads to the symptoms: nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, rapid deep breathing (Kussmaul respirations - the body trying to blow off acid as CO2), fruity breath (acetone, a type of ketone), confusion, and eventually coma.

faqs.question: What usually triggers DKA? I thought my blood sugar was okay.
faqs.answer: The most common triggers are: 1) Infection or illness: Illness increases stress hormones, which raise blood sugar and insulin needs. Pneumonia or UTI are common triggers. 2) Missed insulin doses: Running out of insulin, pump failure, or forgetting injections. 3) New diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes: DKA is often the first sign that leads to diagnosis in previously undiagnosed individuals. 4) Other stressors: Surgery, trauma, certain medications (like steroids).

faqs.question: How is DKA treated in the hospital?
faqs.answer: Treatment involves three critical components given simultaneously: 1) Intravenous (IV) Fluids: Aggressive rehydration is needed to correct the severe dehydration caused by high blood sugar pulling water out of cells and into the urine. 2) Insulin: An IV insulin drip is given to stop ketone production, allow the body to use glucose again, and gradually lower blood sugar. 3) Electrolyte Replacement: Especially potassium. Insulin drives potassium into cells, so blood levels can drop dangerously low during treatment, requiring careful IV replacement to prevent heart rhythm problems.

faqs.question: Can people with Type 2 diabetes get DKA?
faqs.answer: It's much less common in Type 2 diabetes because these individuals usually still produce some insulin, which is typically enough to prevent the massive ketone production seen in Type 1. However, under conditions of extreme stress (like severe infection or trauma), people with Type 2 diabetes can sometimes develop DKA. A related condition, Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS), involves extremely high blood sugar and dehydration without significant ketoacidosis, and is more common in Type 2.

faqs.question: I have diabetes and sometimes I get shaky, sweaty, and confused. My sugar is low when I check it. Is this hypoglycemia?
faqs.answer: Yes, hypoglycemia means low blood glucose (sugar), typically defined as a level below 70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L). The symptoms you describe—shakiness, sweating, anxiety, confusion, rapid heartbeat, dizziness—are the body's adrenergic (adrenaline release) and neuroglycopenic (brain lacking sugar) responses to low glucose. It's a common and dangerous side effect of diabetes treatment, especially insulin or certain oral medications.

faqs.question: What causes blood sugar to drop too low?
faqs.answer: It's usually an imbalance between insulin/medication, food intake, and activity: 1) Too much insulin or medication: Taking more than needed for the amount of food eaten. 2) Skipping or delaying meals: Not eating enough carbohydrate to match the insulin dose. 3) Increased physical activity: Exercise uses up glucose, increasing insulin sensitivity, requiring less insulin or more carbs. 4) Alcohol: Drinking alcohol, especially on an empty stomach, can block the liver from releasing glucose.

faqs.question: What should I do if I feel my sugar going low?
faqs.answer: Follow the Rule of 15: 1) Check your blood glucose if possible. 2) If low (<70 mg/dL) or if you can't check, consume 15 grams of fast-acting carbohydrate. Examples: 4 glucose tablets, 4 ounces (1/2 cup) of juice or regular soda, 1 tablespoon of sugar or honey. 3) Wait 15 minutes and re-check your blood glucose. 4) If still low, repeat step 2. 5) Once glucose is >70-80 mg/dL, eat a small snack containing protein and carbohydrate (like crackers with cheese) if your next meal is more than an hour away, to prevent it from dropping again.

faqs.question: What is hypoglycemia unawareness?
faqs.answer: This is a dangerous complication, usually in people with long-standing Type 1 diabetes or frequent lows. The body stops producing the early warning signs (shaking, sweating, anxiety) of low blood sugar. The person doesn't realize their sugar is dropping until it's dangerously low, leading directly to severe neuroglycopenic symptoms like confusion, seizures, or loss of consciousness. Frequent blood glucose monitoring (or using a Continuous Glucose Monitor - CGM) is critical for these individuals.

faqs.question: My father passed out from low blood sugar. What is Glucagon?
faqs.answer: Severe hypoglycemia (where the person is confused, unable to swallow, unconscious, or seizing) is a medical emergency. You cannot force food or drink into their mouth. Glucagon is a hormone that tells the liver to release stored glucose into the bloodstream. It comes in an emergency kit (injectable or nasal spray) that family members can administer to rapidly raise blood sugar until emergency help arrives. Call 911 immediately in cases of severe hypoglycemia.

faqs.question: I'm constantly thirsty and urinating huge amounts (like gallons) of clear, watery urine, day and night. Is this diabetes?
faqs.answer: This sounds like Diabetes Insipidus (DI), which is completely unrelated to the common sugar diabetes (Diabetes Mellitus). Diabetes just means passing through (referring to urine), and Insipidus means tasteless (unlike the sweet urine of mellitus). DI is a problem with water balance, caused by either your brain not making enough Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH), or your kidneys not responding to it.

faqs.question: What does ADH normally do?
faqs.answer: Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH), also called vasopressin, is made in your hypothalamus (brain) and stored in your pituitary gland. Its job is to tell your kidneys to reabsorb water back into your body, making your urine more concentrated. It's the anti-pee hormone.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have Central DI. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Central Diabetes Insipidus is the most common type. It means the problem is in your brain—your hypothalamus or pituitary gland is not producing or releasing enough ADH. Without ADH, your kidneys don't get the signal to save water, so they excrete massive amounts of dilute urine (polyuria), making you constantly thirsty (polydipsia). Causes include head trauma, brain surgery, tumors, or idiopathic (unknown).

faqs.question: What is Nephrogenic DI?
faqs.answer: Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus means the problem is in your kidneys. Your brain is making ADH perfectly fine, but your kidneys are resistant and cannot respond to the ADH signal. The message isn't getting through. Causes include certain genetic disorders, kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances (like high calcium or low potassium), or certain medications (especially Lithium).

faqs.question: How is DI treated? Do I just drink a lot of water?
faqs.answer: Drinking water is essential to prevent dehydration, but it doesn't fix the underlying problem. Treatment depends on the type: Central DI is treated with Desmopressin (DDAVP). This is a synthetic version of ADH, usually taken as a nasal spray or pill, which replaces the missing hormone and tells the kidneys to conserve water. Nephrogenic DI is harder to treat since the kidneys don't respond to ADH/DDAVP. Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause if possible, a low-salt/low-protein diet, and sometimes diuretics (like hydrochlorothiazide) which paradoxically reduce urine output in NDI.

faqs.question: What exactly is a diabetic coma? Is it just low blood sugar?
faqs.answer: Diabetic coma isn't a single entity but refers to a loss of consciousness occurring in a person with diabetes due to critically abnormal blood glucose levels or their complications. It can be caused by either severely low or severely high blood sugar: 1) Severe Hypoglycemia: Blood sugar drops so low (<40-50 mg/dL) that the brain doesn't have enough fuel to function, leading to seizures or unconsciousness. 2) Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA): Primarily in Type 1, very high blood sugar plus acidic ketones poison the brain. 3) Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS): Primarily in Type 2, extremely high blood sugar (>600-1000 mg/dL) causes severe dehydration and thick, syrupy blood (hyperosmolarity), leading to confusion and coma.

faqs.question: How can I tell if someone is unconscious from high or low sugar?
faqs.answer: It's difficult without checking their blood sugar. Severe Hypoglycemia often has a rapid onset and may be preceded by symptoms like sweating, shakiness, or confusion. The person might be pale and clammy. DKA and HHS usually develop more slowly (hours to days) with preceding symptoms of extreme thirst, urination, vomiting (DKA), rapid breathing (DKA), and increasing lethargy/confusion. When in doubt, assume hypoglycemia (as it's more immediately life-threatening) and give sugar if possible, but the definitive action is to call 911 immediately for anyone with diabetes who is unresponsive.

faqs.question: If someone is unconscious from low sugar, what should I do?
faqs.answer: Call 911 first. Do NOT try to force food, liquids, or insulin into the mouth of an unconscious person – they could choke. If you are trained and have access to it, administer emergency Glucagon (injectable or nasal). You can also rub glucose gel or honey on the inside of their cheek, where some might be absorbed, while waiting for paramedics.

faqs.question: How do paramedics treat someone in a diabetic coma?
faqs.answer: They will immediately check the blood glucose level. If it's low, they will administer intravenous (IV) dextrose (sugar water) to rapidly raise blood sugar. If it's high (suggesting DKA or HHS), they will start IV fluids for rehydration and transport the patient to the hospital for insulin therapy and electrolyte management.

faqs.question: How can diabetic coma be prevented?
faqs.answer: Prevention involves good diabetes management: Regular blood glucose monitoring, taking medications/insulin as prescribed, understanding how food, exercise, and illness affect blood sugar, recognizing and treating low blood sugar promptly (Rule of 15), having sick day management rules (checking sugar/ketones more often, staying hydrated, knowing when to call the doctor), and wearing medical identification.

faqs.question: What's the actual difference between Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes? They both involve high blood sugar, right?
faqs.answer: Yes, both result in high blood sugar, but the cause is completely different. Type 1 Diabetes is an autoimmune disease. The body's immune system attacks and destroys the insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas. There is an absolute lack of insulin. It usually starts in childhood/young adulthood. Type 2 Diabetes is primarily a condition of insulin resistance combined with relative insulin deficiency. The body's cells don't respond properly to the insulin that is being produced, and the pancreas eventually can't keep up. It's strongly linked to lifestyle factors (obesity, inactivity) and genetics, usually starting in adulthood (though increasingly seen in kids).

faqs.question: My doctor checked my A1c and it was 8%. What does that number mean?
faqs.answer: The Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) test measures your average blood glucose control over the past 2-3 months. Glucose in your blood naturally sticks to hemoglobin (the protein in red blood cells). The higher your blood sugar has been, the more glucose gets stuck. An A1c of 8% indicates your average blood sugar has been quite high (roughly equivalent to an average of ~183 mg/dL or 10.2 mmol/L). The target for most people with diabetes is below 7% to reduce the risk of long-term complications.

faqs.question: What are the long-term complications? My sugar doesn't really bother me day-to-day.
faqs.answer: This is the danger of diabetes – the high sugar causes silent damage over years. Major complications affect: 1) Small blood vessels (Microvascular): Leading to Retinopathy (eye damage, blindness), Nephropathy (kidney damage, failure), and Neuropathy (nerve damage, foot numbness/pain, amputations). 2) Large blood vessels (Macrovascular): Accelerating atherosclerosis, leading to Heart attacks, Strokes, and Peripheral artery disease (PAD). Strict glucose control significantly reduces microvascular risks.

faqs.question: What is prediabetes? Am I going to get full diabetes?
faqs.answer: Prediabetes means your blood glucose levels are higher than normal, but not yet high enough to be diagnosed as Type 2 diabetes (A1c 5.7-6.4%, or fasting glucose 100-125 mg/dL). It's a major warning sign and indicates you already have insulin resistance. Without lifestyle changes, most people with prediabetes will progress to Type 2 diabetes within 5-10 years. However, lifestyle changes (weight loss, exercise, healthy diet) can often prevent or delay this progression.

faqs.question: How do drugs like Metformin or Ozempic work for Type 2?
faqs.answer: They target different aspects: Metformin (first-line drug) primarily works by reducing glucose production by the liver and slightly improving insulin sensitivity. Ozempic (semaglutide) is a GLP-1 receptor agonist. It mimics a gut hormone that: 1) Stimulates the pancreas to release insulin only when blood sugar is high. 2) Reduces glucose production by the liver. 3) Slows down stomach emptying, making you feel full. 4) Often leads to significant weight loss. Other classes (like SGLT2 inhibitors) work by making the kidneys excrete excess sugar in the urine.

faqs.question: I can barely breathe through one side of my nose, and I get sinus infections all the time. My doctor says my septum is deviated. What is that?
faqs.answer: The nasal septum is the thin wall made of cartilage and bone that divides your nasal cavity into two nostrils. A deviated septum means this wall is bent, crooked, or off-center. This narrowing of one nasal passage makes it difficult for air to flow through, causing nasal obstruction (stuffiness), and can also block sinus drainage pathways, contributing to recurrent sinusitis.

faqs.question: How did my septum get crooked? Was I born with it?
faqs.answer: It can be either. Some people are born with a deviated septum due to development in the womb. More commonly, it's caused by trauma to the nose—a direct blow (like breaking your nose in sports or an accident) can knock the septum out of alignment, even if the external nose looks straight afterwards.

faqs.question: Will nasal sprays (like Flonase) or allergy pills fix it?
faqs.answer: No. A deviated septum is a structural (anatomical) problem—the wall is physically bent. Medications like nasal steroid sprays (Flonase) or antihistamines can help reduce swelling of the nasal lining (turbinates) around the deviation, which might provide some temporary improvement in airflow, but they cannot straighten the septum itself.

faqs.question: What is a septoplasty surgery?
faqs.answer: Septoplasty is the surgical procedure to correct a deviated septum. An Ear, Nose, and Throat (ENT) surgeon works entirely through the nostrils (no external cuts). They make an incision in the lining (mucosa), lift it up, and then remove or reshape the bent portions of the cartilage and bone. The lining is then laid back down. The goal is purely functional—to improve breathing.

faqs.question: Is septoplasty the same as a nose job (rhinoplasty)?
faqs.answer: No. Septoplasty corrects the internal wall for breathing purposes. Rhinoplasty is cosmetic surgery to change the external shape of the nose. However, the two procedures are often performed together (septorhinoplasty) if a patient has both breathing problems and desires cosmetic changes, as the surgeon can address both issues in one operation.

faqs.question: My teenage son has abdominal pain, and scans found multiple tumors coating the inside of his belly. The biopsy said DSRCT. What is this?
faqs.answer: Desmoplastic Small Round Cell Tumor (DSRCT) is an extremely rare and very aggressive soft tissue sarcoma (a type of cancer). It primarily affects adolescents and young adults, mostly males. It characteristically grows as multiple tumors studding the peritoneum (the lining of the abdominal cavity), often involving the omentum (fatty apron) and surfaces of organs, causing abdominal pain, distension, constipation, and often fluid buildup (ascites).

faqs.question: What causes this? It seems to have come out of nowhere.
faqs.answer: DSRCT is defined by a specific genetic translocation. A piece of the EWS gene on chromosome 22 fuses with the WT1 gene on chromosome 11, creating an abnormal EWS-WT1 fusion protein. This fusion protein acts as a rogue transcription factor, driving the uncontrolled growth of these primitive cancer cells. The cause of this translocation is unknown; it's a random genetic accident.

faqs.question: Is this related to Ewing sarcoma? It also has an EWS gene change.
faqs.answer: They are related in that both are small round blue cell tumors often involving an EWS gene rearrangement, but they are distinct diseases. Ewing sarcoma typically involves an EWS fusion with an ETS family gene (like FLI1) and usually occurs in bone. DSRCT involves EWS fused with WT1 and occurs in the soft tissues, classically the peritoneum.

faqs.question: How is DSRCT treated? It sounds very aggressive.
faqs.answer: Treatment requires a very aggressive multimodal approach due to the rarity and aggressiveness of the disease: 1) Intensive multi-agent chemotherapy: Regimens similar to those used for Ewing sarcoma or rhabdomyosarcoma are used to shrink the tumors. 2) Aggressive surgical debulking: Attempting to remove as much visible tumor as possible from the peritoneal surfaces (cytoreductive surgery). 3) Radiation therapy: Often used to target residual disease. Despite aggressive treatment, the prognosis is generally poor due to the advanced stage at diagnosis and high recurrence rate.

faqs.question: What is HIPEC? My doctor mentioned it might be an option with surgery.
faqs.answer: HIPEC (Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy) is sometimes considered in specialized centers as part of the surgical debulking for DSRCT. After removing all visible tumor, the surgeon fills the abdominal cavity with heated chemotherapy drugs for 60-90 minutes before closing. The heat helps the chemo penetrate the tissue surfaces better, potentially killing microscopic residual cancer cells. Its role in DSRCT is still being studied but may offer benefit in select cases.

faqs.question: I have weak muscles (especially shoulders/hips) and a weird reddish-purple rash on my eyelids and knuckles. What could this be?
faqs.answer: This combination—proximal muscle weakness (difficulty raising arms, getting up from a chair) plus characteristic skin rashes—is highly suggestive of Dermatomyositis (DM).
