faqs.answer: This is a classic sign of psychophysiological insomnia, or conditioned insomnia. You've come to associate your bed with being stressed and awake, rather than with sleep. Your brain has learned that bed = time to worry. This creates a hyper-arousal state (your racing mind) precisely when you want to be winding down. This is a core target of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I).

faqs.question: What's the difference between sleep-onset and sleep-maintenance insomnia?
faqs.answer: Sleep-onset insomnia is difficulty falling asleep at the beginning of the night (like your racing mind problem). Sleep-maintenance insomnia is difficulty staying asleep. People with this type fall asleep easily, but then wake up in the middle of the night (e.g., at 3 AM) and can't get back to sleep. They can be caused by different things (e.g., anxiety often causes onset insomnia, while depression or sleep apnea can cause maintenance insomnia).

faqs.question: I've heard CBT-I is better than sleeping pills. What is it? I don't want to just talk about my sleep.
faqs.answer: CBT-I is not traditional talk therapy. It's a highly structured, practical program that changes your behaviors and thoughts about sleep. Its main tools are Sleep Restriction (where you reduce your time in bed to match the time you actually sleep, building sleep drive) and Stimulus Control (re-training your brain to associate the bed only with sleep). This means if you're not asleep in 20 minutes, you must get up, go to another room, and only return when you're sleepy. It's tough, but it's the most effective long-term cure.

faqs.question: Can I just take melatonin? Will that fix my insomnia?
faqs.answer: Melatonin is a chronobiotic hormone, not a hypnotic (sleeping pill). It doesn't force you to sleep; it just signals to your brain that it's nighttime. It's very effective for circadian rhythm problems, like jet lag or for night owls who need to shift their sleep schedule earlier. It is not very effective for chronic insomnia, which is driven by hyper-arousal and bad habits, not a lack of melatonin.

faqs.question: Is it dangerous to just get by on 4-5 hours of sleep? I've been doing it for years.
faqs.answer: Yes. While some people are short sleepers, most adults need 7-9 hours. Chronic sleep deprivation is not a badge of honor; it has serious long-term consequences. It's linked to a much higher risk of high blood pressure, heart attacks, stroke, type 2 diabetes, obesity (it messes up your hunger hormones), depression, and a weakened immune system. It also severely impacts your cognitive function, memory, and reaction time.

faqs.question: My baby's newborn screen came back abnormal for something called PKU. What does this mean?
faqs.answer: PKU (Phenylketonuria) is one of the most common inherited metabolic disorders. It means your baby was born without (or with a defective) enzyme needed to break down an amino acid called phenylalanine, which is found in all protein. If untreated, phenylalanine builds up in the blood and becomes toxic to the brain, causing severe intellectual disability. The good news is that by catching it on the newborn screen, it can be 100% managed with a special low-protein diet, and your baby can live a normal, healthy life.

faqs.question: How can my child have a metabolic disorder if both my partner and I are perfectly healthy?
faqs.answer: This is because most inherited metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive. This means that both you and your partner are silent carriers of one faulty gene, but you also have one normal gene, which is enough to keep you healthy. Your child, by chance, inherited the one faulty gene from both of you (a 1-in-4 chance with each pregnancy), leaving them with no working copy of the gene, which causes the disorder.

faqs.question: My son has MCAD deficiency. The doctor said he can't fast. Does that mean just skipping breakfast?
faqs.answer: It's much more serious than that. MCAD (Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase) deficiency is a fatty acid oxidation disorder. It means your son's body cannot break down stored fat to use for energy. Glucose (sugar) is his only fuel. When the rest of us fast (like overnight), our bodies switch to burning fat. Your son's body can't do that. If he goes too long without food (e.g., by skipping a meal or during an illness with vomiting), his blood sugar will crash, and toxic byproducts will build up, leading to a metabolic crisis (lethargy, seizures, coma). This is why regular feeding is critical.

faqs.question: What is a lysosomal storage disorder? My niece has Tay-Sachs.
faqs.answer: Lysosomes are the recycling centers inside your cells. They contain enzymes that break down waste products. A lysosomal storage disorder (like Tay-Sachs, Gaucher, or Pompe disease) is caused by a missing enzyme for a specific waste product. Because that waste can't be broken down, it stores (accumulates) inside the lysosome, causing the cell to become damaged and die. In Tay-Sachs, a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside builds up in the nerve cells of the brain, leading to progressive, fatal neurodegeneration.

faqs.question: What is enzyme replacement therapy? Is it a cure?
faqs.answer: For some metabolic disorders (like Gaucher disease or Pompe disease), Enzyme Replacement Therapy (ERT) is a life-changing treatment. It is not a cure, as it doesn't fix the underlying faulty gene. Instead, the missing enzyme is manufactured and given to the patient through a regular IV infusion (e.g., every 2 weeks). This replacement enzyme does the job the body can't, breaking down the stored waste product and stopping or reversing the disease's symptoms. It's a lifelong, very expensive treatment.

faqs.question: I have a bulge in my groin that appears when I stand or cough, and goes away when I lie down. Is this an inguinal hernia?
faqs.answer: That is the classic description of a reducible inguinal hernia. A hernia is a hole or weak spot in your abdominal wall muscles (in this case, in the inguinal canal in your groin). The bulge you see and feel is a loop of your intestine or abdominal fat poking through that hole. When you stand or cough (increasing abdominal pressure), it's pushed out. When you lie down, gravity lets it slide back in.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a direct hernia, not an indirect one. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: It's an anatomical distinction. An indirect inguinal hernia (the most common type) happens when the intestine pokes through the inguinal ring, a natural opening that didn't close properly after birth. This type is common in young people. A direct inguinal hernia is an acquired weakness. It doesn't go through the ring; it pushes directly through a weakened area of the floor of the inguinal canal. This is caused by chronic wear-and-tear and is more common in older men.

faqs.question: My hernia doesn't hurt. Can I just watch it, or do I need surgery?
faqs.answer: If it's a small, painless, reducible hernia, watchful waiting is a safe option, especially for older, less active men. However, most surgeons recommend elective repair because hernias tend to get larger over time and can become uncomfortable. More importantly, they carry the risk of incarceration or strangulation.

faqs.question: What does it mean for a hernia to be incarcerated or strangulated?
faqs.answer: This is the emergency. Incarceration is when the loop of intestine gets trapped in the hernia hole and can't be pushed back in. This causes a bowel obstruction (pain, vomiting, bloating). Strangulation is the next step: the hole is so tight that it cuts off the blood supply to the trapped intestine. This causes the bowel to die (gangrene) and is a life-threatening emergency, requiring immediate surgery.

faqs.question: My surgeon says he'll use mesh for the repair. Is that safe? I've heard bad things.
faqs.answer: Laparoscopic or open tension-free mesh repair is the modern standard of care. The mesh (a sterile, flexible synthetic material) acts as a scaffold over the hernia hole, allowing your own tissue to grow into it, creating a strong, permanent patch. This has a much lower rate of the hernia coming back (recurrence) than old-fashioned sutured repairs. While there have been reports of mesh-related pain or complications (often from pelvic floor/vaginal mesh, which is different), inguinal hernia mesh repair is overwhelmingly safe and effective.

faqs.question: Why do I keep getting ingrown toenails on my big toe, but never on any other toes?
faqs.answer: The big toe (hallux) is the most common victim because it's subjected to the most pressure. The main causes are 1) Improper nail trimming: cutting your toenails too short, especially rounding the corners, which encourages the nail edge to grow down into the skin. 2) Tight shoes: Shoes that are too narrow or tight (like pointy heels or cleats) constantly press the skin of your toe against the nail. 3) Genetics: Some people just have naturally pincer or fan-shaped nails that are curved and predisposed to growing inward.

faqs.question: My toe is red, swollen, and has pus coming out. Can I just soak it at home, or do I need a doctor?
faqs.answer: If it's just a little red and sore, home treatment (warm Epsom salt soaks, gently lifting the nail edge with cotton) might work. But if it's as you describe—very swollen, red, and draining pus—it's infected (called a paronychia). You need to see a doctor. You will likely need oral antibiotics and, more importantly, the ingrown part of the nail needs to be removed to let the infection drain and the toe heal.

faqs.question: What is the procedure like to remove an ingrown toenail? Will it hurt?
faqs.answer: The doctor will perform a partial nail avulsion. First, they will numb your toe completely by injecting local anesthetic at its base (this is the only part that stings). Once you are 100% numb, you won't feel any pain. The doctor will then cut a small, vertical sliver (about 1/8th of an inch) of the nail on the ingrown side and pull that piece out from the root. They will then drain the infection. You'll have a bandage and will feel relief almost immediately.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to put phenol on the nail root to stop it from growing back. Is this permanent?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is called a matrixectomy and is done for people who have chronic, recurring ingrown toenails on the same side. After they remove the sliver of nail, they apply a chemical (usually phenol) to the nail matrix (the root) in that corner. This permanently kills that specific part of the nail root, so a new nail will grow, but it will be slightly narrower and that ingrown edge will never grow back. It's a highly effective, permanent solution.

faqs.question: How am I supposed to cut my toenails to prevent this from happening again?
faqs.answer: The single most important thing is to cut your toenails straight across. Do not round the corners or taper them down the sides. Leave the corners slightly square. The goal is to have the corner of the nail resting on top of the skin, not digging into it. Also, don't cut them too short; they should be about even with the top of your toe.

faqs.question: Why do I get so many ingrown hairs on my neck, but not on my head?
faqs.answer: This is very common, especially in men. It's because neck hairs are often much coarser and curlier. When you shave, you cut the hair at a sharp, beveled angle. As this coarse, curly hair grows back, its sharp tip can't find the surface; it curls back around and pierces into the skin (transfollicular penetration) or grows under the skin (extrafollicular), causing an ingrown hair (pseudofolliculitis barbae). Head hair is often straighter and poses less of a problem.

faqs.question: I have a painful, red lump in my bikini area that looks like a big pimple. Is it an ingrown hair or a boil?
faqs.answer: It's likely an ingrown hair that has become an inflamed foreign body reaction. Your body sees the trapped hair as an invader and launches an immune response, creating a red, tender papule or pustule that looks just like a pimple. A boil (or furuncle) is usually a much larger, deeper, and more painful Staph infection of the entire hair follicle, often with a central head of pus.

faqs.question: I can see the hair trapped under the skin. Is it okay to dig it out with tweezers or a needle?
faqs.answer: This is very tempting, but it's risky. Bathroom surgery with non-sterile tools can introduce bacteria, turning a simple inflamed bump into a painful, infected abscess or boil. It can also cause more inflammation and lead to permanent scarring or dark spots (post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation). The safest way is to apply a warm compress to soften the skin and see if the hair will erupt on its own. If you must, sterilize a needle with rubbing alcohol and gently lift the hair tip out from under the skin, but don't dig for it.

faqs.question: How can I prevent ingrown hairs when I shave?
faqs.answer: The goal is to get a less close shave. 1) Exfoliate before shaving to remove dead skin. 2) Shave after a warm shower, when hairs are soft. 3) Use a sharp, single-blade razor (multi-blade razors pull the hair up and cut it below the skin line, which is the problem). 4) Shave with the grain (in the direction of hair growth), not against it. 5) Don't pull the skin taut. 6) Using an electric razor, which doesn't cut as closely, is often the best solution.

faqs.question: Will laser hair removal get rid of my ingrown hairs for good?
faqs.answer: Yes. Laser hair removal is considered the most effective, permanent solution for severe, chronic ingrown hairs (like pseudofolliculitis barbae). The laser targets the pigment in the hair follicle and destroys it, so the hair can't grow back. If there is no hair, there can be no ingrown hair. It's an excellent option for people with dark, coarse hair in areas like the bikini line or neck.

faqs.question: I feel like I've been hit by a truck. Is this a bad cold or the flu? How can I tell?
faqs.answer: The hit by a truck feeling is the hallmark of the flu. A cold usually comes on gradually with a runny nose, sneezing, and a scratchy throat. The flu hits you suddenly and violently. The key symptoms are a high fever (101-104°F), severe body aches (myalgia), a pounding headache, and profound fatigue and weakness. A runny or stuffy nose can happen, but they are not the main symptoms.

faqs.question: My doctor prescribed Tamiflu (oseltamivir). How does that work? Will it cure me instantly?
faqs.answer: Tamiflu is an antiviral, not a cure. It works by blocking a viral enzyme called neuraminidase, which the flu virus uses to spread from an infected cell to new, healthy cells. By blocking this, it traps the virus and slows down its replication. It is not an antibiotic and won't make you feel better instantly. To be effective, it must be started within 48 hours of your first symptoms. It can then shorten the duration of your illness by about 1-2 days and may reduce the severity of your symptoms.

faqs.question: Why do I need a flu shot every single year? Doesn't it give me immunity?
faqs.answer: It does, but there are two problems. 1) Waning Immunity: The protection you get from the shot fades over the course of the year. 2) Viral Mutation: The influenza virus is sloppy and mutates constantly. This is called antigenic drift. The flu strain circulating this year is slightly different from the one last year, so your old antibodies won't recognize it as well. The new, yearly shot is an educated guess by scientists to match the strains they predict will be most common.

faqs.question: I got the flu shot, but I still got the flu! Does this mean it didn't work?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. It's possible you were exposed to a different strain of flu that wasn't included in the vaccine mismatch). It's also possible you were exposed to the flu before the vaccine had time to take effect (it takes 2 weeks). However, the most important benefit is that even if you do get the flu, studies consistently show that having the vaccine makes your illness significantly milder and dramatically reduces your risk of being hospitalized, ending up in the ICU, or dying from it.

faqs.question: Can the flu turn into pneumonia? I'm young and healthy, so I'm not worried.
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the most common and dangerous complication of the flu, and it can affect anyone. There are two ways this happens: 1) Primary Viral Pneumonia: The flu virus itself can directly infect your lungs, causing a severe, rapidly progressing pneumonia that is very hard to treat. 2) Secondary Bacterial Pneumonia: The flu virus damages your airways and weakens your immune system, which allows bacteria (like Strep pneumoniae or Staph aureus) to invade and cause a secondary pneumonia. This is why you feel better for a day, then suddenly get a relapse with a high fever and a cough that brings up thick, colored phlegm.

faqs.question: My breast is red, swollen, and warm, but I don't have a lump. My doctor gave me antibiotics for mastitis, but they aren't working. Could it be cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the critical red flag for Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC). IBC is a rare but very aggressive type of breast cancer that doesn't form a lump. Instead, the cancer cells block the lymph vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage causes the classic symptoms: redness, swelling (edema), warmth, and often a puckered look to the skin called peau d'orange (like the skin of an orange). If you are given antibiotics for suspected mastitis and it does not get better (or worsens) within 7-10 days, you must return to your doctor and be evaluated for IBC, usually with a skin biopsy.

faqs.question: Why is IBC considered so aggressive? My doctor seems very concerned.
faqs.answer: IBC is aggressive because of its very nature. By the time it's diagnosed (by causing visible skin symptoms), the cancer cells are already in the lymphatic system. This means it has a very high risk of having already spread (metastasized) to distant lymph nodes or other organs. It is almost always diagnosed at Stage III or Stage IV. It also grows very rapidly.

faqs.question: The treatment plan sounds intense: chemo first, then surgery, then radiation. Why in that order?
faqs.answer: This is called neoadjuvant therapy, and it's the standard for IBC. Because the cancer is diffuse (spread throughout the breast and skin) and aggressive, surgery first is not an option; they couldn't get it all. The goal is: 1) Chemotherapy First: To immediately attack the cancer cells everywhere in the body and to shrink the tumor in the breast, making surgery possible. 2) Surgery (Mastectomy): To remove the entire breast and affected lymph nodes. A lumpectomy is not an option for IBC. 3) Radiation Last: To clean up and kill any microscopic cancer cells left behind in the chest wall or skin.

faqs.question: My biopsy came back HER2-positive. What does that mean for my IBC?
faqs.answer: A significant portion of IBC tumors are HER2-positive. This means the cancer cells have too much of a protein called HER2 on their surface, which acts like an on switch, telling the cancer to grow and divide very quickly. While this makes the cancer more aggressive, it's also a good thing in terms of treatment. We have amazing targeted therapy drugs (like Herceptin/Trastuzumab and Perjeta/Pertuzumab) that are given with your chemo. They specifically attack the HER2 protein and are extremely effective at shutting down this type of cancer.

faqs.question: What is peau d'orange and why does my skin look like that?
faqs.answer: Peau d'orange is French for skin of an orange. It's the term for the dimpled, pitted appearance of the skin in IBC. It's caused by the buildup of lymph fluid (edema) in the breast, which makes the skin swell around the hair follicles. The hair follicles themselves are tethered down, so they don't swell, creating the characteristic dimpled look, just like the pores on an orange peel.

faqs.question: What is the actual difference between Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis? My doctor said I have one of them.
faqs.answer: They are the two main types of IBD, but they affect the gut differently. Ulcerative Colitis (UC) affects only the colon (large intestine). It starts at the rectum and spreads upward in a continuous pattern. The inflammation is superficial, affecting only the innermost lining (mucosa). Crohn's Disease can affect any part of the GI tract, from the mouth to the anus. It's often found in skip lesions (a patch of diseased bowel, then a patch of normal bowel) and the inflammation is transmural, meaning it goes through all layers of the bowel wall, which is why it can cause complications like fistulas or strictures.

faqs.question: I'm having bloody diarrhea, urgency, and cramps. Is this just IBS or is it IBD?
faqs.answer: This is a critical distinction. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a functional disorder; it causes cramps and diarrhea, but no physical damage. IBD is an autoimmune disease that causes physical damage to your bowel. The symptoms you're describing, especially bloody diarrhea, are major red flags for IBD. Other alarm symptoms that point away from IBS and toward IBD include weight loss, fever, and waking up at night to have a bowel movement.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to start me on a biologic medicine like Humira or Remicade. How do these work?
faqs.answer: Biologics are a powerful, modern class of drugs for IBD. They are not pills; they are given as an injection or IV infusion. They work by targeting a specific inflammatory messenger (a protein) in your immune system. For example, Humira and Remicade are anti-TNF drugs. They find and neutralize a protein called Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), which is a key driver of the inflammation in your gut. By blocking this one signal, they can turn off the autoimmune attack and allow your bowel to heal.

faqs.question: My Crohn's disease caused a fistula. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is a complication unique to Crohn's. Because the inflammation is transmural (goes through the whole wall), it can form an abnormal tunnel (a fistula) from one loop of your intestine to another, or from your intestine to another organ (like your bladder or skin). For example, a perianal fistula can tunnel from the rectum to the skin near the anus. These are serious and often require a combination of medication (like biologics) and surgery to treat.

faqs.question: Can I control my IBD with diet alone? I don't want to be on medication forever.
faqs.answer: This is a common goal, but for IBD, diet is a supportive therapy, not a primary treatment. Unlike celiac disease (where gluten is the cause), no specific food causes IBD. However, certain foods (like high-fiber, greasy, or spicy foods) can certainly worsen your symptoms during a flare. While some very specific liquid diets (Exclusive Enteral Nutrition) can induce remission in pediatric Crohn's, adults need medication (like 5-ASAs, steroids, or biologics) to control the underlying autoimmune inflammation. You can't diet your way out of an autoimmune attack.

faqs.question: We've been trying for almost a year with no luck. Are we infertile? When should we see a doctor?
faqs.answer: The official medical definition of infertility is the inability to conceive after one year of regular, unprotected intercourse if the woman is under 35. If the woman is 35 or older, the timeline is shortened to six months. If you've hit these milestones, it's time for both partners to see a specialist (a reproductive endocrinologist) for a basic workup.

faqs.question: Is infertility usually a female problem? I'm healthy, so I'm sure it's not me.
faqs.answer: This is a common and harmful misconception. Infertility is not just a female problem. The causes are split roughly into thirds: about one-third of cases are due to female-factor infertility (e.g., ovulation problems, blocked tubes), one-third are due to male-factor infertility (e.g., low sperm count, poor motility), and the final one-third are a combination of both partners' issues or unexplained infertility.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have diminished ovarian reserve. Does that mean I'm in menopause?
faqs.answer: No, it doesn't mean you're in menopause, but it means your egg quantity is lower than expected for your age. Women are born with all the eggs they'll ever have, and this reserve naturally declines. Diminished ovarian reserve (DOR) means your savings account of eggs is running low, which can make it harder to conceive. Your doctor likely checked this with a blood test (AMH level) or an ultrasound (antral follicle count). It doesn't speak to egg quality, just quantity.

faqs.question: What's the difference between IUI and IVF? My doctor mentioned both.
faqs.answer: IUI (Intrauterine Insemination) is a simpler, less-invasive procedure. Washed and concentrated sperm is taken from the male partner (or a donor) and inserted directly into the woman's uterus using a thin catheter, bypassing the cervix. This is often combined with medication to stimulate ovulation. IVF (In Vitro Fertilization) is a multi-step, complex process. The woman takes high-dose medications to grow multiple eggs, which are surgically retrieved. The eggs are then fertilized with sperm in a lab (in vitro = in glass). The resulting embryos grow for 3-5 days before one is transferred back into the uterus.

faqs.question: My husband's semen analysis was bad. What is varicocele and how can it cause infertility?
faqs.answer: A varicocele is the most common correctable cause of male infertility. It's essentially a varicose vein in the scrotum—an enlargement of the veins that drain the testicle. These swollen veins increase the temperature inside the scrotum. The testicles need to be cooler than the rest of the body to produce healthy sperm. This excess heat (and poor circulation) can damage sperm, leading to low sperm count (oligospermia) and poor sperm movement (asthenospermia). It can often be fixed with a minor outpatient surgery.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a virus and bacteria? Why won't my doctor give me antibiotics for my cold?
faqs.answer: This is the most important concept in infectious disease. Bacteria are living, single-celled organisms that can reproduce on their own. They cause bacterial infections like Strep throat, bacterial pneumonia, and UTIs. Antibiotics are drugs that kill bacteria. A Virus is not truly alive; it's just a piece of genetic code (DNA or RNA) in a protein shell. It must invade one of your healthy cells and hijack its machinery to reproduce. Colds, the flu, COVID-19, and chickenpox are all viral infections. Antibiotics have zero effect on viruses. Your doctor won't give them for a cold because they won't work and will only cause side effects and antibiotic resistance.

faqs.question: I keep hearing about antibiotic resistance. How does my taking an antibiotic make the bacteria stronger?
faqs.answer: It's natural selection in real-time. In any bacterial infection, there's a huge population of bacteria. A few of them, by random chance, might have a mutation that makes them naturally resistant to an antibiotic. When you take that antibiotic, it kills all the weak bacteria, but the resistant ones survive. These survivors then multiply, and now you have a new infection where all the bacteria are resistant to that drug. This is why it's so important to only use antibiotics when necessary and to always finish the full prescription.

faqs.question: How does a vaccine work? Does it inject the disease into me?
faqs.answer: A vaccine trains your immune system without making you sick. It introduces a harmless piece of the virus or bacteria (like a spike protein in the COVID vaccine) or a dead or weakened version of the germ. Your immune system sees this invader and builds an army of antibodies and memory cells to fight it. Then, if you are ever exposed to the real, live germ, your immune system already has the memory and the weapons to recognize and kill it immediately, before it can make you sick.

faqs.question: What's the difference between epidemic and pandemic?
faqs.answer: It's a matter of scale. An outbreak is a sudden increase in cases in a small, localized area. An epidemic is when an outbreak spreads over a larger region, like an entire country (the flu epidemic this winter). A pandemic (like pan = all) is when the disease spreads globally, crossing continents and affecting a large number of people worldwide, as we saw with COVID-19.

faqs.question: What is sepsis? My mom got it from a simple UTI.
faqs.answer: Sepsis is not the infection itself; it's your body's overwhelming and life-threatening response to an infection. Sometimes, when your immune system is fighting an infection (like a UTI or pneumonia), it overreacts and starts releasing a flood of inflammatory chemicals into your bloodstream. This widespread inflammation causes your blood pressure to drop, your organs (like kidneys, lungs, and brain) to fail, and blood clots to form. Any infection, even a simple one, can trigger sepsis, which is a medical emergency.

faqs.question: My baby spits up all the time, sometimes hours after a feeding. Is this normal spit-up or is it reflux?
faqs.answer: It's both. Spit-up is reflux. The medical term is gastroesophageal reflux (GER). It's extremely common and normal in infants because the valve (the lower esophageal sphincter) between their stomach and esophagus is still immature and weak. This allows stomach contents (milk and acid) to easily reflux or flow back up. As long as the baby is gaining weight, not in pain, and is otherwise a happy spitter, it's considered normal GER and not a disease.

faqs.question: When does normal reflux (GER) become a disease (GERD)? My baby seems to be in pain.
faqs.answer: It becomes a disease (GERD, Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) when it causes complications. The main signs are: 1) Pain: The baby is extremely fussy, cries during or after feedings, and arches their back as if in pain (this is from the acid burning the esophagus). 2) Poor Weight Gain: The baby is spitting up so much they can't keep enough calories down. 3) Feeding Aversion: The baby starts to refuse the breast or bottle because they associate it with pain. 4) Respiratory Issues: The reflux comes up and gets into their airway, causing a chronic cough, wheezing, or rattling.

faqs.question: What can I do at home to help my baby's reflux? I don't want to use medication.
faqs.answer: Lifestyle changes are the first and most important step. 1) Hold upright: Keep your baby in an upright position (not scrunched in a car seat) for at least 30 minutes after every feeding. 2) Smaller, more frequent feeds: This prevents the stomach from getting too full. 3) Burp often: Burp the baby halfway through the feeding and after. 4) Formula changes: If formula-fed, your doctor might suggest a thickened formula or a hypoallergenic formula, as a milk protein allergy can look identical to reflux.

faqs.question: My doctor suggested silent reflux. My baby doesn't spit up, but he's always coughing, fussy, and has a hoarse voice. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (LPR), or silent reflux. It means the stomach contents are refluxing up the esophagus, past the valve at the top, and spilling over onto the larynx (voice box). Because it doesn't always come all the way out of the mouth, you don't see spit-up. But the acid bathes the delicate voice box, causing inflammation, a hoarse cry, a chronic cough, or a rattling sound in their chest (from inflamed mucus) that isn't pneumonia.

faqs.question: When do babies typically outgrow reflux? I'm so tired of the laundry!
faqs.answer: There's a light at the end of the tunnel! Most babies' reflux peaks around 4-6 months of age. As they start to spend more time upright, as their esophageal sphincter matures, and as they start solid foods (which are heavier and stay down better), the reflux dramatically improves. The vast majority of babies have completely outgrown it by their first birthday.

faqs.question: My baby looks yellow. The nurse said it's jaundice. What causes this?
faqs.answer: Jaundice is the yellowing of the skin and eyes. It's caused by a buildup of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a yellow pigment that's produced when your body breaks down old red blood cells. Normally, the liver processes this bilirubin and excretes it in the stool. Newborns have a double whammy: 1) They have a ton of extra red blood cells from birth that are breaking down fast, creating a lot of bilirubin. 2) Their livers are immature and can't process it all yet. This physiologic (normal) jaundice appears on day 2-3 of life and usually resolves on its own.

faqs.question: My baby's jaundice is from breastfeeding failure. Did I do something wrong?
faqs.answer: This is a poor name for it; it should be called not-enough-breast-milk jaundice. It does not mean your milk is bad! It means the baby isn't getting enough milk in the first few days, often due to a poor latch or delayed milk supply. This causes dehydration and fewer bowel movements. Since bilirubin is pooped out, a baby who isn't pooping enough will reabsorb the bilirubin from their gut back into their blood, making the jaundice worse. The treatment is not to stop breastfeeding, but to fix the feeding (e.g., see a lactation consultant) and feed more often.

faqs.question: The doctor wants to put my baby under bili lights. What is that? Is it safe?
faqs.answer: This is called phototherapy, and it's a very safe and effective treatment. The baby is placed in a bassinet (wearing just a diaper and eye protection) under a special blue-spectrum light. This light is not a tanning light. It works by shining through the skin and changing the shape of the bilirubin molecule. This photo-isomerization makes the bilirubin water-soluble, so the baby's body can excrete it in their urine and bile, bypassing the overworked liver. It's a non-invasive way to flush the bilirubin out quickly.

faqs.question: Why are the doctors so worried about a high bilirubin level? Is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: Yes. While mild jaundice is harmless, extremely high levels of unconjugated bilirubin (the type the liver hasn't processed) are neurotoxic. This bilirubin can cross the blood-brain barrier and deposit in the brain, particularly in the basal ganglia. This can cause a rare but devastating form of permanent brain damage called kernicterus, which leads to hearing loss, cerebral palsy, and developmental delays. This is why all babies are screened and high levels are treated aggressively with phototherapy.

faqs.question: What's the difference between physiologic jaundice and pathologic jaundice?
faqs.answer: Physiologic Jaundice is the normal kind that appears on day 2-3 and fades within 1-2 weeks as the liver matures. Pathologic Jaundice is a sign of an underlying problem. The biggest red flags for this are: 1) Jaundice that appears within the first 24 hours of life. 2) Bilirubin levels that rise very rapidly. 3) Jaundice that lasts longer than 2 weeks. This is often caused by a blood group incompatibility (e.g., Mom is O+ and baby is A+), where Mom's antibodies are hemolyzing (destroying) the baby's red blood cells, creating a massive bilirubin load.

faqs.question: I get this burning pain in my upper stomach, and I feel super full and bloated right after I eat, even just a small meal. Is this indigestion?
faqs.answer: Yes, that is a perfect description of indigestion, which doctors call dyspepsia. The two main symptoms are epigastric pain (pain in your upper abdomen, just below your ribs) and postprandial distress, which is that uncomfortable fullness, bloating, or inability to finish a meal (early satiety). It's a functional disorder, meaning the stomach often looks normal, but it isn't functioning correctly (e.g., it may not be relaxing properly to hold food, or it's hypersensitive).

faqs.question: How is indigestion (dyspepsia) different from heartburn (GERD)?
faqs.answer: They are often confused but are different. Heartburn (GERD) is a reflux problem. It's a burning pain that's behind your breastbone (in your chest/esophagus) and often rises up into your throat, accompanied by a sour, acidic taste (acid regurgitation). It's caused by stomach acid splashing up into your esophagus. Indigestion (Dyspepsia) is a stomach problem. The pain or discomfort is in your upper abdomen (stomach area) and is related to the act of eating itself (feeling too full, bloated, or nauseous), not typically a rising, burning feeling.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to test me for H. pylori. What is that, and what does it have to do with my indigestion?
faqs.answer: Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) is a type of bacteria that can live in the harsh, acidic environment of your stomach. It's a major cause of stomach ulcers. In many people, it doesn't cause ulcers, but it does cause chronic inflammation of the stomach lining (gastritis), which is a primary cause of indigestion/dyspepsia symptoms. Your doctor wants to check for it (with a breath test, stool test, or biopsy) because if you have it, it can be cured with a 2-week course of antibiotics, which could cure your indigestion completely.

faqs.question: Can my stress and anxiety be causing my stomach pain? It seems to get worse when I'm worried.
faqs.answer: Absolutely. This is a classic example of the gut-brain axis. Your gut and brain are in constant communication. Stress and anxiety can physically alter your gut's function. It can increase visceral hypersensitivity (making your stomach nerves over-sensitive to normal stretching), slow down your gastric emptying (making food sit in your stomach longer, causing fullness), and increase acid production. Managing your stress is a key part of managing functional dyspepsia.

faqs.question: I take Advil (ibuprofen) a lot for my headaches. Could that be the problem?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a very common cause. Drugs like ibuprofen, aspirin, and naproxen are NSAIDs (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs). They work by blocking an enzyme, but this enzyme also protects your stomach lining from its own acid. Regular NSAID use can damage this lining, causing inflammation (gastritis), indigestion, and even ulcers. Your doctor will likely tell you to stop the ibuprofen and see if your symptoms improve, and may prescribe a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) like omeprazole to help your stomach heal.

faqs.question: My doctor says I have an incompetent cervix. It sounds so insulting. What does it actually mean?
faqs.answer: It is an older, unfortunate term. The modern, preferred term is cervical insufficiency. It has nothing to do with you as a person. It's a medical diagnosis meaning your cervix (the door at the bottom of your uterus) is not strong enough to stay closed under the weight and pressure of a growing pregnancy. This can cause the cervix to painlessly thin out (efface) and open (dilate) in the second trimester, long before the baby is ready, leading to preterm birth or pregnancy loss.

faqs.question: I had a painless miscarriage in my second trimester. How would I know if this was the cause?
faqs.answer: This is, unfortunately, how it is often diagnosed—after a mid-trimester loss. The classic story of cervical insufficiency is a painless and silent dilation. You don't have contractions, your water doesn't break, you just feel a sudden pressure or see the baby's membranes bulging, often between 16 and 24 weeks. Other risk factors include having had a LEEP procedure or cone biopsy on your cervix in the past, or a D&C that over-dilated your cervix.

faqs.question: I'm pregnant again, and my doctor wants to do a cerclage. What is that?
faqs.answer: A cerclage is a rescue stitch. It's a surgical procedure, usually done between 12-14 weeks, where your OB-GYN places a strong stitch (like a purse string) around your cervix to tie it shut. This stitch acts as a reinforcement, providing the structural support your cervix lacks, to help it stay closed and keep the baby in. The stitch is then clipped and removed in the office around 36-37 weeks, allowing you to go into labor normally.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned progesterone instead of a cerclage. How does a hormone help?
faqs.answer: Vaginal progesterone (a suppository or gel) is another treatment option, particularly for women whose only risk factor is a short cervix (measured on ultrasound) without a prior loss. Progesterone is a pro-gestation (pro-pregnancy) hormone. It's thought to help by keeping the uterus quiet (less irritable), reducing inflammation, and maintaining the firmness of the cervix, making it less likely to thin out and open prematurely.

faqs.question: If I get a cerclage, will I have to be on bed rest for my whole pregnancy?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Decades ago, strict bed rest was recommended, but modern evidence shows it doesn't really help and can actually cause harm (like blood clots and muscle wasting). After a cerclage, your doctor will likely recommend pelvic rest (no sex, nothing in the vagina) and modified activity (e.g., avoiding heavy lifting, strenuous exercise, and prolonged standing), but not necessarily strict bed rest.

faqs.question: My child has these honey-colored crusts around his nose and mouth. The school nurse said it's impetigo. What is that?
faqs.answer: That honey-colored crust is the classic, textbook sign of impetigo. It's a highly contagious bacterial skin infection, usually caused by Staph aureus or Strep pyogenes. It typically starts as a small red blister (vesicle) or pimple that bursts, oozes a little fluid, and then forms that characteristic golden-yellow or honey crust. It's very common in kids and spreads easily.

faqs.question: How did my child get this? Is it from being dirty?
faqs.answer: It's not about being dirty; it's about bacteria getting into the skin. It often starts when there's a small break in the skin (like a cut, a scrape, an insect bite, or even just the raw skin from a runny nose). Bacteria that are normally just on the skin get in that break and start to multiply, causing the infection. It's also very contagious, so kids can get it from close contact with another child who has it or from sharing towels.

faqs.question: My doctor prescribed an antibiotic ointment. Is that enough, or does my son need oral antibiotics?
faqs.answer: For mild, localized impetigo (just a few spots in one area), a prescription-strength antibiotic ointment (like Mupirocin or Bactroban) is the treatment of choice. You gently wash off the crusts with soap and water, then apply the ointment. For more widespread impetigo, or for a more serious type called bullous impetigo (with large blisters), oral antibiotics (like Keflex or amoxicillin) are needed to clear the infection from the inside out.

faqs.question: How long is my child contagious? When can he go back to school?
faqs.answer: Impetigo is highly contagious as long as there are weeping or crusted open sores. The general rule is that a child can return to school or daycare 24 hours after starting effective antibiotic treatment (either oral antibiotics or the prescription ointment). By then, they are no longer considered contagious, even if the sores are still healing.

faqs.question: What is bullous impetigo? My baby has big, floppy blisters, not crusts.
faqs.answer: This is a different form of impetigo, caused only by the Staph aureus bacteria. This specific strain of Staph releases a toxin that causes the top layer of skin (epidermis) to split from the layer below, forming large, floppy blisters (bullae) filled with clear or yellow fluid. When these burst, they leave a red, raw base but don't typically form the thick honey crusts. This form almost always requires oral antibiotics.

faqs.question: My dentist says my wisdom teeth are impacted. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Impacted means the tooth is stuck and cannot erupt (grow) into its normal position. This is usually because there isn't enough room in your jaw. The tooth might be growing in at a severe angle (mesial impaction - a horizontal tooth), or it might be trapped against the tooth in front of it, or stuck completely in the jawbone. These are your third molars, the last teeth to come in.

faqs.question: My wisdom teeth don't hurt. Do I really need to get them taken out?
faqs.answer: This is a common debate. If they are fully impacted (completely encased in bone), not causing any symptoms, and not near a nerve, some surgeons may opt to watch them. However, most impacted wisdom teeth, even painless ones, are recommended for removal. This is because they are a time bomb for future problems. They can decay (get cavities), cause decay in the good molar in front of them (which is very hard to fix), develop cysts or tumors, or get infected.

faqs.question: I have this throbbing pain and bad taste in the back of my mouth, by a wisdom tooth that's halfway in. What's happening?
faqs.answer: You have pericoronitis. This is the most common reason for emergency wisdom tooth removal. The wisdom tooth is partially erupted, meaning a flap of gum tissue (called an operculum) is covering part of the tooth. This flap creates a deep pocket that is impossible to clean, so food and bacteria get trapped under it, causing a painful, swollen, and often pus-filled infection. It's treated with antibiotics and, ultimately, by removing the tooth.

faqs.question: I'm terrified of being awake. Will I be put to sleep for the extraction?
faqs.answer: You almost certainly will be, especially if they are impacted. You have options. 1) Local Anesthetic: Just numbing the area (like for a filling). This is rare for impacted teeth. 2) IV Sedation / Twilight Sleep: This is the most common. An IV line gives you medication that makes you extremely relaxed, sleepy, and you will have no memory of the procedure, but you're technically still conscious and breathing on your own. 3) General Anesthesia: You are completely asleep with a breathing tube, managed by an anesthesiologist. This is used for very difficult or complex cases.

faqs.question: What is dry socket and how can I prevent it?
faqs.answer: Dry socket (alveolar osteitis) is a very painful complication that happens a few days after extraction. After the tooth is pulled, a blood clot forms in the socket (the hole), which is the scaffolding for new bone to grow. A dry socket occurs when this blood clot is dislodged or dissolves too early, leaving the bone and nerves exposed to air, food, and fluids. To prevent it: DO NOT SMOKE. Also, for the first 24-48 hours, do not spit forcefully, do not drink through a straw, and do not rinse vigorously. All these actions create suction that can pull the clot out.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have ITP because my body is eating its own platelets. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: That's a good way to describe it. ITP is an autoimmune disease. For an unknown reason, your immune system mistakenly identifies your own platelets (the tiny blood cells that form clots) as foreign invaders. It creates anti-platelet antibodies that tag your platelets. When these tagged platelets pass through your spleen, your spleen's immune cells (macrophages) see the tags, eat (phagocytose) them, and destroy them. This means your platelets are being destroyed much faster than your bone marrow can make them, leading to a very low platelet count (thrombocytopenia).

faqs.question: I feel fine, but my blood test showed my platelet count is 30,000. Is that dangerous? I'm not bleeding.
faqs.answer: A normal platelet count is 150,000 to 450,000. A count of 30,000 is definitely low (moderate ITP). While you might not be bleeding spontaneously, you are at a very high risk of bleeding if you get injured. The main signs at this level are easy bruising (petechiae and purpura), frequent nosebleeds, or bleeding gums when you brush. The real danger (spontaneous, life-threatening bleeding, like in the brain) is typically at counts below 10,000-20,000. Most doctors will start treatment at a level of 30,000 to be safe.

faqs.question: What is the first-line treatment? My doctor wants to give me high-dose steroids.
faqs.answer: Yes, the first-line treatment is corticosteroids (like Prednisone). This is not an anabolic steroid for muscle-building. It's a powerful anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressant. The high dose stuns your immune system, telling it to calm down and stop making the auto-antibodies that are tagging your platelets. This allows your platelet count to rise. Steroids are usually given for a few weeks and then tapered off. Another first-line option, especially in an emergency, is IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulin), which distracts the spleen.

faqs.question: My child developed ITP right after a virus. Is it permanent?
faqs.answer: ITP in children is a very different disease than in adults. In kids, it's almost always acute and is triggered by a recent viral infection (like a cold or stomach bug). The virus confuses the immune system, which temporarily attacks the platelets. The good news is that in over 80% of children, the ITP resolves completely on its own within 6 months and never comes back. It's often just watched unless the bleeding is severe.

faqs.question: My ITP is chronic. My doctor mentioned splenectomy or Rituximab. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: If your ITP doesn't stay in remission after steroids, it's chronic (this is common in adults). The second-line treatments are very different. A splenectomy (surgical removal of the spleen) is an old, but very effective, cure. It works by removing the factory where your platelets are being destroyed. Rituximab is a biologic medication. It's an antibody that targets and kills the specific B-cells in your immune system that are making the anti-platelet antibodies in the first place. It's a medical splenectomy that can lead to long-term remission without surgery.

faqs.question: I'm convinced I have a serious disease, like cancer or MS. I've been to 5 doctors and all my tests are normal, but I'm not reassured. Am I crazy?
faqs.answer: You are not crazy, but you are suffering. This is the core experience of Illness Anxiety Disorder (formerly hypochondriasis). The disorder is not about the physical symptoms (which are often minor or normal bodily sensations, like a twitch or a headache), but about your interpretation of them. You have a persistent, intense fear of having a serious illness, and this fear persists despite medical reassurance and negative tests. The anxiety itself is the illness.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this and somatic symptom disorder?
faqs.answer: They are similar and overlap, but there's a key difference. In Somatic Symptom Disorder, the person has one or more very real, significant, and distressing physical symptoms (like chronic pain or fatigue) that cause impairment, and they spend an excessive amount of time and energy worrying about those symptoms. In Illness Anxiety Disorder, the person may have no symptoms at all, or very mild ones. The problem is their fear of the idea of being sick (e.g., I'm terrified I might get cancer), not a specific, ongoing physical symptom.

faqs.question: I spend hours every day on Google, looking up my symptoms. Is this cyberchondria part of it?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a primary compulsive behavior of the disorder. It's an attempt to reduce your anxiety, but it actually fuels it. You're reassurance seeking. You go to Google (or your doctor, or a family member) looking for the answer that says you're fine, but you inevitably find one article about a rare disease that matches your symptom, which proves your fear and sends your anxiety skyrocketing, creating a vicious cycle.

faqs.question: I'm the opposite. I'm so scared of what I'll find out that I avoid going to the doctor completely. Is that also part of it?
faqs.answer: Yes. The disorder has two main types: the care-seeking type (who goes to doctors constantly) and the care-avoidant type (who is so terrified of confirming their worst fear that they avoid doctors, checkups, and medical information at all costs). Both behaviors are driven by the same underlying, intense health-related anxiety.

faqs.question: How is this even treated? Do I just take anti-anxiety pills?
faqs.answer: The most effective treatment is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). This therapy directly targets the disorder. It teaches you to: 1) Recognize your catastrophic thinking (e.g., This headache is definitely a brain tumor). 2) Challenge and re-frame those thoughts into more realistic ones. 3) Stop the compulsive behaviors, like Googling symptoms or body scanning (e.g., you will be given response prevention homework to not Google your symptom). Antidepressants (SSRIs) can also be very helpful in turning down the volume of the underlying anxiety, which makes the CBT work even better.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have IgA nephropathy. What is IgA, and what is it doing to my kidneys?
faqs.answer: IgA (Immunoglobulin A) is a normal antibody; it's part of your immune system that lives in your mucous membranes (like your gut and sinuses) and fights off germs. In IgA nephropathy, you produce a defective or abnormal version of this IgA. Your body's immune system sees this defective IgA as a problem and forms immune complexes (clumps of antibodies). These clumps travel through your blood and get trapped in the glomeruli (the tiny, delicate filtering units) of your kidneys. This clogging causes inflammation and scarring, which damages the filters.

faqs.question: The only symptom I have is blood in my urine (pink or cola-colored) whenever I get a cold or stomach bug. Is this related?
faqs.answer: This is the classic, textbook presentation of IgA nephropathy, which is why it's also called synpharyngitic hematuria (meaning with a sore throat). When you get a cold (a pharyngitis) or a GI bug, your body revs up its immune system to fight it, which means it produces a ton of that defective IgA. This wave of IgA overwhelms the kidneys, clogs the filters, and causes immediate inflammation, which allows red blood cells to leak into your urine, making it visibly red or brown. This is often the first sign of the disease.

faqs.question: My urine test also showed proteinuria. Is that more serious than the blood?
faqs.answer: Yes. Finding blood (hematuria) is the clue, but the amount of protein in your urine (proteinuria) is the main indicator of how severe the kidney damage is and how likely it is to progress. Healthy kidney filters never let protein (like albumin) leak through. Protein in the urine means the filters are damaged. The more protein you're leaking, the more damage is happening, and the higher your risk of developing chronic kidney disease and kidney failure over time.

faqs.question: How is this treated? My doctor started me on a blood pressure pill, but my blood pressure is normal.
faqs.answer: The cornerstone of treatment, even with normal blood pressure, is a class of drugs called ACE inhibitors (like Lisinopril) or ARBs (like Losartan). These medications have a special protective effect on the kidneys. They relax the blood vessels inside the kidney filter, which lowers the pressure within the filter. This calms down the filter and significantly reduces the amount of protein you leak. This is the single most important thing to do to slow down the disease. If your proteinuria is still high, your doctor may add steroids (like prednisone) or other immunosuppressants.

faqs.question: Is this the same as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)? My nephew had that.
faqs.answer: They are very, very similar and are considered sister diseases. Both are caused by the exact same defective IgA getting trapped in blood vessels. The only difference is where it gets trapped. In IgA nephropathy (Berger's), the IgA only traps in the kidneys. In Henoch-Schönlein purpura (now called IgA Vasculitis), the IgA traps in the kidneys, plus the skin (causing a purple rash, purpura), the joints (causing arthritis), and the gut (causing abdominal pain). HSP is essentially systemic IgA nephropathy.

faqs.question: My dentist saw a dark spot on my X-ray near the root of my tooth. He said it's a periapical cyst. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is the most common type of jaw cyst. It's almost always caused by a dead tooth. When a tooth's nerve dies (from a deep cavity or trauma), the dead tissue inside becomes infected. Your body's immune system walls off this infection at the apex (the tip) of the tooth's root, creating a fluid-filled sac or cyst. The dark spot on the X-ray is the bone that has been eaten away by this cyst as it grows. It's treated with a root canal or by extracting the dead tooth.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a tumor and a cyst in the jaw?
faqs.answer: A cyst is a sac or capsule that is lined with skin-like (epithelial) cells and is typically filled with fluid or a cheesy material (like keratin). It grows by inflating with fluid, which puts pressure on the bone and erodes it from the inside. A tumor (or neoplasm) is a solid mass of abnormal, new cells that are actively growing. Both are lesions, but a cyst is a fluid-filled sac, and a tumor is a solid tissue growth. Both can be benign (non-cancerous) or, rarely, malignant (cancerous).

faqs.question: I was diagnosed with an ameloblastoma. My surgeon said it's benign but locally aggressive. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is a key concept. Ameloblastoma is the most common benign tumor of the jaw. Benign means it will not metastasize (spread) to your lungs or other parts of your body, so it won't kill you. However, it is locally aggressive (or locally invasive), meaning it grows relentlessly like a root into the surrounding jawbone, destroying it. Because it's so invasive, it can't just be scooped out. It has a very high recurrence rate unless it's removed with wide margins, meaning the surgeon has to take out the tumor plus a cuff of normal, healthy bone around it to get all the roots.

faqs.question: My oral surgeon wants to remove my impacted wisdom tooth because of a dentigerous cyst. Why?
faqs.answer: A dentigerous cyst is the second most common type of jaw cyst. It's a developmental cyst that forms around the crown (the top) of an unerupted or impacted tooth (most often a wisdom tooth). The fluid-filled sac is attached to the neck of the tooth. These cysts are almost always benign, but they must be removed because they can grow very large (sometimes hollowing out a large portion of your jaw), which weakens the bone and can damage adjacent, healthy teeth. The treatment is to remove the cyst and the impacted tooth it's attached to.

faqs.question: I have this hard, bony lump on the roof of my mouth. It's been there for years. Is it cancer?
faqs.answer: It is almost certainly not cancer. If it's in the midline of your hard palate (roof of your mouth) and is rock hard, it's a torus palatinus. If it's on the inside of your lower jaw (by your tongue), it's a torus mandibularis. These tori are very common, completely harmless, benign growths of new, dense bone. They are not tumors. They only need to be removed if they get so large that they interfere with speaking, eating, or (most commonly) getting a denture to fit.

faqs.question: My 4-year-old's knee is swollen and stiff, especially in the morning, but he doesn't complain of much pain. Could this be arthritis? I thought only old people get that.
faqs.answer: Yes, kids can get arthritis, but it's an autoimmune disease, not the wear-and-tear (osteoarthritis) that older adults get. This is called Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA). What you're describing is a classic sign of the most common type (oligoarticular JIA). The morning stiffness is a hallmark. The joint is stiff and sore after a period of rest, but it loosens up as the child starts to move. It's often oligoarticular (meaning few joints, 1-4), with a large joint like the knee being the most common.

faqs.question: What does idiopathic mean? Did I do something to cause this?
faqs.answer: You did nothing to cause this. Idiopathic means we don't know the exact trigger. We know it's an autoimmune disease: the child's immune system gets confused and mistakenly attacks the synovium (the lining of their own joints), causing inflammation, swelling, and stiffness. The trigger for this immune confusion is thought to be a combination of genetic predisposition and an environmental factor (like a virus), but the exact cause is unknown.

faqs.question: My child's rheumatologist is sending him to an eye doctor. What do his eyes have to do with his joints?
faqs.answer: This is critically important. A specific subset of JIA (especially the oligoarticular type, in girls, with a positive ANA blood test) has a very high risk of developing a silent but serious eye inflammation called uveitis. It's silent because it causes no pain and no redness. If it's not caught, the inflammation can cause cataracts, glaucoma, and permanent vision loss. Your child must have regular (e.g., every 3-6 months) checkups with an ophthalmologist (an eye MD) so they can look inside the eye with a slit lamp to catch this inflammation early.

faqs.question: What's the difference between using Advil and a biologic like Enbrel or Humira for JIA?
faqs.answer: NSAIDs (like Advil/ibuprofen or Aleve/naproxen) are symptom treatments. They are anti-inflammatories that reduce the pain and swelling, but they do not stop the underlying autoimmune disease from damaging the joint. Biologics (like Enbrel or Humira) are DMARDs (Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drugs). They are powerful medications (often injections) that target the specific immune system messengers (like TNF-alpha) that are causing the inflammation. They are used to stop the disease in its tracks, prevent permanent joint damage, and put the disease into remission.

faqs.question: My teenager was just diagnosed with systemic JIA. His symptoms started with a high, spiking fever and a rash. Is that still arthritis?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a rare, but very different and more serious, type of JIA, also called Still's Disease. Unlike other JIA types, it doesn't just affect the joints. It's a systemic (body-wide) inflammatory disease. It typically presents not with joint swelling, but with high, spiking fevers (often once a day, in the evening) accompanied by a salmon-colored evanescent rash (it comes and goes with the fever). The joint pain and swelling (arthritis) often appear weeks or months after the fevers start.

faqs.question: I have this red, incredibly itchy rash in my groin and on my inner thighs. It's ring-shaped with a raised border. Is this jock itch?
faqs.answer: That is the perfect, classic description of jock itch, which has the medical name tinea cruris. It is a fungal infection of the skin, caused by the same type of dermatophyte fungus that causes ringworm and athlete's foot. The ring-shaped (annular) rash with a scaly, active border is its hallmark. It's common in athletes because the fungus thrives in warm, moist, dark areas (like the groin, under sweaty athletic gear).

faqs.question: How did I get this? I'm pretty clean.
faqs.answer: It's not about cleanliness, it's about moisture. The fungus is everywhere. It can be spread from person to person (sharing towels) or, most commonly, it can spread from your own feet. Many people have athlete's foot (tinea pedis) without knowing it. When you're drying off or putting on your underwear, the towel or underwear can drag the fungus from your feet up to your groin, where it finds a perfect, warm, moist environment to grow.

faqs.question: I tried using cortisone cream on it, and it got way worse. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a critical mistake. Hydrocortisone is a steroid cream. It calms down inflammation and stops the itch, but it cripples your skin's local immune system. This allows the fungus (which is the actual cause) to grow completely unchecked. The rash will look less red and feel less itchy for a day or two, but it will be spreading rapidly underneath. You must use an anti-fungal cream (like clotrimazole, miconazole, or terbinafine).

faqs.question: How do I tell the difference between jock itch and just chafing?
faqs.answer: Chafing is a friction burn. It's just raw, irritated, red skin (like a strawberry scrape) caused by skin rubbing on skin or skin rubbing on clothing. It usually feels sore or stinging, and it doesn't have that classic ring-shaped or scaly border. Jock Itch is a fungal infection. It is intensely itchy and has a very distinct, advancing scaly border. A key clue is that jock itch (tinea cruris) almost never involves the scrotum or penis; it stays on the groin crease and inner thighs. A yeast (Candida) infection will involve the scrotum.

faqs.question: How do I get rid of it and keep it from coming back?
faqs.answer: To get rid of it, buy an over-the-counter anti-fungal cream (terbinafine/Lamisil is often fastest). Apply it twice a day, and keep using it for 1-2 weeks even after the rash disappears, to kill the spores. To prevent it: 1) Dry your groin last. Dry your body, then your feet, then get a new, clean towel for your groin. 2) Put your socks on before your underwear (this prevents dragging foot fungus up). 3) Wear loose-fitting, moisture-wicking boxer shorts (not tight briefs). 4) Don't sit around in sweaty gym clothes.

faqs.question: I just flew from New York to London, and I feel off—tired during the day, wide awake at 3 AM. Is this just fatigue from the flight?
faqs.answer: It's more than just fatigue; it's jet lag disorder. Your body has an internal 24-hour master clock (your circadian rhythm) in your brain, which is synced to your home time zone (New York). It tells you when to be sleepy and when to be alert. Your body clock is still on New York time, but the external clock (the sun in London) is 5 hours ahead. This mismatch is what causes the classic symptoms: insomnia, daytime sleepiness, foggy-headedness, and even gut problems, as all your body's clocks are out of sync.

faqs.question: Why is flying east (like to Europe) so much harder than flying west (like to California)?
faqs.answer: This is a real phenomenon. It's because your body's natural internal clock is actually slightly longer than 24 hours (e.g., ~24.2 hours). This means your body has a natural tendency to want to drift later—to stay up later and wake up later. Flying west (phase delay) goes along with this. It's easy to stay up later to match California time. Flying east (phase advance) fights your natural clock. You are forced to go to bed earlier and wake up earlier than your body wants to, which is much, much harder to do.

faqs.question: How can light help me adjust? My friend said I need to get morning light.
faqs.answer: Light (especially sunlight) is the single most powerful signal that resets your internal master clock. The timing of the light is critical. To advance your clock (after flying east), you need bright light exposure in the morning (at your new destination). This tells your brain it's morning, wake up now, and helps you shift your clock earlier. To delay your clock (after flying west), you want to get bright light in the evening and avoid light in the morning. This tells your brain it's not bedtime yet, stay up later.

faqs.question: What about melatonin? When should I take it?
faqs.answer: Melatonin is the hormone of darkness; it's the other key signal for your clock. It doesn't knock you out like a sleeping pill; it just tells your brain it's nighttime. When flying east (e.g., to London), you want to advance your clock (go to bed earlier). Taking a small dose (0.5mg - 1mg) of melatonin in the early evening (e.g., 7 PM London time) tricks your brain into thinking night has come early, helping you shift. When flying west, you'd take it at your normal bedtime (e.g., 10 PM California time) to help you get to sleep.

faqs.question: How long will this last? And do jet lag pills work?
faqs.answer: The general rule of thumb is that it takes about one day per time zone crossed to fully adjust. So, a 5-hour time difference might take you 5 days to feel 100% normal. There are no jet lag pills that cure it, other than short-term sleeping aids (like Ambien) to force you to sleep. These don't fix your clock; they just mask the insomnia. The only way to cure it is to reset your clock using the two tools: timed light exposure and timed melatonin.

faqs.question: I just got stung by a jellyfish! It hurts and is tracking up my arm. What should I do right now?
faqs.answer: 1) Get out of the water. 2) Rinse with saltwater (or vinegar, if you know it's a Box jellyfish, but saltwater is always safe). DO NOT use fresh water (like from a shower or water bottle). Fresh water will shock the stinging cells (nematocysts) that are still on your skin and cause them to all fire at once, making the pain much worse. 3) Pluck off tentacles: Use tweezers or a gloved hand to gently lift off any visible tentacles. Don't rub or scrape. 4) Heat, not ice: Once the stingers are off, immerse the area in hot water (as hot as you can stand without burning, ~110-113°F) for 20-40 minutes. This denatures the protein in the venom and is the most effective pain relief.

faqs.question: My friend said I should pee on it. Is that true?
faqs.answer: No! That is a complete myth and can make it worse. Urine is not sterile and is usually hypotonic (closer to fresh water). Like fresh water, it can cause the nematocysts (stingers) to fire, releasing more venom. Stick to saltwater or (if available) vinegar, followed by hot water immersion.

faqs.question: Why shouldn't I scrape it with a credit card or rub it with sand?
faqs.answer: This used to be common advice, but it's now not recommended. The jellyfish leaves thousands of microscopic, spring-loaded stinging cells on your skin, not all of which have fired. When you scrape or rub the area, you are applying pressure that can trigger all these unfired cells to discharge their venom, leading to a second wave of intense pain. The best method is to rinse and gently pluck the visible tentacles.

faqs.question: The sting happened yesterday, and now I have an itchy, red rash. What's that?
faqs.answer: This is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction. The initial pain was from the venom. The rash you have now is an allergic reaction (a form of contact dermatitis) to the proteins in the venom. It's very common for it to appear 24-48 hours later. You can treat this delayed rash with over-the-counter 1% hydrocortisone cream and oral antihistamines (like Benadryl or Zyrtec) to help with the itching.

faqs.question: When should I go to the ER? I'm feeling nauseous and short of breath.
faqs.answer: Go to the ER immediately. Most jellyfish stings are painful but harmless. However, systemic (body-wide) symptoms are a sign of a severe envenomation or a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis). Red flag symptoms that require an ER visit are: difficulty breathing, wheezing, chest tightness, nausea or vomiting, muscle cramps, feeling faint or dizzy, or severe pain that isn't relieved by hot water. This is especially true if you were stung by a Box jellyfish or Irukandji (in Australia/Pacific).

faqs.question: I have these purple, bruise-like spots on my legs that don't hurt and don't go away. My doctor is testing me for HIV. What's the connection?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of AIDS-related (epidemic) Kaposi Sarcoma (KS). KS is a type of cancer that forms from the cells lining blood and lymph vessels. It is caused by a virus called Human Herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi Sarcoma-associated Herpesvirus (KSHV). This virus is fairly rare, but in a healthy person, it usually does nothing. However, in someone with a severely weakened immune system—most commonly from untreated HIV/AIDS—this virus wakes up and causes these purple, red, or brown skin lesions (tumors) to grow.

faqs.question: So is KS a cancer or an infection?
faqs.answer: It's both, which is what makes it unique. It is caused by an oncogenic (cancer-causing) virus (HHV-8). The virus infects the endothelial cells and reprograms them to multiply, forming the cancerous tumors. But the driver of the cancer is the infection, and the reason the infection takes hold is the immunodeficiency (the low CD4 T-cell count from AIDS). This is why the best treatment for AIDS-related KS is not chemo, but antiretroviral therapy (HAART). By treating the HIV, the immune system recovers, which allows it to get the HHV-8 virus back under control, and the KS lesions often shrink and disappear on their own.

faqs.question: I'm an older man of Mediterranean descent, I don't have HIV, but I have these same spots on my ankles. Is it still KS?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is called Classic (or Mediterranean) Kaposi Sarcoma. This is a rare, much less aggressive form of the disease. It's still caused by the HHV-8 virus, but it's not related to HIV. It occurs in older men (usually 60+) of Mediterranean, Jewish, or Eastern European descent. It is very slow-growing (indolent), usually stays confined to the lower legs and ankles, and is not life-threatening. It's often just watched or treated with local radiation.

faqs.question: My KS is in my lungs and stomach, not just my skin. How did it get there?
faqs.answer: This is visceral (internal organ) KS, and it's a very serious complication of AIDS-related KS. The lesions can grow on the lining of your gastrointestinal (GI) tract (stomach, intestines) or your lungs. GI involvement can cause internal bleeding or blockages. Pulmonary (lung) KS is the most dangerous form. The lesions in the airways can cause a severe cough, shortness of breath, or coughing up blood. This visceral disease requires immediate HAART (HIV therapy) and often systemic chemotherapy as well.

faqs.question: I just had a kidney transplant, and now I'm developing KS. Is this related to my anti-rejection drugs?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. This is the third type, called Iatrogenic (or Transplant-related) KS. The anti-rejection medications you take (immunosuppressants) are designed to weaken your immune system so you don't reject your new kidney. If you were already a silent carrier of the HHV-8 virus, this immunosuppression allows the virus to wake up and cause KS, just as it does in AIDS. The treatment is often to reduce or change your immunosuppressive medications, which allows your immune system to strengthen and fight off the HHV-8.

faqs.question: My son is 14 and has developed a hunchback look. His posture is terrible. Is he just slouching or is it something else?
faqs.answer: It could be something more. While postural kyphosis (from slouching) is common, a structural kyphosis is a real problem. The most common type in teenage boys is Scheuermann's Kyphosis. This is not just bad posture. It's a structural deformity where, for unknown reasons, several of the vertebrae (the bricks of the spine) grow into a wedge shape instead of a rectangular shape. This wedging in the upper back forces the spine into a rigid, fixed hunchback that the teen cannot straighten out, even if they try.

faqs.question: How can I tell if my son's hunchback is postural or Scheuermann's?
faqs.answer: Here's the key test: have your son lie flat on his stomach on the floor. A postural kyphosis (from slouching) is flexible. It will completely disappear when he lies down. A structural kyphosis (like Scheuermann's) is rigid. The hump or hunch will still be visible when he's lying flat. A side-view X-ray is the only way to confirm the diagnosis by measuring the wedging of the vertebrae.

faqs.question: My grandmother is stooped over and seems to be shrinking. Is this the same thing?
faqs.answer: No, this is a different type, and it's the most common cause of kyphosis in older adults, especially postmenopausal women. This is Osteoporotic Kyphosis. It's caused by osteoporosis (weak, brittle bones). The vertebrae in the front of the spine become so weak that they fracture and collapse under the normal weight of the body. These compression fractures (which can be painless) cause the bricks to become wedged, and the spine falls forward into that classic dowager's hump.

faqs.question: My son's curve is severe. The doctor is recommending a brace. How will that help?
faqs.answer: For moderate-to-severe Scheuermann's kyphosis in a teen who is still growing, a brace (like a Milwaukee or Boston brace) is the main treatment. The brace is not passive. It's an active brace that is custom-molded to force the teen to extend their spine against the brace's pads. This postural correction (combined with physical therapy) puts pressure on the vertebrae, encouraging them to grow more normally (less wedged) as the teen finishes their growth spurt. It's worn 16-23 hours a day.

faqs.question: What does surgery for kyphosis involve? It sounds terrifying.
faqs.answer: Surgery is only for very severe, rigid curves (e.g., >75-80 degrees) that are causing pain or lung problems. It's a major operation called a posterior spinal fusion with instrumentation. The surgeon makes an incision down the back, re-aligns the spine, and then fuses the wedged vertebrae together into one, solid block of bone using instrumentation (metal rods and screws). This fusion holds the spine in its new, straighter position permanently.

faqs.question: I have this sharp pain behind my kneecap (patella) that's worse when I go down stairs or sit for a long time. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome (PFPS), also known as runner's knee. It's not a joint problem; it's a tracking problem. Your kneecap (patella) is supposed to track smoothly in a groove at the end of your thighbone (femur). In PFPS, muscle imbalances (e.g., weak VMO quad muscle or weak hips/glutes) cause the kneecap to mal-track and rub against the side of the groove, which inflames the cartilage under the kneecap. Going down stairs (a loaded, flexed position) is what irritates it the most.

faqs.question: I'm a runner, and I have a sharp, stabbing pain on the outside (lateral side) of my knee, but only after I've been running for 10 minutes.
faqs.answer: That is almost certainly Iliotibial (IT) Band Syndrome. The IT band is a long, thick strap of fascia that runs from your hip down the outside of your thigh and attaches to your shinbone (tibia) just past your knee. When you run, this band repeatedly snaps or rubs back and forth over a bony prominence on the outside of your knee (the lateral femoral epicondyle). This friction causes intense inflammation and a sharp, stabbing pain, usually at the exact same point in every run.

faqs.question: My knee locks and catches, and I have pain right on the joint line on the inside (medial side). Did I tear something?
faqs.answer: That is highly suspicious for a Meniscus Tear. The meniscus is a C-shaped piece of rubbery cartilage (like a shock absorber) that sits between your thighbone (femur) and your shinbone (tibia). The medial (inner) meniscus is torn most often. When you twist on a bent knee (a pivot injury), you can tear a flap of this cartilage. This flap can then catch or get stuck in the joint, causing the locking, catching, or popping sensation. Pain right on the joint line is the #1 clue.

faqs.question: I'm 60, and my knee is so stiff and achy in the morning, and it grinds when I use the stairs. Is this just old age?
faqs.answer: This is Osteoarthritis (OA), the wear-and-tear arthritis. It's not an autoimmune disease; it's a mechanical problem.
