faqs.answer: This is a common and miserable symptom of certain liver diseases, especially Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC). Your liver is supposed to produce bile and send it to your gut. When the tiny bile ducts inside your liver are damaged, bile (which contains bile salts or bile acids) can't flow. It backs up and spills into your bloodstream. These bile salts then get deposited in your skin, which is what causes the intense, maddening itch (pruritus).

faqs.question: I have cirrhosis from hepatitis C, and my doctor is screening me for liver cancer. How is this screening done?
faqs.answer: This is the standard of care for anyone with cirrhosis, as it's the #1 risk factor. Screening is done with an abdominal ultrasound (to look for any new lesions or nodules) and a blood test for alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (a protein marker that can be high in liver cancer). This is typically done every 6 months. This surveillance is critical because it can catch a tumor when it's small and still curable.

faqs.question: My doctor said my liver tumor is ablatable. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Ablation is a non-surgical way to destroy a small tumor. If your tumor is small (usually < 3-4 cm) and you're not a good candidate for surgical removal (due to poor liver function), this is a great option. A specialist (interventional radiologist) will use a CT scan to guide a needle-like probe directly into the tumor. Then, they use either radiofrequency (RFA) (heat) or microwave (MWA) (also heat) to cook and kill the cancer cells, leaving the rest of the liver intact.

faqs.question: What's the difference between primary liver cancer and metastatic liver cancer?
faqs.answer: This is a crucial distinction. Primary liver cancer (like Hepatocellular Carcinoma or HCC) starts in the liver cells. It's often caused by underlying liver disease like cirrhosis. Metastatic liver cancer (or liver mets) is cancer that started somewhere else (like the colon, breast, or lung) and spread to the liver. They are completely different diseases, and the treatment is based on the original cancer (e.g., you treat colon cancer in the liver with colon cancer drugs, not liver cancer drugs).

faqs.question: I'm on the liver transplant list. Will they still do it even though I have cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes. In fact, a liver transplant is one of the best curative options for early-stage liver cancer (HCC) in a patient with bad cirrhosis. It cures both the cancer and the underlying liver disease at the same time. You must meet very strict Milan criteria (e.g., one tumor < 5 cm, or up to 3 tumors all < 3 cm) to ensure the cancer hasn't spread and that the transplant will be successful.

faqs.question: My father's liver cancer is unresectable and he's starting on immunotherapy. How does this work?
faqs.answer: For advanced liver cancer that can't be removed, immunotherapy (often a combination like Tecentriq and Avastin) has become the new standard of care, replacing older pills. These IV drugs work by taking the brakes off your body's own immune system, allowing your T-cells to see and attack the liver cancer. It's often more effective and better tolerated than the older targeted therapy pills like sorafenib.

faqs.question: I'm pregnant and I'm terrified of listeria. What foods are genuinely high-risk?
faqs.answer: Your concern is valid, as listeria is particularly dangerous during pregnancy. The highest-risk foods are those that are processed, refrigerated, and eaten without further cooking. This includes: deli meats and hot dogs (unless heated until steaming hot), refrigerated pâtés or meat spreads, unpasteurized milk and soft cheeses (like brie, feta, queso fresco, unless the label confirms it's made with pasteurized milk), and refrigerated smoked seafood (like lox).

faqs.question: I ate a sandwich with deli meat yesterday and now I feel fine. Am I in the clear?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, not yet. Listeria has an unusually long incubation period. While you can get symptoms in 1-2 days, it can take anywhere from 1 to 4 weeks (or even up to 70 days) after eating the contaminated food for symptoms to appear. You are likely fine, but you need to be aware of any flu-like symptoms (fever, muscle aches) for the next several weeks.

faqs.question: Why is listeria so much more dangerous for pregnant women? Will it hurt me?
faqs.answer: Listeria is one of the few germs that can cross the placental barrier. For you, the pregnant mother, it may just cause a mild, flu-like illness (fever, muscle aches, fatigue). But for the developing baby, the infection can be devastating, leading to miscarriage, stillbirth, or severe infection in the newborn (neonatal sepsis or meningitis). This is why we treat any suspected case in pregnancy so aggressively.

faqs.question: How is listeria different from regular food poisoning like Salmonella?
faqs.answer: Two big ways. First, listeria is a psychrophile, meaning it can grow and multiply at refrigerator temperatures where other bacteria just sit dormant. This is why refrigerated, ready-to-eat foods are the risk. Second, while Salmonella causes gut-focused illness (diarrhea, vomiting), listeria causes an invasive illness. It gets out of the gut and into the bloodstream (sepsis) or brain (meningitis), which is far more deadly.

faqs.question: My elderly father is suddenly very confused and has a stiff neck. Could this be listeria?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is an emergency. In older adults (over 65) or anyone with a weakened immune system, the most common presentation of listeriosis is meningitis (infection of the brain lining). The classic signs are fever, headache, stiff neck, and confusion or a change in alertness. You need to take him to the emergency room immediately. They will likely perform a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to check for it.

faqs.question: I was diagnosed with a well-differentiated liposarcoma in my thigh. My doctor called it a low-grade tumor. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Well-differentiated is good news. It means the cancer cells look very similar to normal fat cells and are slow-growing (low-grade). This type is the least aggressive and has a very low risk of spreading (metastasizing). The main treatment is surgery to remove it with wide, clear margins (taking a cuff of normal tissue around it). The main risk is that it can come back locally (in the same spot) years later.

faqs.question: I found a deep lump in my abdomen (retroperitoneum) and it's a liposarcoma. Why is the location such a big deal?
faqs.answer: The location (retroperitoneum, which is the deep part of your abdomen behind your organs) is the biggest challenge with liposarcoma. These tumors can grow silently for years, becoming absolutely massive before they cause symptoms (like a full belly or back pain). The main problem is surgery. It's extremely difficult for a surgeon to remove the entire tumor with clear margins because it's wrapped around critical organs, nerves, and blood vessels. This leads to a very high rate of local recurrence.

faqs.question: My tumor was dedifferentiated. How is that different from a well-differentiated one?
faqs.answer: Dedifferentiated means the tumor has changed. Part of it is still a low-grade, well-differentiated liposarcoma, but another part has progressed into a much more aggressive, high-grade sarcoma that looks nothing like fat. These tumors are much more dangerous and have a higher risk of metastasizing (spreading to the lungs). This is why they are treated more aggressively, sometimes with radiation or chemotherapy in addition to surgery.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a liposarcoma and a regular lipoma?
faqs.answer: A lipoma is a completely benign (non-cancerous) growth of normal fat cells. It's usually soft, moveable, and just under the skin. A liposarcoma is a malignant (cancerous) tumor. It's typically deep (in the muscle of the thigh or in the abdomen), firm, and not moveable. A regular lipoma cannot turn into a liposarcoma; they are two totally separate things from the start.

faqs.question: My sarcoma is in my leg. Why is my doctor ordering a CT scan of my chest?
faqs.answer: This is a standard and essential staging scan. Sarcomas, including high-grade liposarcomas, have a tendency to spread hematogenously (through the bloodstream). The first and most common place they land and set up new tumors (metastases) is in the lungs. Your chest CT is to make 100% sure the cancer has not already spread to your lungs, as this would completely change the treatment plan.

faqs.question: I have this soft, squishy, moveable lump under the skin on my back. My doctor says it's just a lipoma but should I be worried?
faqs.answer: No, you shouldn't be worried. A lipoma is the single most common benign soft tissue tumor. It's just a harmless, slow-growing collection of normal fat cells encapsulated in a thin fibrous capsule. The soft, squishy, moveable part is the classic description. They are not cancerous and cannot turn into cancer (liposarcoma), which is a completely different, deeper, and firmer tumor.

faqs.question: My lipoma doesn't hurt, but it's gotten bigger and I hate how it looks in a t-shirt. Can I have it removed?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. The two main reasons for removing a lipoma are cosmetic (you don't like how it looks) or comfort (it's in a spot where it gets irritated, like on your belt line or bra strap). Removal is a very simple, in-office procedure. The doctor will numb the area, make a small incision, pop the lipoma out, and put in a few stitches. It's very quick and effective.

faqs.question: I have dozens of these lumps all over my arms and torso. Some of them are painful. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds less like a single lipoma and more like a condition called familial multiple lipomatosis, which is a genetic tendency to form many lipomas. When the lipomas are painful, it might be a related condition called Dercum's disease or adiposis dolorosa (painful fat syndrome). You should see a dermatologist to get a proper diagnosis for this.

faqs.question: My doctor said we can just watch it. How do we know it won't turn into something bad later?
faqs.answer: We know because the natural history of a lipoma is to be benign. They are not pre-cancerous. Watching it is the standard medical approach for 99% of lipomas. If the lump is soft, slow-growing, and has a classic appearance on an ultrasound (it just looks like fat), there is no medical need to remove it. A liposarcoma (cancer) would look very different on a scan and feel much firmer and deeper.

faqs.question: Is it true that liposuction can be used to remove a lipoma?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is an option, particularly for larger lipomas in cosmetically sensitive areas. Instead of a long incision, a surgeon can make a very small hole, insert a liposuction cannula, and suck the fat out. The advantage is a much smaller scar. The disadvantage is that it's harder to be certain you got the entire capsule, so the risk of it growing back (recurrence) might be slightly higher than with traditional excision.

faqs.question: I have a sore on my lower lip that just won't heal. It's been there for two months and sometimes bleeds. Is this lip cancer?
faqs.answer: This is the classic warning sign and you must get it checked by a dermatologist or an ENT (ear, nose, throat) doctor immediately. A non-healing ulcer, a persistent scab, a white or red patch, or a lump on the lip (especially the lower lip) that lasts more than 2-3 weeks is the primary symptom of lip cancer (which is a type of oral/mouth cancer).

faqs.question: My dad worked outdoors his whole life and now has lip cancer. Is it from the sun?
faqs.answer: Yes, almost certainly. The vast majority of lip cancers (over 90%) occur on the lower lip. This is because, unlike the upper lip which is shaded by the nose, the lower lip gets chronic, direct sun exposure. This UV radiation damage is the #1 risk factor. Tobacco use (smoking and chewing) is the other major cause, and the two together have a synergistic, very high-risk effect.

faqs.question: What's the difference between lip cancer and just a cold sore?
faqs.answer: It's a huge difference. A cold sore (herpes simplex) is a virus. It tingles/burns, forms a blister, then crusts and heals completely in 7-14 days. Lip cancer (squamous cell carcinoma) is a growth. It's a persistent lesion (like an ulcer or a scaly patch) that does not heal and slowly gets larger over weeks and months.

faqs.question: My biopsy came back as squamous cell carcinoma in situ. What does in situ mean?
faqs.answer: In situ means in its original place. This is the earliest, most curable stage of cancer (Stage 0). It means the abnormal cells are only in the very top layer of the skin (the epidermis) and have not invaded into the deeper tissues. It's essentially pre-cancer or pre-invasive cancer and can be cured with a simple procedure to remove that top layer.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to do Mohs surgery to remove my lip cancer. What is that?
faqs.answer: Mohs surgery is a specialized surgical technique that is perfect for skin cancers on the face and lips. Instead of cutting a wide margin all at once, the surgeon removes a very thin layer of the visible cancer and immediately takes it to an in-office lab. They map it and check 100% of the edges under a microscope. If they see any roots left, they go back only in that exact spot and take another thin layer. They repeat this until the margins are 100% clear. This gives the highest cure rate while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue, which is critical for your lip.

faqs.question: I'm a postmenopausal woman and I have intense itching and tearing of my vulvar skin. My doctor said lichen sclerosus. Is this an STD?
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. Lichen sclerosus (LS) is not an infection and it is not contagious in any way. It's a chronic, inflammatory autoimmune skin condition where your own immune system is attacking the skin, particularly in the genital (vulvar and anal) area. This attack makes the skin thin, white, crinkly (like cigarette paper), and very fragile, leading to the intense itching (pruritus) and tearing.

faqs.question: My doctor prescribed a super-potent steroid ointment (Clobetasol) for my vulva. Is it safe to use such a strong steroid there?
faqs.answer: Yes. Not only is it safe, it is the gold standard and only effective treatment. This is a case where you must use the ultra-potent steroid to turn off the autoimmune attack. Using it as prescribed (often daily for a few weeks, then tapering to a maintenance dose 1-2 times a week) is critical. Untreated, the inflammation will cause permanent scarring, loss of the labia, and fusing over the clitoris, which is irreversible. The steroid prevents this.

faqs.question: Does lichen sclerosus increase my risk of cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes, unfortunately, it does. Women with vulvar lichen sclerosus have a small but significant (about 3-5%) increased risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva over their lifetime. This is another critical reason to use the steroid cream, as controlling the chronic inflammation is thought to reduce this risk. It also means you must have a yearly exam by your gynecologist or dermatologist to check for any new lumps, sores, or thickened patches that might need a biopsy.

faqs.question: Can men get lichen sclerosus? My husband has a white patch on his penis.
faqs.answer: Yes, men can get it, though it's much less common. In men, it's sometimes called balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO). It causes a whitish, scarred, tight ring of skin on the head of the penis (glans) and foreskin. It is the most common cause of phimosis (an inability to retract the foreskin) in adult men and can cause problems with urination and erections. Treatment is also with high-potency steroid creams.

faqs.question: I'm so miserable and the itching won't stop. Will this ever go away?
faqs.answer: Lichen sclerosus is a chronic for life condition, and there is no cure. However, it is highly controllable. The goal of treatment is remission. With the diligent use of your steroid ointment, the itching should stop completely, the skin should become stronger, and the disease should go dormant. You will then use a maintenance dose of the ointment for life to keep it in remission and prevent flares and future scarring.

faqs.question: I have these incredibly itchy, purple, flat-topped bumps on my wrists and ankles. What is this?
faqs.answer: That is the absolute classic description of cutaneous lichen planus. The 4 P's are often used: Purple, Polygonal (angled), Pruritic (itchy), Papules (bumps). It's an autoimmune condition where your T-cells (a type of immune cell) attack your skin cells. It often appears on the flexor surfaces (like the inner wrists) and ankles. It is not contagious.

faqs.question: My doctor also found a white, lacy pattern on the inside of my cheeks. Is this related to the rash on my wrists?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is oral lichen planus. It's very common (in about 50% of cases) for the condition to affect both the skin and the mucous membranes (like the inside of your mouth). This white, Wickham's striae (lacy pattern) is the most common form. Sometimes it can be erosive, causing painful, red ulcers in the gums or cheeks that make it hard to eat.

faqs.question: My oral lichen planus is the painful, erosive kind. Is this dangerous?
faqs.answer: It's not dangerous in the short term, but it is a serious quality-of-life issue and needs to be managed by a specialist. Erosive oral lichen planus (which causes red, open sores) does carry a small (around 1%) long-term risk of transforming into oral squamous cell carcinoma (mouth cancer) in that specific spot. This is why you must have regular dental or ENT follow-ups to monitor the lesions.

faqs.question: I just started a new blood pressure medication, and then this rash appeared. Could it be related?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a key possibility. A rash that looks identical to lichen planus can be triggered by certain medications. This is called a lichenoid drug eruption. The most common culprits are some blood pressure drugs (like diuretics or ACE inhibitors), certain NSAIDs, and antimalarials. If your doctor suspects this, they may try to switch your medication to see if the rash resolves.

faqs.question: How do you treat this? The itching is driving me crazy.
faqs.answer: For the skin, the goal is to stop the itch and inflammation. The primary treatment is high-potency topical steroids (creams or ointments) applied directly to the bumps. For the mouth, treatment is trickier but involves sticky steroid gels or mouthwashes. The good news is that cutaneous (skin) lichen planus often burns itself out and resolves on its own, usually within 1-2 years, though it can leave a brownish stain on the skin.

faqs.question: My daughter's school called and said she has lice. I'm mortified. Does this mean my house is dirty?
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. This is the #1 myth about lice. Head lice have nothing to do with personal hygiene or cleanliness. In fact, they are parasites that feed on human blood and actually prefer clean, healthy hair to grip onto. They are spread by head-to-head contact (like kids playing or taking selfies), not by dirt.

faqs.question: I'm using the over-the-counter (OTC) lice shampoo (permethrin) but I'm still seeing bugs. Why isn't it working?
faqs.answer: This is an increasingly common problem. In many areas, lice have developed genetic resistance to the most common OTC pesticides (permethrin and pyrethrins). These are called super lice. You are likely killing some of the live bugs, but not all. You need to switch to a different, non-pesticide-based treatment or see your doctor.

faqs.question: What's the difference between nits and live lice? I'm combing and I don't know what I'm looking for.
faqs.answer: Lice (or louse for one) are the live, six-legged bugs, about the size of a sesame seed, that move quickly and avoid light. Nits are the eggs. They are tiny, oval, and glued to the hair shaft very close to the scalp (warmth for incubation). A viable nit is often tan or brown. A white or clear-looking nit shell that's more than 1/4 inch from the scalp is usually empty or dead. The OTC shampoos do not kill nits, which is why combing and re-treatment are essential.

faqs.question: Do I need to bag all my child's stuffed animals for weeks? I'm going crazy cleaning.
faqs.answer: You can stop. This is another myth that causes unnecessary panic. A head louse is an obligate parasite. It can only survive 24-48 hours at most off a human head (its food source). It can't infest your house. Focus your energy on the head, not the house. Simply wash the bedding and clothes from the last 2 days in hot water and dry on high heat. You can put stuffed animals in the dryer for 30 minutes; you don't need to quarantine them for weeks.

faqs.question: The OTC stuff failed. What else is there? My doctor mentioned Sklice.
faqs.answer: Since the OTC pesticides are failing, the best options are prescription products. Sklice (ivermectin lotion) is a great one-and-done treatment. It's not a pesticide; it works by paralyzing the lice's nervous system. It's safe and kills both live lice and (importantly) the newly hatched nits, so you often don't even need to comb. Other non-pesticide options (like Ulesfia) work by suffocating the lice. These are much more effective against super lice.

faqs.question: My father has Parkinson's symptoms (slow, stiff, shuffling) but he's also having vivid, detailed hallucinations. Is this LBD?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of Lewy Body Dementia. LBD is a cousin to both Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. It's caused by Lewy bodies (protein deposits) in the brain. It has a unique combination of symptoms: 1) Cognitive decline (like Alzheimer's). 2) Parkinsonism (slow movement, stiffness). 3) Vivid, recurrent visual hallucinations (e.g., seeing people or animals that aren't there, which they may not find frightening). 4) Fluctuating cognition (having good days and bad days of clarity).

faqs.question: My mom's cognition seems to flicker on and off. One hour she's clear as a bell, and the next she's confused and staring into space. Is this normal dementia?
faqs.answer: This is not typical for Alzheimer's but is a hallmark feature of LBD. This is fluctuating cognition. Patients can have wild swings in their attention and alertness, sometimes appearing to zone out or take long, unexplained naps during the day. This flickering is a major diagnostic clue for LBD.

faqs.question: My husband has LBD and he acts out his dreams, flailing and yelling in his sleep. It's terrifying. What's happening?
faqs.answer: This is another core feature, called REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD). Normally, when you dream (in REM sleep), your body is paralyzed (atonia) so you don't act out your dreams. In LBD, this paralysis is lost. The person is physically acting out what they are dreaming about, which can be violent and dangerous for both them and their bed partner. This symptom can often appear years before any memory or movement problems.

faqs.question: My dad was given an antipsychotic for his hallucinations and he had a catastrophic reaction. He became almost comatose. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a critical, life-threatening issue. People with LBD have extreme neuroleptic sensitivity. Typical or first-generation antipsychotics (like Haldol) can cause a severe, irreversible worsening of parkinsonism, profound sedation, and confusion. They must be avoided. Even atypical antipsychotics are risky. This severe sensitivity is, itself, a powerful diagnostic clue for LLBD.

faqs.question: What's the 1-year rule I've heard about with Parkinson's and LBD? It's confusing.
faqs.answer: This is the (somewhat arbitrary) rule doctors use to distinguish LBD from Parkinson's Disease Dementia (PDD). If the cognitive problems (dementia) start before or within one year of the movement (Parkinson's) symptoms, the diagnosis is Lewy Body Dementia (LBD). If the person has had well-established Parkinson's for many years and then develops dementia, the diagnosis is Parkinson's Disease Dementia (PDD). Clinically, they are very similar conditions on the same spectrum.

faqs.question: I have a thick, white patch on the inside of my cheek that I can't scrape off. My dentist said leukoplakia. Is this cancer?
faqs.answer: No, leukoplakia itself is not cancer. It's a pre-cancerous or potentially malignant lesion. It's a clinical term for a white patch that cannot be scraped off and isn't caused by another condition (like thrush, which can be scraped off). It's a red flag that the tissue is irritated and abnormal. The only way to know if it's benign or has cancerous cells is with a biopsy.

faqs.question: What causes leukoplakia? I'm a heavy smoker.
faqs.answer: You've identified the #1 cause. Chronic tobacco use (smoking, and especially chewing tobacco or dipping) is the main culprit. The chemicals in tobacco constantly irritate the lining of the mouth, causing the cells to overgrow and thicken as a protective callus, which looks white. Other causes include chronic irritation (like a jagged tooth or poorly fitting denture rubbing one spot) and heavy alcohol use (which acts synergistically with tobacco).

faqs.question: My biopsy came back as hyperkeratosis with no dysplasia. What does dysplasia mean?
faqs.answer: That is the best possible result. Hyperkeratosis just means the cells are thickened (like a callus), but they are normal cells. Dysplasia is the word for pre-cancerous cells. No dysplasia means your leukoplakia is benign. Mild dysplasia is a low risk. Severe dysplasia or carcinoma in situ is very high risk and is essentially one step away from invasive cancer. Your benign lesion was likely just from irritation, but you must still stop smoking.

faqs.question: My doctor said my patch is hairy leukoplakia. How is that different?
faqs.answer: Hairy leukoplakia is a completely different condition with a specific cause. It's not pre-cancerous. It's caused by the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) and is almost exclusively seen in people with a severely weakened immune system, most often from HIV/AIDS. It has a hairy or feathery appearance, almost always on the sides of the tongue. It's a powerful sign of immunosuppression.

faqs.question: My leukoplakia has no dysplasia. If I stop smoking, will it go away?
faqs.answer: Yes, very often. For leukoplakia that is benign and clearly linked to tobacco, stopping smoking completely is the main treatment. The patch will often shrink or disappear entirely within 6-12 months of quitting. Even if it doesn't, you have dramatically reduced your risk of it ever progressing to cancer.

faqs.question: What's the difference between acute and chronic leukemia? My dad was just diagnosed.
faqs.answer: This is the most important distinction. Acute leukemia (like AML or ALL) is fast and aggressive. The blast cells (immature, cancerous cells) are completely non-functional. They build up rapidly in the bone marrow, crowding out all normal blood production. This is a medical emergency that causes severe symptoms (fatigue, infection, bleeding) and must be treated immediately with intensive chemotherapy. Chronic leukemia (like CML or CLL) is slow and insidious. The cancer cells are more mature (they partially work) and build up slowly over years. It's often found by accident on a routine blood test and may not need treatment for a long time.

faqs.question: My routine bloodwork showed a very high white blood cell count, but I feel fine. My doctor is sending me to a hematologist. Why?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), the most common chronic leukemia in adults. It's a slow-growing cancer of a type of white blood cell (B-lymphocytes). These cancerous cells build up in the blood but often don't cause symptoms for years. This is a classic watch and wait disease, where you may be monitored for years before ever needing treatment.

faqs.question: My son (age 4) has been so tired, pale, and is bruising all over. The doctor said it might be ALL. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is an emergency. Those are the red flag symptoms of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), which is the most common childhood cancer. The blast cells are crowding out the bone marrow. The paleness and fatigue are from anemia (no red cells). The bruising is from thrombocytopenia (no platelets/clotting cells). The fevers/infections are from neutropenia (no healthy white cells). The good news is that pediatric ALL, while terrifying, is one of the great success stories of modern medicine, with a very high cure rate (over 90%) with chemotherapy.

faqs.question: What is the Philadelphia chromosome? My doctor found it on my CML test.
faqs.answer: The Philadelphia chromosome is the specific genetic smoking gun for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). It's a translocation where part of chromosome 9 and part of chromosome 22 swap places. This swap creates a new, fused BCR-ABL gene, which is a cancer on-switch that tells the bone marrow to produce white blood cells uncontrollably. The discovery of this led to the first-ever targeted cancer drug, Gleevec (imatinib), a pill that specifically turns off that gene, putting the CML into remission.

faqs.question: I have CLL and my doctor said I'm watch and wait. How will we know when it's time to start treatment?
faqs.answer: Starting treatment is not based on your white blood cell count. It's based on how the disease is affecting you. The triggers for starting treatment are: 1) B-symptoms: Drenching night sweats, fevers, or significant weight loss. 2) Symptomatic anemia or thrombocytopenia: Your counts drop low enough to make you dangerously tired or cause bleeding. 3) Symptomatic organomegaly: Your lymph nodes or spleen get so big they are painful or pressing on organs. Until one of those happens, watch and wait is safer than treatment.

faqs.question: I had a large fibroid removed, but the pathology came back as leiomyosarcoma. How did they miss this?
faqs.answer: This is a rare and tragic situation. Uterine leiomyosarcoma (LMS) is a malignant cancer of the smooth muscle of the uterine wall. A fibroid (leiomyoma) is a benign tumor of the same muscle. They can look identical on an ultrasound or MRI. The only way to tell the difference is pathology after removal. It's estimated that about 1 in 350 to 1 in 1000 surgeries for fibroids turns out to be a hidden sarcoma. It was not missed; it was occult (hidden).

faqs.question: My doctor used a morcellator during my fibroid surgery. Now I'm hearing this is bad?
faqs.answer: This is the central controversy. A morcellator is a tool that chops up the fibroid into small pieces to remove it through a small keyhole incision (laparoscopy). If the fibroid was actually an occult leiomyosarcoma, the morcellator can upstage the cancer by spraying microscopic, malignant cells all over the abdominal cavity. This has been shown to dramatically worsen prognosis. Because of this risk, power morcellation is now rarely used uncontained (i.e., without a special bag).

faqs.question: My leiomyosarcoma isn't in my uterus; it's in the retroperitoneum (abdomen). How did it get there?
faqs.answer: Leiomyosarcoma is a cancer of smooth muscle, and smooth muscle isn't just in the uterus. It's also in the walls of blood vessels. A retroperitoneal LMS, a very rare and aggressive type, is thought to arise from the smooth muscle in the wall of a large blood vessel, like the inferior vena cava. These, like liposarcomas, can grow very large and silently in the abdomen before being found.

faqs.question: Why is my doctor ordering a CT scan of my lungs for a tumor in my uterus?
faqs.answer: This is essential staging. Leiomyosarcoma, as a high-grade sarcoma, has a high tendency to spread through the bloodstream, not the lymph nodes. The #1 site it spreads to (metastasizes) is the lungs. Your chest CT is to ensure there is no evidence of spread, as this would change your treatment from curative-intent surgery to systemic treatment with chemotherapy.

faqs.question: I'm being told that leiomyosarcoma is chemo-resistant. If it spreads, what are the options?
faqs.answer: LMS is considered relatively chemo-resistant, meaning it doesn't respond as well as some other cancers. However, chemotherapy is the standard of care for metastatic disease. The most common first-line regimens are doxorubicin-based, or a combination of gemcitabine and docetaxel. These don't typically cure metastatic disease, but they can be very effective at shrinking tumors and controlling the disease, often for long periods.

faqs.question: I went on vacation last week, and now I have a high fever, cough, and feel awful. The ER doc said it looks like severe pneumonia. Could it be Legionnaires'?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a classic scenario. Legionnaires' disease is a severe, atypical pneumonia caused by Legionella bacteria. The bacteria thrive in warm, man-made water systems. The #1 source of outbreaks is large building plumbing, especially in hotels, hospitals, and cruise ships (from cooling towers, hot tubs, and decorative fountains). You get sick by inhaling the contaminated water mist, not by drinking it.

faqs.question: My dad has Legionnaires' and is very confused. The doctors also said his sodium is low. Is that related?
faqs.answer: Yes, these are extrapulmonary signs that are classic clues for Legionnaires'. The infection can cause hyponatremia (dangerously low sodium in the blood) and neurological symptoms (like confusion, headache, or delirium) that are often way out of proportion to the cough. Some patients also have gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea and vomiting. This combination of pneumonia + confusion + low sodium is highly suspicious.

faqs.question: How do they test for Legionnaires' disease? Is it a normal test?
faqs.answer: No, it's not on a standard pneumonia test. The fastest and most common test is the urinary antigen test. This test detects a specific protein from the Legionella bacteria that is shed in your urine. It's very quick (gives an answer in hours) and is the best way to get a rapid diagnosis so the correct antibiotics can be started.

faqs.question: My doctor said the penicillin family of antibiotics won't work. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a critical point. Legionella is an atypical bacteria that lives inside our own cells (intracellularly). Beta-lactam antibiotics (like penicillin and amoxicillin) can't penetrate the human cell wall to kill the bacteria. Legionnaires' must be treated with specific antibiotics that can get inside the cell, namely macrolides (like azithromycin) or fluoroquinolones (like levofloxacin). Starting the wrong antibiotic is a major reason for treatment failure.

faqs.question: Can I get Legionnaires' from my home air conditioner?
faqs.answer: It is extremely unlikely. Home and car air conditioners do not work by evaporating water, so they don't create the aerosolized mist that Legionella needs to travel. The risk is from large, complex water systems like cooling towers for big buildings, hot tubs, plumbing systems in hotels, and decorative fountains. It is not considered a risk in a private residence.

faqs.question: My 6-year-old son started limping, and he says his knee hurts. His pediatrician is ordering X-rays of his hip. Why?
faqs.answer: This is the classic, tricky presentation of Perthes disease. The problem is in the hip, but the pain is often referred to the knee or thigh. This is because a nerve (the obturator nerve) serves both joints. The hip joint is inflamed, but the child's brain interprets the pain as coming from the knee. Your pediatrician is correct to X-ray the hip.

faqs.question: What actually is Legg-Calve-Perthes disease? The doctor said something about blood supply.
faqs.answer: Perthes is a childhood condition where the blood supply to the ball part of the hip joint (the femoral head) is temporarily disrupted. Without blood, that ball of bone dies (this is avascular necrosis). Over a few years, the body will: 1) Remove the dead bone (fragmentation), and 2) Regrow new bone (reossification). The whole process is about a race to see if the new bone grows back in a nice, round shape before the hip socket deforms.

faqs.question: My son's hip X-ray looks awful, like the bone is collapsing. Is he going to be disabled?
faqs.answer: It's terrifying to see, but that fragmentation or collapse phase is a normal part of the disease process as the dead bone is being resorbed. The key to a good outcome is the child's age at diagnosis. Because your son is 6, he is in the best prognostic group. Children under 6-7 have a huge amount of remodeling potential and often grow a new, round femoral head with no treatment other than observation and activity restriction (no jumping/running).

faqs.question: Why is my son, who is 10, being put in a Petrie cast (a brace that holds his legs apart)?
faqs.answer: This is because his age is a risk factor. Children diagnosed over the age of 8-9 have less remodeling potential. The goal of treatment in an older child is containment. The cast or brace (or sometimes surgery) holds the soft femoral head deep inside the round, cup-like socket (the acetabulum), using the socket as a mold to help the new bone grow back in the correct, round shape. This prevents it from flattening out (like a mushroom), which leads to early arthritis.

faqs.question: Will my child develop arthritis later in life because of this?
faqs.answer: This is the primary long-term concern. The entire goal of treatment is to prevent this. The final outcome depends on the shape of the femoral head when it finishes regrowing. If it regrows perfectly round, the risk of arthritis is very low. If it regrows in a flattened or mushroom shape (called coxa magna), the joint will not be congruent, and this bad fit will cause it to wear out, leading to symptomatic hip arthritis in their 30s, 40s, or 50s.

faqs.question: My EKG said I have LVH. What does that mean? Is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: LVH (Left Ventricular Hypertrophy) means the main pumping chamber of your heart (the left ventricle) has become thickened and muscular. Think of it like any other muscle: if it works harder, it gets bigger. A thickened heart wall is not healthy; it becomes stiff and less efficient. It's dangerous because it is a major risk factor for developing heart failure, arrhythmias (like atrial fibrillation), and stroke.

faqs.question: Why did this happen? I don't feel sick.
faqs.answer: LVH is a silent condition for a long time. The #1 cause by far is chronic, untreated high blood pressure (hypertension). For years, your left ventricle has had to pump against that high pressure to get blood to your body. To compensate, its muscle wall has thickened. The treatment for LVH is the aggressive treatment of your high blood pressure. By lowering your blood pressure, you unload the heart.

faqs.question: Can I reverse my LVH? Or is my heart permanently damaged?
faqs.answer: Yes, to a degree, LVH is reversible. This is the main goal of treatment. By aggressively controlling your blood pressure with lifestyle changes (low salt diet, exercise) and, most importantly, medication, you can reduce the workload on your heart. Over months and years, the thickened, stiff muscle can remodel and become thinner and more pliable, which significantly lowers your risk of heart failure.

faqs.question: My doctor specifically prescribed an ACE inhibitor for my blood pressure. Does it matter which drug I take?
faqs.answer: Yes, it matters. While all blood pressure drugs will help, certain classes have been shown to be particularly good at regressing or reversing the hypertrophy. ACE inhibitors (like lisinopril) and ARBs (like losartan) are considered first-line choices for a patient with hypertension and LVH because they are especially effective at promoting this favorable remodeling of the heart muscle.

faqs.question: My blood pressure is normal, but I'm an athlete and my echo said I have LVH. Is this the same thing?
faqs.answer: No, this is a completely different and important distinction. This is athlete's heart. Intense, endurance-based athletic training also makes the heart muscle thicken to keep up with the demand. However, this is physiologic (healthy) hypertrophy. The heart thickens, but it does not become stiff or dysfunctional. An athlete's heart is larger but functions better than normal. A cardiologist can tell the difference on an echocardiogram.

faqs.question: My toddler's blood test showed a high lead level. We don't have lead paint! Where could it come from?
faqs.answer: This is a terrifying and common scenario. While peeling paint in homes built before 1978 is the #1 source (from dust and chips), it's not the only one. Other sources include: contaminated soil around an old house, drinking water (if you have old lead pipes or brass fittings), imported toys or pottery (especially brightly colored glazes), certain folk remedies (like Greta or Azarcon), or take-home lead from a parent who works in construction, battery recycling, or a firing range.

faqs.question: My child's level is 6 µg/dL. The doctor said this is elevated but low. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. Any lead level in a child is a cause for serious concern. Decades of research have shown there is no safe level of lead. Even low levels (like 5-10 µg/dL) have been irrefutably linked to permanent neurological damage, including lower IQ, learning disabilities, ADHD, and behavioral problems. The level 6 is not a medical emergency, but it is an urgent call to action to find the source of the lead and eliminate it immediately.

faqs.question: What's the difference between chelation and just finding the source?
faqs.answer: Finding the source (abatement) is the primary treatment for 99% of cases. You must stop the lead from getting in. Chelation is a medical treatment for severe, acute poisoning (levels usually over 45 µg/dL). It involves giving a drug that grabs the lead in the blood and allows you to excrete it in urine. It is not used for low-level exposure, as it has side effects and (most importantly) it does not reverse the neurological damage that has already been done.

faqs.question: I'm an adult who works in construction. I've been having joint pain, brain fog, and high blood pressure. Could this be lead?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a classic picture of adult lead poisoning, which is almost always occupational. In adults, lead poisoning presents differently. Instead of developmental problems, it causes subtle systemic issues: high blood pressure (hypertension), peripheral neuropathy (numbness/tingling in hands/feet), joint/muscle pain (arthralgia), memory problems (brain fog), and anemia. You need a blood lead test immediately.

faqs.question: Does cooking with a cast iron skillet cause lead poisoning?
faqs.answer: No. A properly seasoned cast iron skillet is safe and a great source of dietary iron, not lead. The only (rare) risk is from old cast iron pots that were not intended for cooking, but rather for melting lead for bullets or weights, and are now being unknowingly used for food.

faqs.question: My 3-year-old's eye wanders, but her vision seems fine. The doctor said lazy eye. How can she have it if her eye isn't lazy?
faqs.answer: This is a key confusion. Lazy eye (amblyopia) is not a problem with the eye muscle; it's a problem with the brain. It means the vision pathway from one eye to the brain has failed to develop properly. This happens because the brain is ignoring the signal from that eye. The reason it's ignoring it is often a different problem, like strabismus (a misaligned or wandering eye), which you are describing.

faqs.question: What's the difference between amblyopia and strabismus? My doctor used both words.
faqs.answer: They are the cause and effect. Strabismus is the misalignment of the eyes (e.g., an eye turns in or out). When the eyes are misaligned, the brain gets two different pictures (double vision). To fix this, the brain suppresses or turns off the image from the wandering eye. Amblyopia is the result of this suppression: the vision in that turned off eye becomes permanently blurry from disuse. So, strabismus causes amblyopia.

faqs.question: My son's eyes are perfectly straight, but my doctor says he has amblyopia in his left eye. How?
faqs.answer: This is the other major cause, called refractive amblyopia. It means one eye has a very different glasses prescription than the other (e.g., one eye is very farsighted, the other is not). The brain sees one clear image (from the good eye) and one blurry image (from the bad eye). It prefers the clear image and ignores the blurry one. The vision in the blurry eye then fails to develop. This is silent and is often only caught at a school screening.

faqs.question: My doctor wants my daughter to wear a patch over her good eye for 2 hours a day. How does that help the bad eye?
faqs.answer: This is the gold standard treatment. It's based on neuroplasticity. By blocking the good eye, you are forcing the brain to use the lazy eye. This exercises the lazy eye's weak visual pathway and stimulates it to develop and get stronger. It is critical that this is done during the critical period of visual development (before age 7-9) while the brain is still plastic enough to re-wire.

faqs.question: I'm 25 and I've always had a lazy eye. Is it too late to fix it? Can I just get surgery?
faqs.answer: This is two separate questions. Surgery (strabismus surgery) can straighten your eye. This is a cosmetic fix; it makes your eye look straight, but it will not improve the vision. Patching or vision therapy to improve the vision (the amblyopia) is considered very difficult after the critical period (around age 9). The brain is much less plastic. While some new studies are looking at adult amblyopia treatment, it is generally considered a permanent vision loss if not caught and treated in childhood.

faqs.question: Every time I blow up balloons, my lips get itchy and my hands get a rash. Is this a latex allergy?
faqs.answer: Yes, that sounds very much like a latex allergy. The allergy is to the proteins in the natural rubber latex. Symptoms can range from mild (like the contact rash on your hands or itchy lips, called contact dermatitis) to immediate and severe. The most dangerous reactions are from exposure to mucous membranes (like your lips/mouth) or from inhaling the powder from latex gloves, which can cause anaphylaxis (wheezing, swelling, drop in blood pressure).

faqs.question: I'm a nurse and I've worn latex gloves for 10 years without a problem. Now I suddenly have a severe allergy. How?
faqs.answer: This is the classic way a latex allergy develops. It's an acquired sensitivity. The #1 risk factor for developing a latex allergy is frequent, high-level exposure. Healthcare workers, rubber industry workers, and people with spina bifida (who have had many surgeries) are the highest-risk groups. Your immune system has become sensitized to the latex proteins over time and now sees them as a dangerous invader.

faqs.question: I'm allergic to latex. My doctor told me I might also be allergic to bananas and avocados. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a real and important phenomenon called latex-fruit syndrome. The proteins in natural rubber latex are structurally similar to proteins found in certain foods. Your immune system gets confused and reacts to both. The most common cross-reactive foods are banana, avocado, kiwi, and chestnut. Not everyone with a latex allergy has this, but you should be cautious when eating these foods.

faqs.question: If I'm having surgery, what do I need to do?
faqs.answer: You must emphatically tell your surgeon, your anesthesiologist, and all pre-op staff that you have a confirmed latex allergy. This is a major safety issue. Your surgery will need to be scheduled (often as the first case of the day to avoid latex dust in the air) in a latex-free operating room. The staff will use all non-latex gloves, catheters, tape, and equipment to prevent you from having a life-threatening anaphylactic reaction while you are under anesthesia.

faqs.question: What's the difference between latex allergy and irritant contact dermatitis from gloves?
faqs.answer: Irritant contact dermatitis is not an allergy. It's the most common reaction. It's just a raw, dry, itchy rash caused by the mechanical irritation of wearing gloves, sweating, and washing hands frequently. Allergic contact dermatitis (Type IV) is a delayed allergic reaction (24-48 hours later) to the chemicals used to process the rubber. True latex allergy (Type I) is an immediate allergic reaction (minutes) to the latex proteins themselves, which causes hives or anaphylaxis.

faqs.question: I had a cold and now I've completely lost my voice. It's just a squeak. Is this laryngitis?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic presentation of acute, viral laryngitis. The same virus that caused your cold (like a rhinovirus) has now infected your larynx (your voice box). This causes your vocal cords, which are normally thin and vibrate smoothly, to become swollen, red, and inflamed. When they're swollen, they can't vibrate properly, which is why your voice becomes hoarse, raspy, or disappears completely.

faqs.question: How long will this last? I have a big presentation on Friday!
faqs.answer: For typical viral laryngitis, you should expect your voice to be very bad for 3-5 days, with it slowly returning to normal over 1-2 weeks. The worst thing you can do for your presentation is try to push through it. This can cause severe vocal strain, bruising, or nodules, and make your recovery much longer. You need to be on absolute voice rest.

faqs.question: What is voice rest? Does whispering count?
faqs.answer: This is a critical point. Whispering is worse than regular talking. It is extremely strenuous and slams your already-swollen vocal cords together. Absolute voice rest means no sound. No talking, no whispering, no clearing your throat. You should communicate by writing or texting. This allows the swelling to go down as fast as possible. Also, drink lots of water and run a humidifier.

faqs.question: My voice has been hoarse for over a month now, but I'm not sick. What else could it be?
faqs.answer: This is chronic laryngitis, and you must see an ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat) doctor. Hoarseness lasting more than 3-4 weeks is a red flag and is not from a simple virus. The ENT needs to look at your vocal cords with a tiny camera (a laryngoscopy). Causes of chronic hoarseness include: acid reflux (LPR) burning the cords, vocal nodules or polyps (from voice overuse), smoking, or, most seriously, laryngeal (vocal cord) cancer.

faqs.question: I have terrible acid reflux (GERD) and I'm always hoarse in the morning. Are they related?
faqs.answer: Yes, 100%. This is called laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR) or silent reflux. Stomach acid is splashing up all the way to your throat while you sleep, bathing your vocal cords in acid all night. This causes chronic inflammation, a lumpy feeling in the throat, a persistent cough, and a deep, gravelly morning hoarseness. The treatment is aggressive acid reflux control.

faqs.question: I just got back from a trip to Africa and now I have a high fever, shaking chills, and a headache. Could this be malaria?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic presentation and you must treat it as a medical emergency. Malaria is the #1 life-threatening fever to consider after travel to an endemic area (like sub-Saharan Africa, parts of Asia, and South America). The symptoms (high fever, cyclical chills, drenching sweats, headache, muscle aches) can look just like the flu, but it can get severe very quickly.

faqs.question: I took my anti-malaria pills (Malarone) exactly as prescribed. Does that mean I'm safe?
faqs.answer: No. Anti-malarial prophylaxis (pills) is extremely effective, but no pill is 100% effective. There is always a small breakthrough risk. Your symptoms must be investigated for malaria regardless of whether you took your pills. You need to go to an ER and tell them exactly where you traveled and that you need a malaria blood smear.

faqs.question: What's a blood smear? How do they test for it?
faqs.answer: The gold standard test is a thick and thin blood smear. A lab technician takes a drop of your blood, smears it on a glass slide, and looks at it under a microscope. They are visually searching for the malaria parasites inside your red blood cells. This is the only way to not only diagnose it, but also to identify the species (type) of malaria.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have Plasmodium falciparum. Why is that specific type a big deal?
faqs.answer: This is the most dangerous type. P. falciparum is the killer malaria. It is the species responsible for almost all malaria deaths. It's so dangerous because it multiplies very rapidly in the blood, can infect a huge percentage of your red blood cells, and (most importantly) it causes the infected red cells to become sticky. These sticky cells can clog the tiny blood vessels in your brain (causing cerebral malaria, coma, and death), kidneys, and lungs.

faqs.question: Can I give malaria to my family? Is it contagious?
faqs.answer: No. Malaria is not contagious from person to person. It has a complex life cycle and can only be transmitted through the bite of an infected Anopheles mosquito. You are not a danger to your family (unless they were also on the trip with you and got bitten).

faqs.question: By the end of the day, my eyelids are drooping, my vision is double, and it's hard to chew my food. But I feel fine in the morning. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the hallmark description of Myasthenia Gravis. MG is an autoimmune disease where your own antibodies block or destroy the receptors for acetylcholine (ACh) at the neuromuscular junction. ACh is the chemical signal that tells a muscle to contract. The key feature is fatigable weakness: your muscles work fine at first, but with repeated use, the signal fails, and you get weak. Rest (like a night's sleep) restores the signal, so you feel strong again in the morning.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to do a CT scan of my chest to look at my thymus gland. What does that have to do with my droopy eyelids?
faqs.answer: This is a critical part of the workup. The thymus gland (a small immune organ behind your breastbone) is the command center for your immune system. In about 75% of MG patients, the thymus is abnormal (it's hyperplastic or overgrown). In about 10-15% of patients, there is a tumor on the thymus (a thymoma). The abnormal thymus is thought to be the factory producing the bad antibodies. Removing it (a thymectomy) is a key part of treatment and can lead to remission.

faqs.question: My doctor did an ice pack test on my eye and it got better. How is that possible?
faqs.answer: This is a classic, simple bedside test for MG. The transmission of the nerve signal (ACh) at the neuromuscular junction is more efficient at colder temperatures. By placing an ice pack on your droopy eyelid for 2-5 minutes, you cool the underlying muscle. This improves the signal, and the eyelid magically opens. This is a very strong sign that you have MG.

faqs.question: What is a myasthenic crisis? My doctor warned me about it.
faqs.answer: A myasthenic crisis is a life-threatening emergency. It's when the weakness becomes so severe that it affects your respiratory muscles (your diaphragm and chest wall). You become unable to take a deep breath or cough effectively, leading to respiratory failure. This is often triggered by an infection, stress, or certain medications. It requires immediate hospitalization and, often, a ventilator to help you breathe while the bad antibodies are cleaned from your blood (with plasmapheresis or IVIG).

faqs.question: My doctor prescribed Mestinon (pyridostigmine). How does this work?
faqs.answer: Mestinon is not an immunosuppressant; it doesn't fix the underlying disease. It's a symptomatic treatment. It's an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This means it blocks the enzyme that normally recycles your nerve signal (ACh). By blocking this enzyme, it lets the little bit of ACh you have hang around in the junction for longer, giving it more time to find an open receptor. This boosts the signal and improves your muscle strength, but it's a temporary fix that wears off in a few hours.

faqs.question: I've been exhausted for 8 months. It's not just tired—it's a crash. And my brain fog is so bad I can't work. Is this ME/CFS?
faqs.answer: What you're describing, especially the crash, is the hallmark symptom of ME/CFS. This is post-exertional malaise (PEM). It's not normal fatigue; it's a profound, pathological exhaustion and worsening of all symptoms (brain fog, muscle pain, flu-like feeling) that is triggered by even minor physical or mental exertion. This crash is often delayed by 24-48 hours and can last for days or weeks. This symptom must be present for a diagnosis.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to try graded exercise therapy but it's making me so much worse. Am I doing it wrong?
faqs.answer: You are not doing it wrong. Graded exercise therapy (GET) is an outdated and harmful recommendation for ME/CFS. It's based on the wrong idea that the fatigue is deconditioning. Because the core symptom of ME/CFS is PEM, pushing through the fatigue is the worst thing you can do. It will cause repeated crashes and can make your baseline condition permanently worse. The correct approach is pacing.

faqs.question: What is pacing? How is it different from just resting?
faqs.answer: Pacing is an active energy management strategy. It's about preventing the crash (PEM). You need to find your energy envelope (the small amount of mental/physical activity you can do without triggering symptoms) and then stay under it, no matter what. This means stopping before you get tired, taking scheduled rest breaks (lying down in a dark, quiet room) throughout the day, and being ruthless about prioritizing your energy. It's about energy budgeting, not energy spending.

faqs.question: I used to be so active, but now I get dizzy and my heart races just from standing up. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is extremely common in ME/CFS. It's a co-morbid condition called orthostatic intolerance or POTS (Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome). Your autonomic nervous system (which controls automatic things like heart rate and blood pressure) is not working correctly. When you stand up, your blood pools in your legs, and your heart rate sky-rockets to try and compensate. This is physically exhausting and contributes to the fatigue and brain fog.

faqs.question: My ME/CFS started right after a bad case of mono (Epstein-Barr virus). Is it related?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a very common trigger. While the exact cause of ME/CFS is unknown, it is very well-documented that it can begin as a post-viral syndrome following a significant infection. The most common triggers are Epstein-Barr Virus (mono), but also Ross River virus, Q fever, and now (most significantly) COVID-19 (which is what Long COVID is for many people).

faqs.question: My 3-year-old son is toe walking and has huge calf muscles. He also struggles to stand up (he climbs up his legs). Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. You must take him to a pediatrician immediately and mention your concerns. What you are describing are the absolute classic signs of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD). The climbing up the legs is called the Gower's sign. The huge calves are not muscle; they are pseudohypertrophy, where the muscle tissue has been replaced by fat and scar tissue. DMD is a severe, genetic muscle-wasting disease that affects boys, and early diagnosis is critical.

faqs.question: What is dystrophin? My doctor said my son is missing it.
faqs.answer: Dystrophin is the shock absorber protein for your muscles. It's a huge protein that connects the inside of a muscle cell to the outside, providing stability. In Duchenne MD, a genetic mutation means the boy's body produces no dystrophin at all. Without it, every single muscle contraction causes a tiny tear or injury to the muscle cell. Over time, this repeated damage destroys the muscle, which is replaced by fat and scar tissue. In the less-severe Becker MD, some dystrophin is made, so the disease is milder.

faqs.question: I'm a 30-year-old woman and I've been diagnosed with myotonic dystrophy. I thought only boys got MD?
faqs.answer: This is a common misconception. Muscular Dystrophy is an umbrella term for over 30 different genetic diseases. Duchenne is the most common childhood form and affects boys. Myotonic Dystrophy is the most common adult-onset form and affects men and women equally. Its hallmark symptom is myotonia—the inability to relax a muscle (e.g., your hand gets stuck after a strong grip). It's a multi-system disease that also affects the heart, eyes (cataracts), and hormones.

faqs.question: My son with Duchenne is being put on steroids. How does that help his muscles?
faqs.answer: Corticosteroids (like Prednisone or Deflazacort) are the only medication proven to slow the progression of Duchenne MD. They don't fix the underlying problem (the missing dystrophin), but they are powerful anti-inflammatories. They help by reducing the inflammation caused by the constant muscle damage, which slows down the rate of muscle-wasting. This has been proven to prolong ambulation (keep boys walking for 1-3 years longer) and protect heart and lung function.

faqs.question: I'm a carrier for Duchenne MD. Does that just mean my sons are at risk?
faqs.answer: Primarily, yes. As a carrier, you have a 50% chance of passing the faulty gene to your son (who would have DMD) and a 50% chance of passing the carrier status to your daughter. However, carriers are not always asymptomatic. A small percentage of female carriers (called manifesting carriers) can have muscle weakness themselves, or (more commonly) are at a significant risk for cardiomyopathy (a weakening of the heart muscle). All female carriers must be monitored by a cardiologist for life.

faqs.question: I pulled my hamstring. What's the difference between a strain and a tear?
faqs.answer: They are the same thing, just different degrees of severity. A strain is a tear of the muscle fibers. We grade them: Grade 1 strain: A mild pull. A few muscle fibers are overstretched or have microscopic tears. It's sore, but you have full strength. Grade 2 strain: A partial tear of a significant number of muscle fibers. It's more painful, and you will have swelling and loss of strength. Grade 3 strain: A complete rupture of the muscle. You may see a ball of muscle bunched up, have severe pain, and a total loss of function. This often requires surgery.

faqs.question: I hurt my back lifting a box. It's so painful. Should I go to the ER? Should I be on bed rest?
faqs.answer: An acute muscle strain in the back is extremely painful but rarely an emergency. The red flag signs that require an ER visit are: loss of bowel/bladder control, numbness in the saddle area (groin), or progressive weakness in your legs. If you only have back pain, the treatment is not bed rest. Active recovery is now the standard. Bed rest for more than a day actually weakens your muscles and makes it worse. You should alternate heat/ice and stay as active as you can tolerate.

faqs.question: What is RICE? My coach told me to do it for my pulled calf muscle.
faqs.answer: RICE is the old, traditional acronym for acute injury, but it's been updated. It stands for Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation. The Rest part is now debated, as active recovery is better. The Ice part is also debated, as some believe it may slow healing. The most important parts are Compression (wrapping it with an ACE bandage to reduce swelling) and Elevation (getting it above your heart). A more modern term is PEACE & LOVE (Protect, Elevate, Avoid anti-inflammatories, Compress, Educate... & Load, Optimism, Vascularisation, Exercise).

faqs.question: Why do I keep pulling the same hamstring over and over?
faqs.answer: This is a classic re-injury cycle. The #1 risk factor for a muscle strain is a previous strain. This is because when the muscle healed, it likely healed with inflexible scar tissue. This scar tissue is not as pliable as normal muscle, so it's the weak link that re-tears every time you push it. This is why physical therapy is so critical after a Grade 2 strain—to properly remodel that scar tissue, regain full flexibility, and correct any underlying muscle imbalances (like weak glutes) that caused the strain in the first place.

faqs.question: Should I use heat or ice for my sore, strained neck muscle?
faqs.answer: For the first 24-48 hours after the acute injury, ice is generally preferred. It's a vasoconstrictor, so it numbs the pain and helps reduce swelling and inflammation. After 48 hours, or for a chronic tight muscle, heat is better. Heat is a vasodilator. It increases blood flow to the area, which helps relax the tight muscle spasm and can promote healing.

faqs.question: I keep getting excruciating charley horse cramps in my calf in the middle of the night. What causes this?
faqs.answer: These are nocturnal leg cramps, and they are very common but miserable. The exact cause is unknown, but they are not the same as exercise cramps. The top theories include: nerve-related (an over-excited, misfiring nerve in your spine), dehydration, electrolyte imbalance (low magnesium or potassium), or simply muscle fatigue from over-use during the day. Often, just forcefully stretching the muscle (flexing your foot up toward your shin) is the only way to break the cramp.

faqs.question: I heard eating bananas helps. Is it true I'm just low on potassium?
faqs.answer: This is the most common myth, but it's rarely the answer. While a severe electrolyte imbalance can cause cramps, your body regulates electrolytes very tightly. It's much more likely due to dehydration (which concentrates your electrolytes) or neuromuscular fatigue. That said, ensuring you are well-hydrated and have a balanced diet (which includes potassium from bananas, potatoes, etc., and magnesium from nuts/seeds) is an easy first step.

faqs.question: I'm a runner and I only get cramps in my hamstrings at the end of a long, hot race. Is this just dehydration?
faqs.answer: This is the classic exercise-associated muscle cramp (EAMC). For decades, we blamed dehydration and electrolytes. However, the new and more accepted theory is altered neuromuscular control. The cramp is not from the muscle itself, but from a misfiring of the nerves. As you get fatigued, the protective reflexes in your spinal cord get confused—they excite the muscle too much and inhibit its relaxation. This is why stretching (which resets this reflex) helps.

faqs.question: I heard drinking pickle juice can stop a cramp. Is that for real?
faqs.answer: Yes, it sounds crazy, but it's true, and it proves the neuromuscular theory. Studies show that drinking a small amount of pickle juice can break a cramp in under 90 seconds. This is way too fast for the juice to be digested and change your body's electrolytes. The current theory is that the acidic/salty taste triggers a neural reflex in your throat/stomach that sends a stop signal to your spinal cord, short-circuiting the misfiring nerve and stopping the cramp.

faqs.question: My leg cramps are new and I'm also on a new statin (cholesterol) medication. Could they be related?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a known side effect. Muscle-related complaints (myalgia) are the most common side effect of statin medications. While cramps are less common than general soreness, it's definitely a possibility. You should not stop your medication, but you should report this to your doctor. They may check a blood test (for CK levels) to ensure there's no serious muscle damage, or they may try switching you to a different type of statin.

faqs.question: I was fully vaccinated with the MMR as a kid. How did I still get the mumps as a college student?
faqs.answer: This is a common and valid question. The MMR vaccine is excellent, but its effectiveness can wane or decrease over time. A person who had two doses as a child may have reduced immunity 10-20 years later. This is why outbreaks are most common in close-contact settings like college dorms, where a vaccinated person with waned immunity can catch it from someone else.

faqs.question: My face is incredibly swollen on one side. How do I know if it's mumps or just a swollen lymph node or tooth abscess?
faqs.answer: Mumps causes a very specific type of swelling. It's an infection of the parotid glands (salivary glands) which are located in front of your ear and wrap around the angle of your jaw. This swelling is often described as a chipmunk cheek that makes your earlobe disappear and pushes your jaw out. A swollen lymph node is usually smaller, under the jawline, and a tooth abscess is typically centered on the gum line with extreme tooth pain.

faqs.question: I'm an adult male with mumps. My doctor seemed really concerned about orchitis. What is that and how common is it?
faqs.answer: Mumps orchitis is a serious complication that occurs in about 15-30% of post-pubertal males who get the mumps. It's a painful inflammation and swelling of one or (less commonly) both testicles, which usually appears about a week after the facial swelling. While it is very painful and can cause testicular atrophy (shrinkage), it is important to know that sterility (inability to father children) as a result is actually very rare, even if one testicle is affected.

faqs.question: Besides the chipmunk cheeks and fever, what other complications should I watch for?
faqs.answer: Mumps is a systemic virus. While parotitis is most common, it can also cause viral meningitis or encephalitis (headache, stiff neck, confusion), which is a medical emergency. It can also, rarely, cause oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries) in females or pancreatitis (severe abdominal pain). The most common unexpected complication is, rarely, permanent deafness in one ear.

faqs.question: My son has mumps. Can I give him aspirin for the fever?
faqs.answer: No. Never give aspirin (or any product containing salicylates) to a child or teenager with a viral illness, including mumps. This can lead to Reye's syndrome, a rare but life-threatening condition that causes severe liver and brain swelling. You should only use acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil) for fever and pain.

faqs.question: My child had a very mild case of COVID-19 a month ago, and now has a high fever and a rash. Could this be MIS-C?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic timeline and you need to see a doctor immediately. MIS-C is a delayed, post-infectious syndrome. It is not the acute COVID-19 illness. It's a massive, body-wide inflammatory response that happens about 2 to 6 weeks after the initial infection, even if the infection itself was mild or asymptomatic. The persistent high fever (over 3 days), rash, and red eyes are major warning signs.

faqs.question: This sounds a lot like Kawasaki disease. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: This is an excellent observation, as they are both inflammatory vasculitis syndromes. The main difference is the age and the symptoms. Kawasaki disease typically affects toddlers (under 5). MIS-C typically affects older children and adolescents (average age 8-11). Also, MIS-C is far more likely to cause severe gastrointestinal symptoms (intense stomach pain, vomiting, diarrhea) and cardiac (heart) inflammation than Kawasaki disease.

faqs.question: The doctor said my child's heart is inflamed. Does this mean they will have permanent heart damage?
faqs.answer: Heart involvement is the most serious part of MIS-C. It can cause myocarditis (inflammation of the heart muscle), which makes the heart weak and unable to pump properly. It can also cause coronary artery aneurysms (like Kawasaki). The good news is that with prompt treatment (using IVIG and steroids to cool down the inflammation), the vast majority of children have complete recovery of their heart function within a few weeks or months. Follow-up with a cardiologist is essential.

faqs.question: Is MIS-C contagious? Can my other children get it?
faqs.answer: No. MIS-C itself is not contagious. You cannot catch it from your child. It is an individual's abnormal immune response to a past infection. The contagious part (the COVID-19 infection) already happened weeks ago.

faqs.question: Why did my child get this and other kids who had COVID didn't? Was it something I did?
faqs.answer: You did absolutely nothing wrong. This is not caused by anything you did or didn't do. It is a rare complication, and we don't fully understand why some children's immune systems overreact this way while others don't. It is likely a complex combination of the child's individual genetics and their specific immune response to the virus.

faqs.question: My husband was just diagnosed with MSA. His symptoms look just like Parkinson's disease. How are they different?
faqs.answer: This is a common and difficult situation. MSA is a Parkinson's-plus syndrome, meaning it has parkinsonism (slow movement, stiffness) but with other severe symptoms. The key differentiator is autonomic failure. This means the automatic parts of the nervous system fail early and severely. This includes profound orthostatic hypotension (getting dizzy and fainting upon standing), severe bladder/bowel incontinence, and erectile dysfunction. These symptoms are much more prominent in MSA than in typical Parkinson's.

faqs.question: The doctor tried giving my wife Levodopa (Sinemet) for her stiffness, but it didn't really work. Is this a bad sign?
faqs.answer: A poor or transient (short-lived) response to Levodopa is, unfortunately, a strong diagnostic clue that points away from Parkinson's disease and toward an atypical syndrome like MSA. People with Parkinson's usually have a dramatic and sustained response to Levodopa, while those with MSA often have little to no benefit, or the benefit they do get fades quickly.

faqs.question: What is the prognosis for MSA? I'm scared to look it up.
faqs.answer: It is a difficult, progressive neurological disease. It's important to be honest about this. Unlike Parkinson's, which can have a slow progression over decades, MSA progresses much more rapidly. The median survival from the onset of symptoms is typically in the range of 6-10 years. The progression is driven by the autonomic failure and loss of mobility, which leads to complications like falls, pneumonia (from swallowing issues), and infections.

faqs.question: My dad has the MSA-C type. The doctor said it affects his cerebellum. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: MSA is divided into two types based on the dominant motor symptom. MSA-P (Parkinsonian) has the stiffness and slowness as the main problem. MSA-C (Cerebellar) has ataxia as the main problem. The cerebellum is the balance center of the brain. This means your father's main symptoms are likely severe unsteadiness, a drunken walk (ataxia), and poor coordination, in addition to the autonomic failure.

faqs.question: My partner keeps acting out his dreams, yelling and thrashing in his sleep. Is this related?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a very common symptom called REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD). It's often one of the earliest signs of MSA (and other synucleinopathy diseases like Parkinson's and Lewy Body Dementia), sometimes appearing years before other symptoms. It's caused by the brain's failure to paralyze the body during dream (REM) sleep.

faqs.question: My MRI shows lesions in my brain. Does this mean I have MS? I'm terrified.
faqs.answer: Finding white matter lesions (or plaques) on an MRI is a key part of the diagnosis, but it does not automatically mean you have MS. These lesions are scars of inflammation, but they can be caused by other things too (like migraines, high blood pressure, or other inflammatory diseases). To diagnose MS, a neurologist must confirm the lesions are disseminated in space (in typical MS locations like near the ventricles or on the spinal cord) AND disseminated in time (showing evidence of new and old lesions, meaning attacks happened at different times). A single MRI is often not enough.

faqs.question: What's the difference between relapsing-remitting (RRMS) and progressive (PPMS) MS?
faqs.answer: This is the most important distinction in MS. Relapsing-Remitting MS (RRMS) is the most common form (85%). It's defined by clear attacks (relapses) where new symptoms appear (like optic neuritis or numbness) that last for days or weeks, followed by remission where they get better. Primary Progressive MS (PPMS) is rare (~15%). It is not defined by attacks. It's a slow, steady, gradual worsening of disability from the very beginning, most often causing walking and leg problems.

faqs.question: What does an MS flare or relapse actually feel like?
faqs.answer: A relapse (or flare) is the appearance of a new neurological symptom, or the significant worsening of an old one, that lasts for more than 24 hours and is not explained by a fever or infection. It's the physical manifestation of a new area of inflammation (a new lesion) in your brain or spinal cord. Common relapses include: optic neuritis (painful, blurry vision in one eye), transverse myelitis (numbness/weakness from the waist down), or severe vertigo.

faqs.question: My doctor wants me to start a disease-modifying therapy (DMT) even though I feel fine right now. Why?
faqs.answer: This is the most critical part of modern MS care. You feel fine because you are in remission. However, silent inflammation (new lesions on MRI without new symptoms) may still be occurring. The DMTs (which are pills, injections, or infusions) are not to treat your current symptoms. Their job is to prevent future relapses and future lesions. By calming your immune system, they are proven to slow down the long-term progression of the disease and prevent future disability. Starting one early is the best way to protect your brain.

faqs.question: I've been feeling exhausted and my symptoms get worse when I'm hot or stressed. Is this a new relapse?
faqs.answer: No, this is not a relapse; this is called a pseudo-relapse or Uhthoff's phenomenon. MS damages the insulation (myelin) on your nerves. These short-circuited nerves are very sensitive to changes in your body, especially heat. When you get hot (from a hot shower, exercise, or a fever), your old symptoms (like blurry vision or fatigue) can re-appear temporarily. As soon as you cool down, they go away. This is not new inflammation and does not require steroids; it's just an unmasking of old damage.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have MGUS and not myeloma. What's the difference and am I going to get cancer?
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction. MGUS (Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance) is not cancer. It means your plasma cells are producing a monoclonal (abnormal) protein, but at a very low level and it's not causing any organ damage. Multiple Myeloma is cancer. It's when these cells grow out of control, crowd the marrow, and do cause organ damage. The main difference is that MGUS is asymptomatic. The risk of MGUS progressing to myeloma is very low, about 1% per year.

faqs.question: What is the CRAB criteria? My doctor said I don't have it.
faqs.answer: CRAB is the acronym for the major symptoms of active multiple myeloma, which signal that it's time to start treatment. C = High Calcium. R = Renal (kidney) failure.
