A = Anemia (low red blood cells, causing fatigue). B = Bone lesions (holes in the bones, causing pain or fractures). If you have a high level of plasma cells plus one or more CRAB features, you have active myeloma. If you don't (e.g., smoldering myeloma), you may just be monitored.

faqs.question: I've been having terrible back pain, and my X-ray showed lytic lesions. What are those?
faqs.answer: This is the B in CRAB and is the most common symptom of myeloma. Lytic lesions are essentially holes in your bone. The cancerous plasma cells (myeloma cells) activate the cells that dissolve bone (osteoclasts) and deactivate the cells that build bone (osteoblasts). This eats away at the bone, most often in the spine, ribs, and skull, causing severe pain and a very high risk of pathologic fractures (a break from a minor or no injury).

faqs.question: My doctor is talking about a stem cell transplant. That sounds terrifying. Is it my only option?
faqs.answer: An autologous stem cell transplant (using your own stem cells) is a standard, and very effective, part of the treatment plan for most newly diagnosed myeloma patients who are healthy enough. It is not a cure, but it is the best way to get the deepest and longest remission. The process involves: 1) Giving you high-dose chemotherapy to kill all the myeloma, and 2) Rescuing you with your own healthy stem cells (which were collected and frozen beforehand) so your bone marrow can regrow. It is not the same as an allogeneic (donor) transplant, which is much riskier.

faqs.question: Is multiple myeloma curable?
faqs.answer: For the vast majority of patients, multiple myeloma is not considered curable, but it is highly treatable and manageable. It is a chronic cancer. With modern treatments (like immunotherapy, proteasome inhibitors, and transplants), patients can go into deep remissions that last for many, many years. The goal is to control the disease, manage symptoms, and maintain a high quality of life for as long as possible.

faqs.question: My father was just diagnosed with medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) and his doctor wants me to get a RET gene test. Why?
faqs.answer: This is extremely important. Unlike other thyroid cancers, Medullary Thyroid Cancer (MTC) is strongly linked to a genetic syndrome. About 25% of all MTC cases are hereditary and caused by an inherited mutation in the RET proto-oncogene. This is the gene that defines Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2). If your father has this gene, you have a 50/50 chance of having it too. Finding this out before you get sick is life-saving.

faqs.question: I tested positive for the RET mutation. My doctor is talking about a prophylactic thyroidectomy. You mean remove my healthy thyroid?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a terrifying concept, but it is the standard of care and a life-saving preventative measure. If you have the MEN 2 mutation, your risk of developing MTC is almost 100%. It is not a question of if, but when. By removing your thyroid before the cancer develops (or when it's just microscopic), you are curing the cancer before it can ever spread and become incurable. MTC is the most dangerous part of this syndrome.

faqs.question: What's the difference between MEN 2A and MEN 2B?
faqs.answer: They are both caused by RET mutations, but in different locations on the gene, which leads to different problems. MEN 2A (the most common) is the triad of: 1) Medullary thyroid cancer (100%), 2) Pheochromocytoma (50%), and 3) Hyperparathyroidism (20%). MEN 2B is much rarer and more aggressive. It includes: 1) Medullary thyroid cancer (100%, and much earlier), 2) Pheochromocytoma (50%), plus 3) Marfanoid habitus (tall, lanky) and Neuromas (benign nerve tumors on the lips, tongue, and eyelids).

faqs.question: My doctor said I also need to be screened for pheochromocytoma. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is the second major part of the syndrome. A pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland (which sits on top of your kidney). This tumor leaks massive amounts of adrenaline (epinephrine) into your body. This causes spells of a racing heart (palpitations), pounding headache, and drenching sweats, along with dangerously high blood pressure. If you have a pheochromocytoma, it must be removed before your thyroid surgery, or the anesthesia can cause a fatal hypertensive crisis.

faqs.question: If I have the MEN 2 gene, do my kids need to be tested?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a dominant genetic condition, meaning you only need one copy of the bad gene to have the syndrome. If you have it, each of your children has a 50% chance of having inherited it from you. Genetic testing for children in an MEN 2 family is critical and is often done in infancy, as the prophylactic thyroidectomy for some high-risk MEN 2B mutations is recommended in the first year of life.

faqs.question: I have hyperparathyroidism and now my doctor is testing me for MEN 1. What is that?
faqs.answer: MEN 1 is a rare, inherited syndrome (caused by a mutation in the MEN1 gene) that causes tumors in multiple endocrine glands. The classic triad (often called the 3 P's) is: 1) Parathyroid (hyperparathyroidism, which causes high blood calcium - this is the first sign in >95% of patients), 2) Pancreatic (neuroendocrine tumors, like gastrinomas or insulinomas), and 3) Pituitary (tumors, often prolactinomas). If you have hyperparathyroidism, especially at a young age, your doctor is checking to see if it's syndromic (part of MEN 1).

faqs.question: What's the difference between MEN 1 and MEN 2?
faqs.answer: They are completely separate genetic syndromes, caused by different genes, and affecting different glands. MEN 1 (MEN1 gene) is the 3 P's: Parathyroid, Pancreas, Pituitary. MEN 2 (RET gene) is Medullary thyroid cancer and Pheochromocytoma. They do not overlap.

faqs.question: My high calcium (hyperparathyroidism) doesn't bother me. Why does my doctor want to operate?
faqs.answer: In MEN 1, hyperparathyroidism is caused by all four parathyroid glands being overgrown (hyperplasia), not just one bad gland (adenoma) as in the general population. While you may feel fine, chronic high calcium (bones, stones, groans, and psychiatric overtones) is silently damaging your body, primarily by causing kidney stones, bone loss (osteoporosis), and sometimes cognitive fogginess. Surgery to remove 3.5 of the glands is the main treatment.

faqs.question: My doctor ordered a fasting gastrin level. What does that have to do with my other glands?
faqs.answer: This is to screen for the P in Pancreas. The most common pancreatic tumor in MEN 1 is a gastrinoma. This tumor secretes massive amounts of the hormone gastrin, which tells your stomach to make acid. This causes a severe, recurrent ulcer disease called Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES). A simple blood test for a high gastrin level is the first step in looking for it.

faqs.question: If I have MEN 1, what does screening look like for me?
faqs.answer: Because you are at high risk for multiple tumors, you will be on a lifelong screening program. This will typically involve: Annual blood tests (for calcium, parathyroid hormone, gastrin, prolactin) and Regular imaging (like CT, MRI, or endoscopic ultrasound) to look for pancreatic and pituitary tumors before they grow large or cause symptoms. The goal is surveillance and proactive management.

faqs.question: I have this painful, red bump on my leg that looks like a spider bite, but it's getting worse. Could this be MRSA?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic presentation of community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA). It almost always starts as a red bump or pimple that people mistake for a spider bite. But it quickly becomes a swollen, painful, warm abscess (a deep pocket of pus) that may drain. You need to see a doctor today. Do not try to pop it yourself; this can spread the infection deeper.

faqs.question: What does MRSA even mean? Why is it resistant?
faqs.answer: MRSA stands for Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Staph is a very common germ (bacteria) on our skin. Methicillin represents the entire family of standard penicillin-like antibiotics (like amoxicillin, penicillin, cephalexin/Keflex). This specific strain of staph has acquired a resistance gene (the mecA gene) that makes all of those antibiotics useless against it. This is why we must use special, non-beta-lactam antibiotics.

faqs.question: The doctor drained my abscess. Why do I also need to take antibiotics like Bactrim or doxycycline?
faqs.answer: For a simple skin abscess, Incision & Drainage (I&D) is the most important treatment—getting the pus out is key. However, if the abscess is large, if you have multiple abscesses, if you have a fever, or if the infection is spreading (a cellulitis), the doctor will add an antibiotic. They must choose one that works against CA-MRSA, and the most common oral options are Bactrim (TMP-SMX), doxycycline, or clindamycin.

faqs.question: My son is a wrestler and keeps getting these. How can we stop it?
faqs.answer: CA-MRSA is spread by skin-to-skin contact and fomites (contaminated objects). It's rampant in high-contact groups like athletes (wrestlers, football players), in crowded living conditions (dorms, barracks), and in gyms. The keys to prevention are: 1) Do not share towels, razors, or equipment. 2) Cover all wounds with a clean bandage at all times. 3) Shower immediately after practice/games. 4) Disinfect equipment regularly.

faqs.question: My doctor said I'm a carrier and I need to be decolonized. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: About 30% of people carry Staph aureus in their nose without it being an infection. A smaller percentage carry MRSA. If you are having recurrent infections, your doctor may try to decolonize you to get rid of this reservoir. This usually involves a 5-10 day regimen of: 1) Using an antibiotic ointment (mupirocin) inside your nostrils, and 2) Washing your entire body daily with an antiseptic soap (like Hibiclens/chlorhexidine).

faqs.question: My child had a ministroke (TIA) and the angiogram showed a puff of smoke. The doctor said Moyamoya. What is that?
faqs.answer: Moyamoya is Japanese for puff of smoke, and it describes what the angiogram looks like. In this rare disease, the large arteries at the base of the brain (the internal carotids) become progressively narrowed and blocked. The brain, starving for blood, tries to compensate by growing a net of tiny, fragile blood vessels to bypass the blockage. It's this messy, fragile net of vessels that looks like a puff of smoke on the scan. These tiny vessels are what bleed or clot, causing strokes.

faqs.question: My daughter's symptoms (weakness) seem to happen when she cries or blows on hot soup. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a hallmark symptom in children. Crying, hyperventilating, or blowing (which are all hyperventilation) causes a person to blow off carbon dioxide. In all people, low CO2 in the blood causes brain arteries to constrict. In a normal person, this is fine. In a child with Moyamoya, whose arteries are already critically narrow, this slight constriction is the straw that breaks the camel's back. It cuts off the blood flow and causes a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke.

faqs.question: The doctor is recommending revascularization surgery. What does that involve?
faqs.answer: This is the primary treatment for Moyamoya, as there is no medication that stops the blockage. The goal of surgery is to re-plumb the brain, giving it a new, healthy blood supply from the outside. A neurosurgeon will take a healthy artery from your scalp (the superficial temporal artery) and connect it directly to an artery on the surface of your brain (a direct bypass). This gives the brain the blood it's starving for and encourages the fragile moyamoya vessels to shrink, reducing stroke risk.

faqs.question: I'm 35 and I was just diagnosed after a brain bleed. I thought this was a kids' disease?
faqs.answer: Moyamoya has two peaks for diagnosis: one in childhood (around age 5-10) and another in adulthood (in the 30s-40s). The presentation is different. Children almost always present with ischemic strokes or TIAs (from the blockage). Adults are more likely to present with hemorrhagic strokes (a bleed) from one of the fragile, abnormal moyamoya vessels rupturing.

faqs.question: I read this is common in Japan. Is it genetic?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is most common in people of East Asian descent, particularly Japanese and Korean, which strongly suggests a genetic component. A specific gene, RNF213, has been identified as a major susceptibility gene for the disease. However, it's also seen in people of all ethnicities, and the exact cause is still not fully understood.

faqs.question: My hand shakes when I try to drink water, but not when it's resting. My dad's hand shakes when it's resting. Are these the same?
faqs.answer: No, this is a critical difference. A shake that happens at rest and gets better with action is a resting tremor, the hallmark of Parkinson's disease. A shake that happens with action (like holding a cup or writing) is an action or intention tremor, the hallmark of Essential Tremor. They are two completely different neurological conditions. A movement disorder specialist (a type of neurologist) can tell the difference.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a tremor, a tic, and dystonia?
faqs.answer: A tremor is a rhythmic, shaking movement. A tic (like in Tourette syndrome) is a brief, sudden, repetitive movement (like a head jerk or eye blink) that is often preceded by an urge and can be briefly suppressed. Dystonia is a sustained muscle contraction that causes a twisting or abnormal posture (like your head being pulled to one side, or your hand cramping shut when you write).

faqs.question: My mother is having jerky dance-like movements in her arms and face that she can't control. What could this be?
faqs.answer: This sounds like chorea (from the Greek for dance). It's a non-rhythmic, flowing or writhing involuntary movement. The most famous cause of chorea is Huntington's disease, a progressive genetic disorder. However, it can also be caused by strokes, high blood sugar, or certain medications.

faqs.question: When I get anxious, my hand starts to shake. Is this just nerves or a real disorder?
faqs.answer: This could be physiologic tremor. All of us have a very fine, fast tremor that you can't see. This tremor gets enhanced (more noticeable) by adrenaline. This is why you shake when you are anxious, have had too much caffeine, or are sleep-deprived. This is not a disease. However, if you have an underlying Essential Tremor, anxiety and adrenaline will also make that tremor significantly worse.

faqs.question: What is a movement disorder specialist? My regular doctor seems unsure.
faqs.answer: This is a neurologist who has done additional fellowship training focusing only on conditions like Parkinson's, tremor, dystonia, and Huntington's. They are super-specialists. Because the diagnosis of these conditions is almost 100% based on visual clinical examination (watching you move) and not a blood test or scan, you want an expert who has seen it all to make the correct diagnosis.

faqs.question: I have a slow-growing, painless lump in my leg. My doctor said it's a myxofibrosarcoma. Is this related to fat like a liposarcoma?
faqs.answer: No, it's a different type of soft tissue sarcoma. While a liposarcoma arises from fat cells, a myxofibrosarcoma arises from fibroblast cells (connective tissue) and is notable for its myxoid (jelly-like or mucous-like) stroma. It's one of the most common sarcomas in the arms and legs of older adults (age 50-70).

faqs.question: My doctor said this cancer is infiltrative and has tentacles. What does that mean for surgery?
faqs.answer: This is the key feature and biggest challenge of myxofibrosarcoma. Unlike other tumors that grow as a ball, this one grows tentacles or tails that infiltrate along the layers of muscle and tissue, often far beyond what the surgeon can see or feel. This means there is a very high risk of local recurrence (it coming back in the same spot) because a few tentacles are left behind. This is why the surgeon must take wide margins (a huge cuff of normal tissue), and radiation is almost always used to clean up the area.

faqs.question: What's the difference between low-grade and high-grade myxofibrosarcoma?
faqs.answer: This is the most important prognostic factor. Low-grade tumors are very indolent (lazy). They have a very high risk of local recurrence (coming back in the same spot) but a very low risk of metastasizing (spreading to the lungs). High-grade tumors are much more aggressive. They also have a high risk of local recurrence, but they additionally have a much higher risk (up to 30-40%) of spreading to the lungs. This is why high-grade tumors are often treated with chemotherapy.

faqs.question: My tumor was low-grade, but it came back 5 years later, and now they're saying it's high-grade. How did it change?
faqs.answer: This is a known and dangerous behavior of this specific sarcoma. It is common for myxofibrosarcoma to progress in grade over time. It may start as a low-grade tumor, but when it recurs (comes back), it can come back as a higher, more aggressive grade. This is why all recurrences must be biopsied and treated very aggressively.

faqs.question: Why do I need a CT scan of my chest for a tumor in my leg?
faqs.answer: This is a staging scan. All sarcomas, especially high-grade ones, have a tendency to spread through the bloodstream, and the #1 place they land and form new tumors (metastases) is in the lungs. Your chest CT is to make 100% sure the cancer has not already spread, as this would completely change the treatment plan from curative-intent local surgery to systemic treatment with chemotherapy.

faqs.question: I have these deep, aching knots in my shoulders that won't go away. My doctor said myofascial pain. Is this the same as fibromyalgia?
faqs.answer: No, they are different, though often confused. Fibromyalgia is a centralized pain syndrome (a problem with how your brain processes pain) that causes widespread, symmetrical pain and tenderness all over your body, plus severe fatigue. Myofascial Pain Syndrome (MPS) is a localized pain problem. It's caused by trigger points—which are specific, taut bands (knots) in a muscle—that cause both local pain and (importantly) referred pain (pain in a different, predictable location).

faqs.question: What is referred pain? My doctor pressed on my shoulder and my hand went numb.
faqs.answer: That is the hallmark of a trigger point. A trigger point refers pain and other sensations (like numbness, tingling, or aching) in a predictable pattern that is different from a pinched nerve (dermatome). For example, a trigger point in your scalene neck muscle can refer pain all the way down your arm, mimicking carpal tunnel syndrome. A trigger point in your gluteus minimus muscle can refer pain down your leg, mimicking sciatica.

faqs.question: What causes these trigger points to form?
faqs.answer: They are usually caused by micro-trauma to the muscle. This can be from an acute injury (like whiplash) or, more commonly, from chronic muscle overload. This includes poor posture (like tech neck from looking at a phone), repetitive motions (like using a mouse all day), or even things like vitamin D deficiency or poor sleep, which make your muscles more irritable.

faqs.question: My physical therapist wants to do dry needling. Is that the same as acupuncture? It sounds scary.
faqs.answer: It is not the same as acupuncture (which is based on meridians). In dry needling, the therapist inserts a thin, dry (no-medication) needle directly into your trigger point. The goal is to elicit a local twitch response (the muscle jumps). This twitch is thought to break the knot, release the muscle tension, and reboot the nerve-muscle connection, providing significant and often immediate pain relief.

faqs.question: I just get massages, but the knots always come back. What am I doing wrong?
faqs.answer: Massage is great for temporary relief, but it's passive. The trigger points are just the symptom. They are coming back because the underlying cause hasn't been fixed. This is where physical therapy is critical. A good PT will not only release the trigger point (with dry needling or manual therapy) but will also identify why it's there. They will then give you stretching and strengthening exercises to correct the postural imbalances (e.g., strengthening your weak mid-back to fix your forward shoulder posture) that are causing the knot in the first place.

faqs.question: I keep having these sudden, jerking spasms in my arm. It's like a jolt I can't control. Is this a seizure?
faqs.answer: It might be, or it might be myoclonus. Myoclonus is the medical term for a sudden, brief, involuntary muscle jerk. It's not a shaking (like a tremor); it's a shock-like contraction. It can be a symptom of many different things. A myoclonic seizure is a type of epilepsy, but myoclonus can also be caused by nerve damage, medication side effects, or metabolic problems (like kidney failure).

faqs.question: As I'm falling asleep, I sometimes have a hypnic jerk that wakes me up. Is this a myoclonus?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the most common (and completely normal) type of myoclonus. These hypnagogic jerks or sleep starts are physiologic (benign) myoclonus. Hiccups are another form of normal, physiologic myoclonus (a jerk of your diaphragm). This is not a sign of a neurological disease.

faqs.question: My myoclonus only happens after I've been working out. What could that be?
faqs.answer: This is often exercise-induced myoclonus. It's usually benign and thought to be from hyperexcitability of the motor neurons due to fatigue. However, any new-onset myoclonus should be evaluated by a neurologist to rule out more serious causes.

faqs.question: My father had a cardiac arrest, and now that he's in the hospital, he's having constant jerks. The doctor called it anoxic myoclonus.
faqs.answer: This is a very serious and, unfortunately, very common finding. After a cardiac arrest, the brain is starved of oxygen (this is anoxia). This anoxic brain injury can cause severe, widespread, and constant myoclonic jerks (called myoclonic status). It is generally a sign of a very severe brain injury.

faqs.question: How do you even treat myoclonus? It's so fast.
faqs.answer: Treatment depends entirely on the cause. If it's from a medication, you stop the medication. If it's from kidney failure, dialysis will help. If there is no reversible cause and the jerks are disabling (e.g., in epilepsy or progressive myoclonic ataxia), we treat it symptomatically. The medications most effective at calming the jerks are often anti-seizure medications, particularly Levetiracetam (Keppra) or clonazepam.

faqs.question: I had a bad case of the flu (or COVID) 2 weeks ago, and now I'm having chest pain and my heart feels like it's fluttering. Could this be my heart?
faqs.answer: Yes, and you must take this very seriously. This is the classic presentation of viral myocarditis. The virus (like Influenza, COVID-19, or Coxsackie) infects your heart muscle, or (more commonly) your immune system's response to the virus attacks your heart muscle, causing inflammation. This myocarditis (inflammation of the heart muscle) can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, and, in severe cases, acute heart failure.

faqs.question: The ER doctor said my troponin level is high. I thought that meant a heart attack?
faqs.answer: A high troponin level is the blood test for a heart attack (myocardial infarction). Troponin is a protein that is only released from injured heart muscle. In a heart attack, the injury is from a blocked artery. In myocarditis, the injury is from inflammation. Both spill troponin into the blood. So, you are having heart muscle damage, but the cause is inflammation, not a blockage. The ER will do an angiogram to prove your arteries are clear, which confirms the diagnosis of myocarditis.

faqs.question: My son (a teenage boy) had myocarditis after his COVID vaccination. Is this common?
faqs.answer: This is a very rare (but real) side effect that was identified, primarily in adolescent and young adult males, after the mRNA COVID-19 vaccines. The vast, vast majority of these cases were mild, self-resolving, and the patients recovered fully. It's important to know that the risk of getting myocarditis from the COVID-19 infection itself is significantly higher and more severe than the rare risk from the vaccine.

faqs.question: My doctor told me I can't exercise for 3 to 6 months. That seems extreme! I feel fine now.
faqs.answer: This is the most critical part of your recovery, and it is not extreme. Your heart muscle is inflamed and weak. Exercising (getting your heart rate up) puts enormous stress on this inflamed muscle. This can trigger life-threatening arrhythmias (ventricular tachycardia) or cause permanent scarring (fibrosis). This scarring is what leads to long-term heart failure. You must rest your heart, with no competitive sports or heavy exertion, until your cardiologist (and follow-up echo/MRI) confirms the inflammation is completely gone.

faqs.question: Will I have permanent heart damage from this?
faqs.answer: The good news is that the vast majority of people with acute viral myocarditis make a full recovery with no long-term damage, if they are treated (with supportive heart failure medications) and if they follow the strict rest/no-exercise protocol. However, a small percentage can develop chronic dilated cardiomyopathy (a weak, baggy heart) that leads to long-term heart failure.

faqs.question: What's the difference between myocardial ischemia and a heart attack (myocardial infarction)?
faqs.answer: This is a supply and demand problem. Ischemia (also called angina) is a warning. It's when a coronary artery is narrowed (e.g., 70% blocked), and when you demand more blood (like by walking uphill), not enough can get through. This starves the heart muscle of oxygen, causing chest pain. It's temporary and reversible. When you rest, the pain goes away and there is no permanent damage. A Myocardial Infarction (heart attack) is when the plaque ruptures and a clot completely blocks the artery (100%). The oxygen starvation is permanent, and the heart muscle dies. This is an emergency.

faqs.question: I had a positive stress test. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: A positive stress test means you developed ischemia (or signs of it on your EKG) when you stressed your heart (by walking on a treadmill or with medication). It means you almost certainly have a significant blockage (or blockages) in your coronary arteries. A negative test is when you reached your target heart rate with no pain and no EKG changes. A positive test is the green light for your cardiologist to order a cardiac catheterization (angiogram) to go look for the blockage.

faqs.question: I'm a woman and I don't get crushing chest pain. I just get exhausted, nauseous, and have jaw pain. Could this be ischemia?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is critically important. While classic angina is chest pressure, women, older adults, and diabetics are far more likely to have atypical symptoms. These anginal equivalents can include: profound shortness of breath (especially with exertion), nausea, jaw pain, back pain, or just extreme, sudden fatigue. This is your heart's warning sign, and it must be taken just as seriously as chest pain.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have stable angina. What makes it unstable?
faqs.answer: Stable angina is predictable. You know it will happen when you walk up two flights of stairs, and you know it will go away when you rest. Unstable angina is an emergency and is ACS (Acute Coronary Syndrome), just like a heart attack. Unstable means: 1) It's new. 2) It's happening at rest (e.g., while watching TV). 3) It's worsening (your stable angina that used to happen after 2 blocks now happens after 1). This is a sign your plaque is unstable and about to rupture, and you need to go to the ER.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have microvascular ischemia. My angiogram was normal. How is that possible?
faqs.answer: This is a common and frustrating diagnosis, especially in women. An angiogram only sees the large, epicardial arteries on the outside of the heart. Microvascular ischemia means your large arteries are clean, but the tiny, microscopic arteries that dive into the heart muscle are dysfunctional. They don't dilate (open up) properly when you exercise. So, you get real ischemia and real chest pain, but the plumbing (the big arteries) looks fine. This is treated with medication, not stents.

faqs.question: My doctor said my bone marrow is scarred and my spleen is massive. I have myelofibrosis. What is happening?
faqs.answer: Myelofibrosis is a rare, chronic blood cancer. In this disease, your blood factory (the bone marrow) is taken over by abnormal stem cells. These cells release inflammatory signals that cause massive scar tissue (fibrosis) to build up inside your marrow. Because your marrow is scarred and clogged, it can't make blood cells. Your body tries to compensate by starting to make blood in other organs. The main backup factory is your spleen, which is why it becomes massive (this is extramedullary hematopoiesis).

faqs.question: My blood smear showed teardrop red cells. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is a hallmark sign of myelofibrosis on a blood smear. Your red blood cells are born in the bone marrow. In MF, to get out of the marrow, they have to squeeze their way through all of that dense scar tissue. This squeezing deforms them and stretches them into a teardrop shape. Seeing these cells is a strong clue that something is physically wrong inside the marrow.

faqs.question: What is the JAK2 mutation? My doctor tested me for it.
faqs.answer: The JAK2 (V617F) mutation is the on-switch for this disease (and its cousins, polycythemia vera and essential thrombocythemia). The JAK2 gene is a growth signal for your bone marrow. In about 50-60% of MF patients, this gene is mutated to be stuck in the on position. This is what drives the overproduction of abnormal cells and the inflammation that causes the scarring. Finding this mutation confirms the diagnosis.

faqs.question: I'm having drenching night sweats and I've lost 20 pounds. Is this from the MF?
faqs.answer: Yes. These are the severe constitutional symptoms of myelofibrosis. The disease is driven by a massive storm of inflammation (cytokines) from the abnormal cells. This inflammation is what causes the B symptoms: drenching night sweats, fever, profound fatigue, and cachexia (unintentional weight loss) as your body burns energy from the constant inflammation. JAK inhibitors (like Jakafi/ruxolitinib) are pills that are extremely effective at turning off this inflammation, shrinking the spleen, and stopping these symptoms.

faqs.question: Is a stem cell transplant the only cure?
faqs.answer: Yes. An allogeneic stem cell transplant (using a donor's stem cells) is the only potential cure for myelofibrosis. All other treatments (like JAK inhibitors) are palliative—they control the symptoms and the spleen, but they do not cure the underlying disease. The transplant is a very high-risk procedure, so it is typically only an option for younger, fitter patients who have high-risk disease. It works by completely replacing your scarred, abnormal marrow with a new, healthy one from your donor.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have MDS and called it pre-leukemia. Am I going to get leukemia?
faqs.answer: Pre-leukemia is a scary, but common, way to describe MDS. MDS is a form of bone marrow cancer, but it's usually low-grade. It means your bone marrow factory has become ineffective and is producing blood cells that are abnormal (dysplastic) and die before they ever get out into your bloodstream. This leads to low blood counts. The risk of MDS transforming into Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) depends entirely on your risk score (which is based on your blood counts and specific chromosome changes). For low-risk MDS, the risk is very low. For high-risk MDS, it is significant.

faqs.question: My main problem is anemia (low red cells). Why can't I just take iron pills?
faqs.answer: This is not a storage problem; it's a factory problem. Your factory (bone marrow) has plenty of iron, but it's ineffective—it can't build a proper red blood cell. So, giving you more iron is useless and can actually be dangerous (causing iron overload). Your anemia is because the dysplastic (abnormal) red cells are dying in the factory before they can be released. This is why the main treatment for MDS-anemia is blood transfusions or growth factor shots (ESA) to stimulate the factory to work harder.

faqs.question: What does dysplasia mean? My doctor said my cells look dysplastic.
faqs.answer: Dysplasia is a pathologist's word for abnormal-looking. When they look at your bone marrow under a microscope, your cells just look wrong. For example, your baby red blood cells might have two nuclei instead of one, or your baby neutrophils might not have the right granules. This abnormal morphology is the hallmark of MDS and proves that the factory is faulty.

faqs.question: I need blood transfusions every few weeks, and now my doctor is worried about iron overload. How?
faqs.answer: This is a major, long-term complication of MDS. Every bag of red blood cells you receive contains a large amount of iron. Your body has no natural way to excrete this excess iron. Over time (usually after 20-30 transfusions), this iron builds up and gets deposited in your vital organs, primarily your liver and heart, where it acts like a rust and causes organ damage. Your doctor will monitor your ferritin (iron storage) level and may start you on iron chelation therapy (a pill or shot that grabs the iron so you can excrete it).

faqs.question: My MDS has a 5q deletion. Is that good or bad?
faqs.answer: That is very specific and, relatively speaking, good news. Deletion 5q (del-5q) is a specific genetic subtype of MDS. It's good for two reasons: 1) It's associated with low-risk MDS and a low risk of transforming to leukemia. 2) It is uniquely sensitive to a specific oral medication, Lenalidomide (Revlimid). This pill is highly effective at fixing the anemia in del-5q patients, often making them transfusion-independent.

faqs.question: I had optic neuritis (blurry, painful vision) and my doctor thought it was MS. But my MOG antibody test came back positive. What is this?
faqs.answer: You have been diagnosed with MOGAD. This is a newly recognized autoimmune disease that, for decades, was misdiagnosed as MS (Multiple Sclerosis) or NMOSD (Neuromyelitis Optica). It's not MS. It's a different disease where your immune system specifically attacks a protein on your optic nerves and spinal cord called MOG (Myelin Oligodendrocyte Glycoprotein). Finding the MOG antibody in your blood is what defines this disease and rules out MS.

faqs.question: How is MOGAD different from MS? My symptoms were the same.
faqs.answer: The acute attacks (like optic neuritis or transverse myelitis) look identical. The differences are critical: 1) Recovery: MS attacks often leave residual damage. MOGAD attacks, while often more severe at onset (e.g., both eyes go blind), tend to have an excellent recovery after high-dose steroids. 2) MRI: MS brains are littered with chronic, smoldering lesions. MOGAD brains often look clean between attacks. 3) Prognosis: MS is (often) a progressive disease that gets worse between relapses. MOGAD is not progressive; you are well between attacks.

faqs.question: I had one bad attack of transverse myelitis. My doctor says I might not need long-term treatment. Is that true?
faqs.answer: This is a key feature of MOGAD. About 50% of people (especially adults) have a monophasic course—they have one single, bad attack (like optic neuritis or myelitis), are treated, and it never comes back. The other 50% (especially children) have a relapsing course. Because of this 50/50 chance, your doctor may treat your acute attack and then watch you. If you have a second attack, you will be diagnosed with relapsing MOGAD and will be put on a long-term immunosuppressant (like Rituximab or CellCept) to prevent future attacks.

faqs.question: Are the disease-modifying therapies for MS (like Copaxone or Gilenya) used for MOGAD?
faqs.answer: No, and this is critically important. Not only do the MS DMTs not work for MOGAD, but some of them (like interferon) are thought to worsen MOGAD and cause more relapses. This is why getting the correct diagnosis (MS vs. MOGAD vs. NMOSD) is the most important step. The treatment for relapsing MOGAD is long-term immune suppression (e.g., IVIG, Rituximab, mycophenolate), not MS DMTs.

faqs.question: My child had a seizure and encephalitis (brain inflammation) and was diagnosed with ADEM. Is this related?
faqs.answer: Yes. ADEM (Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis) is a monophasic inflammatory attack on the brain, often post-viral. It's now known that a large percentage of pediatric ADEM cases are, in fact, the first presentation of MOGAD. Any child presenting with ADEM must be tested for the MOG antibody, as a positive test means they are at high risk for a future relapse (like optic neuritis) and have MOGAD.

faqs.question: I have a canker sore on the side of my tongue that just won't heal. It's been 3 weeks. When should I worry?
faqs.answer: You should worry now and see an ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat) or dentist immediately. A typical aphthous ulcer (canker sore) is painful and heals within 7-14 days. The red flag for mouth cancer (squamous cell carcinoma) is any ulcer, red patch, or white patch in the mouth that does not heal after 2-3 weeks. Cancerous lesions are often (but not always) painless in the early stages, which makes them easy to ignore.

faqs.question: What's the difference between mouth cancer in the front (lip/tongue) and the back (tonsil/base of tongue)?
faqs.answer: This is the most important distinction in modern oral cancer. They are two different diseases with different causes. Front-of-mouth cancer (oral cavity: lip, gums, floor of mouth, front 2/3 of tongue) is the classic type, almost always caused by tobacco and alcohol use. Back-of-mouth cancer (oropharynx: tonsils, base of tongue) is now overwhelmingly (70-80% of cases) caused by the Human Papillomavirus (HPV), the same virus that causes cervical cancer. This HPV-positive cancer responds much better to treatment.

faqs.question: I've never smoked, but I was just diagnosed with HPV-positive tonsil cancer. How did I get this?
faqs.answer: HPV is a very common sexually transmitted virus that is primarily spread through oral-genital contact. Most people (over 80%) get an HPV infection in their lifetime, and their immune system clears it with no symptoms. In a very, very small number of people, the virus hides in the crypts of the tonsils for decades, and (rarely) it can turn on a cancer gene and cause cancer 20-30 years later. It is not a sign of promiscuity; it's a sign of a very common virus that, in your case, unfortunately, persisted.

faqs.question: My dentist found a white patch (leukoplakia) under my tongue. He wants to biopsy it. Does this mean it's cancer?
faqs.answer: No. Leukoplakia (white patch) or erythroplakia (red patch) are pre-cancerous lesions. It means the tissue is abnormal and at risk. The biopsy is to find out how abnormal it is. The pathologist will grade it as benign, mild dysplasia, moderate dysplasia, or severe dysplasia/carcinoma in situ. Severe dysplasia is essentially pre-cancer (Stage 0) and will be removed. The biopsy is to catch it before it becomes an invasive cancer.

faqs.question: I'm having my oral cancer surgically removed. The doctor also wants to do a neck dissection. Why? The cancer is in my tongue.
faqs.answer: This is the standard of care. Oral cancer (especially of the tongue) has a very high risk of metastasizing (spreading) early to the lymph nodes in the neck. It does this microscopically, long before you can feel a lump. The neck dissection is a staging and curative procedure where the surgeon prophylactically removes the lymph nodes in that drainage basin to check them. Finding positive nodes means the cancer has spread, and you will need adjuvant (add-on) radiation or chemo-radiation after surgery.

faqs.question: Why am I a mosquito magnet? My friends are fine, but I get eaten alive.
faqs.answer: It's not your sweet blood—it's your smell. Mosquitoes (only the females bite) hunt using a few cues. The #1 cue is carbon dioxide (CO2); they can see your CO2 plume from a distance. People with a higher metabolic rate (e.g., people who are larger, pregnant, or have just exercised) exhale more CO2 and are brighter targets. Up close, they smell your skin odor (the specific mix of chemicals like lactic acid and ammonia in your sweat). This is largely genetic, and some people's odor profile is just more attractive to them.

faqs.question: My child's mosquito bites swell up to the size of a golf ball and get hard. Is he allergic?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a real (and common) allergic reaction called Skeeter Syndrome. Most people just have a small, itchy bump. Your child is having a large, local allergic reaction to the proteins in the mosquito's saliva. This can cause massive swelling, heat, redness, and sometimes even low-grade fever. It's not a sign of infection. It can be treated with topical steroids (hydrocortisone) and oral antihistamines (like Benadryl or Zyrtec).

faqs.question: I scratched my bite and now it's hot, red, and weeping yellow pus. What's wrong?
faqs.answer: The bite is now infected. This is a secondary bacterial infection (a cellulitis or impetigo). The mosquito bite itself was just itchy. When you scratched it (especially with dirty fingernails), you inoculated (introduced) bacteria from your skin (like Staph or Strep) into the open wound. This is now a bacterial infection that needs to be seen by a doctor. You will likely need oral antibiotics to clear it up.

faqs.question: I got bit a week ago and now I have a fever and a bad headache. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. While most bites are harmless, mosquitoes are vectors for serious diseases. Depending on where you live (or traveled), a fever, headache, body aches, and stiff neck a few days to two weeks after a bite could be a sign of a mosquito-borne illness like West Nile Virus. You should see a doctor and tell them you were recently bitten.

faqs.question: What's more effective, DEET or natural repellents like citronella?
faqs.answer: Hands down, DEET is the gold standard and is far more effective and longer-lasting than any natural alternative. It is the most-studied, safest, and most effective repellent. The percentage (e.g., 20% vs 50%) does not mean it's stronger—it means it lasts longer. For natural options, the only one that comes close is Picaridin or Oil of Lemon Eucalyptus (PMD), which are also EPA-registered as effective, but typically for a shorter duration than DEET.

faqs.question: I have this weird pain in the ball of my foot, like my sock is bunched up or I'm walking on a pebble. Sometimes my toes go numb. What is this?
faqs.answer: That is the absolute classic description of a Morton's Neuroma. It's not really a tumor or cancer. It's a benign (harmless) thickening of the tissue around the interdigital nerve that runs between your metatarsal bones (the long bones of your foot). The most common spot is between the 3rd and 4th toes. When you walk, this thickened nerve gets pinched between the bones, causing the pebble feeling, sharp pain, or numbness/tingling in those two toes.

faqs.question: Why did I get this? My doctor blamed my bad shoes.
faqs.answer: Your doctor is very likely correct. The #1 risk factor is footwear. Anything that squeezes your forefoot (metatarsal bones) together pinches that nerve. This includes high heels (which jam your weight onto the forefoot) and narrow, pointy-toed shoes. People with flat feet or bunions are also at higher risk because their foot mechanics already put stress on that area.

faqs.question: My podiatrist wants to give me a cortisone shot. How does that help?
faqs.answer: A corticosteroid injection is a common and effective first-line treatment. The neuroma is an inflamed, swollen nerve. The steroid is a powerful anti-inflammatory that is injected right at the hot spot to calm down the inflammation and shrink the swollen tissue. This de-pinches the nerve and can give you significant (or even permanent) relief. It may take 1-2 shots.

faqs.question: What's a metatarsal pad? Will that help?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is another key conservative treatment. A metatarsal pad (or neuroma pad) is a small, teardrop-shaped pad. You place it in your shoe so it sits just behind the painful ball of your foot. It is not a cushion for the spot. Its job is to lift and separate the metatarsal bones, giving the pinched nerve more room so it doesn't get squished when you walk. This, combined with wide-toed shoes, is very effective.

faqs.question: If the shot doesn't work, is surgery my only option?
faqs.answer: If you've failed conservative measures (wide shoes, metatarsal pads, steroid injections), then yes, surgery is the next step. The surgeon has two options: 1) A decompression (where they just release the tight ligament over the nerve to give it more room), or 2) A neurectomy (where they go in and cut out the neuroma and that small section of nerve). This is very effective at stopping the pain, but it will leave you with permanent numbness in the web space between those two toes (which most people don't mind).

faqs.question: I have this hard, waxy, discolored patch on my stomach. My doctor said morphea. Is this the same as scleroderma?
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction. Morphea is a form of localized scleroderma. This means it's an autoimmune disease where collagen is overproduced, causing the skin to become hard and waxy (sclerotic), but it is confined only to the skin (and sometimes the tissue just under it). Systemic scleroderma (or systemic sclerosis) is the scary one. It is a different disease that also causes skin hardening plus it affects internal organs (like the lungs, heart, and kidneys). Morphea does not turn into systemic scleroderma.

faqs.question: My morphea looks like a streak or line down my forehead. My doctor called it en coup de sabre.
faqs.answer: This is linear morphea. When it happens on the face or scalp, it's called en coup de sabre (French for cut of a sword) because it looks like an indented scar. This type is more serious than a plaque on your trunk because, as it's tethered to the bone, it can atrophy (waste away) the tissue underneath it (the fat, muscle, and even bone) and cause cosmetic asymmetry. It's often treated more aggressively.

faqs.question: My patch is active—it's red and itchy around the edge. What does active mean?
faqs.answer: The active phase is the inflammatory phase. The lilac-colored or red ring around the waxy center is where your immune system is currently attacking and laying down the new, bad collagen. This is the window of opportunity for treatment. We use anti-inflammatory treatments (like strong topical steroid creams or calcipotriene) on this active border to try and turn off the attack and stop the scar from getting bigger.

faqs.question: Will these patches ever go away? Will my skin go back to normal?
faqs.answer: Morphea often burns itself out (becomes inactive) after 3-5 years. The active red border will fade, and the skin will soften. However, it often leaves permanent post-inflammatory changes. The scar tissue (sclerosis) may soften but not disappear, and it often leaves a darkened (hyperpigmented) or sometimes lightened (atrophic) patch behind. The goal of treatment is to limit the size of this permanent damage.

faqs.question: My child has linear morphea on his leg. Is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: Linear morphea on a limb (arm or leg) in a child must be watched closely by a pediatric rheumatologist. Because the sclerotic band is tethered to the bone and crosses joints, it can anchor the skin. As the child's bones grow, the anchored skin doesn't, and this can lead to joint contractures (a frozen or bent joint) or even a limb length discrepancy (one leg becomes shorter than the other). This is why it's treated aggressively with physical therapy and systemic medications (like methotrexate).

faqs.question: I'm 8 weeks pregnant and I'm nauseous all day. Why is it called morning sickness when it's 24/7?
faqs.answer: Morning sickness is a terrible name. All-day sickness is far more accurate. It's thought to be caused by the massive surge of the pregnancy hormone hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), which peaks around 8-10 weeks of pregnancy (which is exactly when most women feel the worst). Because your hCG levels are high 24/7, the nausea can be constant. It often fades as you enter the second trimester, when hCG levels start to drop.

faqs.question: I'm so sick I can't eat anything. Is this going to hurt my baby?
faqs.answer: This is a very common worry, but in the first trimester, the baby is tiny (the size of a raspberry at 8 weeks) and has very low caloric needs. The baby will take what it needs from your body's stores. As long as you are staying hydrated (this is the key!), the nausea and poor eating for a few weeks will not harm your baby. The eating for two part comes later. Just eat what you can, when you can.

faqs.question: What can I actually do? Eat crackers isn't working.
faqs.answer: The cracker advice is about never letting your stomach get empty, as an empty stomach produces acid and makes nausea worse. The #1, first-line medical advice is the Unisom and B6 combination. You can take Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) during the day, and then add a Unisom SleepTab (which is just the antihistamine doxylamine) at night. This combination is proven to be safe, effective, and is the active ingredient in the prescription drug Diclegis.

faqs.question: I can't keep anything down, not even water, and I've lost 5 pounds. When does it become serious?
faqs.answer: You are describing Hyperemesis Gravidarum (HG). This is not morning sickness; it's a severe medical condition. The red flags are: losing more than 5% of your pre-pregnancy weight, inability to tolerate liquids for > 12 hours, and signs of dehydration (dark tea-colored urine, dizziness, high heart rate). You must go to your doctor or the ER. You will likely need IV fluids to rehydrate you and stronger, prescription anti-nausea medications (like Zofran or Reglan).

faqs.question: I'm 10 weeks pregnant with twins and I'm so much sicker than with my first. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: Yes. It is very normal to be sicker with a twin (or multiple) pregnancy. The leading theory is that morning sickness is dose-dependent on the hCG hormone. A twin pregnancy produces far higher levels of hCG than a singleton pregnancy, so it is very common (and expected) for your nausea and vomiting to be significantly more severe.

faqs.question: I feel down and empty all the time. How do I know if I'm just sad or if I have major depression?
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction. Sadness is a normal, temporary human emotion that is usually a reaction to an event (e.g., a loss or disappointment). Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is a clinical illness. The red flags are: 1) Duration: The empty or hopeless feeling is present most of the day, almost every day, for at least two weeks. 2) Anhedonia: You've lost all interest or pleasure in things you used to enjoy (food, hobbies, socializing). 3) Functional Impairment: It's interfering with your ability to function (work, sleep, eat, or care for yourself).

faqs.question: What's the difference between major depression and bipolar disorder?
faqs.answer: Major Depression (or unipolar depression) is a disorder of one pole: the low (depression). Bipolar Disorder is a disorder of two poles: the low (depression) and the high (mania or hypomania). A person with bipolar disorder has episodes of depression, but they also have episodes of mania (high energy, no sleep, racing thoughts, grandiose ideas, reckless behavior). Giving an antidepressant to someone with bipolar depression can be dangerous and can trigger a manic episode.

faqs.question: What does hypomania feel like? My doctor asked if I've had it.
faqs.answer: This is the key to diagnosing Bipolar II Disorder. Hypomania is a milder high than full mania. It doesn't break from reality (no psychosis), but it's a clear change from your normal self. Your friends/family would notice. You might feel on top of the world, have tons of energy on no sleep (e.g., you sleep 3 hours and feel wired), be hyper-productive or hyper-social, talk really fast, or be irritable and snappy. It feels good (or agitated), so people rarely report it to a doctor—they only report the lows.

faqs.question: I have depression. Do I have to take medication? Can't I just do therapy?
faqs.answer: For mild to moderate depression, therapy (especially Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy, CBT) is a first-line and highly effective treatment, and it may be all you need. For severe depression (e.g., you can't get out of bed, you have suicidal thoughts), the evidence is clear that a combination of both medication (like an SSRI) and therapy is far more effective than either one alone. The meds help turn down the static and fix the biology (giving you the energy to get out of bed), and the therapy teaches you the skills to change your thinking and prevent a relapse.

faqs.question: I was diagnosed with seasonal affective disorder (SAD). Is that a real mood disorder?
faqs.answer: Yes. It is a real and official subtype of major depression. It is not just the winter blues. It is a predictable, recurring major depressive episode that begins only in the fall/winter (as the days get shorter) and completely remits (goes away) only in the spring/summer. It's thought to be triggered by the lack of sunlight disrupting your circadian rhythm and your serotonin levels. The first-line treatment for it is Light Therapy (sitting in front of a 10,000-lux light box for 30 minutes every morning).

faqs.question: I'm a 19-year-old and I've been exhausted for 3 weeks, with a terrible sore throat and swollen glands. Is this mono?
faqs.answer: That is the absolute classic triad for infectious mononucleosis in a young adult: 1) Profound fatigue (a wiped out exhaustion, not just tired), 2) Severe sore throat (pharyngitis), often with white exudate (pus) on the tonsils, and 3) Swollen lymph nodes (cervical adenopathy), especially a chain of them on the back of your neck. You need to see a doctor for a monospot test.

faqs.question: Why is it called the kissing disease? My girlfriend feels fine.
faqs.answer: It's called that because the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), which causes 90% of mono, is transmitted through saliva. This can be from kissing, but it's also from sharing drinks, water bottles, or utensils. The incubation period is very long (4-6 weeks), so you could have been exposed over a month ago. Also, many people (especially young children) get infected with EBV, have no symptoms at all, and then shed the virus in their saliva silently for life. Your girlfriend may be one of these asymptomatic carriers.

faqs.question: My doctor told me I can't play football or lift weights for a month. Why? I just have a sore throat!
faqs.answer: This is the most serious and non-negotiable part of mono. The EBV virus also infects your spleen, causing it to become enlarged and fragile (splenomegaly). Your spleen is under your left ribcage. If you receive any trauma to your abdomen (a tackle, a fall, or even just straining from heavy lifting), your enlarged, fragile spleen can rupture. A ruptured spleen is a life-threatening internal bleeding emergency. You must be on pelvic rest (no contact sports, no heavy lifting) until a doctor clears you (usually 4-6 weeks).

faqs.question: My monospot test came back negative, but my doctor is sure I have mono. How is that possible?
faqs.answer: The monospot test is a rapid test that looks for heterophile antibodies in your blood. It is notoriously unreliable in the first 1-2 weeks of the illness (it can be false negative up to 25% of the time). A negative monospot does not rule out mono. Your doctor is making the diagnosis clinically (based on your classic symptoms) and may order the definitive test, which is the EBV-antibody panel (which looks for specific IgM and IgG antibodies to the virus itself).

faqs.question: How long will this fatigue last? I can't function.
faqs.answer: This is the hallmark of mono. The acute symptoms (fever, sore throat) usually go away in 1-2 weeks. However, the profound fatigue and malaise (general unwellness) can linger for 4 to 8 weeks, and sometimes for months. You cannot push through it. You must give in to the fatigue and rest, or you will prolong your recovery.

faqs.question: My doctor found an abnormal protein in my blood and said I have MGUS. He said it's not cancer but pre-cancer. Should I be terrified?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and scary thing to hear. The key word is Undetermined Significance. MGUS is not cancer. It's a benign (non-cancerous) condition where a group of your plasma cells (a type of immune cell) are producing an abnormal protein. The only reason it's called pre-cancer is that it has a very low risk (about 1% per year) of progressing into a cancer like multiple myeloma. For the vast majority of people, it remains benign for their entire life.

faqs.question: What's the difference between MGUS and smoldering myeloma? My numbers are confusing.
faqs.answer: This is a numbers game. The diagnosis depends on how much abnormal protein there is and how many plasma cells are in your bone marrow. MGUS is the lowest level (abnormal protein < 3 g/dL and < 10% plasma cells in the marrow). Smoldering Myeloma is the intermediate stage (protein > 3 g/dL OR > 10% plasma cells). The key is that neither MGUS nor Smoldering Myeloma has any organ damage (no CRAB symptoms: high Calcium, Renal failure, Anemia, Bone lesions). Active Myeloma is when you do have organ damage.

faqs.question: My doctor just wants to watch and wait. Why aren't we treating this before it turns into something?
faqs.answer: This is the standard of care because, for 99% of people, there is nothing to treat. MGUS itself is harmless. The treatments for myeloma (like chemotherapy) are highly toxic and have serious side effects. Giving this toxic treatment to a person who has a 99% chance each year of not developing cancer would be causing far more harm than good. Watch and wait (with blood tests every 6-12 months) is the safest and most effective way to monitor you, allowing doctors to act only if it ever shows signs of progressing.

faqs.question: Can I lower my M-protein spike with diet or exercise? I want to do something.
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, no. The production of this abnormal M-protein (monoclonal protein) is an autonomous process from that specific clone of plasma cells. It is not related to your diet, lifestyle, weight, or exercise. There is no known lifestyle modification that can make the protein level go down or reduce the risk of progression. The best thing you can do is live a healthy life and be diligent about your follow-up blood tests.

faqs.question: Does this abnormal protein damage my body? My doctor mentioned my kidneys.
faqs.answer: In most cases, no. But in a small subset of MGUS, the protein itself (even at low levels) can be sticky and cause damage, most commonly to the kidneys or nerves. This is a newer concept called MGRS (Monoclonal Gammopathy of Renal Significance) or MGNS (of Neurologic Significance). If you have MGUS and new, unexplained kidney problems or neuropathy, your doctor will investigate if the benign protein is the culprit, which would require treatment.

faqs.question: My son has these weird, pearly, dimpled bumps on his chest. My doctor said molluscum and that it's from a virus?
faqs.answer: Yes, that's exactly right. Molluscum contagiosum is a very common, benign skin infection caused by a poxvirus. It's extremely common in young children. The pearly or waxy bump with a tiny dimple or pit in the center is the classic description. They are harmless but can be very annoying.

faqs.question: How did my child even get this? And is it true it's contagious?
faqs.answer: It's highly contagious, which is why it's in the name! It spreads very easily through: 1) Direct skin-to-skin contact (e.g., kids wrestling, playing). 2) Fomites (contaminated objects), especially wet ones. The #1 culprit is sharing towels, bath toys, or kickboards at the swimming pool. 3) Autoinoculation (self-spreading), which is the most common reason it multiplies—the child scratches a bump, gets the waxy core (which is full of virus) under their fingernail, and then scratches somewhere else, planting a new one.

faqs.question: My doctor said the treatment is to... do nothing? Why won't they remove them?
faqs.answer: This is often the best advice, called benign neglect. Because it's a harmless virus, your child's immune system will eventually recognize it and clear it on its own. The problem is this can take a long time (6-18 months, or even longer). The removal treatments (like freezing, scraping, or blister beetle juice) can be painful, scary for a child, and can leave scars, whereas the molluscum itself usually heals without a scar. Doctors often wait it out, unless the bumps are in a very sensitive spot (like the eyelid) or the child is autoinoculating them everywhere.

faqs.question: The skin around the bumps is now red, itchy, and eczematous. Is this an infection?
faqs.answer: This is actually a good sign! This is called the BOTE sign (Beginning of the End) or molluscum dermatitis. It's a sign that your child's immune system has woken up, recognized the virus, and is launching an inflammatory attack to get rid of it. This eczema reaction is the beginning of the end for those bumps, which will often get red and crusted and then disappear for good.

faqs.question: I'm an adult and I have bumps in my groin area. Is this the same thing?
faqs.answer: Yes, in adults, molluscum is often (though not always) considered a sexually transmitted infection (STI). It's spread the same way: through close, skin-to-skin contact. It's still harmless, but in an adult, doctors are much more likely to actively treat and remove the bumps (e.g., with cryotherapy/freezing) to prevent you from spreading it to a partner.

faqs.question: What are the ABCDEs of melanoma? How do I know if my mole is bad?
faqs.answer: The ABCDEs are the red flag rules for spotting a melanoma. Asymmetry (one half doesn't match the other). Border (the edges are irregular, scalloped, or poorly defined). Color (it's not one uniform color; it has shades of black, brown, tan, or even red/blue). Diameter (it's larger than 6mm, the size of a pencil eraser—though they can be smaller). Evolving (this is the most important one—the mole is changing in size, shape, color, or is new and growing).

faqs.question: I'm 30 and I just got a new mole. I thought you were born with your moles?
faqs.answer: This is a myth. While you are born with some, most benign nevi (normal moles) appear during your childhood, teen years, and 20s/30s. This is totally normal and is related to sun exposure and genetics. However, any new mole that appears after age 40 should be looked at with much higher suspicion by a dermatologist, as the risk of a new spot being a melanoma is higher.

faqs.question: My dermatologist biopsied a mole and said it was atypical or dysplastic. Does this mean it was cancer?
faqs.answer: No, it does not mean it was cancer. A dysplastic or atypical nevus is a mole that looks weird under the microscope. It's disorganized and has some (but not all) of the features of a melanoma. It is not cancer, but it's a marker. Having one atypical mole isn't a big deal (the biopsy cured it). Having many atypical moles (called Dysplastic Nevus Syndrome) means you are at a significantly higher genetic risk of developing melanoma elsewhere on your body, and you need very close skin checks.

faqs.question: What's the ugly duckling sign? My doctor mentioned it.
faqs.answer: This is a rule that dermatologists use and is very helpful. Most of your normal moles look like each other; they have a signature pattern. The ugly duckling is the one mole that looks like nothing else on your body. It's the odd one out—it's bigger, or darker, or a different shape than all your other family of moles. This outlier is the one that deserves the most suspicion and should be checked.

faqs.question: I have a bumpy, fleshy mole on my back that's raised. My doctor isn't worried. Why? Isn't raised bad?
faqs.answer: Not at all. Raised is not one of the ABCDE criteria. A dermal nevus is a very common, benign mole that is fleshy, raised, soft, and skin-colored or light brown. It's been there for years and is stable. This is a completely different type of mole from a melanoma, which is often flat (or newly raised) and darkly/irregularly pigmented. Raised does not equal dangerous.

faqs.question: I don't have seasonal allergies, but I'm always congested and sneezing inside my house. Could this be mold?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a classic perennial (year-round) indoor allergy. While dust mites are the #1 culprit, mold allergy is a very common #2. The symptoms (stuffy nose, sinus pressure, sneezing, post-nasal drip) are chronic and are worse in specific hot spots in your house (like a damp basement, bathroom, or a musty smelling room). The spores from the mold are what you're inhaling and reacting to.

faqs.question: I looked, but I don't see any black mold. Can I still be allergic?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. First, toxic black mold (Stachybotrys) is rare, and the allergy is not to the toxin; it's to the spores. Second, the most common allergic molds (like Alternaria and Cladosporium) are often not black. Third, and most importantly, the mold is often hidden. It can be inside the walls (from a slow leak), under carpets or wallpaper, or in your HVAC/AC system. You don't have to see it to be reacting to it; you just have to smell that musty or damp odor.

faqs.question: My allergies get worse when I'm raking leaves in the fall. Is that mold too?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the other major type of mold allergy. Molds (like Alternaria) are outside as well. They live on decaying organic matter. The highest outdoor mold counts are not in the summer; they are in the fall, when the wet leaves are on the ground. Raking leaves stirs up these spores into the air, and you inhale them, triggering your hay fever (allergic rhinitis) symptoms.

faqs.question: How do I fix this? I can't get rid of all the mold.
faqs.answer: You can't, but you can control it. Mold needs water to grow. The #1 treatment is moisture control. 1) Fix all leaks. 2) Run a dehumidifier in your basement or damp areas, keeping the humidity below 50% (ideally 35-45%). 3) Run a HEPA air purifier in your bedroom to scrub the spores from the air you breathe all night. 4) Clean your bathroom/shower regularly with a bleach-based or anti-fungal cleaner to kill the visible surface mildew.

faqs.question: My doctor said my asthma is related to my mold allergy. How?
faqs.answer: This is a very strong and dangerous link. Mold is a major trigger for asthma. For people with a mold-allergic asthma, inhaling the mold spores can trigger not just a sneezy reaction, but a full-blown asthma attack (wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath). This is allergic asthma, and controlling your environment (your mold exposure) is just as important as using your inhaler.

faqs.question: I thought I was pregnant, but my ultrasound showed a snowstorm and the doctor said molar pregnancy. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is a very confusing and frightening diagnosis. A molar pregnancy (a hydatidiform mole) is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease. It is an abnormal pregnancy. It's non-viable (it can never become a baby). It's an abnormal growth of the placental (trophoblastic) tissue inside your uterus. This tissue grows rapidly in a grape-like or snowstorm pattern, which is what the doctor saw. A complete mole has no fetal tissue at all; a partial mole has some, but it's genetically abnormal.

faqs.question: My hCG levels were sky-high (like 200,000) and I was sicker than I've ever been. Is that related?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the hallmark sign. The abnormal placental tissue (the mole) is what produces the pregnancy hormone hCG. Because this tissue is overgrowing, it produces massive amounts of hCG, far higher than a normal pregnancy. This sky-high hCG level is what causes the severe hyperemesis (nausea/vomiting), preeclampsia, and other exaggerated pregnancy symptoms very early on.

faqs.question: My doctor did a D&C to remove it. Am I cured now?
faqs.answer: The D&C (Dilation & Curettage) is the first step, but it is not the cure. The cure is the follow-up. The most critical part of a molar pregnancy is that, in a small number of women (about 15-20%), some molar cells can remain in the uterine wall, or even spread. This is not cancer yet, but it's persistent disease (called Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia or GTN).

faqs.question: Why do I have to get weekly blood tests? My doctor said I can't get pregnant for a year.
faqs.answer: This is the critical follow-up I mentioned. We must track your hCG levels down to zero (and negative) for several weeks/months. If the hCG plateaus (stops dropping) or, worse, starts to rise again, it means you have persistent GTN (the cells are growing again). This requires chemotherapy to cure (it's highly curable). The reason you cannot get pregnant is that a new, healthy pregnancy also produces hCG. We would have no way of knowing if your rising hCG was from a new, healthy pregnancy or from recurrent, cancerous molar tissue. It would mask the cancer.

faqs.question: Did I get this because of something I did? Will it happen again?
faqs.answer: You did nothing wrong. A molar pregnancy is a genetic accident that happens at fertilization (e.g., in a complete mole, an empty egg is fertilized by a sperm that duplicates, or by two sperm). It is not related to your diet, exercise, or lifestyle. It is very random and bad luck. The risk of it happening again is very low (only about 1-2%), so the vast majority of women go on to have normal, healthy pregnancies afterward.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have MCTD. He said it's an overlap of Lupus, Scleroderma, and Myositis. How can I have all three?
faqs.answer: MCTD (Mixed Connective tissue Disease) is an overlap syndrome. It means you don't fit neatly into one box. You have clinical features (symptoms) from all three of those autoimmune diseases. For example, you might have the puffy fingers and Raynaud's of Scleroderma, plus the joint pain and rash of Lupus, plus the muscle weakness of Polymyositis. The one thing that ties it all together (and defines the diagnosis) is a single, specific blood test.

faqs.question: My bloodwork showed a high-titer, speckled ANA and I'm positive for anti-RNP. What is RNP?
faqs.answer: This is the key to the diagnosis. A high-titer (very positive) anti-U1-RNP antibody (or just RNP) is the hallmark blood test for MCTD. In fact, you must have this antibody to be diagnosed. This RNP antibody is what's causing your immune system to attack your tissues. Having only this antibody (and not the marker antibodies for Lupus (like anti-Smith) or Scleroderma (like anti-Scl-70)) is what points your doctor to MCTD.

faqs.question: My worst symptom is Raynaud's phenomenon. My fingers turn white, blue, and red, and it's so painful.
faqs.answer: This is a core feature of MCTD. Severe Raynaud's phenomenon (where your blood vessels in your fingers/toes spasm and shut down in the cold) is universal in MCTD (it's seen in 95-100% of patients). It's often the very first symptom, appearing years before any of the joint pain or muscle weakness begins.

faqs.question: What's the prognosis? Is this better or worse than just having Lupus?
faqs.answer: It's different. For a long time, MCTD was considered milder than Lupus or Scleroderma. This is partially true, as it tends to have a lower risk of severe kidney or brain involvement (which is common in Lupus). However, MCTD has its own major, serious risk, which is Pulmonary Hypertension (high blood pressure in the lungs). This is the most serious complication of MCTD and is what your doctor will be screening you for (with an echocardiogram) for the rest of your life.

faqs.question: Will my MCTD evolve into just Scleroderma?
faqs.answer: This is a key question in rheumatology. Over time (10-20 years), a large number of patients who are first diagnosed with MCTD will evolve and differentiate into a clear-cut case of Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma). This is why the puffy fingers and sclerodactyly (tight skin on the fingers) are such important clues. However, many patients remain MCTD for life.

faqs.question: I get this weird, sharp pain on one side of my lower belly every month, and it lasts for a day. Is this appendicitis?
faqs.answer: It's very unlikely to be appendicitis, because the key is that it's cyclical (it happens every month) and it's brief (lasts a day or less). This is the classic description of Mittelschmerz (German for middle pain). It is ovulation pain. It's a one-sided pain that happens mid-cycle (about 14 days before your next period), which is exactly when your ovary is releasing an egg (ovulating).

faqs.question: Why does ovulation hurt? What's actually happening?
faqs.answer: Doctors aren't 100% sure, but there are two main theories: 1) Follicle Rupture: As the follicle (the cyst holding the egg) grows, it stretches the surface of your ovary, causing a dull ache. Then, when it ruptures to release the egg, it causes a sharp pain. 2) Irritation: When the follicle ruptures, it also releases a small amount of follicular fluid (and sometimes a tiny bit of blood) into your pelvis. This fluid is irritating to the lining of your pelvis (the peritoneum), which causes the sharp, crampy pain for the next few hours (or day) until your body reabsorbs it.

faqs.question: How do I know for sure it's Mittelschmerz and not an ovarian cyst or endometriosis?
faqs.answer: The timing is the #1 clue. Mittelschmerz only happens mid-cycle. Endometriosis or cyst pain is often worse just before or during your period. Mittelschmerz is also one-sided and it often alternates sides from month-to-month (as your ovaries take turns ovulating). The pain is also sharp or crampy but not usually ER-level severe, and it goes away (with an ibuprofen) within 24 hours. If your pain lasts for days, or you have a fever, or it's 10/10 severe, that is not Mittelschmerz.

faqs.question: I just started tracking my cycle to get pregnant. Can I use this pain to know when I'm fertile?
faqs.answer: Yes! This is one of the best fertility awareness signs. Mittelschmerz is the sign that you are just about to ovulate, or are in the process of ovulating. This pain is your body's go-time signal, and it pinpoints your most fertile window (the 2-3 days leading up to and including that pain).

faqs.question: This just started happening to me, and I'm 35. I never had it before. Why now?
faqs.answer: This is very common. Mittelschmerz can start (or stop) at any time in your reproductive life. It's often masked for years if you were on hormonal birth control (like the pill), because the pill stops ovulation. So, you wouldn't have ovulation pain. If you stopped the pill a year ago, it's very common to discover (or re-discover) this new ovulation pain.

faqs.question: I'm 50 and I'm suddenly getting short of breath just walking up stairs. My doctor heard a murmur and said mitral stenosis. I've never had a heart problem!
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation. The #1 cause of Mitral Stenosis (a narrowing of your mitral valve) is not a birth defect; it's damage from Rheumatic Fever (a strep throat complication) that you had as a child (even 30-40 years ago). The valve was silently scarring and narrowing for decades. You are just now symptomatic because the valve has become critically narrow, and blood is backing up into your lungs (this is the shortness of breath).

faqs.question: What's a diastolic murmur or opening snap? My doctor wrote that in my chart.
faqs.answer: This is the sound that defines your diagnosis. Stenosis means stiff and narrow. When your atrium (top chamber) pumps, it has to force the blood through your stiff, narrow valve. This forcing creates a low-pitched, rumbling sound (a diastolic murmur). The opening snap is the click sound the stiff valve leaflets make as they are forced open. This sound is unique to mitral stenosis.

faqs.question: My atrium is severely enlarged. Is that dangerous?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the consequence of the stenosis and is the engine for the two worst complications. Because the left atrium (top chamber) has to push so hard for years to get blood through the narrow valve, it stretches out and enlarges. This stretched chamber is electrically unstable and is the #1 reason patients with mitral stenosis develop Atrial Fibrillation (Afib). It's also stagnant (blood doesn't flow well), which is why you are at a very high risk of forming a blood clot that can cause a stroke.

faqs.question: I'm in Afib now. Why is this so much worse than just the stenosis?
faqs.answer: Afib (Atrial Fibrillation) is the decompensation event. In Afib, your atrium is no longer pumping; it's just quivering (at 300+ bpm). You just lost the one thing that was pushing the blood through your narrow valve (the atrial kick). Your heart rate also goes very fast. A fast heart rate shortens filling time (diastole). This is a disaster for mitral stenosis: you have no pump and less time to get blood through the narrow valve. This is why you go into acute heart failure (your lungs fill with blood) very quickly.

faqs.question: My doctor is talking about a balloon valvuloplasty. How does that fix the valve?
faqs.answer: For the right kind of mitral stenosis (where the valve is stiff but not calcified), this is a fantastic, minimally invasive treatment. A cardiologist routes a catheter (a tube) from your leg vein, up to your heart, and across to the mitral valve. They then inflate a balloon inside your narrow valve. This cracks the fused, scarred valve leaflets open, widening the valve orifice and immediately relieving the stenosis (the backup).

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a leaky mitral valve. I feel fine, but he seems worried. Why?
faqs.answer: This is chronic, severe mitral regurgitation (MR). The leak means that every time your heart pumps (squeezes), a jet of blood shoots backward into your atrium (top chamber). Your heart has to do double duty—it has to pump blood forward to your body + re-pump the blood that leaked back. For years, your heart can compensate (it enlarges and beefs up). You feel fine. The worry is that your heart will eventually fail from this volume overload. The damage (a weak, baggy heart) can become irreversible.

faqs.question: What's the MitraClip? My grandpa is too sick for open heart surgery.
faqs.answer: A MitraClip is a transcatheter (minimally invasive) repair device. It's for patients who are too high-risk (e.g., too old, too frail, or have heart failure) for a traditional open-heart surgery. A catheter (a tube) is routed from your leg vein, up to your heart, and across to the mitral valve.
