When you suddenly remove it, your brain becomes massively over-excited, leading to severe anxiety, tremors, and potentially fatal seizures. You must never stop a benzodiazepine without a very slow medical taper.

faqs.question: My son says he takes his friend's Adderall (stimulant) to study. He says it's safe because it's a prescription. Is that true?
faqs.answer: No, that is absolutely false and very dangerous. When not used for ADHD, stimulants like Adderall can cause significant side effects, including severe anxiety, paranoia, insomnia, and, most dangerously, cardiac problems like high blood pressure, irregular heartbeat, and even heart attack or stroke in people with underlying conditions.

faqs.question: My doctor wants me to start Suboxone (buprenorphine) for my painkiller addiction. Am I just trading one addiction for another?
faqs.answer: This is a common fear, but it's a misunderstanding of the treatment. Addiction is the chaotic, compulsive use that ruins your life. Physical dependence is what Suboxone provides. It's a long-acting, partial-opioid that stabilizes your brain. It stops the withdrawals and blocks the cravings, but it does not get you high. This allows you to break the cycle of compulsive use and rebuild your life. It's a medication-assisted treatment, like insulin for a diabetic.

faqs.question: What is Narcan (naloxone), and why is my doctor telling me to have it if I'm prescribed painkillers?
faqs.answer: Naloxone (brand name Narcan) is an emergency overdose-reversal drug. It's a nasal spray that works by kicking the opioids off the brain's breathing receptors, instantly restoring breathing in someone who has overdosed. Prescribing it alongside opioids is a new safety standard. It's a fire extinguisher—you have it in the hopes you never need it, but if you (or someone who visits your home) accidentally takes too much, it can save a life.

faqs.question: I just turned 43, and suddenly I can't read my phone. I have to hold my arm all the way out to see it. My distance vision is perfect. What's happening?
faqs.answer: Welcome to the 40s club. This is presbyopia, and it's not a disease—it's a 100% normal, universal part of aging, just like wrinkles. The natural lens inside your eye, which has to flex or zoom to focus up close, has begun to lose its flexibility. It can't flex enough to focus on your phone anymore, so you have to move your phone away to get it into focus.

faqs.question: How is this different from being farsighted? I thought that's what farsightedness was.
faqs.answer: It's a great question, as the symptom is similar. Farsightedness (hyperopia) is a refractive error you're born with—it means your eyeball is too short, so light focuses behind your retina. Presbyopia is a focusing problem. It's a loss of flexibility in your lens. You can have perfect vision your whole life and still get presbyopia.

faqs.question: I've been nearsighted (myopic) my whole life, and now my friends all need readers, but I can read better if I take my glasses off. Why?
faqs.answer: You're experiencing the myopic advantage. Your nearsightedness is already pre-focused for up-close. When you take your glasses off, your eye's natural focal point is right where you hold your phone. You've had built-in reading glasses your whole life. You will still have presbyopia—you'll notice it when you're wearing your distance glasses and try to read—but you can cheat by taking them off.

faqs.question: I hate the idea of readers or bifocals. What are my other options?
faqs.answer: You have several. You can get progressive lenses, which are no-line bifocals. A very popular option is monovision with contact lenses, where one eye is corrected for distance and your other (dominant) eye is corrected for reading—your brain learns to blend the two. There are also multifocal contact lenses. Surgically, there are options like corneal inlays or lens replacement.

faqs.question: Is it normal for me to feel bloated, extremely irritable, and weepy for a whole week before my period? It's like a switch flips, and then I'm fine the day my period starts.
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic definition of PMS. The key is the timing and the pattern. The symptoms (bloating, irritability, breast tenderness, crying spells) consistently appear in the luteal phase (the 7-10 days before your period) and, most importantly, they go away completely within a day or two of your period starting.

faqs.question: My PMS is so bad I feel completely hopeless, anxious, and filled with rage. It's not just irritability—it's ruining my job and relationships. Is this just PMS?
faqs.answer: That sounds less like PMS and more like Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD), which is a much more severe, psychiatric form. While PMS is irritability, PMDD is severe depression, anxiety, rage, or hopelessness that is still tied to your cycle. It's a severe reaction in your brain to the normal hormone changes, and it requires medical treatment.

faqs.question: Why does this happen? Is it a hormone imbalance?
faqs.answer: This is a common myth. For most women, it is not a hormone imbalance—your hormone levels are probably perfectly normal. The problem is that your brain is abnormally sensitive to the normal fluctuation (specifically, the drop) of progesterone and estrogen that happens right before your period. It's a neurochemical sensitivity, not a hormonal disease.

faqs.question: My doctor suggested taking an antidepressant (like Zoloft or Prozac) for just the two weeks before my period. How can that work?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and effective treatment for PMDD. Unlike for depression (which takes weeks to treat), an SSRI for PMDD can work very quickly, sometimes in a day or two. It's not really treating depression—it's stabilizing your brain's serotonin system, which is what gets destabilized by the hormone drop, thus preventing the severe mood symptoms.

faqs.question: Will going on the birth control pill help?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is a first-line treatment. The pill works by preventing ovulation and flat-lining your hormones. By preventing the big hormonal drop that triggers your symptoms, the pill can be extremely effective. The most effective way is often to take the pill continuously (skipping the placebo sugar-pill week), so you don't have a period or the hormonal fluctuation at all.

faqs.question: I keep feeling my heart skip a beat or have a big, hard thud in my chest, especially when I'm resting at night. Am I having a heart attack?
faqs.answer: While it's always good to get chest symptoms checked, this skipped or thudding sensation is the classic description of a PVC. What you're feeling is not a skipped beat, but an early beat (the PVC), which is then followed by a pause as your heart resets. During that pause, your heart over-fills with blood, and the next normal beat is very forceful (the thud) as it pumps that extra blood out.

faqs.question: My doctor says my heart is structurally normal and my PVCs are benign. How can they be benign when they feel so awful?
faqs.answer: This is the key distinction. In a heart that is structurally normal (meaning your echocardiogram is fine, no heart-failure, no valve problems), isolated PVCs are overwhelmingly benign. They are an electrical annoyance, not a plumbing or muscle problem. They feel terrifying, but they are not dangerous or life-threatening.

faqs.question: I notice them way more when I'm stressed, haven't slept, or after I've had coffee or alcohol. Is that a real connection?
faqs.answer: Yes, 100%. PVCs are notoriously sensitive to triggers. The most common are adrenaline (from stress or anxiety), caffeine, alcohol, dehydration, and fatigue. For many people, simply cutting back on coffee, improving sleep, and managing stress can reduce the PVCs dramatically.

faqs.question: My Holter monitor caught thousands of them, but my doctor still isn't worried. Why not?
faqs.answer: Your doctor is looking at the burden. In a healthy heart, you can have thousands of PVCs (e.g., a 5% burden) and it's still considered benign. Treatment (like a beta-blocker) is only started if the burden is extremely high (e.g., over 10-15% of all your heartbeats) to the point where the bad beats could start to weaken the heart muscle over time (a PVC-induced cardiomyopathy).

faqs.question: What is actually considered premature? Is there a specific time?
faqs.answer: This is a common question. While it's very subjective, the clinical definition from the International Society for Sexual Medicine for lifelong PE is: 1) Ejaculation always or nearly always occurs before or within about 1 minute of vaginal penetration, 2) You have an inability to delay ejaculation, and 3) It causes you personal distress.

faqs.question: I've had this problem my entire life, with every single partner. Is this psychological?
faqs.answer: This is lifelong (or primary) PE. While anxiety can make it worse, this form is not considered to be in your head. It's thought to be a neurobiological issue—your nervous system is just wired to have a very sensitive ejaculatory reflex, possibly related to serotonin receptors.

faqs.question: I used to be fine and had good control, but this just started happening in the last year. What could cause that?
faqs.answer: This is acquired (or secondary) PE, and it's almost always caused by a new underlying problem. The most common causes are 1) Psychological (new relationship anxiety, stress, depression), 2) A new medical problem (like prostatitis - a prostate infection, or a thyroid problem), or 3) Erectile dysfunction (you may be unconsciously rushing to finish before you lose your erection).

faqs.question: My doctor prescribed an antidepressant (like Zoloft) for me to take daily. How will that help this problem?
faqs.answer: This is the most common and effective medical treatment. A known side effect of the SSRI class of antidepressants (like Zoloft, Paxil, or Prozac) is delayed ejaculation. In this case, your doctor is using that side effect as the intended treatment. It helps turn down the sensitivity of your ejaculatory reflex.

faqs.question: I don't want to take a daily pill. Are there any other options?
faqs.answer: Yes. There are two other main categories. 1) Behavioral techniques like the stop-start or squeeze method, which are about learning to recognize the point of no return and training your reflex. 2) Topical anesthetics (numbing creams, sprays, or wipes) with lidocaine or prilocaine. You apply this to the head of the penis 10-15 minutes before sex to decrease the physical sensation just enough to delay ejaculation.

faqs.question: I did everything right during my pregnancy, so why did I still go into labor early?
faqs.answer: This is one ofr the most painful and common questions. In over 50% of preterm births, the exact cause is unknown. It is almost never your fault. While risk factors exist (like infections, carrying twins, or a history of preterm birth), labor can also be triggered by things you have no control over, like a silent placental abruption or your water breaking for no apparent reason. You did not cause this.

faqs.question: My baby was born at 35 weeks, a late preterm. Everyone says, at least he's not a micro-preemie, but I'm still worried. What are the real long-term risks?
faqs.answer: It's true that a 35-weeker has a much better prognosis, but your concerns are valid. Late preterm babies are not just small full-term babies. Their brains, lungs, and livers are still immature. They are at a higher risk for feeding difficulties (a weak suck/swallow), jaundice, and minor breathing issues. Long-term, they have a slightly higher (but still small) risk of developmental or learning delays compared to full-term babies, which is why close follow-up is so important.

faqs.question: My baby is in the NICU. Why are they so focused on him maintaining his temperature and finishing his bottles?
faqs.answer: These are two of the biggest milestones for going home. Preterm babies lack the body fat to thermoregulate (maintain their own temperature), so they burn all their calories just trying to stay warm instead of growing. An open crib (vs. an incubator) proves they can do this. The suck-swallow-breathe reflex is a complex brain function that isn't fully developed until 34-36 weeks, so finishing all bottles is a sign of brain maturity and shows he's ready to thrive at home.

faqs.question: What is my baby's corrected age, and why do we use it?
faqs.answer: Your baby's corrected age (or adjusted age) is their age from their original due date, not their birthday. If your baby was born 2 months early (at 32 weeks) and it's now 4 months after their birth, their chronological age is 4 months, but their corrected age is only 2 months. You must use this corrected age when tracking developmental milestones (like rolling over or cooing) for the first 2 years, otherwise, they will appear to be delayed when they are actually right on track for their brain age.

faqs.question: I'm 36 weeks and my feet are so swollen I can't wear shoes, but my doctor says it's normal. How do I know if it's normal swelling or preeclampsia swelling?
faqs.answer: The key difference is normal swelling (edema) is usually just in the feet and ankles, gets worse at the end of the day, and gets better after you've been lying down all night. Preeclampsia swelling is more pathologic—it's often sudden, severe, and non-pitting (when you press it, it doesn't leave an indent). Most importantly, it affects your hands, face, and around your eyes, and it doesn't go away overnight.

faqs.question: My doctor says I have HELLP syndrome. How is that different from just severe preeclampsia?
faqs.answer: HELLP syndrome is a specific, life-threatening complication or variant of severe preeclampsia. Preeclampsia is defined by high blood pressure and protein in your urine. HELLP is a diagnosis made from your bloodwork. It stands for Hemolysis (your red blood cells are breaking apart), Elevated Liver enzymes (your liver is in distress), and Low Platelets (your blood is losing its ability to clot). It means the disease is affecting multiple organ systems and is a true emergency.

faqs.question: I'm on blood pressure medicine, so why is my doctor saying the only cure is to deliver the baby?
faqs.answer: This is a critical point. Preeclampsia is not just high blood pressure—it's a disease of the placenta. The placenta is releasing toxins that are poisoning your blood vessels, causing high blood pressure and organ damage. The medications can manage your blood pressure, but they do not stop the placenta from releasing these toxins. The only way to cure the disease and stop the organ damage is to remove the source of the problem, which is the placenta.

faqs.question: I have a killer headache that Tylenol won't touch, and I'm seeing flashing lights in my vision. Should I just lie down?
faqs.answer: No. You need to call your doctor or go to the hospital immediately. A severe, persistent headache and visual changes (like flashing lights, floaters, or blurriness) are severe features. They are neurologic signs that the high blood pressure is now affecting your brain, and you are at high risk of having a seizure (eclampsia) or a stroke. This is a medical emergency.

faqs.question: My doctor says my A1c is 6.0% and I have prediabetes. What does this actually mean?
faqs.answer: An HbA1c (or A1c) test measures your average blood sugar over the last 3 months. A normal A1c is below 5.7%. A diabetic A1c is 6.5% or higher. You are in the prediabetes warning zone (5.7% - 6.4%). It means your blood sugars are higher than normal, but not yet high enough to be type 2 diabetes. It is a yellow light—a crucial warning sign that you are on the path towards diabetes.

faqs.question: I feel perfectly fine. Are there any symptoms of prediabetes?
faqs.answer: No. Prediabetes has zero symptoms. You feel perfectly normal. The only way to know you have it is from a blood test (like an A1c or a fasting glucose). The classic symptoms of diabetes (like extreme thirst, frequent urination, or blurry vision) don't start until your blood sugars are much higher and you've already crossed the line into full-blown type 2 diabetes.

faqs.question: My doctor said I can reverse this. Is that really true, or am I just delaying the inevitable?
faqs.answer: It is absolutely true. Prediabetes is a state of insulin resistance that is highly reversible. Research (like the Diabetes Prevention Program) has shown that by losing just 5-7% of your body weight (that's only 10-14 pounds for a 200lb person) and getting 150 minutes of weekly exercise (like a brisk walk), you can reduce your risk of progressing to type 2 diabetes by over 50%.

faqs.question: My doctor wants me to start Metformin for my prediabetes. Do I really need a pill? Can't I just do it with diet?
faqs.answer: This is a great conversation to have with your doctor. Lifestyle change (diet and exercise) is the most powerful treatment. Metformin is a safe, effective pill that helps your body use its own insulin more efficiently. Your doctor may be recommending it in addition to lifestyle changes because you have other risk factors (like a very high BMI or a strong family history), or to give you an extra boost to get your numbers down quickly. For many, lifestyle alone is enough.

faqs.question: My 7-year-old daughter is developing breast buds. My doctor says this is central precocious puberty but her MRI is normal. What caused it?
faqs.answer: This is idiopathic central precocious puberty, and it's the most common type in girls (over 80% of cases). It means that for no known reason (no tumor, no injury), your daughter's puberty clock (the GnRH signal in her brain) just switched on too early. It's a timing error, not a sign of a dangerous underlying disease.

faqs.question: My doctor says the treatment will put her into menopause. That sounds so extreme!
faqs.answer: It's a scary-sounding term, but it's not what's happening. The treatment is a GnRH agonist (like a Lupron shot). This medication works by overwhelming the puberty switch in her brain, telling it to shut down. It pauses her puberty completely, effectively turning off the estrogen production. Her body will revert to a pre-pubertal state. It is 100% reversible—when you stop the medication, her puberty will re-start at a more appropriate age.

faqs.question: If we don't treat it, what's the harm? Isn't it just an early bloomer?
faqs.answer: There are two main harms. The first is psychosocial—a 7 or 8-year-old is not emotionally or mentally ready to deal with breast development, menstruation, and other body changes. The second is physical—and this is key—it can make her short as an adult. The estrogen from puberty is what closes the growth plates in her bones. If her puberty finishes at age 9 or 10, her growth plates will close years too early, and she will stop growing, resulting in a short adult height.

faqs.question: What's the difference between central and peripheral precocious puberty?
faqs.answer: Central means the problem is central in the brain—the GnRH clock has just turned on early. Peripheral means the brain is fine, but the body is the problem. A gland (like an ovary or adrenal gland) has gone rogue and is releasing estrogen or testosterone without being told to by the brain. This is often caused by a cyst or tumor on the gland and is a different kind of medical problem.

faqs.question: My newborn with PWS is floppy and has no interest in eating. I've read this is a disease of uncontrollable hunger. When does that switch happen?
faqs.answer: You are in Phase 1 (infancy), which is defined by hypotonia (floppiness) and a failure to thrive. Many babies need a feeding tube. The switch to Phase 2—hyperphagia (uncontrollable, pathological hunger)—is a gradual process that usually begins between ages 2 and 5. It's caused by a dysfunction in the hypothalamus (the hunger center of the brain), and it's a critical, life-altering change.

faqs.question: What does uncontrollable hunger (hyperphagia) really mean? Does he just want extra snacks?
faqs.answer: This is not normal hunger. It's a constant, primal, starvation signal from the brain that never turns off. They never feel full (satiety). This leads to obsessive thoughts about food, food-seeking, and life-threatening binge-eating. This is why environmental control (locking all cabinets, fridges, and even trash cans) becomes a matter of life and death, as they can eat to the point of a stomach rupture or choking.

faqs.question: My child is 5, and the hunger has started. My doctor insists we start growth hormone (GH). Why would I give GH to a child who is at risk for obesity?
faqs.answer: This is a critical, and life-changing, treatment. Yes, PWS causes obesity, but it also causes growth hormone deficiency. The GH does not make them hungrier. It fundamentally changes their body composition—it helps them build muscle and burn fat. This (along with a strict diet) is the only thing that can fight the obesity. It also helps with their energy, stamina, and bone density.

faqs.question: Is it true my child will have behavioral issues?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, behavioral outbursts are a core feature of the syndrome, separate from the hunger. They are often linked to the hypothalamic brain dysfunction. Common issues include obsessive-compulsive behaviors (like skin-picking), extreme stubbornness, emotional black-and-white thinking, and sudden, explosive meltdowns (often triggered by a no or a change in routine). These are neurological, not just bad behavior.

faqs.question: I had a J-pouch (IPAA) surgery for my Ulcerative Colitis, and I've been great for a year. Now I'm having cramping, urgency, and bloody diarrhea again. Is my colitis back?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of pouchitis. Your colitis is not back (because your colon is gone), but you have a new inflammation inside your J-pouch. The J-pouch is made from your small intestine, and it can develop its own inflammatory condition. It's the most common complication of J-pouch surgery.

faqs.question: My doctor says my pouchitis is probably from bacterial overgrowth. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: The J-pouch acts as a storage reservoir, which is not a normal job for the small intestine. This stagnant environment can allow a bad balance of bacteria to overgrow. These bacteria (or their byproducts) can irritate the lining of the pouch, causing the inflammatory pouchitis symptoms.

faqs.question: Why am I being treated with antibiotics (like Cipro and Flagyl)? I thought this was an inflammatory disease like my UC?
faqs.answer: This is a key difference. While it feels like a UC flare, the primary cause of most pouchitis is thought to be bacterial. For this reason, the first-line and most effective treatment is a 10-14 day course of antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin and/or Metronidazole/Flagyl). In most cases, this resets the gut flora and the inflammation resolves dramatically.

faqs.question: What if the antibiotics don't work, or it keeps coming back? My doctor mentioned my Crohn's?
faqs.answer: This is the next step in thinking. If your pouchitis is chronic and doesn't respond to antibiotics (or immediately relapses), your doctor has to ask why. The two main possibilities are: 1) You have antibiotic-dependent pouchitis and need a long-term strategy. 2) You were misdiagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis, and you actually have Crohn's disease of the pouch. A scope and biopsy are needed to tell the difference.

faqs.question: It's been 6 months since my vasectomy, and I still have this constant, dull, grinding ache in my testicle. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: No. Normal post-vasectomy pain resolves in a few weeks. A constant, chronic pain that lasts 3 months or more is called Post-Vasectomy Pain Syndrome (PVPS). It's a known complication that affects a small percentage of men, and it's a real, physical condition.

faqs.question: What is causing this pain? Did the doctor mess up?
faqs.answer: It's very unlikely the doctor messed up. There are two main theories. 1) Congestive Epididymitis: Your testicles still make sperm, but now the pipe (the vas deferens) is blocked. This can cause a back-pressure of sperm in the epididymis (the tube behind the testicle), leading to a chronic, congestive ache. 2) Nerve Entrapment: The surgery (or the subsequent scarring) may have irritated or trapped one of the tiny nerves in the spermatic cord, leading to a neuropathic (nerve) pain.

faqs.question: My urologist wants to try a cord block. What is that?
faqs.answer: A spermatic cord block is a diagnostic test. Your doctor will inject a local anesthetic (numbing medicine) into the spermatic cord, right where the nerves are. If your pain goes away completely for a few hours, it proves that the pain is neuropathic (coming from those nerves). This is a very good sign, as it means you are a good candidate for a surgical nerve-stripping procedure.

faqs.question: What are my treatment options? I can't live like this.
faqs.answer: Treatment is stepped. 1) Medical: A long course of anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) and nerve-pain medications (like Gabapentin or Amitriptyline). 2) Injections: The cord block (see above). 3) Surgical: If the pain is congestive, a vasectomy reversal can restore the flow and relieve the back-pressure. If the pain is neuropathic (proven by a cord block), a microsurgical denervation (where they cut the nerves) can be very effective. A last resort is removal of the testicle (orchiectomy).

faqs.question: I thought PTSD was only for soldiers in combat. Can I have it from a car accident (or a difficult childbirth / domestic abuse)?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. PTSD can be caused by any event that you perceived as life-threatening or terrifyingly unsafe. This 100% includes car accidents, a traumatic medical event (like an emergency C-section), domestic violence, or a natural disaster. The source of the trauma does not matter; it's the brain's response to it.

faqs.question: It's been 3 weeks since my accident, and I'm having flashbacks and nightmares. Is this PTSD?
faqs.answer: It might be, but the timing is key. If the event was less than one month ago, the diagnosis is Acute Stress Disorder (ASD). The symptoms (flashbacks, nightmares, avoidance) are identical to PTSD. If those same symptoms are still present more than one month after the event, the diagnosis converts to PTSD.

faqs.question: I don't have flashbacks, but I am so irritable, I fly off the handle at the smallest thing, and I'm always scanning for danger. Is this PTSD?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is another cluster of core PTSD symptoms called Hyperarousal and Reactivity. Your threat system (your amygdala) is stuck in the on position. You are living in a constant state of fight or flight, which is why you're jumpy, irritable, easily angered, and can't relax. It's not a flashback (re-experiencing), but it's just as much a part of PTSD.

faqs.question: What's the difference between avoidance and just moving on?
faqs.answer: Avoidance is a key symptom that maintains the PTSD. Moving on is processing the memory and it losing its charge. Avoidance is actively changing your life to avoid any reminder of the trauma. This means refusing to drive on the highway where you crashed, avoiding all news stories about accidents, and refusing to talk or even think about the event. This avoidance prevents your brain from ever filing away the memory as over.

faqs.question: I had polio 50 years ago and recovered. Now, my muscles are getting new weakness and I'm exhausted all the time. Is the polio back?
faqs.answer: The polio virus is not back or reactivated. This is a new condition called Post-Polio Syndrome (PPS). When you had polio, the virus killed many of your motor neurons (the nerves that plug in to your muscles). To compensate, your surviving neurons sprouted super-branches to adopt the orphaned muscle fibers. This has put those surviving neurons under immense stress for 50 years. Now, those over-worked neurons are burning out and dying off, which is what's causing the new weakness.

faqs.question: My instinct is to push through and exercise to re-strengthen the weak muscles. Is that right?
faqs.answer: No. This is a critical mistake and the opposite of what you should do. The no pain, no gain and use it or lose it mottos do not apply to PPS. Your muscles are weak because the nerve is dying. Pushing through and exercising to fatigue will only accelerate the burnout of your remaining, over-worked neurons and can make your weakness permanently worse. The new rule is conserve to preserve.

faqs.question: What kind of exercise can I do?
faqs.answer: You need to work with a physical therapist who specializes in PPS. The goal is not strength-building; it's non-fatiguing exercise. This means very light aerobic activity (like a warm-water pool) to maintain cardiovascular health, and gentle stretching. You must never exercise to the point of muscle burn or exhaustion. You must also learn to pace your day and use assistive devices (like a cane or scooter) to save your muscles, not challenge them.

faqs.question: Why am I suddenly so sensitive to cold? My leg that was affected by polio gets so cold and painful.
faqs.answer: This is a very common and frustrating symptom of PPS. It's thought to be caused by the original polio damage to your autonomic nervous system—the system that controls the automatic functions like constricting and dilating your blood vessels to conserve heat. Your thermostat in that limb is broken, making you very sensitive to cold.

faqs.question: I was perfectly healthy during my entire pregnancy. How is it possible I have preeclampsia after I delivered my baby?
faqs.answer: This is a terrifying and confusing diagnosis, but it is real. Postpartum preeclampsia is a delayed presentation. The seeds of the disease (a poorly-implanted placenta) were there all along, but your body was compensating. The massive fluid shifts and hormonal changes in the first few days after delivery can unmask the underlying disease, causing your blood pressure to spike dangerously for the first time.

faqs.question: I'm 3 days home from the hospital. What warning signs should I be watching for?
faqs.answer: You must watch for: 1) A severe headache that Tylenol/Ibuprofen doesn't help. 2) Visual changes (flashing lights, floaters, blurriness). 3) Sudden, severe swelling in your hands and face. 4) Pain in your upper-right belly, under your ribs. 5) Shortness of breath. Any of these are a go to the ER sign.

faqs.question: How is this treated? I'm breastfeeding. Can I take the medication?
faqs.answer: The immediate treatment is magnesium sulfate (an IV drip) in the hospital to prevent a seizure (eclampsia). To control your blood pressure, you will be started on oral blood pressure pills (like Labetalol or Nifedipine), which are safe for breastfeeding. You will have to stay on these pills for several weeks until your body resets and your blood pressure normalizes.

faqs.question: I'm crying all the time, but it's been 3 weeks since I had my baby. How do I know if this is the baby blues or real postpartum depression?
faqs.answer: The key differences are timing and severity. The baby blues are a weepy, overwhelmed feeling that peaks around 3-5 days after birth and goes away on its own by week 2. Postpartum depression (PPD) can start any time in the first year and is much more severe. It's a feeling of hopelessness, worthlessness, and anhedonia (no joy). It doesn't go away on its own and requires treatment.

faqs.question: I don't feel sad or depressed—I feel pure rage. I'm so angry and irritable at my partner and my baby. Is this PPD?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is one of the most misunderstood faces of PPD. Postpartum rage and severe irritability are very common symptoms. It's not always crying in a corner. It can be a hair-trigger temper, feeling out of control with your anger, and feeling touched out. This is a recognized part of the PPD/Anxiety spectrum.

faqs.question: I'm having terrifying, intrusive thoughts about bad things happening to my baby. Am I a bad mother? Am I going crazy?
faqs.answer: You are not a bad mother, and you are not crazy. This is postpartum anxiety or postpartum OCD. These unwanted, intrusive thoughts are extremely common (but no one talks about them). The fact that they horrify you is the proof that you are a good mother. They are ego-dystonic (the opposite of what you want). This is a treatable anxiety disorder, not a sign of psychosis.

faqs.question: If I tell my doctor I'm this depressed, are they going to take my baby away?
faqs.answer: This is the #1 fear that stops women from getting help. The answer is no. Your doctor, nurse, or midwife's only goal is to get you well. They understand that PPD is a medical complication of childbirth, just like preeclampsia or an infection. They will start you on a path to treatment (therapy and/or medication) so you can be the healthy, happy mother you want to be. They are there to help you, not punish you.

faqs.question: My shingles rash went away two months ago, but the skin where the rash was still hurts! It's a burning, stabbing pain. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: This is normal for a complication of shingles. This is Postherpetic Neuralgia (PHN). Postherpetic means after the herpes (zoster). Neuralgia means nerve pain. The shingles virus damaged the sensory nerves in that patch of skin. The rash is gone, but the nerve is still injured and is misfiring pain signals to your brain.

faqs.question: Why does my shirt brushing against the skin hurt so bad? Even a bedsheet is agonizing.
faqs.answer: This is a classic neuropathic (nerve pain) symptom called allodynia. It means a stimulus that is normally not painful (like a light touch) is perceived by your brain as excruciating. This is a hallmark of PHN and proves the pain is coming from the nerve itself.

faqs.question: Will this ever go away? Or am I stuck with this pain for life?
faqs.answer: For most people, it does get better. PHN is defined as pain lasting more than 3 months after the rash. It can last for months, or in some cases, a year or two, but it burns itself out and slowly fades over time. In a smaller percentage of (often elderly) patients, the pain can be permanent.

faqs.question: My Tylenol and Ibuprofen do nothing for this pain. Why?
faqs.answer: This is because Tylenol and Ibuprofen are anti-inflammatories. They work on muscle or tissue pain. Your pain is neuropathic (nerve pain). It requires different medications. The first-line treatments are nerve pain drugs (like Gabapentin or Lyrica), nerve-calming antidepressants (like Amitriptyline), or topical treatments (like a Lidocaine patch) that numb the skin.

faqs.question: I feel a bulge in my vagina when I strain, and I'm having trouble having a bowel movement. It feels stuck. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of a rectocele (a posterior prolapse). The thin wall of tissue between your rectum and your vagina has weakened. When you strain, your rectum is bulging forward into your vagina. This bulge is what you feel, and it creates a pocket where stool can get stuck, making it very hard to empty your bowels.

faqs.question: I've found that I have to splint—meaning, press my fingers on the back of my vagina—to be able to poop. Is this a sign of a rectocele?
faqs.answer: Yes. This splinting is a hallmark sign. What you are doing is manually pushing that bulge or pocket back into place, which un-kinks the rectum and allows the stool to pass. It's a very common coping mechanism that women discover on their own.

faqs.question: What caused this? Did I do something wrong?
faqs.answer: You did nothing wrong. This is caused by damage to the pelvic floor. The #1 cause is childbirth (especially vaginal deliveries, forceps, or big babies). The #2 cause is chronic straining from a lifetime of constipation. Both of these (and just age/menopause) can stretch and weaken that critical fascia (connective tissue) between the rectum and vagina.

faqs.question: Do I have to have surgery for this?
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. If the bulge is mild and not bothering you, you do nothing. If it's bothering you, the first step is non-surgical. This includes: 1) Pelvic floor physical therapy to strengthen the supporting muscles. 2) A pessary (a small, silicone device you wear in your vagina, like a diaphragm) to hold the bulge up and relieve the symptoms. Surgery (a posterior repair) is only for severe, bothersome prolapse that has failed these other treatments.

faqs.question: I'm 58, and my memory is perfect. But I'm having vision problems. I can't read, I misjudge distances when I'm driving, and I can't see all the objects on my desk. My eye doctor says my eyes are fine.
faqs.answer: This is the classic, tragic presentation of Posterior Cortical Atrophy (PCA). This is a visual variant of Alzheimer's disease. The problem is not your eyes; it's your brain. The plaque and tangle pathology of Alzheimer's is, in your case, starting in the visual processing centers (the posterior cortex) of your brain, not the memory centers (the hippocampus). Your brain is seeing, but it can't interpret what it's seeing.

faqs.question: How is this not just Alzheimer's?
faqs.answer: It is Alzheimer's pathology, but it's a different clinical presentation. In typical Alzheimer's, the first symptom is memory loss, and vision problems come much later. In PCA, the first symptom is visual processing failure, and your memory, insight, and social skills can remain perfectly intact for many years. This is why it's so often misdiagnosed, because you don't look like a typical Alzheimer's patient.

faqs.question: What does the atrophy part mean?
faqs.answer: Atrophy means shrinkage. If you got a brain MRI, it would show that the back (posterior) part of your brain (the occipital and parietal lobes) is shrinking or atrophying as the brain cells die. This is the visual part of your brain. In typical Alzheimer's, the shrinkage is seen first in the memory parts of the brain.

faqs.question: I went in the sun, and now I have these painful, fragile blisters all over the backs of my hands. My doctor says this is porphyria cutanea tarda.
faqs.answer: This is the most common form of porphyria. It's a photocutaneous type, meaning sun (photo) + skin (cutaneous). You have a porphyrin (a chemical) building up in your blood. When sunlight hits your skin, it activates these porphyrins, which then release free radicals that literally burn your skin from the inside out. This makes the skin incredibly fragile and causes the blisters, especially on sun-exposed areas like your hands and face.

faqs.question: Why did this just start? I'm 50. I've been in the sun my whole life.
faqs.answer: This is a key feature of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). You were born with a genetic tendency for it, but it's set off or triggered later in life. The most common triggers that overwhelm your liver and unmask the disease are: 1) Alcohol use, 2) Hepatitis C infection, 3) Iron overload (hemochromatosis), or 4) Estrogen (like from birth control pills).

faqs.question: I had a sudden, horrifying attack of abdominal pain, vomiting, and my arms and legs felt paralyzed and numb. My doctor said this is acute porphyria. How is this related to the skin type?
faqs.answer: It is not related. This is a completely different, far more dangerous type. The skin type (PCT) is a nuisance. The acute type (like Acute Intermittent Porphyria or AIP) is a life-threatening neurologic emergency. It's caused by a different enzyme problem. You do not get a skin rash. Instead, you have attacks where a neurotoxin builds up and attacks your nervous system, causing the severe belly pain, vomiting, and paralysis.

faqs.question: What can trigger one of these acute attacks? I'm terrified it will happen again.
faqs.answer: This is critical to know. The acute porphyrias are triggered by medications and hormones. The most dangerous triggers are unsafe drugs (especially barbiturates, sulfa antibiotics, and many anti-seizure meds). Other triggers include alcohol, crash-dieting (fasting), and hormonal surges (like in your menstrual cycle). You must wear a medical alert bracelet and check all new medications against a porphyria-safe drug list.

faqs.question: I'm a 20-year-old athlete, and my calf gets excruciating pain and goes dead only when I'm running, but it's fine when I rest. My trainer says it's shin splints, but it feels different.
faqs.answer: This is the classic story for PAES. Shin splints or muscle strains are a constant, dull ache. Your pain is claudication—it's caused by a lack of blood flow only during exertion. You likely have functional PAES: your calf muscle is so large (from athletics) that when it flexes, it's compressing your popliteal artery (the main artery behind your knee), cutting off blood to your lower leg. When you rest, the muscle relaxes, and the blood flows again.

faqs.question: What's the difference between functional and anatomical PAES?
faqs.answer: Functional means your anatomy is normal, but your muscle is just too big and is externally squishing the artery. Anatomical means you were born with an error—either your artery takes a weird path around the muscle, or your muscle attaches in the wrong spot, trapping the artery. Both cause the same symptoms.

faqs.question: How do they diagnose this? My pulses are normal when I'm sitting in the office.
faqs.answer: This is the key. The only way to diagnose it is with a provocative test. A doctor will check your pulses (or do an ultrasound) at rest (they'll be normal), and then have you actively plantarflex your foot (like pointing your toe against resistance). In PAES, this flex will squish the artery and your pulse will disappear. This confirms the diagnosis.

faqs.question: My father has an aneurysm behind his knee (popliteal). I've heard of brain aneurysms. Is this going to burst?
faqs.answer: This is a key difference. Unlike brain or aortic aneurysms (AAAs), the #1 danger of a popliteal aneurysm is not rupture (bursting). It's very, very rare for them to burst. The #1 danger is that the bulge in the artery causes stagnant blood flow, which forms a blood clot. This clot can then break off and embolize (travel) down your leg, blocking all blood flow to your foot, which is a limb-threatening emergency.

faqs.question: My dad's is small and the doctor just wants to watch it. Is that safe?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the standard of care. If the aneurysm is small (e.g., less than 2 cm) and has no clot (mural thrombus) inside it on the ultrasound, the risk of it throwing a clot is very low. Surgery (a bypass) has its own risks, so it's safer to just watch it with a yearly ultrasound. Surgery is recommended when it grows larger (over 2 cm) or if a clot is seen forming inside it.

faqs.question: My dad has one behind his knee. The doctor now wants to check his other knee and his belly (aorta). Why?
faqs.answer: This is critically important. Popliteal artery aneurysms are sentinels. They have a very high association with aneurysms elsewhere. About 50-70% of people with one, will also have one in their other knee. And, most importantly, about 40-50% will also have an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA), which is silent and is life-threatening if it bursts. Finding the knee aneurysm has just saved his life by triggering the search for the belly one.

faqs.question: I have this painful callus on the bottom of my foot, but it has black dots in it. Is this a wart?
faqs.answer: Yes. A normal callus is just thick, dead skin. A plantar wart (a wart on the plantar or bottom surface of your foot) is a viral infection (HPV) that grows into the skin. The black dots are the smoking gun—those are tiny, clotted blood vessels (capillaries) that the wart suckered into growing up into it to feed it.

faqs.question: Why did freezing (cryotherapy) it at the doctor's office twice not work?
faqs.answer: Plantar warts are notoriously stubborn. Because they grow into the foot (pushed in by your body weight), the freezing often only kills the top layer. The root of the virus is deeper, and it just grows back. It often takes many (e.g., 5-10) aggressive freezing treatments, or switching to a different treatment (like salicylic acid, or minor surgery) to finally kill the entire root.

faqs.question: How did I even get this? I'm very clean.
faqs.answer: It has nothing to do with being dirty. The wart virus (HPV) loves warm, wet environments. You get it by walking barefoot in a communal area, like a gym locker room, a dorm shower, or a public pool deck. The virus enters through a micro-cut or scrape in your skin, and then it can lay dormant for months before it grows large enough for you to see it.

faqs.question: Why does my heel hurt excruciatingly badly on the first few steps I take out of bed in the morning?
faqs.answer: This is the cardinal sign of plantar fasciitis. Here's why: your plantar fascia (the bowstring on the bottom of your foot) is inflamed and has micro-tears. When you sleep, your foot is in a relaxed, pointed-down position, and that fascia scars down and shortens overnight. When you take your first step in the morning, you are violently re-tearing that shortened, scarred tissue. After a few minutes of warming it up, it stretches out and feels a bit better.

faqs.question: My doctor said heel spurs don't cause the pain. I have a huge heel spur on my X-ray. How can that not be the problem?
faqs.answer: This is a very common misconception. The heel spur is the result of the problem, not the cause. Your plantar fascia has been pulling on its insertion point on your heel bone for years. In response to this chronic pulling, your bone has grown a spur. Many people have giant spurs and zero pain. The pain is coming from the inflammation in the fascia (the soft-tissue), not the spur (the bone). We treat the fascia, not the spur.

faqs.question: I've been stretching my calf and rolling my foot on a frozen bottle, and it's not enough. What's the real fix?
faqs.answer: Stretching and icing are good, but they are often not enough. The real fix is stopping the re-injury. 1) Support: You must never walk barefoot. You need supportive shoes with a good arch support all the time. 2) Night Splint: The most effective treatment is a night splint (or a Strassburg sock). You wear it to bed, and it keeps your foot at a 90-degree angle all night. This stops the fascia from shortening overnight. When you wake up, that first-step pain is gone, because the tissue is already stretched.

faqs.question: Isn't the plague from the Middle Ages? Does this still exist?
faqs.answer: Yes, it absolutely still exists. It is not gone. The Black Death (the plague) is a bacterial infection (Yersinia pestis) that is endemic (naturally lives) in wild rodent populations (like prairie dogs, squirrels, and rats) in certain parts of the world, including the American Southwest (e.g., Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado).

faqs.question: How do people even get it?
faqs.answer: There are three main ways. 1) Bubonic (most common): You are bitten by a flea that had previously bitten an infected rodent. The bacteria travel to your lymph node (the bubo), which becomes a huge, painful swelling in your groin or armpit. 2) Pneumonic: You inhale the bacteria (e.g., from an infected person or animal that is coughing). This is the most dangerous form and is transmissible from person-to-person. 3) Septicemic: The bacteria get directly into your bloodstream.

faqs.question: My cat caught a prairie dog and is now sick with a fever and a huge abscess under his jaw. Could I get the plague from my cat?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a high-risk scenario. Cats are very susceptible to plague and can get it from eating infected rodents. That abscess could be a bubo. You are at risk in two ways: 1) From handling his secretions (the pus). 2) Extremely high risk if he develops the pneumonic (lung) form and coughs on you. You need to take your cat to a vet immediately and tell your own doctor.

faqs.question: Is it treatable? Or is it a death sentence?
faqs.answer: It is highly treatable if caught early. The plague bacteria are very sensitive to basic antibiotics (like gentamicin or doxycycline). The problem is that it progresses very fast. If you have flu-like symptoms and a bubo (a swollen lymph node) after hiking or camping in the Southwest, you must go to an ER and tell them I'm worried about the plague. If it is not treated, it is often fatal.

faqs.question: I'm 30 weeks pregnant and just had sudden, severe, constant abdominal pain and dark red vaginal bleeding. What's the difference between this and placenta previa?
faqs.answer: What you are describing is the classic sign of a placental abruption. The key differences are: 1) Placenta Previa is painless, bright red bleeding. 2) Placental Abruption is painful, dark red (or port wine) bleeding. Previa is a location problem (the placenta is covering the exit). Abruption is a separation problem—the placenta is peeling away from the uterine wall before the baby is born.

faqs.question: Why is this an emergency? The bleeding isn't that heavy.
faqs.answer: The amount of visible bleeding does not matter. The real danger is the concealed bleeding behind the placenta. This abruption is a catastrophe for two reasons: 1) For the baby: The placenta is their lifeline. As it peels off, the baby is losing its oxygen supply. 2) For you: It can trigger a clotting cascade called DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation), where your body uses up all its clotting factors, leading to massive, uncontrollable hemorrhage.

faqs.question: My doctor said my cocaine use (or smoking / high blood pressure) caused this. How?
faqs.answer: These are the biggest risk factors. Cocaine (and to a lesser extent, the nicotine from smoking) is a powerful vasoconstrictor—it squeezes your blood vessels. This can cause a vasospasm in the vessels behind the placenta, making them rupture and tear the placenta off the wall. Chronic high blood pressure (hypertension) also puts so much strain on those delicate placental vessels that it makes them fragile and prone to tearing.

faqs.question: I'm 28 weeks and just had a gush of bright red, painless bleeding. My ultrasound says I have a complete placenta previa. What does this mean?
faqs.answer: Placenta previa is a location problem. Previa means in the way. It means your placenta has implanted at the bottom of your uterus, and it is completely covering your cervix (the exit). The painless, bright red bleeding is the warning shot—it's caused by the thinning of your lower uterus in the third trimester, which shears the edge of the placenta, causing it to bleed.

faqs.question: I had a low-lying placenta at my 20-week scan. Is there a chance it will move up?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. This is very common. The placenta itself doesn't move, but as your uterus grows and stretches (like a balloon), it pulls the low-lying placenta up and away from the cervix. If it was low-lying (near, but not on the cervix) at 20 weeks, there is a >90% chance it will be in a normal position by your 32-week scan. A complete previa is less likely to move.

faqs.question: Why do I have to have a C-section for a previa? My body was made to give birth.
faqs.answer: In this one situation, your body cannot safely deliver vaginally. The placenta (the baby's life-support) is plugging the exit. If you were to go into labor, your cervix would dilate (open). This dilating would violently tear the placenta (which is a bag of blood vessels) off the uterine wall. This would cause catastrophic, non-stop hemorrhage in you, and it would instantly cut off the blood and oxygen supply to your baby. A planned C-section is the only safe way to deliver.

faqs.question: I've had two C-sections before this pregnancy. Is that why I have a previa?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the #1 risk factor. A scar on your uterus (from a C-section or a D&C) is damaged tissue. The placenta prefers to implant in healthy tissue. If you have scarring on the upper part of your uterus, the placenta will seek out healthy, un-scarred tissue, and it's forced to implant in the lower part, which is why it ends up covering the cervix.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a placenta previa and I've had 2 C-sections, so they are worried about a placenta accreta. What is that?
faqs.answer: Placenta accreta is one of the most dangerous complications in pregnancy. Previa means the placenta is at the exit. Accreta means that the placenta's roots (the villi) have grown too deeply into the uterine wall. Normally, the placenta sticks to the lining (like Velcro) and peels off easily after birth. An accreta placenta has grown into the muscle of the uterine wall (like the roots of a tree) and cannot be separated.

faqs.question: Why is this life-threatening?
faqs.answer: It's life-threatening because, after the baby is born, the placenta will not detach. If a doctor tries to pull it out, it will tear the uterine wall, causing massive, uncontrollable, arterial hemorrhage. The only way to control the bleeding is to not even try to detach the placenta, and to perform a planned hysterectomy (removing the entire uterus, with the placenta still attached) immediately after the baby is delivered.

faqs.question: Why is having a C-section scar and a previa the perfect storm for this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic cause. Your C-section scar is defective tissue—it lacks the normal stop sign layer (the decidua) that tells the placenta roots stop growing here. You have a previa, so your placenta is implanted directly on top of this defective scar, which has no stop sign. The placenta roots see no stop sign and just keep growing right through the scar and invading the muscle (and sometimes the bladder).

faqs.question: I got this one, single, large, scaly oval patch on my chest, and now, 2 weeks later, I have hundreds of small, pink spots all over my back. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the textbook, classic presentation of Pityriasis Rosea. That first, large patch is called the herald patch or mother patch—it's the announcement of the rash. The widespread breakout of smaller patches that happens 1-2 weeks later is the secondary eruption. It's a very common, harmless viral rash.

faqs.question: My doctor said the rash on my back looks like a Christmas tree. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is the classic distribution of the secondary rash. The oval spots on your back tend to align themselves along your cleavage lines (your ribs). This alignment creates a pattern that looks like the drooping branches of a Christmas tree. It's a key diagnostic clue.

faqs.question: How did I get this? Is it contagious? Is it herpes?
faqs.answer: It is not contagious. It is not an STD. It's thought to be triggered by a reactivation of a benign human herpesvirus (like HHV-6 or HHV-7)—these are not the cold sore or genital herpes viruses. These are childhood viruses (like the roseola virus) that live dormantly in your system forever. For an unknown reason, one of them reactivates and causes the rash.

faqs.question: How long will this last, and how do I make it go away? The itching is driving me crazy!
faqs.answer: This is a self-limiting illness. It cannot be cured with an antiviral pill or antibiotic. It has to run its course, which is typically 6 to 8 weeks (it can be longer or shorter). The only treatment is for the itch (symptomatic relief)—you can use topical steroid creams, oral antihistamines (like Benadryl), or calamine lotion. Some dermatologists use sunlight (phototherapy) to help clear it faster.

faqs.question: My doctor found a non-functioning pituitary tumor. If it's not making hormones, why do we even need to treat it?
faqs.answer: A non-functioning adenoma doesn't produce excess hormones, but it can still cause serious problems just by its size. As it grows, it can press on the surrounding structures, most importantly the optic nerves, leading to tunnel vision or even blindness. It can also compress and damage the normal pituitary gland, causing a deficiency of essential hormones (hypopituitarism).

faqs.question: I've been having vision problems and headaches. Why is my doctor ordering an MRI of my brain for an eye issue?
faqs.answer: This is a classic sign of a pituitary tumor. The pituitary gland sits right below the optic chiasm, which is where the optic nerves from both eyes cross. A growing tumor can press on this intersection, causing a very specific type of vision loss, usually affecting the peripheral (outer) vision in both eyes, often described as tunnel vision. The headaches are also from the pressure of the tumor.

faqs.question: I have a prolactinoma and my doctor wants to treat it with medicine (cabergoline) first, not surgery. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the standard and most effective treatment for prolactinomas. These specific tumors are uniquely sensitive to medications called dopamine agonists (like cabergoline or bromocriptine). These drugs are highly effective at shrinking the tumor and lowering prolactin levels, often restoring normal hormone function and vision without any surgery at all.

faqs.question: I have Cushing's disease from a pituitary tumor. Will I go back to normal after surgery?
faqs.answer: Surgery to remove the tumor is the primary goal and often cures Cushing's disease. However, recovery can be a long process. Your body has been suppressed by high cortisol for so long that the rest of your pituitary gland has gone to sleep. After surgery, you will likely need to take replacement cortisol (like prednisone) for many months, or even years, and slowly taper off as your body learns to produce its own again. Physical and emotional symptoms also take time to resolve.

faqs.question: How is it possible to remove a brain tumor through my nose? What are the risks of this?
faqs.answer: This is called the transsphenoidal approach. The surgeon passes small instruments through the nasal passages and the sphenoid sinus (an air-filled cavity behind the nose) to reach the pituitary gland at the base of the brain, without making an external incision on the face or head. The main risks include potential damage to the normal pituitary gland (leading to hormone deficiencies), a leak of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the brain lining, or, rarely, bleeding or infection.

faqs.question: My child is incredibly itchy at night, but I can't see anything. Is it definitely pinworms?
faqs.answer: Intense itching around the anus, especially at night, is the most common sign of pinworms. The female worms migrate out at night to lay their eggs on the surrounding skin, which causes the itching. The worms themselves are very small, white, and look like tiny threads, so they can be hard to spot. Your doctor will likely recommend a tape test to confirm.

faqs.question: I'm supposed to do the tape test on my child. This feels weird. When is the best time, and what am I looking for?
faqs.answer: It does feel strange, but it's the most effective test. The best time is first thing in the morning, before your child uses the toilet or bathes. Take a piece of clear sticky tape, press the sticky side firmly against the skin right around the anus for a few seconds. Then, fold the tape sticky-side in on itself or stick it to a glass slide. The doctor will look at the tape under a microscope for the tiny, microscopic eggs.

faqs.question: I'm cleaning like crazy, but my kid keeps getting reinfected. Where are we going wrong?
faqs.answer: Reinfection is extremely common because the eggs are microscopic, very light, and can survive for 2-3 weeks on surfaces. The most common source is the child scratching at night, getting eggs under their fingernails, and then transferring them to their mouth or to surfaces. You must treat the entire household at the same time, even if no one else has symptoms. Also, wash all bedding, towels, and pajamas in hot water on the same day you take the medicine.

faqs.question: Can I get pinworms from my dog or cat?
faqs.answer: No. Pinworms (Enterobius vermicularis) are human-specific parasites. They cannot infect dogs, cats, or other pets. The infection is passed only from human to human, usually by ingesting the microscopic eggs.

faqs.question: The medicine says to take one dose and then another in two weeks. Why the wait?
faqs.answer: The medication (like mebendazole or albendazole) is very good at killing the adult worms, but it doesn't kill the eggs. The two-week waiting period is designed to allow any eggs that were left behind (either in the environment or already swallowed) to hatch into new worms. The second dose then kills these newly hatched worms before they can mature and lay more eggs, thus breaking the life cycle.

faqs.question: My eye is red, but it's not really goopy, just super watery and itchy. Is this the pink eye that's really contagious?
faqs.answer: It sounds like you have viral or allergic conjunctivitis. Both are different from bacterial pink eye. If it's extremely itchy with watery discharge, especially in both eyes, and you have other allergy symptoms (like sneezing), it's likely allergic. If it's watery, red, and feels gritty (like sand in your eye), and maybe you had a cold recently, it's likely viral. Viral pink eye is highly contagious, while allergic is not.

faqs.question: How can the doctor tell if my pink eye is bacterial (needs antibiotics) or viral (just have to wait it out)?
faqs.answer: Doctors usually diagnose based on symptoms. Bacterial pink eye typically has a thick, continuous discharge of pus (green or yellow) that makes the eyelids stick together, especially after sleeping. It often starts in one eye. Viral pink eye usually has a watery discharge, feels gritty, and is often associated with a cold or sore throat. It frequently spreads to the other eye.

faqs.question: My doctor said it's viral and antibiotics won't help, but my daycare says my child needs a doctor's note and drops to go back. What should I do?
faqs.answer: This is a common dilemma. Antibiotic drops do not treat viral conjunctivitis, and the 24-hour return rule is really for bacterial pink eye after starting antibiotics. However, many schools/daycares have a blanket policy. You should explain to them that the doctor diagnosed it as viral, which antibiotics won't help. The best prevention is hand-washing. Some doctors may provide a note explaining this, or a daycare may simply require the child to stay home until the eye is no longer red and watery, which can take a week or more.

faqs.question: My vision is a little blurry with this. Is that normal, or is it something more serious?
faqs.answer: Some mild blurriness that clears with blinking (due to discharge or tearing) can be normal. However, if you have persistent blurry vision, severe pain, feel like something is stuck in your eye, or become very sensitive to light (photophobia), you need to see a doctor immediately. This could be a sign of a more serious condition like keratitis (inflammation of the cornea) or uveitis.

faqs.question: This happens to me every spring. Is it possible for allergic conjunctivitis to look this bad?
faqs.answer: Yes. Allergic conjunctivitis can be very severe. The main symptom is intense, overwhelming itching, along with watery eyes, redness, and swelling of the eyelids. It almost always affects both eyes at the same time and occurs seasonally (like with pollen) or after exposure to an allergen (like pet dander). It is not contagious and is treated with antihistamine or mast cell stabilizer eye drops.

faqs.question: My child's doctor said this tumor is in the pineal gland. What does that part of the brain even do?
faqs.answer: The pineal gland is a tiny gland located deep in the center of the brain. Its main job is to produce melatonin, the hormone that regulates your sleep-wake cycles (circadian rhythm). Tumors in this area can disrupt sleep, but more often they cause problems by pressing on nearby brain structures.

faqs.question: My son has been having terrible headaches and vomiting, and his eyes look stuck looking upwards. How does a brain tumor cause that?
faqs.answer: These are classic symptoms of a pineal region tumor. The tumor can block the normal flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain, causing a buildup of pressure called hydrocephalus. This pressure causes the severe headaches (often worse in the morning) and vomiting. The specific eye problem you're describing is called Parinaud syndrome. The tumor presses on a part of the brainstem that controls eye movements, making it difficult or impossible to look up.

faqs.question: I've never heard of this. How common is pineoblastoma, and is it related to retinoblastoma?
faqs.answer: Pineoblastoma is a very rare and aggressive (Grade 4) brain tumor, primarily affecting children. It is a type of embryonal tumor, meaning it arises from primitive, undeveloped cells. It can be related to retinoblastoma (a cancer of the eye). Some children with the genetic mutation for retinoblastoma (in the RB1 gene) can develop tumors in the pineal gland, which is sometimes called trilateral retinoblastoma.

faqs.question: The treatment plan (surgery, radiation, chemo) sounds really aggressive. Why is this needed?
faqs.answer: Because pineoblastoma is a high-grade (malignant) tumor, it grows quickly and has a high risk of spreading to other parts of the brain and spinal cord through the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). A combination of treatments is necessary. Surgery is done to get a diagnosis and remove as much of the tumor as possible (which can also help relieve the hydrocephalus). Radiation and chemotherapy are then needed to kill the remaining microscopic cancer cells and treat or prevent spread.

faqs.question: I'm seeing scary statistics online. Is this survivable? What factors matter most for prognosis?
faqs.answer: It's true that this is a very serious cancer, but treatment has improved. The prognosis depends heavily on several factors: the child's age (very young children, under 3, have a harder time as radiation is often avoided), whether the cancer has already spread (metastasized) at the time of diagnosis, and how much of the tumor can be safely removed during surgery. You must speak directly with your pediatric neuro-oncology team about your child's specific case.

faqs.question: I have pain shooting down my leg (sciatica). Is that from a pinched nerve in my back, even if my back itself doesn't hurt?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. This is the most common presentation. The sciatic nerve is a large nerve formed from roots in your lower back (lumbar spine). A herniated disc or bone spur can press on one of these nerve roots. The nerve root gets inflamed and sends pain signals along its entire path, which runs down your buttock and the back of your leg, even if you feel no pain at the actual pinch site in your spine.

faqs.question: I'm getting numbness and tingling in my fingers. How can this be from a pinched nerve in my neck?
faqs.answer: This is called cervical radiculopathy. The nerves that provide feeling and control movement in your arms and hands all originate from your spinal cord in your neck (cervical spine). Just like in the low back, a herniated disc or bone spur in your neck can compress one of these nerve roots. Depending on which nerve root is pinched, you will feel symptoms (numbness, tingling, pain, or weakness) in a specific part of your shoulder, arm, or hand.

faqs.question: The doctor did an X-ray, but it looked fine. Why do I still have pain? Do I need an MRI?
faqs.answer: An X-ray is excellent for looking at bones. It can show if you have arthritis, bone spurs, or a narrowed disc space. However, it cannot see soft tissues. The most common cause of a pinched nerve is a herniated disc, which is soft. An MRI is the best test to visualize the discs, nerves, and spinal cord to confirm if a disc is bulging or herniated and is a-ctually pressing on a nerve.

faqs.question: How long should I wait for this to heal on its own before considering injections or surgery?
faqs.answer: Most cases of pinched nerves (about 80-90%) from a herniated disc will improve significantly or resolve on their own within 6 to 12 weeks with conservative care (activity modification, anti-inflammatory meds, physical therapy). If the pain is severe and not improving, or if you have significant weakness, an epidural steroid injection may be offered. Surgery is usually only considered after failing conservative care or if you have progressive weakness or red flag symptoms.

faqs.question: It hurts when I sit. What's the best position to sleep or sit in to get some relief?
faqs.answer: For sciatica (low back pinched nerve), sitting often increases pressure on the discs and is the most painful position. Try to stand and walk as tolerated. When sitting, use a chair with good lumbar support. When sleeping, try lying on your back with a pillow under your knees, or on your side (the non-painful side) with a pillow between your knees. This keeps your spine in a neutral alignment.

faqs.question: Did I get this from being unclean or sitting too much? I'm really embarrassed.
faqs.answer: This is a very common misconception. Pilonidal disease is not caused by poor hygiene. It's thought to be caused by loose hairs (often stiff body hair) being forced under the skin or into pores in the crease of the buttocks (the natal cleft) due to friction, pressure, and sitting. It's a follicle problem, not a cleanliness problem. It's much more common in men, people who sit a lot, and those with coarse body hair.

faqs.question: I had one lanced (drained) in the ER, and it came right back. Why won't it go away?
faqs.answer: An incision and drainage (I&D) is an emergency procedure to treat the abscess (the painful infection) but it doesn't treat the underlying disease. The disease is the tract, or pit, under the skin that hair and debris get trapped in. After draining the infection, the pit remains and is very likely to get infected again. Permanent treatment requires a surgical procedure to remove the entire cyst and tract.

faqs.question: It just looks like a small dimple or pit at the top of my tailbone, but it keeps getting sore. Is this a pilonidal cyst?
faqs.answer: That's exactly how it often starts. The pilonidal sinus is the small opening or pit in the skin of the natal cleft. It may be asymptomatic for a long time, or it might get intermittently sore, drain a small amount of fluid, or get blocked. If it gets blocked and infected, it develops into a painful pilonidal abscess (cyst).

faqs.question: My doctor is talking about surgery. What's the difference between a simple excision and a cleft lift procedure?
faqs.answer: A simple excision involves cutting out the cyst and either stitching the wound closed (which has a high risk of infection and recurrence) or leaving it open to heal from the bottom up (which requires months of wound packing). A cleft lift (or flap procedure) is a more specialized surgery. It removes the diseased tissue and reshapes the natal cleft to be shallower, moving the scar off the midline. This dramatically reduces pressure and friction, leading to a much faster recovery and a much lower chance of it ever coming back.

faqs.question: After surgery, what can I do to make sure this never comes back?
faqs.answer: The most important thing is to keep the area clean and dry. Many surgeons also strongly recommend permanent hair removal (e.g., laser hair removal) in the entire natal cleft region. Removing the hair eliminates the fuel for the disease, making recurrence much less likely.

faqs.question: The doctor said this is a Grade 1 tumor. Does that mean it's not cancer?
faqs.answer: In the context of brain tumors, Grade 1 means it is the least aggressive type. It is considered benign, meaning it grows very slowly and tends to stay in one place (it doesn't spread or metastasize). While it's not cancer in the way a fast-spreading Grade 4 tumor is, it is still a serious condition because it's a growth in the brain that can press on and damage vital structures.

faqs.question: My child's tumor is in the cerebellum. How will that affect their balance and coordination after surgery?
faqs.answer: The cerebellum is the part of the brain that controls balance, coordination, and fine motor skills. A tumor in this area (the most common location for this tumor) is why your child may have been clumsy, stumbled, or had trouble with tasks like writing. Surgery in this area can temporarily worsen these symptoms. A condition called cerebellar mutism syndrome (trouble with speech, coordination, and emotion) can sometimes occur after surgery but usually improves with rehabilitation.

faqs.question: The tumor is near the optic nerve. Does this mean my child will go blind?
faqs.answer: This is called an optic pathway glioma. These tumors can press on the optic nerves and cause vision loss. The goal of treatment (which may be observation, chemotherapy, or rarely surgery) is to preserve vision. Complete blindness is not a given, and many children maintain good vision. Your child will need to be followed very closely by a neuro-ophthalmologist to monitor for any changes.

faqs.question: If the surgeon removes it all, why are they still talking about follow-up scans or even chemo/radiation?
faqs.answer: If the surgeon achieves a gross total resection (GTR), meaning they are confident they removed the entire visible tumor, the prognosis is excellent and often a cure. Follow-up scans (MRIs) are done for years just to be certain it doesn't return. If the tumor is in a location where it cannot be removed completely (like the optic pathway or brainstem) without causing severe damage, then chemotherapy (or less commonly, radiation) may be used to shrink or stop the growth of the remaining tumor.

faqs.question: Is this tumor related to any genetic conditions?
faqs.answer: Yes, in some cases. Pilocytic astrocytomas, especially those in the optic pathway, are strongly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1). If a child is diagnosed with an optic pathway glioma, they will almost always be evaluated for NF1 (which can also cause cafe-au-lait spots on the skin).

faqs.question: I get these attacks of a racing heart, pounding headache, and sudden sweating, and my blood pressure goes sky-high. My anxiety meds don't help. Could it be this?
faqs.answer: It's possible, and you should definitely be evaluated for it. These spells are the hallmark of a pheochromocytoma. The tumor, usually on the adrenal gland, randomly releases massive bursts of adrenaline (epinephrine and norepinephrine). This causes the classic fight or flight symptoms: pounding headache, heart palpitations, profuse sweating, and dangerously high blood pressure. It can feel just like a panic attack, but it's caused by a physical tumor.

faqs.question: My doctor ordered a 24-hour urine test. What are they looking for in my urine?
faqs.answer: They are testing for metanephrines and catecholamines. These are the breakdown products of adrenaline. When the tumor releases adrenaline, your body breaks it down, and the byproducts are excreted in your urine. Measuring the total amount over 24 hours (rather than a single blood test) gives a better picture of what your body is producing over time and is less likely to miss a burst from the tumor.

faqs.question: Why do I need to take special blood pressure pills (alpha-blockers) for two weeks before surgery?
faqs.answer: This is the most critical part of your pre-operative care. Your body is used to being flooded with adrenaline. During surgery, when the tumor is handled, it can release a massive, life-threatening surge of adrenaline. You must first be alpha-blocked (with drugs like phenoxybenzamine) to block the effects of this adrenaline on your blood vessels. This prevents your blood pressure from becoming dangerously high during the operation. After that, you may also be given beta-blockers to control your heart rate.

faqs.question: Is this tumor a cancer? Will I need chemo?
faqs.answer: Most pheochromocytomas (about 85-90%) are benign, meaning they don't spread to other parts of the body. The primary treatment is surgical removal. However, even benign tumors are dangerous because of the hormones they produce. A small percentage are malignant (cancerous) and can spread. These may require additional treatments like radiation or specific types of chemotherapy, but the first step is always surgery.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned genetic testing. Does having a pheochromocytoma mean my family is at risk?
faqs.answer: It might. Up to 40% of pheochromocytomas are caused by an inherited genetic mutation (e.g., in genes like SDHB, SDHD, VHL, RET). If you are found to have one of these mutations, it means other family members could be at risk for developing pheochromocytomas or other related tumors, and they should be offered genetic counseling and screening.

faqs.question: My baby's newborn screening came back positive for PKU. What does this mean right now? What do I need to do?
faqs.answer: This means your baby's body likely can't break down an amino acid called phenylalanine (Phe), which is found in protein. The immediate first step is to confirm the diagnosis with another blood test. If confirmed, your baby must immediately start a special metabolic formula that is very low in Phe. You will work with a metabolic clinic and a dietitian to manage this. The key is that this was caught early. By sticking to the diet, you can prevent the severe intellectual disabilities PKU causes.

faqs.question: I know I have to follow the diet, but how strict is strict? What happens if I cheat or have a high-phenylalanine meal?
faqs.answer: For classic PKU, strict means for life. High-protein foods like meat, dairy, nuts, and even bread and pasta are essentially off-limits. You must drink a special formula to get the protein you need without the Phe. Cheating causes your blood Phe levels to spike. In children, this causes irreversible brain damage. In adults, off-diet high levels cause brain fog, anxiety, depression, tremors, and slow thinking. It's a neurotoxin to your brain.

faqs.question: I'm an adult with PKU and was told I could go off-diet as a kid. Now I'm having brain fog and anxiety. Should I go back on the diet?
faqs.answer: This was common advice decades ago, but we now know it was wrong. High Phe levels are toxic to the adult brain as well. The symptoms you're describing—brain fog, anxiety, slow processing, headaches—are classic signs of high Phe levels. You should absolutely see a metabolic specialist. Going back on diet (even if it's difficult) can dramatically improve your neurological and psychological symptoms.

faqs.question: I'm a woman with PKU. What do I need to do before I get pregnant?
faqs.answer: This is called Maternal PKU, and it is critically important. You must be in strict metabolic control (on diet, with very low Phe levels) before you even try to conceive. If your Phe levels are high during pregnancy, the Phe acts as a teratogen (like alcohol or a drug) and will cross the placenta, severely damaging your baby's developing brain and heart, even if the baby doesn't have PKU. You must work with your clinic to manage this.

faqs.question: I've heard about a new medicine (Kuvan/sapropterin). How do I know if that will work for me instead of just the diet?
faqs.answer: Sapropterin (Kuvan) is a form of BH4, a co-factor that helps the deficient enzyme work better. It only works for a subset of people with PKU, typically those with milder or BH4-responsive forms. It doesn't work for classic PKU.
