Carbidopa is a helper drug that prevents the levodopa from being broken down in your body before it reaches your brain. It is the most effective drug for Parkinson's. It doesn't stop working, but as the disease progresses, the brain's ability to store and use the dopamine smoothly can wane, leading to on-off fluctuations where the medication wears off before the next dose.

faqs.question: I'm having very vivid, sometimes violent, dreams where I act them out, (punching or kicking). My wife is scared. Is this a symptom?
faqs.answer: This is a very specific and common symptom called REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD). In normal REM sleep, your body is paralyzed so you don't act out your dreams. In Parkinson's, this paralysis fails, leading you to physically act out your dreams. What's significant is that RBD can often appear years or even decades before the motor symptoms (like tremor) ever begin.

disease_name: Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system

faqs.question: I'm a heavy smoker, and I've developed severe dizziness, balance problems, and slurred speech over just a few weeks. My brain MRI is normal. What is going on?
faqs.answer: You need to be urgently evaluated for a paraneoplastic syndrome, specifically paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. Paraneoplastic means related to cancer. The idea is that your body's immune system has mounted an attack against an underlying, hidden cancer (often small cell lung cancer in smokers). The antibodies (like anti-Hu) it creates to fight the cancer cross-react and mistakenly attack your cerebellum (the balance center of your brain). The neurological symptoms often appear months or years before the cancer itself is detectable.

faqs.question: My doctor is ordering a paraneoplastic antibody panel and a PET scan. How do these help?
faqs.answer: This is the exact right workup. The antibody panel is a blood or spinal fluid test that looks for the specific rogue antibodies (like anti-Hu, anti-Yo, anti-Ri) that are known to cause these syndromes. Finding one of these antibodies is strong evidence. The PET scan is a full-body scan designed to light up any areas of hidden cancer (the primary tumor) that may be triggering the immune response. The goal is to find and treat the underlying cancer, which is the only way to stop the immune attack.

faqs.question: Will my neurological symptoms (memory loss, weakness) go away if the cancer is treated?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, in many paraneoplastic syndromes, the neurological damage is irreversible because the antibodies have already destroyed the nerve cells. The prognosis is often poor. The primary goal of treatment (e.g., steroids, IVIG, plasmapheresis) is to stop the progression of the damage, not to reverse what's been done. The most important step is treating the underlying cancer, as this is the only way to stop the fuel for the antibody production.

faqs.question: What is Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS)? My doctor mentioned it.
faqs.answer: LEMS is another paraneoplastic syndrome that causes severe muscle weakness, especially in the legs (difficulty climbing stairs or getting out of a chair). It's caused by an antibody that attacks the channels that release a chemical (acetylcholine) to make muscles contract. It is very strongly associated (about 60% of cases) with an underlying small cell lung cancer. A unique feature is that muscle strength may temporarily improve with brief exercise, unlike in Myasthenia Gravis.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a paraganglioma in my neck. Is this the same as a pheochromocytoma?
faqs.answer: They are sister tumors. A pheochromocytoma is a tumor of the adrenal gland (which sits on the kidney) that releases adrenaline. A paraganglioma is the same type of tumor, but it's located outside the adrenal gland, along the sympathetic nerve chain—in the abdomen, chest, or, in your case, the neck (a carotid body tumor). Both can (but don't always) produce adrenaline, causing the same panic attack symptoms (high BP, sweating, palpitations).

faqs.question: Mine is non-secreting (not making adrenaline). Can't we just leave it alone?
faqs.answer: Even if it's non-secreting, a paraganglioma in the neck (a carotid body tumor) is sitting in a very dangerous neighborhood. It's often wrapped around the carotid artery (which supplies blood to your brain) and important nerves (like those controlling your voice, swallowing, and tongue). They are almost always removed because as they grow, they will eventually compress these structures, and the risk of surgery becomes much higher.

faqs.question: Why am I being sent for genetic testing? My doctor mentioned SDHB.
faqs.answer: This is extremely important. Unlike pheochromocytomas, a very high percentage (30-40% or more) of paragangliomas are caused by an inherited genetic mutation. Mutations in the SDH genes (like SDHB, SDHC, SDHD) are the most common. Finding a mutation, especially in SDHB, is critical because it tells your doctor you are at a much higher risk for the tumor to be malignant (cancerous), to metastasize, or for you to develop multiple tumors in the future. It also means your family members must be tested.

faqs.question: What's the difference between an SDHB and SDHD mutation?
faqs.answer: They are both in the same gene family, but they behave differently. An SDHB mutation carries the highest risk of malignancy (cancer) and spread. An SDHD mutation is indolent (less aggressive) but is known for causing multiple tumors, especially in the head and neck, and it's parent-of-origin specific—meaning you generally only get the disease if you inherit the mutation from your father.

faqs.question: I had my first panic attack, and I thought I was dying. My heart was pounding, I couldn't breathe, and my chest hurt. How do I know it wasn't a heart attack?
faqs.answer: This is the classic, terrifying dilemma, and you should always go to the ER for a first-time episode to rule out a heart attack. A doctor will tell the difference with an EKG and blood tests (cardiac enzymes), which are normal in a panic attack. Key differences: a panic attack hits a peak of terror within 10 minutes and then subsides. A heart attack is often a crushing pressure that persists or gets worse, and is often associated with exertion, while a panic attack can happen at rest.

faqs.question: During my panic attacks, I get this terrifying feeling that I'm not real, or the world around me looks fake or foggy. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a very common, though deeply disturbing, symptom. It's called derealization (feeling the world is unreal) and depersonalization (feeling detached from yourself, like you're in a movie). It's a psychological defense mechanism—your brain is so overwhelmed by the fight or flight response that it checks out as a way to protect you from the perceived terror.

faqs.question: I'm so afraid of having another one that I'm afraid to leave my house. What is happening to me?
faqs.answer: This is the transition from having panic attacks to developing Panic Disorder. The core of the disorder is not just the attacks themselves, but the fear of the fear—the intense anticipatory anxiety about when the next one will strike. This fear can lead to agoraphobia, where you avoid any place or situation (like driving, stores, or crowds) where you might have an attack and can't escape. This is the time to seek therapy, like CBT.

faqs.question: How can Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) stop something that feels so physical?
faqs.answer: CBT is the most effective treatment for panic disorder. It works by breaking the cycle of panic. It teaches you that the physical symptoms (racing heart, dizziness) are just a harmless adrenaline surge, not a heart attack. A key part is interoceptive exposure, where you purposefully induce the symptoms (e.g., spinning in a chair to get dizzy) in a safe place, teaching your brain to stop interpreting these feelings as dangerous, which disconnects the fear button.

faqs.question: I have the worst, most severe upper-belly pain of my life, and it's boring straight through to my back. I can't get comfortable. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the textbook description of acute pancreatitis. The pancreas is an organ deep in your abdomen, right in front of the spine, which is why the pain radiates or bores through to the back. It's an intense, constant, 10/10 pain. It's a medical emergency, and you need to go to the ER immediately.

faqs.question: My doctor said my pancreatitis was caused by gallstones. How can a gallbladder stone hurt my pancreas?
faqs.answer: This is one of the two most common causes (along with alcohol). The gallbladder and the pancreas share a common duct (tube) that they use to drain into the small intestine. If a small gallstone passes out of the gallbladder, it can get stuck in this common duct, plugging the drain for the pancreas. The digestive enzymes that the pancreas makes get backed up, and they begin to auto-digest and inflame the pancreas itself.

faqs.question: Why am I not allowed to eat or drink anything (NPO) in the hospital? I'm starving.
faqs.answer: This is the most important first treatment, called pancreatic rest. The second you eat or drink anything, your brain sends a signal to your pancreas to wake up and start producing those digestive enzymes. This is the last thing you want when the organ is already inflamed and auto-digesting. By keeping your stomach completely empty (NPO) and giving you IV fluids for hydration, you let the pancreas go to sleep and heal.

faqs.question: My dad has chronic pancreatitis from years of drinking. How is that different from an acute attack?
faqs.answer: Acute pancreatitis is a sudden, severe, but often one-time event that, if you survive it, the pancreas can return to normal. Chronic pancreatitis is a different disease. It's a smoldering, long-term, irreversible scarring and destruction of the pancreas (often from chronic alcohol use). It leads to constant pain, inability to digest food (malabsorption, greasy stools), and, because the insulin-making cells are destroyed, diabetes.

faqs.question: My case is severe, and they're worried about necrosis. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: In mild pancreatitis, the organ is just inflamed. In severe necrotizing pancreatitis, the inflammation is so bad that parts of the pancreas die (this is necrosis). This dead tissue is a perfect food for bacteria, and it can become infected, leading to a life-threatening abscess in your abdomen and sepsis (body-wide infection). This is a very serious complication that may require surgery or drainage.

faqs.question: My doctor found a PNET. Is this the same as pancreatic cancer that everyone talks about?
faqs.answer: No, and this is a critical difference. The pancreatic cancer with a very poor prognosis (adenocarcinoma) arises from the exocrine (digestive enzyme) cells. Your tumor, a PNET, arises from the neuroendocrine (hormone-making) cells. PNETs are much rarer, are often very slow-growing (indolent), and have a much better prognosis and different treatment than adenocarcinoma. This is the type of cancer Steve Jobs had.

faqs.question: My PNET is non-functioning. What does that mean, and why did it take so long to find?
faqs.answer: PNETs are grouped into two types. Functioning tumors produce massive amounts of a hormone, causing a clear syndrome (e.g., an insulinoma makes too much insulin, causing low blood sugar). Non-functioning tumors (the most common type) don't produce a hormone, so they cause no symptoms at all. They are usually found by accident on a scan, or only after they grow very large and start to cause mass effect (like vague belly pain or jaundice).

faqs.question: I have an insulinoma and I keep having episodes of severe confusion, sweating, and low blood sugar. Are these related?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the exact functional syndrome for an insulinoma, which is a PNET of the insulin-making cells. The tumor is pumping out insulin 24/7, which causes your blood sugar to crash to dangerously low levels (hypoglycemia). This starves your brain of sugar, causing the confusion, sweating, and panic symptoms. This is a medical emergency, and the cure is surgical removal of the tumor.

faqs.question: The tumor has spread to my liver (metastatic). I thought PNETs were slow-growing. What are my options now?
faqs.answer: Even slow-growing (indolent) tumors can spread (metastasize) over time, and the liver is the most common site. But even with metastatic disease, the prognosis is far better than with standard pancreatic cancer. Because the tumors are indolent, you may live with the disease for many years. Treatment is focused on controlling it, not necessarily curing it, using options like octreotide (a hormone blocker) or PRRT (a special type of targeted radiation).

faqs.question: I had a CT scan for something else, and they incidentally found a cyst on my pancreas. Should I be terrified this is cancer?
faqs.answer: First, take a deep breath. This is happening all the time as scan quality improves, and the vast majority of these incidental cysts are benign (non-cancerous). However, some types of cysts (like IPMNs or MCNs) are considered pre-cancerous, meaning they have the potential to one day turn into cancer. Your doctor's job now is to figure out which type you have.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have an IPMN (Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm). What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is the most common type of pre-cancerous cyst. It's a cyst that grows from the pancreatic ducts (the plumbing of the pancreas) and produces a thick, sticky fluid called mucin. They are graded based on where they are: Side-branch IPMNs (growing from a small side-duct) are very common and low-risk. Main-duct IPMNs (growing in the main pipe) are high-risk and almost always require surgery.

faqs.question: My cyst is a side-branch IPMN, and my doctor wants to just watch it with MRIs. Is this safe? Shouldn't we just take it out?
faqs.answer: This is the standard-of-care for small (<3cm), side-branch IPMNs with no worrisome features. The risk of a small side-branch cyst ever turning into cancer is very, very low (much lower than the risk of major pancreatic surgery). Active surveillance (with an annual MRI or endoscopic ultrasound) is the safest approach. Surgery is only recommended if it grows, develops a nodule, or the main duct starts to widen.

faqs.question: What's an endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)? My doctor wants to do this to get fluid from the cyst.
faqs.answer: An EUS is the best test to characterize a cyst. It's like a regular upper endoscopy, but the scope has a tiny ultrasound on the end. The doctor passes it down your throat, and from your stomach, it can get high-definition pictures of your pancreas through the stomach wall. They can then pass a tiny needle through the scope into the cyst to suck out (aspirate) some of the fluid. Analyzing this fluid for CEA (a tumor marker) or mucin is the best way to tell if it's a pre-cancerous (mucinous) cyst or a totally benign (serous) one.

faqs.question: My father's skin and eyes turned yellow (painless jaundice), and his urine is dark. Why is the doctor ordering a scan of his pancreas?
faqs.answer: This is the classic, tell-tale sign of pancreatic cancer in the head of the pancreas. The tumor grows and compresses the common bile duct, which runs right through that part of the pancreas. This compression plugs the flow of bile from your liver. The bile backs up into your bloodstream, turning your skin yellow (jaundice) and spilling into your urine, making it dark like tea. Because it's a blockage, it's typically painless until the tumor gets very large.

faqs.question: Why is this cancer so deadly? Why is it always found so late?
faqs.answer: There are two main reasons. 1) Location: The pancreas is hidden deep in the abdomen, so tumors (especially in the body or tail) cause no symptoms until they are massive. They don't cause jaundice, just vague, non-specific back pain or weight loss that is easily ignored. 2) Biology: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is incredibly aggressive. It is surrounded by a thick, fibrous stroma (scar tissue) that chemo can't penetrate, and it metastasizes (spreads) to the liver and lymph nodes very, very early, often before it's even visible on a scan.

faqs.question: My mom's tumor is resectable, and they are talking about a Whipple procedure. I've heard this is a massive operation.
faqs.answer: It is. The Whipple (pancreaticoduodenectomy) is one of the largest and most complex operations in all of surgery. To remove the head of the pancreas, the surgeon must also remove the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and the end of the bile duct. Then, they have to re-plumb your entire digestive system (stomach, bile duct, and remaining pancreas) back into your intestine. It has a long, difficult recovery, but for a resectable tumor, it is the only chance for a cure.

faqs.question: I'm a type 2 diabetic, and my blood sugar, which was stable for years, is suddenly out of control. My doctor seems worried.
faqs.answer: This is a major red flag. While long-standing diabetes is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer, a new onset or suddenly worsening diabetes in an older adult (especially with weight loss) can be a symptom of the cancer itself. The growing tumor can damage the insulin-producing cells, causing new or hard-to-control diabetes. This often precedes the jaundice or pain symptoms by 6-12 months.

faqs.question: It's not just a little uncomfortable; it's a sharp, deep pain inside during thrusting. What could be causing that?
faqs.answer: This is called deep dyspareunia, and it's different from entry pain. Deep pain is often caused by a collision with a sensitive internal structure. The most common causes are gynecological conditions like endometriosis (where uterine tissue is on the ligaments behind the uterus), adenomyosis, or uterine fibroids. It can also be from pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) or ovarian cysts. It needs a full GYN workup.

faqs.question: It hurts right at the entrance, like a burning, stinging, or tearing feeling, as soon as penetration starts. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is superficial or entry dyspareunia. The most common cause, especially post-menopause or when breastfeeding, is vaginal atrophy (thinning and dryness) due to low estrogen. In younger women, it can be from vulvodynia (chronic nerve pain at the opening), vestibulodynia, or an over-active pelvic floor. An untreated yeast infection or skin condition (like lichen sclerosus) can also cause it.

faqs.question: It feels like my muscles are clamping shut involuntarily, like hitting a wall, making penetration impossible. Is this vaginismus?
faqs.answer: Yes, your description is the perfect definition of vaginismus. It is an involuntary (a reflex) spasm of the pelvic floor muscles surrounding the vaginal opening, often in anticipation of pain. It's a mind-body loop where the fear of pain causes the muscles to guard and spasm, which then causes the pain, reinforcing the fear. The most effective treatment is specialized pelvic floor physical therapy to learn how to down-train and relax these over-active muscles, often using dilators.

faqs.question: This has only been a problem since I had my baby. I had tearing and stitches. Is it normal for it to still hurt?
faqs.answer: It is common, but it is not normal and it is treatable. The pain can be from several things: scar tissue from your tear/episiotomy that isn't stretching, nerve irritation in the scar, vaginal dryness (common if you are breastfeeding due to low estrogen), or hypertonic (overly tight) pelvic floor muscles that are guarding the area that was injured. A pelvic floor physical therapist is the best person to diagnose and treat this.

faqs.question: My nipple has been scaly, itchy, and sometimes oozes, just like eczema, but my steroid cream isn't working. Why is my doctor suggesting a biopsy?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of Paget's disease of the breast. Eczema-like symptoms that are on one nipple only, don't respond to typical treatments, and persist for weeks are a major red flag. Paget's disease is a rare form of breast cancer where cancer cells (originating from a duct inside the breast) migrate to the skin of the nipple and areola, causing the rash-like appearance. A biopsy is the only way to confirm this.

faqs.question: Is this related to Paget's disease of the bone? I'm confused about the name.
faqs.answer: No, they are two completely separate and unrelated diseases, despite sharing the same name (after the doctor who first described them). Paget's disease of the breast is a form of breast cancer. Paget's disease of the bone is a chronic, non-cancerous bone disorder. Having one does not put you at risk for the other.

faqs.question: My mammogram and ultrasound were both normal, but the biopsy of my nipple skin was Paget's. How is this possible?
faqs.answer: This is a common and important scenario. In many cases (up to 50%), the Paget's disease is associated with an underlying in situ cancer (DCIS) that is not a lump and may be too small or scattered to be seen on a mammogram or ultrasound. The cancer cells are present in the milk ducts, but haven't formed a distinct mass. A breast MRI is often ordered in this situation to get a better look at the extent of the disease.

faqs.question: If the cancer is just on the nipple, why is my surgeon talking about a mastectomy? Can't they just remove the nipple?
faqs.answer: The cancer on the nipple is just the tip of the iceberg. The Paget's cells have migrated from a cancer inside the milk ducts. If that underlying cancer (DCIS or invasive) is widespread throughout the ducts, a mastectomy is often the safest option. If the underlying cancer is found to be very small and contained, a central lumpectomy (removing the nipple, areola, and the ducts just behind them) followed by radiation may be an option.

faqs.question: I was diagnosed with Paget's disease, and they also found an invasive tumor. Does this make my prognosis worse?
faqs.answer: The prognosis is determined almost entirely by the underlying breast cancer, not the Paget's disease on the skin (which is just a sign). If the underlying cancer is just DCIS (non-invasive), the prognosis is excellent. If there is also an invasive tumor (meaning it has broken out of the duct), the prognosis and treatment will be based on the size, grade, and node status of that invasive cancer, just like any other common type of breast cancer.

faqs.question: I was bitten by a stray dog, but the wound is small and the dog ran off. Do I really need to get the rabies shots? What's the risk?
faqs.answer: Yes, you absolutely must be evaluated for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Rabies is 99.9% fatal once symptoms begin; there is no treatment at that point. The risk is not worth taking. Because the dog is stray and cannot be observed for 10 days to see if it's healthy, you must assume it could have been rabid. The PEP shots are a life-saving prevention that must be given before symptoms start.

faqs.question: I'm terrified of the rabies shots. I've heard it's a series of 20 painful shots in the stomach. Is that still true?
faqs.answer: This is a very common myth, and it is completely false today. The old-fashioned stomach shots haven't been used in decades. The modern rabies post-exposure treatment is: 1) Rabies Immune Globulin (RIG): This is a one-time dose of antibodies, and some of it is infiltrated around the wound (this is the only part that can be uncomfortable). 2) The Rabies Vaccine: This is a series of four (or five for immunocompromised) simple shots, just like a flu shot, given in your arm (deltoid muscle) over two weeks (on days 0, 3, 7, and 14). It is very safe and not unusually painful.

faqs.question: I woke up and found a bat flying in my bedroom. I don't think it bit me, but my doctor is strongly recommending I get the full shots. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a standard, critical public health recommendation. Bat bites (and scratches) are tiny and can be almost invisible (like a pinprick), and they can happen while you are asleep without waking you up. Because a bat in a room with a sleeping person is a high-risk exposure and rabies is 100% fatal, the recommendation is always to get the full post-exposure prophylaxis.

faqs.question: What actually happens if I get rabies? Why can't they just treat it once the symptoms start?
faqs.answer: Once symptoms begin (like fever, tingling at the bite, then anxiety, agitation, and hydrophobia - fear of water/swallowing), the rabies virus has already traveled from the bite, up the nerves, and into the brain. At this point, it causes a severe, irreversible, and fatal inflammation of the brain (encephalitis). There is no cure or effective treatment. The post-exposure shots only work before the virus reaches the brain, by training your immune system to intercept and kill it.

faqs.question: I was bitten by my neighbor's cat. Do I need the shots? My neighbor says the cat is fine and up-to-date on its shots.
faqs.answer: This is a different scenario. If the pet is a domestic dog, cat, or ferret, and the owner can provide proof of current vaccination, you are generally considered safe. If the vaccination status is unknown, the pet must be quarantined and observed by animal control for 10 days. If the animal remains healthy for those 10 days, it proves it could not have had rabies at the time of the bite, and you do not need the shots. If it gets sick, it is tested, and you would start the shots.

faqs.question: I got hit in my left side playing football. I felt okay, but now hours later, my belly is tender and I have a bizarre, sharp pain in my left shoulder. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is a medical emergency. The combination of a blow to the left side and delayed-onset referred pain in the left shoulder is the classic Kehr's sign for a ruptured spleen. The spleen is bleeding into your abdomen, and the blood is irritating the phrenic nerve, which shares a pathway with nerves in your shoulder. You need to go to an ER immediately for a CT scan.

faqs.question: My son has mono (mononucleosis), and the doctor said no contact sports for a month because his spleen could rupture. How can a virus make an organ rupture?
faqs.answer: The virus that causes mono (EBV) infects the spleen and causes it to become significantly enlarged and spongy (a condition called splenomegaly). This large, fragile spleen is extremely vulnerable to rupture, even from minor trauma (like a tackle) or even just forceful tensing of the abdominal muscles. This is the #1 cause of non-traumatic spleen rupture.

faqs.question: The ER doctor said my spleen has a Grade 2 rupture and they want to observe me in the hospital. Isn't that dangerous? Shouldn't they take it out right away?
faqs.answer: This is now the standard of care for low-grade (Grades 1-3) spleen ruptures in patients who are hemodynamically stable (i.e., your blood pressure is good and you're not bleeding out). It's called non-operative management. Removing the spleen (splenectomy) is a last resort. Your spleen is a vital immune organ, so doctors will do everything they can to let it heal on its own with strict bed rest, IV fluids, and constant monitoring. Surgery is only for very severe ruptures or unstable patients.

faqs.question: If they do have to remove my spleen (splenectomy), what does that mean for my life? Can I live normally without it?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can live a completely normal, active life without your spleen. However, you will be considered immunocompromised. The spleen is your body's main filter for a specific type of encapsulated bacteria. Without it, you are at a small but lifelong, serious risk of a rapid, overwhelming infection called overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI).

faqs.question: I'm going to have my spleen removed. Why am I being told I need a bunch of new vaccines before the surgery?
faqs.answer: This is to protect you from OPSI. Before your spleen is removed (if it's a planned surgery) or as soon as possible after (if it's an emergency), you must be vaccinated against the most common encapsulated bacteria. This includes the vaccines for: Pneumococcus (e.g., Prevnar 20), Meningococcus (MenACWY and MenB), and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). You will also need to be vigilant about getting a flu shot every year.

faqs.question: I had a terrible ear infection, then I felt a pop, fluid drained out, and the pain suddenly got better. Did my eardrum burst?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic sequence of events. The infection (otitis media) caused pus and pressure to build up behind your eardrum. The pressure became so great that it tore a small hole in the eardrum, which is the pop. The fluid (pus) then drained out, which is why the pressure and pain were immediately relieved. This is called a spontaneous perforation.

faqs.question: I was slapped hard on the side of my head, and now my ear feels full, my hearing is muffled, and I have ringing (tinnitus). Is my eardrum ruptured?
faqs.answer: It is highly likely. This is a traumatic perforation. The sudden, intense air pressure from the slap (or from an explosion, or scuba diving) can tear the eardrum. The muffled hearing and full feeling are because the eardrum can no longer vibrate properly to transmit sound. You need to see a doctor (ENT) to confirm the diagnosis and check for any other damage.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a hole in my eardrum. Will it heal on its own, or am I going to need surgery?
faqs.answer: The vast majority (over 90%) of small-to-medium sized traumatic perforations will heal completely on their own within a few weeks to a few months. Your doctor will likely just monitor it. Surgery (a tympanoplasty or myringoplasty) is usually only for very large perforations, or for holes that fail to heal after several months, or for holes caused by chronic infections.

faqs.question: What are the rules while it's healing? Can I swim? Why do I have to be so careful about getting water in my ear?
faqs.answer: The most important rule is keep the ear completely dry. Your eardrum is the barrier that protects your middle ear (the space behind it) from the outside world. With a hole, water, soap, and bacteria can get directly into this sterile space, causing a severe middle ear infection. You must not swim, and you must use a cotton ball with Vaseline or an earplug when showering.

faqs.question: Is it safe for me to fly on a plane with a ruptured eardrum?
faqs.answer: This is one of the few perks of a perforated eardrum. It is perfectly safe to fly. Normally, people have to pop their ears to equalize the pressure between the middle ear and the airplane cabin. Since you have a hole in your eardrum, the pressure is already equalized. You won't feel any ear pain or pressure at all. (In contrast, flying with an ear infection but no perforation is extremely painful and dangerous).

faqs.question: Shortly after every meal, my food effortlessly comes back up into my mouth. It's not acidic or forceful like vomiting. I just re-chew and re-swallow it. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the textbook description of rumination syndrome. It is a behavioral disorder where there is an effortless, non-acidic, and repetitive regurgitation of recently eaten food back into the mouth. It's caused by an involuntary (but learned) contraction of the abdominal muscles, which squeezes the stomach and pushes food back up. It is not vomiting and not acid reflux.

faqs.question: My doctor keeps treating me for acid reflux (GERD), but the PPI meds (like omeprazole) do absolutely nothing. How is rumination different?
faqs.answer: This is a very common misdiagnosis. GERD is a plumbing problem where acid from the stomach leaks up due to a weak valve, often causing heartburn. Rumination is a pressure problem—it's an active (though unconscious) abdominal muscle squeeze that pushes food up. Acid blockers fail because acid isn't the problem. The regurgitated food in rumination often tastes the same as when it was first eaten, not sour or bitter.

faqs.question: Is this a psychological problem? It feels totally physical and out of my control.
faqs.answer: It's best described as a neuro-gastrointestinal or behavioral disorder. It's a learned physical reflex that has become an unconscious habit. While it can be associated with stress or anxiety, it is not considered a primary psychological disorder. The treatment is physical and behavioral, not psychiatric medication.

faqs.question: How do you even treat this? My GI doctor referred me to a behavioral therapist, which seems weird.
faqs.answer: The treatment is highly specific and effective, but it is not a pill. It's a form of behavioral therapy, and the most important technique is diaphragmatic breathing (belly breathing). The therapist will teach you to do this immediately after you swallow. You cannot physically ruminate (squeeze your abs in) at the same time you are doing diaphragmatic breathing (pushing your belly out). It's a competing maneuver that retrains your body and breaks the learned reflex.

faqs.question: Can this cause any real damage, like bad breath or tooth decay, or is it just an embarrassing habit?
faqs.answer: While the food itself isn't as acidic as vomit, it does contain some stomach acid. Over time, this can lead to dental erosion (tooth decay), bad breath (halitosis), and, if severe, can cause weight loss and nutritional deficiencies. It's more than just an embarrassing habit and should be treated.

faqs.question: I'm pregnant and was just exposed to someone with rubella. I think I had the MMR vaccine as a kid. What should I do?
faqs.answer: You need to call your obstetrician immediately. They will order a rubella titer, which is a blood test to confirm that you are immune (i.e., that your childhood vaccine is still working). If you are immune, you and your baby are safe. If the test shows you are not immune, this is a very serious situation, as rubella can cause Congenital Rubella Syndrome.

faqs.question: What is Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS)? Why is it so dangerous?
faqs.answer: CRS is what happens when a non-immune pregnant woman gets infected with rubella, especially in the first trimester. The virus crosses the placenta and infects the fetus, causing devastating, permanent birth defects. The classic triad of defects is deafness, cataracts (leading to blindness), and cardiac (heart) defects. It can also cause intellectual disability and other problems.

faqs.question: I've heard rubella called 3-day measles. Is it just a mild version of regular measles?
faqs.answer: No, they are completely different viruses. Rubella (or German measles) is typically a much milder illness than regular measles (rubeola). It causes a mild fever, a faint red rash, and swollen lymph nodes (especially behind the ears). It's called 3-day measles because the rash often fades after just a few days. Its only real danger is to an unborn fetus.

faqs.question: My blood test shows I'm non-immune to rubella. Can I get the MMR vaccine during my pregnancy to protect my baby?
faqs.answer: No, you absolutely cannot. The MMR vaccine is a live-virus vaccine. This means it contains a weakened, but still living, version of the virus. There is a theoretical (though small) risk that the vaccine virus itself could infect the fetus. You must wait and get the vaccine immediately after you give birth (it's safe with breastfeeding) to protect your future pregnancies.

faqs.question: If rubella is so mild, why do we still vaccinate all kids for it?
faqs.answer: We vaccinate for herd immunity to protect pregnant women. The vaccinated child is not really being protected from a dangerous illness (for them), they are being made part of a protective bubble that stops the virus from circulating in the community, thereby preventing it from ever finding a non-immune pregnant woman.

faqs.question: My 1-year-old has explosive, watery diarrhea (like 10 times a day) and is vomiting. Is this rotavirus?
faqs.answer: It is very likely. Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe, dehydrating gastroenteritis (stomach flu) in infants and young children. The hallmark is the sudden onset of profuse, watery diarrhea (often pale and with a distinct, foul smell) and vomiting. The main danger is not the virus itself, but the dehydration it causes, which can be life-threatening in small children.

faqs.question: My baby got the rotavirus vaccine, but he still got sick. Does this mean the vaccine didn't work?
faqs.answer: No, it means the vaccine is working as intended. The rotavirus vaccine (which is an oral, liquid vaccine) is not designed to prevent all infection. It is designed to prevent severe infection. A vaccinated child might still get a mild-to-moderate case of rotavirus, but the vaccine is highly effective (over 90%) at preventing the severe, dehydrating diarrhea that would land a child in the hospital on an IV.

faqs.question: What's the treatment? Can I give my child Imodium or antibiotics?
faqs.answer: Absolutely no antibiotics—this is a virus. You should also never give anti-diarrheal medicines (like Imodium) to an infant, as it can be dangerous. The only treatment is supportive care, which means fluid management. You must prevent dehydration. Give small, frequent sips of an oral rehydration solution (like Pedialyte). Avoid juice and sugary drinks, which can make diarrhea worse.

faqs.question: How do I know if my baby is dehydrated? What are the ER warning signs?
faqs.answer: The warning signs of dangerous dehydration are: 1) No wet diapers for 6-8 hours, 2) Crying with no tears, 3) A sunken soft spot (fontanelle) on the head, 4) A dry, tacky mouth and tongue, and 5) Extreme sleepiness or floppiness (lethargy). These are signs that you need to go to the emergency room immediately for IV fluids.

faqs.question: I've heard the vaccine has a rare risk of intussusception. What is that? Is it safe?
faqs.answer: This is a known, but very rare, risk (about 1 in 20,000 to 1 in 100,000 doses). Intussusception is a serious condition where one part of the intestine telescopes into another, causing a blockage. There is a small window of increased risk in the week after the first dose. Despite this, every major medical body in the world agrees that the benefit of the vaccine (preventing thousands of hospitalizations and deaths from dehydration) far outweighs this very small risk.

faqs.question: I have this deep, dull ache in my shoulder. It's worst at night—I can't sleep on that side. It also hurts when I try to lift my arm to the side. Is this my rotator cuff?
faqs.answer: This is the classic, textbook presentation of a rotator cuff tendinopathy or tear. The night pain (especially when lying on the affected shoulder) and painful arc (pain when lifting your arm between 60 and 120 degrees) are hallmark symptoms. The rotator cuff is a group of four tendons that stabilize your shoulder, and they are likely inflamed or partially torn.

faqs.question: Did I tear this from one big injury, or from my job (painting/construction)?
faqs.answer: It can be either. A traumatic tear is from a specific event, like falling hard on an outstretched arm. More commonly, it's a degenerative tear, which is an overuse injury that happens slowly over time. This is very common in jobs or sports that require a lot of overhead activity (like painting, swimming, or baseball), which repeatedly pinches and frays the tendons.

faqs.question: My MRI shows a partial tear. Does this mean I'm going to need surgery?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. In fact, most partial-thickness tears and full-thickness tears in older, less-active patients are treated without surgery first. The best treatment is a dedicated course of physical therapy. This doesn't heal the tear, but it strengthens the surrounding muscles (like your deltoid and scapular stabilizers) to compensate for the torn tendon, which reduces pain and restores function.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a rotator cuff tear and a bursitis or impingement?
faqs.answer: These are all related and often happen together. Impingement is the mechanism: the space in your shoulder is narrow, and the rotator cuff tendon and bursa (a fluid-filled sac) get pinched by the bone above them. Bursitis is the result of this pinching—the bursa sac becomes inflamed. A Tear is the long-term consequence: if the tendon is pinched (impinged) for long enough, it frays and eventually tears, like a rope.

faqs.question: When is surgery (arthroscopic repair) necessary?
faqs.answer: Surgery is usually reserved for: 1) Acute, large traumatic tears in younger, active patients. 2) Full-thickness tears in active patients who want to return to overhead sports. 3) Anyone (with a partial or full tear) who has failed at least 3-6 months of high-quality physical therapy and still has disabling pain and weakness.

faqs.question: My baby had a very high fever (103°F) for 3 days, but she was happy and playful. Now the fever is gone, and she's covered in a pink rash. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic, textbook case of roseola (also called sixth disease). It's caused by a very common virus (herpesvirus 6). The hallmark is a high fever for 3-5 days, often in a child who seems unusually well or only mildly fussy. The moment the fever breaks, the characteristic lacy pink rash appears, starting on the trunk and spreading to the neck and arms. The rash is not itchy and is a sign that the illness is over.

faqs.question: How can she be so happy with such a high fever? It was terrifying.
faqs.answer: This fever-rash disconnect is the key diagnostic clue for roseola. While any high fever needs to be evaluated (especially a first one), doctors are often reassured when a parent says, The fever was 104, but she was still crawling around and playing. In contrast, a child with the flu or bacterial infection with that high of a fever is usually limp, ill, and miserable.

faqs.question: My child had a febrile seizure when his fever spiked. The ER doctor said it was from the roseola. Will this happen again? Does he have epilepsy?
faqs.answer: This is very scary, but common. Roseola is the #1 cause of febrile seizures (seizures caused by a rapid spike in temperature) in infants 6-18 months old. This does not mean your child has epilepsy. Simple febrile seizures are not dangerous, do not cause brain damage, and the vast majority of children outgrow them. However, you should always follow up with your pediatrician.

faqs.question: How is this treated? Is there a medicine for it?
faqs.answer: No, there is no medicine for the virus. The treatment is just supportive care for the fever. You can use fever-reducers like acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Motrin, if over 6 months) to keep your child comfortable. The rash requires no treatment at all and will fade on its own in 1-2 days.

faqs.question: When is my child contagious? Now that she has the rash?
faqs.answer: No. This is the tricky part. The child is contagious during the fever phase, before anyone knows it's roseola. By the time the characteristic rash appears (and the fever is gone), the child is typically no longer contagious and is fine to return to daycare.

faqs.question: I don't have acne, but my face (cheeks, nose) is always flushing bright red, especially when I drink wine or eat spicy food. Is this rosacea?
faqs.answer: This sounds exactly like neurovascular or erythematotelangiectatic rosacea. The hallmark is the flushing and blushing in response to common triggers (like alcohol, sunlight, spicy food, stress, or heat). This is not an allergy, but an over-reactivity of the blood vessels in your facial skin. Over time, this flushing can lead to persistent, fixed redness and broken capillaries (telangiectasias).

faqs.question: I'm developing little red pimples and bumps on my cheeks and nose, but they're not blackheads. My doctor called it papulopustular rosacea. How is this different from acne?
faqs.answer: This is the inflammatory type of rosacea. It looks like acne, but there's a key difference: rosacea does not have comedones (the blackheads and whiteheads that are the starting point for acne). The bumps are purely inflammatory (papules and pustules) and are centered on the blush areas of your face.

faqs.question: My 60-year-old father's nose has become thick, red, and bumpy. He says it's from drinking, but is it rosacea?
faqs.answer: This is a form of advanced rosacea called phymatous rosacea or rhinophyma. It is not caused by drinking, although alcohol can trigger flushing and make it worse (this is a major, unfair stigma). It's caused by a severe, long-term inflammation of the oil glands, which leads to this overgrowth or thickening of the skin, most commonly on the nose. It's almost exclusive to men.

faqs.question: My eyes are always gritty, dry, and red, and my eyelids get crusty. My eye doctor said it might be ocular rosacea. How can this affect my eyes?
faqs.answer: This is a very common (over 50% of patients) but often-missed part of the disease. The same inflammation that affects your skin can also affect the meibomian (oil) glands in your eyelids. This leads to a blepharitis (eyelid inflammation) and dry eye that feels gritty, watery, and light-sensitive. In some people, the eye symptoms are the only or first sign of rosacea.

faqs.question: What's the best treatment? My doctor gave me a cream (metronidazole) and a sulfur wash. How do these work?
faqs.answer: Treatment depends on the type. For inflammatory (pimple) rosacea, topical medications like metronidazole, azelaic acid, or ivermectin (Soolantra) are used to calm the inflammation (they are not antibiotics in this case). Sulfur washes also have anti-inflammatory properties. For the flushing and redness, the best treatments are often procedural—like V-beam or BBL lasers, which specifically target and destroy the broken blood vessels. Identifying and avoiding your personal triggers is also a key part of management.

faqs.question: My child has a round, scaly bald spot on his head, and the hairs look broken off at the surface. Is this ringworm?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of tinea capitis, or ringworm of the scalp. The ringworm name is a misnomer—there is no worm. It is a fungal infection of the hair and skin. The fungus (dermatophyte) invades the hair shaft, making it brittle and causing it to break off, which creates the scaly, black dot bald patch. It's very common in children.

faqs.question: Why won't the anti-fungal cream I bought (like for athlete's foot) work on his scalp?
faqs.answer: This is a critical point. Ringworm on the body (tinea corporis) lives on the skin, so creams work. Ringworm on the scalp (tinea capitis) lives deep inside the hair follicle. Creams cannot penetrate that deep. Scalp ringworm must be treated with an oral, prescription anti-fungal medicine (like griseofulvin or terbinafine) that is taken for 6-8 weeks, along with an anti-fungal shampoo (like ketoconazole) to reduce shedding.

faqs.question: My son's scalp has become a big, boggy, oozing, inflamed lump. The doctor called it a kerion. What is that?
faqs.answer: A kerion is an intense inflammatory reaction to the fungal infection. It's not a bacterial infection (though it can get one); it's your body's own immune system over-reacting to the fungus. It's a very good sign that your body is fighting the infection, but it can be painful and often needs to be treated with a short course of oral steroids (like prednisone) to calm the inflammation and prevent permanent, scarring hair loss.

faqs.question: How did my child get this? And can my other kids get it?
faqs.answer: It is highly contagious. It's spread by fomites—inanimate objects. The most common way to get it is by sharing contaminated objects like combs, brushes, hats, pillows, or hair clippers. You should wash all bedding in hot water and soak all hair-care items in bleach or replace them. All other household members (especially other children) should be checked by a doctor, as they can be asymptomatic carriers.

faqs.question: I have this very itchy, ring-shaped rash. It's clear in the middle and scaly on the active red border. Is this really a worm?
faqs.answer: No, it is not a worm. This is tinea corporis, a fungal infection of the top layer of your skin. It's caused by the same type of fungus (dermatophyte) that causes athlete's foot and jock itch. It gets the ringworm name because it often (but not always) grows outwards in a ring, leaving clear skin in the center as the active (scaly, red, itchy) border expands.

faqs.question: I've been using an over-the-counter anti-fungal cream (like clotrimazole) for a week, and it's not better. Am I using the wrong thing?
faqs.answer: This is common. First, you need to use it for long enough. You must continue to apply the cream twice a day for at least 1-2 weeks after the rash has completely disappeared, to kill any remaining spores. A common mistake is to stop as soon as it looks better. Second, if it's still not working, it may be a more resistant fungus, and you may need a prescription-strength topical or even an oral anti-fungal pill.

faqs.question: I put hydrocortisone cream on it, and the rash got worse and spread. Why?
faqs.answer: This is a classic mistake. Hydrocortisone is a steroid, which suppresses your skin's immune system. While it might temporarily make the itch feel better, you are turning off your body's ability to fight the fungus. This allows the fungus to grow wild, making the rash much larger, less ring-shaped, and harder to treat. This is sometimes called tinea incognito.

faqs.question: How did I even get this? I'm very clean. Can I get it from my cat?
faqs.answer: Yes. Pets are a very common source, especially cats and kittens (which can be carriers without showing symptoms). It's also spread from human to human (common in wrestlers, tinea gladiatorum) or from damp surfaces (like a locker room floor, which is how you get athlete's foot, tinea pedis). You can then auto-infect your body by, for example, drying your feet and then your body with the same towel.

faqs.question: My toddler's legs are starting to bow outwards. My mother-in-law said it's rickets. I thought that was a disease from old books?
faqs.answer: Rickets is making a comeback, and bowed legs (or knock-knees) are the most visible sign. Rickets is a condition of soft bones in children. It's caused by a severe deficiency in Vitamin D. Vitamin D is essential for your body to absorb calcium from food. Without Vitamin D, the bones don't mineralize properly, and the growth plates (the ends of the bones) become soft, weak, and frayed. The bowing is the leg bones bending under the child's own weight.

faqs.question: How can my child be Vitamin D deficient? I thought breast is best?
faqs.answer: This is a key point: breast milk is the perfect food, but it contains almost no Vitamin D. The old-fashioned way babies got Vitamin D was from sunlight. In modern life (with sunscreen and less outdoor time), this doesn't happen. This is why the American Academy of Pediatrics insists that all exclusively breastfed babies MUST receive supplemental Vitamin D drops (400 IU/day) from the first few days of life.

faqs.question: Besides the bowed legs, what are other signs? My doctor looked at my baby's wrists.
faqs.answer: Because the growth plates are soft and flared, doctors can see and feel widening at the fastest-growing bones. This includes the wrists and the costochondral junctions on the ribs. This creates a line of beads or knots down the chest, known as the rachitic rosary. Other signs are a soft skull (craniotabes) and delayed closing of the soft spot (fontanelle).

faqs.question: Is this permanent? If we start Vitamin D now, will my child's legs straighten out?
faqs.answer: The good news is that nutritional rickets is 100% reversible and curable with high-dose Vitamin D and calcium supplementation. Once the soft growth plates are given the minerals they need, they will harden (re-mineralize), and in most cases, the bowed legs will straighten out completely on their own as the child grows. Surgery is only for very severe, persistent deformities.

faqs.question: I have terrible joint stiffness, but it's worst when I wake up. It takes me an hour to get going. Is this different from regular arthritis (osteoarthritis)?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a key difference. Morning stiffness that lasts for more than 30-60 minutes is a classic sign of inflammatory arthritis, like RA. In contrast, regular osteoarthritis (OA) is a wear and tear disease. OA stiffness is worst after activity (at the end of the day) or is very brief (less than 15 minutes) in the morning.

faqs.question: The pain is in my hands and wrists, and it's symmetrical—it affects the same joints on both my left and right sides. Why is that?
faqs.answer: This symmetric pattern is another hallmark of RA. RA is an autoimmune disease, meaning your entire immune system is attacking your joint linings (the synovium) throughout your body. This systemic attack is why the inflammation shows up in the same joints (like the knuckles, wrists, and feet) on both sides of the body at the same time.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to start a biologic drug (like Humira or Enbrel). The commercials about infection risk are scary. Why can't I just take Advil?
faqs.answer: Advil (an NSAID) is just a painkiller—it masks the pain but does nothing to stop the disease. RA is a destructive disease. The inflammation is actively eroding and destroying your bone and cartilage. You must take a DMARD (Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drug) like methotrexate, or a biologic, which turns down your immune system to stop the destruction. The goal is remission. The risk of a disabled, destroyed joint from untreated RA is far higher than the (small, manageable) risk of infection from the drugs.

faqs.question: My blood test for Rheumatoid Factor (RF) was negative, but my doctor is still diagnosing me with RA. How is that possible?
faqs.answer: This is called seronegative RA, and it's very common (about 20-30% of patients). You can have all the classic symptoms of RA (symmetrical, inflammatory joint pain, morning stiffness) but have negative bloodwork (a normal RF and anti-CCP). The diagnosis is clinical—it's based on the pattern of your symptoms and what the doctor finds on your joint exam. The treatment is exactly the same.

faqs.question: Besides my joints, I am exhausted all the time and have these firm lumps on my elbows. Are these symptoms related to RA?
faqs.answer: Yes. The profound, flu-like fatigue is a major symptom of the systemic inflammation. The firm lumps are called rheumatoid nodules. They are harmless, non-painful lumps of inflammatory tissue that form under the skin, usually over pressure points like the elbow or back of the heel. They are a classic sign of RA.

faqs.question: My child had a bad strep throat a few weeks ago, and now he has a fever and his knees and elbows are swollen and painful. What is going on?
faqs.answer: You need to see a doctor immediately. This is the classic presentation of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). ARF is an autoimmune reaction that can happen 2-4 weeks after an untreated (or poorly treated) Group A strep throat infection. The main symptom is a migratory polyarthritis—pain and swelling that jumps from one large joint (like the knees) to another (like the elbows).

faqs.question: Why is the doctor listening so carefully to his heart? The problem is his joints.
faqs.answer: The joint pain is painful, but temporary. The real danger of rheumatic fever is carditis—inflammation of the heart, especially the heart valves. The immune system, in its attempt to fight the strep, mistakes the heart valve tissue for the strep bacteria and attacks it. This can cause permanent, lifelong scarring and damage to the valves (Rheumatic Heart Disease).

faqs.question: What's the treatment? My doctor said he needs penicillin even though his strep test is negative now.
faqs.answer: The treatment has two parts. First, he will get a high-dose anti-inflammatory (like aspirin or naproxen) to calm down the joint pain and inflammation. Second, he must get a shot of long-acting penicillin (or 10 days of pills). Even though the strep test is negative, the goal is to kill any lingering strep bacteria that are still stoking the fire of the immune reaction.

faqs.question: The doctor said my son has to have a penicillin shot every month until he's 21. This sounds crazy. Why?
faqs.answer: This is called secondary prophylaxis, and it is the most important part of the treatment. Once a person has had rheumatic fever, their immune system is primed. If they get another strep throat, they have a very high risk (50%) of getting another, more severe attack of ARF, which will do more damage to their heart. The monthly penicillin shot prevents them from ever getting strep throat again, which in turn protects their heart from future damage.

faqs.question: My 4-year-old has a strange, grape-like mass coming out of her vagina. Her doctor said it might be sarcoma botryoides. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is a very specific, rare subtype of rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS). Sarcoma botryoides literally means a sarcoma that looks like a bunch of grapes. It is a tumor of primitive muscle cells (a soft-tissue sarcoma) that grows in hollow, mucosal-lined organs, and in little girls, this is most commonly the vagina. It needs to be biopsied immediately.

faqs.question: My teenage son has a painless, growing lump on his arm, and the doctor said rhabdomyosarcoma. I thought this was a baby cancer?
faqs.answer: Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft-tissue cancer in children, but it has two main types that are very different. The embryonal type (like the sarcoma botryoides) is most common in young children. The alveolar type is more common in adolescents and young adults. It is a more aggressive tumor that often appears in the large muscles of the arms, legs, or trunk.

faqs.question: My child's RMS is in his head (parameningeal). Why is this location considered so high-risk?
faqs.answer: A parameningeal location (like in the sinuses, near the ear, or at the base of the skull) is high-risk because the tumor can directly invade the meninges—the lining of the brain and spinal cord. This means the cancer cells can get into the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and spread. This requires a much more aggressive treatment plan, including radiation to the head and often chemotherapy injected directly into the spinal fluid (intrathecal chemo).

faqs.question: The treatment plan (chemo, radiation, AND surgery) seems so aggressive. Is all of that really necessary?
faqs.answer: Yes. RMS is an aggressive cancer, and multi-modal therapy is the standard of care. It is highly sensitive to chemotherapy, so chemo is the first step to shrink the tumor. Then, surgery is done to remove as much of the remaining tumor as possible. Finally, radiation is used to clean up any microscopic cancer cells left behind in the tumor bed. This combination gives the absolute best chance for a cure.

faqs.question: I've seen the warning on baby aspirin: Do not give to children with a fever. Why? What is Reye's syndrome?
faqs.answer: Reye's syndrome is a rare but extremely dangerous (life-threatening) condition that causes sudden brain swelling (encephalopathy) and severe liver failure. It almost exclusively occurs in children who are recovering from a viral illness (especially influenza or chickenpox) and who were given aspirin (or any salicylate-containing product, like Pepto-Bismol).

faqs.question: How can aspirin and a virus interact to cause something so terrible?
faqs.answer: The exact mechanism is still unknown, but it's thought that the virus (especially the flu) primes the body's mitochondria (the power plants inside cells). The aspirin, in this primed state, then acts like a toxin that shuts down the mitochondria, especially in the liver. This causes the liver to fail, which floods the body (and brain) with ammonia, leading to the brain swelling, seizures, and coma.

faqs.question: What are the warning signs? My child had the flu, and now he's vomiting constantly and is really confused.
faqs.answer: This is an emergency. The key sign is a change in the illness. The child seems to be recovering from the flu/cold, and then suddenly starts persistent, non-stop vomiting. This is quickly followed by neurological changes: brain fog, irrational behavior, delirium, confusion, or extreme lethargy (progressing to seizures or a coma). You must go to an ER immediately and tell them you are worried about Reye's syndrome.

faqs.question: Is this still a problem? I never hear about it anymore.
faqs.answer: No, Reye's syndrome is now incredibly rare, because the public health campaigns (starting in the 1980s) to never give aspirin to kids were so successful. It is a disease of medical history for the most part, but it's still a risk if people are unaware and give aspirin to a child with a virus. This is why all pediatricians recommend only acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Motrin) for fever in children.

faqs.question: My baby girl was developing perfectly—crawling, starting to talk—and then around 18 months, she stopped and started losing her skills. She won't use her hands anymore. What is happening?
faqs.answer: This is the devastating and classic presentation of Rett syndrome. It is a neurodevelopmental regression disorder. It almost exclusively affects girls, who have a period of (seemingly) normal development for the first 6-18 months, followed by a stagnation and then a regression where they lose their purposeful hand skills (like

faqs.question: Now my daughter is constantly wringing her hands or clapping them. She does it all the time. Is this part of it?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the single most recognizable hallmark sign of Rett syndrome. The loss of purposeful hand use (like picking up a toy) is replaced by a stereotypy—a repetitive, purposeless hand movement. This is most commonly hand-wringing, hand-washing, clapping, or mouthing (putting hands in the mouth).

faqs.question: My doctor said this is a genetic disorder (MECP2). Does that mean I gave it to her? Is my next child at risk?
faqs.answer: This is a critical, and often misunderstood, point. Rett syndrome is caused by a genetic mutation (in the MECP2 gene), but in over 99% of cases, it is a de novo or sporadic mutation. This means the mutation happened randomly in that one sperm or egg cell. It was not inherited from you. The recurrence risk (the chance of it happening in your next pregnancy) is extremely low, less than 1%.

faqs.question: Will she ever walk or talk again? What is the prognosis?
faqs.answer: Rett syndrome is a lifelong, severe disability. Most girls will lose their verbal skills and will not regain speech (though many can learn to communicate with eye-gaze devices). Many girls do learn to walk, but their gait is often stiff and apraxic (unsteady and poorly coordinated), and many lose this ability later in life. The focus of therapy is not on regaining skills, but on maintaining mobility, managing complications (like scoliosis and seizures), and maximizing quality of life.

faqs.question: My partner and I are trying to conceive. I'm having orgasms, but almost no semen (or none at all) comes out. My urine looks cloudy afterward. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of retrograde ejaculation, or a dry orgasm. It's an issue where the internal sphincter (the muscle at the neck of your bladder) fails to close during orgasm. Because the bladder offers less resistance than the urethra, the semen (which is produced normally) refluxes or shoots backward into the bladder, instead of forward out of the penis. It's not harmful, but it is a major cause of male infertility.

faqs.question: Why is this happening? What causes it?
faqs.answer: The most common causes are all related to nerve damage that controls that bladder neck muscle. This includes: 1) Diabetes (diabetic neuropathy), 2) Medications (especially alpha-blockers like Flomax/tamsulosin, used for an enlarged prostate), and 3) Surgery (especially prostate or pelvic surgeries that have cut those nerves).

faqs.question: Is there a treatment for this? Will I ever be able to ejaculate normally?
faqs.answer: It depends on the cause. If it's from a medication (like Flomax), it's 100% reversible and will stop as soon as you stop the drug. If it's from nerve damage (diabetes, surgery), it's often permanent. However, some oral medications (like pseudoephedrine) can sometimes tighten the bladder neck muscle enough to restore forward ejaculation.

faqs.question: If I can't be cured, does this mean I can never have biological children?
faqs.answer: No. You are still producing normal, healthy sperm; it's just going to the wrong place. A fertility specialist (urologist) can retrieve the sperm from your urine. You will be asked to alkalinize your urine (to make it less toxic to sperm) and then provide a urine sample immediately after ejaculating. The lab can spin down the urine, isolate the healthy sperm, and use it for assisted reproduction (like IUI or IVF).

faqs.question: Sometimes when I check my baby boy's diaper, one testicle is missing. But then at his bath (in the warm water), it's back. What is happening?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of a retractile testicle. It's not an undescended testicle (which is stuck in the groin). Your son's testicle is normal and descended, but he has a very overactive cremaster reflex. This is a muscle that pulls the testicle up toward the body in response to cold, touch, or a startle. The warm bath relaxes the muscle, and the testicle drops back down into its normal position in the scrotum.

faqs.question: Is this dangerous? Does it need to be fixed?
faqs.answer: In most cases, a retractile testicle is considered a normal variant and is not dangerous. It does not affect fertility or hormone production. The vast majority of these will settle down on their own as the boy goes through puberty, as the testicle becomes heavier and the reflex becomes less active.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this and a true undescended testicle?
faqs.answer: A true undescended testicle (cryptorchidism) is a testicle that never made it into the scrotum. It is stuck in the groin or abdomen and cannot be pulled down, even by a doctor. This is a problem that requires surgery (orchiopexy). A retractile testicle can be easily pulled down by a doctor into the scrotum, it just pops back up when they let go.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to monitor it every year. Why? What are they watching for?
faqs.answer: They are watching for one specific complication: an ascending testicle. In a small number of boys, a testicle that was retractile can become stuck in the up position as the boy grows (the string doesn't grow as fast as the boy). It ascends and becomes an acquired undescended testicle. This would require surgery. So, the annual check is to make sure the doctor can still bring it down into the scrotum.

faqs.question: I took a flash photo of my baby, and in all the pictures, one of her eyes has a white pupil (a cat's eye) instead of the normal red-eye. Is this just a bad photo?
faqs.answer: NO. This is a medical emergency. You must see a pediatrician or ophthalmologist immediately. This white reflex (called leukocoria) is the #1 sign of retinoblastoma, which is a cancer of the eye in children. The red-eye is the normal flash-reflecting off the healthy, red retina. The white glow is the flash-reflecting off a tumor that has grown on the retina.

faqs.question: My child's eyes also seem crossed (strabismus). I thought this was a lazy eye, but now the doctor is worried about cancer.
faqs.answer: This is the second most common sign. A lazy eye (strabismus) can be a simple muscle problem, or it can be the brain's way of tuning out the image from an eye that can't see. If a tumor (retinoblastoma) is growing in the center of the vision (the macula), the child can't see out of that eye, and it will drift inwards or outwards.

faqs.question: My child has it in both eyes. The doctor said this is heritable and germline. Does this mean I gave it to him?
faqs.answer: Retinoblastoma in both eyes (bilateral) is always the heritable (genetic) form. This means your child was born with a germline mutation in the RB1 gene. This mutation can be inherited from a parent (who may have had it and not known), or it can be a de novo (new) mutation that happened in the sperm or egg. You need genetic counseling. This also means your child has a lifelong risk of developing other cancers (like bone or soft-tissue sarcomas) later in life.

faqs.question: What's the treatment? Are they going to have to remove my child's eye?
faqs.answer: The goal is Save life, save eye, save vision, in that order. If the tumor is very large and has filled the eye, the safest option to save the life (and prevent spread) is enucleation (removing the eye). However, for smaller tumors, modern eye-sparing treatments are used. This often involves intra-arterial chemotherapy, where a tiny catheter is threaded from the groin all the way to the tiny artery of the eye, delivering a high-dose of chemo only to the eye, sparing the rest of the body.

faqs.question: I have diabetes. My doctor said I need a diabetic eye exam every year, but my vision is perfect. Why?
faqs.answer: This is critical. Diabetic retinopathy is the #1 cause of blindness in working-age adults, and it has zero symptoms in its early, most-treatable stages. High blood sugar slowly damages the tiny blood vessels in your retina, causing them to leak. You will not feel this or see this until it's very advanced. The yearly dilated exam allows the doctor to see these tiny leaks decades before you would notice them, and they can use a laser to seal them and save your vision.

faqs.question: My grandmother has macular degeneration. She says the lines on her grid look wavy or bent. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is the classic, early sign of wet macular degeneration. The macula is the center of your sharp vision. In wet AMD, abnormal, leaky blood vessels grow under the retina. This leaking fluid lifts and warps the retina, which is why a straight line (like on a door frame or an Amsler grid) appears wavy or distorted. This is a vision emergency that requires immediate treatment.

faqs.question: What are these injections my grandfather gets in his eye every month for his wet AMD? It sounds horrific.
faqs.answer: It sounds terrible, but it's a miracle treatment that has saved millions from blindness. He is getting anti-VEGF injections (like Avastin, Lucentis, or Eylea). These drugs stop the leaky, abnormal blood vessels from growing. The needle is tiny (like a hair), the eye is 100% numbed (he feels nothing but pressure), and the injection itself takes less than 5 seconds. This treatment can dry up the retina, restore vision, and must be given repeatedly (often monthly) to keep the leaky vessels at bay.

faqs.question: What's the difference between wet and dry macular degeneration?
faqs.answer: Dry AMD is the most common (90% of cases). It is a slow wear and tear of the retina, where drusen (waste-products) build up, and the retina slowly atrophies or thins. It causes slow vision loss over decades. Wet AMD is the advanced form (10% of cases). It is fast and aggressive. It's when the dry AMD triggers the body to grow the new, leaky blood vessels, which cause sudden distortion and central vision loss. You can only have wet AMD if you had dry AMD first.

faqs.question: All of a sudden, I'm seeing a ton of floaters and brief flashes of light in my peripheral vision. Am I overreacting, or is this an emergency?
faqs.answer: This is a vision emergency. You need to see an ophthalmologist the same day. These flashes (photopsia) and new shower of floaters are the classic symptoms of a posterior vitreous detachment (PVD), which is the jelly in your eye (the vitreous) pulling away from the retina. In 10-15% of cases, when it pulls away, it tears the retina. This retinal tear is the precursor to a full retinal detachment.

faqs.question: It looks like a dark, gray curtain or shadow is slowly coming across the vision in one of my eyes. It doesn't hurt. What should I do?
faqs.answer: This is the classic sign that the retinal tear has now progressed to a retinal detachment. The curtain is the part of your retina that has peeled off the back of your eye, and it is blind in that area. This is a surgical emergency. You need to go to an eye ER immediately. If you wait, the curtain will spread to the center of your vision (the macula), and your chance of recovering your reading vision drops dramatically.

faqs.question: My doctor said I need surgery today. What happens if I wait? Will I go blind?
faqs.answer: Yes. If the curtain (the detachment) has not yet reached your central vision (your macula is on), you need surgery that day to save your central vision. If you wait, and the macula detaches, you will permanently lose your sharp, reading vision. Even if it's repaired later, you will never read normally with that eye again. The curtain is a race against the clock.

faqs.question: Why did this happen? I didn't get hit. My doctor said being very nearsighted (high myopia) is a risk factor. Why?
faqs.answer: This is the #1 risk factor. Being nearsighted means your eyeball is longer or more stretched than normal. This stretching makes your retina thinner and more fragile (like a stretched-out balloon), especially on the edges. This fragile retina is much more prone to developing spontaneous tears and holes, which then lead to a detachment.

faqs.question: My surgeon is talking about injecting a gas bubble (pneumatic retinopexy) and making me stay face-down for a week. How does that fix a detachment?
faqs.answer: The gas bubble acts as an internal splint. The surgeon first freezes or lasers the retinal tear. Then they inject the gas bubble, which floats (gas rises). By positioning your head face-down, the gas bubble rises and presses the detached retina back against the wall of the eye, sealing the tear (like a patch on a tire), and holding it in place long enough for the laser/freezing to create a permanent scar and weld the retina back in place.

faqs.question: At night, when I'm trying to fall asleep, I get this horrible, creepy-crawly feeling deep in my legs. It's not painful, just an irresistible urge to move. Is this RLS?
faqs.answer: This is the perfect, classic description of RLS. The four key features are: 1) An urge to move the legs (often with a creepy-crawly or soda-fizzing feeling), 2) It starts or gets worse with rest (like sitting on a couch or lying in bed), 3) It is relieved by movement (like stretching or getting up to walk), and 4) It is worse at night. If you have these four, you have RLS.

faqs.question: My doctor ordered a ferritin level (iron test). How can low iron in my blood affect my legs?
faqs.answer: This is the most common, and most treatable, underlying cause. RLS is a neurological disorder thought to be caused by a dopamine imbalance in the brain. Iron is essential for making dopamine. Even if your hemoglobin (your blood count) is normal, if your storage iron (ferritin) is low (especially under 50-75), your brain can be iron-starved. This disrupts dopamine, which triggers the RLS. Taking an iron supplement is often the first and best treatment.

faqs.question: Is it true that my Benadryl (antihistamine) could be making my RLS worse?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Many common over-the-counter medications are major triggers for RLS. The worst offenders are antihistamines (like Benadryl/diphenhydramine, and PM sleep aids), anti-nausea medicines (like promethazine), and many antidepressants (especially SSRIs like Prozac or Zoloft). These drugs can unmask or worsen RLS.

faqs.question: My RLS is so severe. My doctor mentioned dopamine agonists (like pramipexole). Are these safe?
faqs.answer: These drugs (like Mirapex/pramipexole or Requip/ropinirole) are very effective in the short-term, as they directly mimic dopamine in the brain. However, they are now used with extreme caution. With long-term, nightly use, they have a very high risk of augmentation—a severe, paradoxical worsening of the RLS, where the symptoms start earlier in the day, become more intense, and spread to the arms. They are now second-line drugs after iron and other non-dopamine drugs (like Gabapentin).

faqs.question: My 2-month-old has a bad cold, but he's breathing really fast, and I can see his ribs sucking in with each breath. Is this an emergency?
faqs.answer: YES. This is an emergency. This is the classic sign of bronchiolitis, which in infants is most often caused by RSV. The sucking in (called retractions) and fast breathing (tachypnea) mean the tiny airways in his lungs (the bronchioles) are so swollen and clogged with mucus that he is in respiratory distress and cannot get enough oxygen. You need to go to the ER immediately.

faqs.question: My 4-year-old just has a snotty nose, but my baby is in the hospital. Why is RSV so much more dangerous for infants?
faqs.answer: It's a matter of airway size. In an adult or older child, the airways are wide, so even if they swell, you can still breathe (it's just a cold). In an infant, the bronchioles (the smallest airways) are already the size of a single human hair. Even a tiny bit of swelling and mucus can plug them completely, which is what causes the life-threatening respiratory distress (bronchiolitis).

faqs.question: I'm an adult in my 70s, and my doctor recommended an RSV vaccine. I thought this was a baby disease?
faqs.answer: This is a new and very important development. We now know that RSV is also extremely dangerous for older adults (over 65) and those with chronic lung (COPD) or heart (CHF) disease. In seniors, RSV can cause a severe viral pneumonia that is just as deadly as the flu. The new RSV vaccines (approved in 2023) are specifically for this age group to prevent severe, lower-respiratory tract disease.

faqs.question: Is there a medicine (like Tamiflu for the flu) that can treat RSV, or do we just have to wait it out?
faqs.answer: For almost all patients (babies and adults), there is no antiviral treatment. The treatment is 100% supportive: 1) Oxygen (if levels are low) and 2) Suction (to clear the thick mucus from the nose and airways so the baby can breathe and drink). You just have to support the body until its own immune system fights off the virus, which usually takes 5-7 days.

faqs.question: I'm pregnant. I heard there's a new RSV vaccine for me that can protect my baby? How does that work?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the other major breakthrough (approved in 2023). A new RSV vaccine (Abrysvo) is approved to be given to the mother late in pregnancy (32-36 weeks). This causes your body to create a massive surge of anti-RSV antibodies, which then cross the placenta and get donated to your baby. The baby is then born with a high level of your maternal antibodies, which protects them from severe RSV during their first, most-vulnerable 6 months of life.

faqs.question: I'm having two types of pain: a sharp pain in my stump, and a cramping pain in the foot that's no longer there. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: This is a very common experience. The pain in your stump (your residual limb) is called residual limb pain or stump pain.
