However, a node that stays swollen for more than 4-6 weeks after you're otherwise healthy, or one that is continuing to grow, should be re-evaluated by a doctor. This is considered persistent lymphadenopathy and warrants a closer look.

faqs.question: The swollen node in my armpit is small, soft, and I can move it around. My friend said cancer nodes are hard and stuck in place. Is that true?
faqs.answer: That is a general rule of thumb, but it's not foolproof. Reactive nodes (from infection or inflammation) are typically soft, tender, and mobile (shotty nodes). Nodes that are worrisome for malignancy (like lymphoma or metastatic cancer) are often larger (over 2 cm), very firm or rubbery, non-tender, and fixed (feel stuck to the underlying tissue). However, there is a lot of overlap, and no one can tell for sure just by feeling. Any persistent node needs a medical check.

faqs.question: Why are the lymph nodes in my groin swollen? I don't have an infection there, but I do have a cut on my foot.
faqs.answer: That is the most likely cause. Lymph nodes act as filters for a specific drainage basin in the body. The lymph nodes in your groin (inguinal nodes) filter lymph fluid from your entire leg, foot, and genital area. An infection from a cut on your foot, an ingrown toenail, or even severe athlete's foot will cause the nodes upstream in your groin to swell as they fight the infection.

faqs.question: My doctor said my nodes are just reactive and to wait. What does reactive mean, and why aren't they doing a biopsy?
faqs.answer: Reactive (or reactionary) means the lymph nodes are enlarged because they are doing their job—reacting to something. This is almost always an infection (like a virus, strep throat, or mono) or inflammation. A doctor will recommend waiting because in the vast majority of cases, the node will shrink on its own once the underlying trigger is gone. A biopsy is an invasive procedure and is typically reserved for nodes that are highly suspicious, very large, or persist for many weeks.

faqs.question: Can I have swollen nodes all over my body (neck, armpits, groin) from just a virus?
faqs.answer: Yes. Swollen nodes in two or more unrelated areas of the body is called generalized lymphadenopathy. While this can be a sign of systemic diseases (like lymphoma, leukemia, or advanced cancer), it is also very commonly caused by systemic viral infections. The classic examples are infectious mononucleosis (mono) and HIV. Autoimmune diseases like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis can also cause it.

faqs.question: I woke up with a swollen, stiff knee, but I don't remember injuring it. What could cause that?
faqs.answer: This is called a knee effusion or water on the knee. When it happens without a clear injury, it suggests an underlying inflammatory process. Common causes include an arthritis flare-up (like osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis), gout or pseudogout (crystal deposits), or an infection in the joint. It could also be a delayed reaction to a minor, forgotten tweak or a degenerative tear in your meniscus.

faqs.question: My knee is not just swollen, it's very red, hot to the touch, and I have a fever. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. Go to an emergency department. A swollen, hot, red joint combined with a fever is the classic sign of septic arthritis, which is a serious infection inside the joint space. This is a medical emergency. The infection can rapidly destroy your cartilage and joint. You need immediate evaluation, and doctors will likely need to drain the knee (arthrocentesis) and start strong IV antibiotics.

faqs.question: This is the third time my knee has swollen up after playing basketball. It feels unstable. What am I damaging?
faqs.answer: Recurrent swelling and instability after a specific activity strongly suggest a structural problem inside the knee. The most likely culprits are a torn meniscus (the shock absorber cartilage) or a sprained or torn ligament, like the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Each time it swells, it's a sign of inflammation from this unhealed injury. You need an orthopedic evaluation, likely with an MRI, to see what's damaged.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to drain my knee. Is that procedure painful, and what can they learn from it?
faqs.answer: The procedure is called arthrocentesis. The doctor will numb the area with a local anesthetic, so you'll feel a pinch and some pressure, but it's generally more uncomfortable than severely painful. Draining the fluid can provide immediate pain relief by reducing the pressure. More importantly, the fluid is sent to a lab to be analyzed. They can tell if the swelling is from inflammation, bleeding (from an injury like an ACL tear), crystals (from gout), or infection (from bacteria). It is the single most important diagnostic test for a swollen knee.

faqs.question: How can I get the swelling down at home? Is it better to use ice or heat?
faqs.answer: For acute swelling, ice is the correct choice. Heat (like a heating pad) will increase blood flow and can make swelling and inflammation worse. The best home care is the RICE principle: Rest (stay off the leg), Ice (apply a cold pack for 15-20 minutes every few hours), Compression (use an elastic bandage), and Elevation (prop your leg up on pillows, ideally above the level of your heart).

faqs.question: I went swimming in a fresh water lake, and now I have an intensely itchy, pimply rash just on the parts of my body that were under my swimsuit. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds exactly like swimmer's itch (cercarial dermatitis). It's a rash caused by an allergic reaction to microscopic parasites (larvae called cercariae) that are released from infected snails in fresh or salt water. They burrow into the top layer of your skin by mistake (they are looking for water birds, their natural host) and then die, triggering the allergic, itchy reaction.

faqs.question: My friend swam in the exact same spot at the same time and is totally fine. Why did I get it and they didn't?
faqs.answer: Swimmer's itch is an allergic reaction. Just like some people are allergic to pollen and others aren't, some people are more sensitive to these parasites. It's also possible you were in a slightly different part of the water, or you didn't towel off as vigorously or as quickly as your friend. Toweling off immediately after exiting the water can sometimes rub the parasites off before they have a chance to burrow.

faqs.question: The itching is driving me crazy, especially at night. What's the best way to treat this?
faqs.answer: The rash and itching will go away on their own in about a week as the parasites die and your body clears the reaction, but the itching can be severe. To manage it, you can use over-the-counter corticosteroid creams (like 1% hydrocortisone), apply cool compresses, take colloidal oatmeal baths, or apply calamine lotion. Oral antihistamines (like Benadryl or Claritin) can also help reduce the itch, especially at night.

faqs.question: Is this contagious? Can I spread it to my family by sharing a towel?
faqs.answer: No, it is not contagious at all. The rash is your body's personal allergic reaction to the parasite larvae, which are trapped in your skin and die. They cannot be passed from person to person. You can't give it to anyone, and you can't get it from anyone.

faqs.question: How can I prevent this from happening again? I love swimming in that lake.
faqs.answer: Prevention is key. Avoid swimming in areas known to have swimmer's itch, especially in shallow, warm, marshy areas where snails are common. Towel off briskly and immediately after getting out of the water. Some people find that applying a waterproof sunscreen before swimming can create a barrier that makes it harder for the parasites to penetrate the skin, though this is not a guarantee.

faqs.question: My ear canal is itchy, red, and it really hurts when I pull on my earlobe. Is this swimmer's ear or a regular (middle) ear infection?
faqs.answer: That pain when you pull on the outer ear (the pinna or tragus) is the hallmark sign of swimmer's ear (otitis externa). This is an infection of the skin in the ear canal. A middle ear infection (otitis media) is behind the eardrum and typically doesn't cause pain when the outer ear is wiggled. Swimmer's ear also often has discharge and a full or muffled hearing feeling.

faqs.question: I haven't even been swimming. How did I get swimmer's ear?
faqs.answer: The name is a bit misleading. While it's common from water (which washes away protective earwax and creates a moist environment for bacteria), it can be caused by anything that damages the delicate skin of the ear canal. This includes using Q-tips, scratching an itchy ear, wearing earbuds or hearing aids that irritate the skin, or even getting soap or shampoo in the ear. Any small break in the skin can let bacteria or fungi in.

faqs.question: I get this every time my kids go to the pool. What can I do to prevent it?
faqs.answer: Prevention is all about keeping the ears dry. Have them wear earplugs designed for swimming. Most importantly, after swimming, help them dry their ears by tilting their head to each side and gently pulling the earlobe. You can also use a blow-dryer on the lowest, coolest setting held far from the ear. A few preventative drops of a 50/50 mixture of white vinegar and rubbing alcohol can also help by drying the canal and restoring its normal acidic pH.

faqs.question: My doctor gave me antibiotic eardrops. How am I supposed to get them in if my ear is swollen shut?
faqs.answer: This is a common problem when the infection is severe. If the canal is swollen, the doctor may place a small, compressed sponge called an ear wick inside the canal. You then put the drops onto the outside of the wick. The wick absorbs the drops and transports the medicine deep into the canal, past the swelling. The wick is typically left in for a couple of days and then removed.

faqs.question: The pain is gone, but my ear still feels clogged and my hearing is muffled. Is the infection still there?
faqs.answer: It's very common for the muffled hearing and clogged feeling to last for a few days after the pain stops. The ear canal is likely still swollen, and there is probably a combination of discharge, debris, and the eardrops themselves blocking the canal. It does not necessarily mean the infection is failing treatment. You should complete your full course of antibiotics, and the sensation should resolve. If it doesn't, see your doctor for a follow-up to have the ear cleared.

faqs.question: I found a lump that feels smooth, round, and moves around easily. My doctor said it's probably a fibroadenoma, but I'm still worried. How can they be sure without a biopsy?
faqs.answer: A smooth, mobile lump in a younger woman is classically a benign (non-cancerous) fibroadenoma. An ultrasound is very good at distinguishing these. A fibroadenoma will typically have a distinct, smooth border and a uniform oval shape, which is very different from the irregular, spiky (spiculated) appearance of a typical cancer. If the imaging characteristics are perfectly benign (e.g., BI-RADS 2), a doctor may confidently recommend short-term follow-up (e.g., another ultrasound in 6 months) instead of an immediate biopsy.

faqs.question: My mammogram came back dense, and they found microcalcifications. Does this mean I have cancer?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Dense breasts just means you have more fibrous and glandular tissue, which makes mammograms harder to read. Calcifications are tiny specks of calcium, and they are extremely common and mostly benign (harmless). However, the pattern of the calcifications matters. Scattered, round calcifications are fine. But calcifications that are in a tight cluster or have an irregular shape (pleomorphic) can be an early sign of DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ) or breast cancer. This finding is why you are being called back for more pictures (magnification views) or a biopsy.

faqs.question: I have a painful, lumpy area in my breast that seems to get worse right before my period. Is it less likely to be cancer if it hurts?
faqs.answer: In general, yes. Pain is not a typical symptom of breast cancer. Breast pain (mastalgia) and lumpiness that changes with your menstrual cycle are classic symptoms of benign fibrocystic changes. These changes are driven by hormones and are very common, not cancerous. However, any new, distinct, and persistent lump should be checked, even if it's painful. A very small percentage of cancers (like inflammatory breast cancer) can cause pain.

faqs.question: The ultrasound couldn't tell if my lump was a complex cyst or a solid mass, so now they want to do a core needle biopsy. What is that like?
faqs.answer: A core needle biopsy is the standard way to get a definitive diagnosis. It's an in-office procedure. The area is numbed with local anesthetic (like at the dentist). The radiologist uses ultrasound to guide a special, spring-loaded needle to the lump. You will hear a click or thump as it takes a tiny (rice-sized) sample of tissue. They usually take 3-5 samples. You will feel pressure, but you shouldn't feel sharp pain. It's much less invasive than surgery and gives the pathologist a real tissue sample to analyze.

faqs.question: I'm a man and I found a small, hard lump right under my nipple. Is it even possible for me to get breast cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is possible. Male breast cancer is very rare (less than 1% of all breast cancers), but it does happen. Men have breast tissue, and that tissue can become cancerous. The most common sign is exactly what you're describing: a hard, painless lump under the nipple/areola area. Another common cause in men is gynecomastia (benign breast tissue growth), but any new, firm lump in a man's breast must be taken seriously and evaluated by a doctor immediately.

faqs.question: I sweat so much from my armpits, even when I'm just sitting still and not hot. It soaks through my shirts. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds like focal hyperhidrosis. This is a medical condition where the nerves that control your sweat glands are overactive. It's not related to temperature or stress; the glands are just on all the time. The most common areas are the armpits (axillary hyperhidrosis), palms, and soles of the feet. It's not dangerous, but it can be very distressing. There are treatments for it.

faqs.question: I shower every day, use deodorant, and I still feel like I have B.O. What am I doing wrong?
faqs.answer: You're probably not doing anything wrong. First, make sure you are using an antiperspirant (which stops sweat) and not just a deodorant (which only masks odor). Second, body odor is caused by bacteria on your skin breaking down sweat. Using an antibacterial soap (like one with benzoyl peroxide) in odor-prone areas (armpits, groin) can help reduce the bacteria. Also, some foods (like garlic, onions, and cruciferous vegetables) can contain sulfur compounds that are excreted through sweat and can affect odor.

faqs.question: I've tried every clinical strength antiperspirant and they don't work. What's the next step for my excessive armpit sweating?
faqs.answer: You have several options. The next step is usually a prescription-strength antiperspirant from your doctor (like those containing aluminum chloride hexahydrate). If that fails, a very common and effective treatment is botulinum toxin (Botox) injections. Botox is FDA-approved for axillary hyperhidrosis; it blocks the nerve signals that tell the sweat glands to activate. The results last for about 6-9 months.

faqs.question: My sweat has suddenly started to smell different, almost fruity or like nail polish remover. Is this something I should worry about?
faqs.answer: Yes, you should see a doctor. A sudden, new, and distinct fruity or acetone smell to your breath or sweat can be a sign of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). This is a life-threatening emergency that occurs when your body doesn't have enough insulin and starts burning fat for fuel, producing ketones. Other warning odors include a bleach smell (which can indicate liver or kidney problems). These are not to be ignored.

faqs.question: I've been waking up in the middle of the night drenched in sweat, and my sheets are soaked. It's not hot in my room. Should I be concerned?
faqs.answer: Yes, this needs to be evaluated by a doctor. These are called drenching night sweats and are different from just feeling warm. Waking up and needing to change your pajamas or sheets is a B symptom that can be associated with several serious conditions. These include infections (like tuberculosis), hormonal imbalances (like menopause or a thyroid issue), and certain cancers (most notably, lymphoma). Your doctor will need to do a full workup.

faqs.question: Sometimes my heart will suddenly start racing, like 180 beats per minute, for no reason. It feels like a flip-flop and then it's off. Is this a panic attack or SVT?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of SVT. The key features are the abrupt start and stop (like a light switch) and a very fast, but regular rhythm. A panic attack usually has a gradual ramp-up and ramp-down, and is associated with feelings of anxiety or fear (though SVT can cause panic). The flip-flop you feel is likely the premature beat that kicks off the fast rhythm.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to bear down like I'm having a bowel movement if it happens again. How on earth does that stop my heart from racing?
faqs.answer: This is called a vagal maneuver. The vagus nerve is a major nerve that helps control your heart rate. By bearing down (or blowing into a syringe, or splashing ice-cold water on your face), you are stimulating this nerve. Stimulating the vagus nerve releases a chemical (acetylcholine) that acts as a brake on the heart's electrical system, and it can often break the short-circuit that is causing the SVT, returning you to a normal rhythm.

faqs.question: Is this dangerous? Am I going to have a heart attack? It feels terrible when it happens.
faqs.answer: For most young, healthy people, paroxysmal SVT (episodes that come and go) is not life-threatening. It is benign but bothersome. It is not the same as a heart attack (a blockage) and is not likely to cause one. However, if the episodes are very fast (over 200 bpm), last for a long time (30+ minutes), or if you have other heart conditions (like heart failure), it can put a strain on the heart. The main risk is feeling dizzy or lightheaded and fainting (syncope).

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned a procedure called cardiac ablation. How does burning a part of my heart fix the fast rhythm?
faqs.answer: SVT is usually caused by an extra electrical pathway or a short circuit in your heart's conduction system. An ablation is a curative procedure. They thread thin wires (catheters) through a vein in your leg up to your heart. They first map the heart's electricity to find the exact location of that extra pathway. Then, they use a special catheter to deliver radiofrequency energy (heat) or cryo-energy (cold) to that tiny spot, destroying it. This permanently breaks the short-circuit, and in over 95% of cases, cures the SVT for good.

faqs.question: I notice my SVT happens more when I'm tired, dehydrated, or have had a lot of caffeine or alcohol. Are these known triggers?
faqs.answer: Yes, those are the most commonly reported triggers. While the underlying cause is the extra electrical pathway you were born with, these triggers are factors that can make the heart more irritable and more likely to use that pathway. Other common triggers include stress, anxiety, lack of sleep, and large meals. For many people, avoiding these triggers can significantly reduce the frequency of their episodes.

faqs.question: I got a really bad sunburn on my back. Now I have huge blisters, I feel nauseous, and I have the chills. Is this sun poisoning?
faqs.answer: Yes. Sun poisoning isn't a medical term, but it's what people call a severe sunburn (a second-degree burn) that has systemic symptoms. The blistering means the damage is deep. The nausea, chills, fever, and headache are a sign of a body-wide inflammatory response to the severe skin damage and dehydration. This is a serious burn, and you should focus on hydration, cool compresses, and pain relief. If you feel very dizzy or confused, you should seek medical attention.

faqs.question: Should I pop the blisters from my sunburn? What's the best thing to put on them?
faqs.answer: No, do not pop the blisters. The fluid-filled bubble is a sterile bandage that protects the raw, damaged skin underneath from infection. If you pop it, you open a wound. Let them drain on their own. For treatment, the best thing is 100% aloe vera gel (ideally chilled in the fridge) for its cooling properties. Avoid any creams that contain petroleum (like Vaseline) or lidocaine/benzocaine, as these can trap heat or cause an allergic reaction.

faqs.question: My burn is finally peeling, and it's driving me crazy. Is it bad to peel the skin off?
faqs.answer: It's best to let it peel on its own. The peeling skin is a sign that the new layer of skin underneath is ready, but pulling it off prematurely can rip skin that isn't ready, creating an open sore and increasing infection risk. The best thing to do is keep the area well-moisturized with a gentle, unscented lotion. This will make the peeling less noticeable and less tempting to pick at.

faqs.question: I got sunburned really badly as a kid, with blisters. Does that one bad burn mean I'm guaranteed to get skin cancer?
faqs.answer: It doesn't guarantee it, but it does significantly increase your risk. Research has shown that even one blistering sunburn in childhood or adolescence can more than double a person's lifetime risk of developing melanoma (the most serious skin cancer). Sun damage is cumulative, but severe, blistering burns are particularly damaging to the DNA in your skin cells. This makes it crucial for you to be vigilant about sun protection now and for the rest of your life, and to get regular skin checks from a dermatologist.

faqs.question: My skin isn't burned red, but after I was in the sun, I got an intensely itchy, bumpy rash on my chest and arms. Is this a sunburn?
faqs.answer: That does not sound like a typical sunburn. It sounds more like a sun allergy, most commonly Polymorphous Light Eruption (PMLE). This is an immune system reaction to sunlight, and it typically appears as an itchy, red, bumpy (papular) rash on sun-exposed skin. It often happens after the first significant sun exposure of the season (like on spring break) and tends to get better as the summer goes on (hardening).

faqs.question: My friend posted a very dark message online, saying everyone would be better off without me. How do I know if they're just venting or if they're truly suicidal?
faqs.answer: You must treat this as serious. Vague statements like I can't do this anymore or specific ones like you'd be better off without me are major warning signs. The best thing to do is to reach out to them directly and privately (call or text). Be direct. Ask, Are you thinking about killing yourself? Asking the question does not plant the idea. It opens the door and shows you're willing to talk about it. If you are worried they are in immediate danger, call 911 or a suicide hotline (like 988 in the U.S.) for guidance.

faqs.question: I'm having suicidal thoughts, but I'm scared if I tell a therapist, they'll hospitalize me immediately. Is that true?
faqs.answer: This is a very common fear. A therapist's primary goal is to keep you safe. Simply having suicidal ideation (thoughts) does not mean you will be hospitalized. Therapists are trained to assess your risk. They will ask if you have a specific plan, if you have the means to carry out the plan (e.g., access to pills or a weapon), and what your intent is. They will only break confidentiality and seek hospitalization if you are at high, imminent risk of harming yourself. You can and should talk to them about your thoughts.

faqs.question: What's the difference between passive thoughts (like I wish I wouldn't wake up) and active thoughts (like I am going to kill myself)?
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction in risk assessment. Passive ideation is a desire to be dead or for death to happen, but without a plan or intent to cause one's own death. Active ideation is thinking about and/or planning a specific method to end one's life. While active ideation with a plan represents a more immediate, acute danger, both are signs of significant depression and distress and should be taken very seriously as a cry for help.

faqs.question: My teenager just started an antidepressant (SSRI), and they seem more agitated and anxious. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: This is a critical side effect to watch for. In a small number of people, particularly adolescents and young adults, starting an antidepressant can sometimes increase agitation, anxiety, and, in rare cases, suicidal thoughts or behaviors. This is often called an activation effect and is most common in the first few weeks. You must contact their doctor immediately and report this change. They may need to adjust the dose or change the medication.

faqs.question: Why do I feel this way? I don't have a reason to be depressed. My life is good, but I can't shake the feeling of wanting it to end.
faqs.answer: This is the nature of clinical depression. It is a medical illness, not a logical response to life events. It's caused by a complex mix of brain chemistry (neurotransmitters like serotonin), genetics, and inflammation. The feeling of hopelessness and worthlessness is the disease. It's not a personal failure or a lack of gratitude. It's a sign that your brain is unwell and needs treatment, just like any other organ in your body.

faqs.question: Every spring, the first time I go in the sun, I get an intensely itchy, red, bumpy rash on my chest and arms. It goes away if I stay inside. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of Polymorphous Light Eruption (PMLE), the most common type of sun allergy. Polymorphous means it can look different in different people (bumpy, blotchy, etc.), but it's typically an itchy, red rash that appears hours to days after sun exposure. It happens on skin that has been covered all winter, and crucially, it often spares the face, which is exposed year-round.

faqs.question: How is this different from a regular sunburn? It doesn't blister and peel, it's more like hives.
faqs.answer: You're right, it's completely different. A sunburn is a burn—it's the skin's radiation damage from UV rays, causing redness, pain, and peeling. A sun allergy (like PMLE) is an immune system reaction to sunlight. Your immune system mistakenly identifies a sun-altered component of your own skin as foreign and attacks it, causing an itchy, inflammatory, hive-like rash.

faqs.question: Does this mean I can never go in the sun? Will broad-spectrum sunscreen prevent it?
faqs.answer: Broad-spectrum sunscreen is essential, but it may not be enough. PMLE is often triggered by UVA rays, which penetrate deeper and are not as well-blocked by all sunscreens (SPF only measures UVB). You need a high-SPF sunscreen with excellent UVA protection (look for PA++++ or a broad-spectrum label with ingredients like zinc oxide, avobenzone, or ecamsule). The best prevention is clothing (UPF-rated shirts) and avoiding peak sun (10 a.m. - 4 p.m.).

faqs.question: Once I have the rash, what's the fastest way to get rid of the itching?
faqs.answer: First, get out of the sun. The rash will fade on its own in a few days if you avoid further exposure. To treat the intense itch, you can use over-the-counter 1% hydrocortisone cream and take oral antihistamines (like Zyrtec or Claritin). Cool, wet compresses can also be very soothing.

faqs.question: Why does this only happen at the beginning of summer? By August, I'm usually fine.
faqs.answer: This is a key feature of PMLE called hardening. As the summer progresses, repeated, gradual exposure to UV light causes your skin to harden or desensitize. Your immune system's reaction becomes less severe. This is also the basis for a medical treatment, where a dermatologist can harden your skin in the spring using controlled doses of UV light (phototherapy) to prevent the rash from happening.

faqs.question: I'm a new mom and I'm terrified of SIDS. I know back to sleep is the rule, but what if my baby rolls onto their stomach on their own?
faqs.answer: This is a very common anxiety. The Back to Sleep rule is about the position you put your baby in. If your baby is old enough and strong enough to roll from their back to their stomach on their own, they generally have developed the head and neck control to protect their airway. You do not need to stay up all night flipping them back over. However, you must ensure the rest of the sleep environment is safe: a firm mattress and nothing else in the crib (no blankets, pillows, bumpers, or toys).

faqs.question: Are those home breathing monitors or smart socks proven to prevent SIDS? Are they worth the money?
faqs.answer: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) does not recommend any home cardiorespiratory monitors as a strategy to reduce the risk of SIDS. There is no evidence that they work, and they can lead to false alarms (causing panic) or a false sense of security. The only proven ways to reduce SIDS risk are the ABCs of safe sleep: baby Alone, on their Back, in a Crib (or bassinet/pack-n-play).

faqs.question: I know bed-sharing is a risk factor, but my baby will only sleep if they are in my bed. Is there any safe way to do it?
faqs.answer: The AAP officially recommends against bed-sharing at any time due to the high risk of suffocation, strangulation, and SIDS. The risk is especially high if you or your partner smoke, have taken any sedating medication or alcohol, or if the baby is under 4 months old. The safest alternative is room-sharing: keeping the baby's separate crib or bassinet in your room, next to your bed, for at least the first 6 months. This gives you proximity for feeding while keeping the baby in their own safe space.

faqs.question: I heard the risk is highest between 2 and 4 months. Why that specific age?
faqs.answer: You are correct; the vast majority of SIDS deaths (90%) occur before 6 months of age, with the peak being between 1 and 4 months. This is thought to be a vulnerable period where several factors intersect: 1) The baby's arousal instinct (their brain's ability to wake up in response to a problem, like not getting enough air) is still immature, and 2) They are just beginning to roll over, but may not be strong enough to roll back or lift their head effectively if they get into an unsafe position.

faqs.question: Does anyone actually know what causes SIDS? Is it a breathing problem?
faqs.answer: SIDS is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning it's the cause of death when no other reason (like suffocation) can be found. The leading theory is the Triple-Risk Model: 1) a vulnerable infant (e.g., with an underlying, undetectable brainstem abnormality that controls arousal), 2) a critical developmental period (the 1-4 month peak), and 3) an external stressor (like sleeping on their stomach, overheating, or exposure to smoke). The baby gets into an unsafe situation and, due to the underlying vulnerability, their brain fails to wake them up to cry or turn their head.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a heart attack and sudden cardiac arrest? I thought they were the same thing.
faqs.answer: This is a critical distinction. A heart attack (myocardial infarction) is a plumbing problem. A blockage in an artery stops blood flow to the heart muscle, and the muscle starts to die. The person is awake and having symptoms (like chest pain). Sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) is an electrical problem. The heart's electrical system malfunctions (e.g., goes into ventricular fibrillation), causing the heart to quiver or stop beating entirely. The person instantly loses consciousness. A heart attack, however, can sometimes trigger a cardiac arrest.

faqs.question: My father collapsed and died from SCA. He seemed healthy. What causes a person's heart to just stop like that?
faqs.answer: In older adults, the most common cause is underlying, and often silent, coronary artery disease (blockages) that leads to a fatal arrhythmia. In younger people (under 35), the causes are more often structural or genetic. These include hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (an abnormally thick heart muscle), arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (muscle replaced by scar tissue), or channelopathies (like Long QT syndrome) which are invisible, genetic defects in the heart's ion channels.

faqs.question: My father had SCA, and my uncle died suddenly in his 40s. Does this mean it's genetic and I'm at high risk?
faqs.answer: Having multiple family members, especially young ones, with SCA is a major red flag for an inherited (genetic) heart condition. You and other first-degree relatives (siblings, children) should absolutely be evaluated. This involves seeing a cardiologist, specifically an electrophysiologist. The workup will include a detailed family history, an EKG, and an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart). They may also recommend genetic testing to look for known sudden death genes.

faqs.question: Are there any warning signs before a cardiac arrest, or does it just come out of the blue?
faqs.answer: For about 50% of people, the SCA is the first sign of a problem. However, in the other 50%, there are warning signs in the weeks or hours before, but they are often missed. These can include new or worsening chest pain (angina), severe shortness of breath, unexplained fainting or blacking out (syncope), especially during exercise, and heart palpitations. Fainting during physical activity is a major warning sign that should never be ignored.

faqs.question: If I see someone collapse, what's more important: starting chest compressions (CPR) or finding an AED (defibrillator)?
faqs.answer: Do both, but start CPR immediately. The new mantra is Call, Push, Shock. 1) Call: Yell for help. Tell a specific person to call 911 and find an AED. 2) Push: Immediately start fast, hard chest compressions in the center of the chest. Do not stop. This manual pumping keeps blood moving to the brain. 3) Shock: The second the AED arrives, open it, turn it on, and follow its voice prompts. The AED is the only thing that can shock the heart back into a normal rhythm. CPR keeps the brain alive until the AED can do its job.

disease_name: Subconjunctival hemorrhage (broken blood vessel in eye)

faqs.question: I woke up and the entire white part of my eye is bright red with blood. It looks terrifying, but it doesn't hurt. Should I go to the ER?
faqs.answer: As scary as it looks, a subconjunctival hemorrhage is almost always harmless and does not require an ER visit, as long as you have no pain and no change in your vision. It's essentially a bruise on the surface of the eye. A tiny blood vessel under the clear surface (the conjunctiva) broke and the blood spread out. It's trapped, so it can't go anywhere, making it look very dramatic.

faqs.question: I just sneezed really hard (or coughed, or lifted something heavy) and this happened. Can something that simple really cause it?
faqs.answer: Yes. Any sudden spike in pressure (a Valsalva maneuver) can pop one of those fragile blood vessels. The most common causes are coughing, sneezing, vomiting, straining, or heavy lifting. Sometimes you just wake up with it and have no idea what caused it. It's also more common in people on blood thinners (like aspirin or warfarin) or who have high blood pressure.

faqs.question: Is there anything I can do to make it go away faster? Eyedrops?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, no. There is no treatment. You just have to wait for your body to reabsorb the blood. Regular lubricating eye drops (artificial tears) can help if the eye feels a little scratchy, but no get the red out drop will work, as this isn't vessel dilation (like in pink eye), it's pooled blood. It's just like a bruise on your skin; it has to fade on its own.

faqs.question: How long will I look like this? Will it fade or just disappear?
faqs.answer: It will take about 1 to 2 weeks to go away completely. Just like a bruise, it will change colors as it heals. The bright red will often fade to a more orange or yellowish color before disappearing entirely. It will not fade evenly; it will just get smaller or change color until it's gone.

faqs.question: This is the third time this has happened this year, and I don't know why. Should I be concerned?
faqs.answer: While a single-episode is no big deal, recurrent subconjunctival hemorrhages are a reason to see your doctor for a check-up. It could be a sign that your blood pressure is not well-controlled, or it could be a sign of a mild bleeding disorder. Your doctor will want to check your blood pressure and may order some simple blood tests (like a platelet count and coagulation panel).

faqs.question: I was just sitting here and suddenly got the worst headache of my life. It felt like a thunderclap in my head. Am I having an aneurysm?
faqs.answer: You must go to an emergency room immediately by ambulance. A thunderclap headache—a severe headache that peaks in intensity within 60 seconds—is the classic symptom of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). This is often caused by a ruptured brain aneurysm and is a life-threatening emergency. Do not wait and see or try to sleep it off.

faqs.question: My mom had a brain bleed from a ruptured aneurysm. Does this mean I'm likely to have one too?
faqs.answer: Having a first-degree relative (parent, sibling) with a brain aneurysm does increase your risk, especially if you have two or more affected relatives. You should speak to your doctor or a neurologist about screening. For high-risk individuals, doctors may recommend non-invasive screening tests like an MRA (Magnetic Resonance Angiogram) or CTA (CT Angiogram) to look for unruptured aneurysms.

faqs.question: I went to the ER for the worst headache, and they did a CT scan that was negative. Why do they still want to do a spinal tap (lumbar puncture)?
faqs.answer: This is standard and very important. A CT scan is excellent at finding blood in the brain, but it can miss a very small hemorrhage, especially if it's been more than 6-12 hours since it started. A spinal tap (lumbar puncture) is the gold standard test to rule out an SAH. They will look for blood in your spinal fluid. If there's no blood, they can definitively say you did not have a subarachnoid hemorrhage.

faqs.question: They found and treated my ruptured aneurysm. What is vasospasm? My doctors keep talking about it.
faqs.answer: Cerebral vasospasm is a dangerous complication that occurs after the initial bleed, typically peaking 3-10 days later. The blood that is coating the outside of the brain arteries (from the hemorrhage) irritates them, causing them to spasm and narrow. This narrowing can cut off blood flow to parts of the brain, causing a new stroke. This is why you are kept in the intensive care unit (ICU) for so long after the aneurysm is fixed—so they can monitor you closely for vasospasm and treat it with medication.

faqs.question: They want to coil my aneurysm. What does that mean? Is it safer than clipping it?
faqs.answer: Coiling (endovascular coiling) is a minimally-invasive procedure. A neurosurgeon guides a tiny catheter from an artery in your groin up into your brain. They then deploy tiny, soft platinum coils into the aneurysm bubble until it is packed full, which causes the blood to clot and seals it off. Clipping is an open-brain surgery where a small metal clip is placed on the neck of the aneurysm from the outside. The choice between coiling and clipping depends on the aneurysm's size, shape, and location. For many, coiling is now the preferred first-line treatment.

faqs.question: I have a painful, red lump on the edge of my eyelid, right where my eyelashes are. Is this a stye or a pimple?
faqs.answer: That is the classic description of an external stye (or hordeolum). It's essentially a small abscess caused by a bacterial (usually staph) infection in an eyelash follicle or an oil gland at the eyelid margin. A pimple is less common in that specific spot. An internal stye is similar but deeper inside the eyelid, caused by an infection in a different oil gland (meibomian gland).

faqs.question: How can I get this to go away fast? I've been using warm compresses and it's not draining.
faqs.answer: Warm compresses are the #1 treatment, but you have to do them correctly. You need to apply a very warm (as warm as you can tolerate without burning) wet washcloth to the eye for 10-15 minutes, 4-5 times a day. The heat and moisture are meant to soften the material and encourage the stye to come to a head and drain on its own. It can take a couple of days of this. Do not try to squeeze or pop it, as this can spread the infection.

faqs.question: I keep getting styes, one after another. Why does this keep happening?
faqs.answer: Recurrent styes are often linked to an underlying condition called blepharitis, which is a chronic inflammation of the eyelids. This condition creates an environment where bacteria (like staph) are always present on the eyelid margins, making it easy for glands to get infected. It can also be from stress, hormonal changes, or not fully removing eye makeup. A good lid hygiene routine (using warm water or special lid scrubs) can help prevent them.

faqs.question: Is a stye contagious? Can I spread it to my other eye or to my kids?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is mildly contagious. It's a bacterial infection, and the pus inside the stye contains staph bacteria. You can spread it by touching the stye and then touching your other eye. To prevent spreading it, wash your hands frequently, don't share towels or pillowcases, and avoid touching or rubbing your eyes.

faqs.question: My stye is gone, but it left a small, hard, painless lump behind. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is very common. It's called a chalazion. It means the infection (the stye) has cleared, but the blockage of oil and inflammatory debris remains, forming a hard, non-tender cyst. A chalazion is not an active infection. Sometimes they go away on their own with more warm compresses, but if it persists and bothers you (or affects your vision), an ophthalmologist can drain it with a simple in-office procedure.

faqs.question: My 4-year-old son suddenly started stuttering, getting stuck on the first letter of a word. Is this normal? Will he grow out of it?
faqs.answer: This is very common and is called developmental stuttering or normal disfluency. It often appears between ages 2 and 5, when a child's language skills are exploding, but their motor skills for speech are still catching up. They are thinking faster than they can talk. Many children (up to 75-80%) do grow out of it on their own. However, it's always a good idea to get an evaluation from a speech-language pathologist (SLP) to be safe.

faqs.question: When should I worry about my child's stuttering? Are there red flags that mean it's more serious?
faqs.answer: Yes. An SLP should be seen if the stuttering lasts for more than 6 months, if it starts after age 3 1/2, or if you see secondary behaviors. These include physical tension (like grimacing, fist clenching, or blinking hard) while trying to speak, or if the child starts to avoid speaking or says I can't talk and shows frustration. A family history of stuttering also increases the risk that it will persist.

faqs.question: When my son gets stuck on a word, my instinct is to tell him to slow down or take a deep breath. Is this helpful?
faqs.answer: It's a natural instinct, but it's generally not helpful. It can make the child feel more self-conscious and pressured, which can make the stuttering worse. The best thing to do is to be patient, maintain natural eye contact, and let them finish their thought. Don't interrupt or finish their sentences for them. Model a slow, relaxed speaking pace in your own speech, rather than telling them to slow down.

faqs.question: Did I do something to cause my child's stutter? Is it from stress or a scary event?
faqs.answer: No, you did not cause your child's stutter. This is a common guilt parents feel, but it's unfounded. Stuttering is a neurodevelopmental disorder. The exact cause isn't known, but it's strongly linked to genetics (it runs in families) and differences in brain wiring for speech production. While stress or excitement can trigger a stuttering moment, it is not the root cause of the disorder.

faqs.question: I'm an adult and I've stuttered all my life. It gets so much worse when I'm on the phone or public speaking. Why?
faqs.answer: This is called a situational trigger and it's all about pressure. Situations like using the phone, speaking to an authority figure, or public speaking create a performance anxiety and a high communicative pressure. This fear of stuttering makes you tense up, which in turn makes the stuttering more severe, creating a feedback loop. A speech-language pathologist who specializes in adults can teach you strategies (like stuttering modification or fluency shaping) to manage these specific, high-stakes situations.

faqs.question: My mom had a ministroke (TIA), and her symptoms went away. Does this mean she's in the clear, or is she still at risk?
faqs.answer: A TIA (transient ischemic attack) is a major warning sign. The symptoms are temporary because the blockage was brief, but it means the underlying cause (like a clot source or diseased artery) is still there. Her risk of having a major, permanent stroke is extremely high, especially in the first few days and weeks. She needs an urgent medical workup to find the cause and start preventative treatment immediately.

faqs.question: The stroke affected my dad's speech, but his arm and leg are fine. Why did it affect one thing and not the other?
faqs.answer: The brain is highly specialized. Different areas control different functions. A stroke is damage to a specific part of the brain from a blocked or burst blood vessel. In your dad's case, the stroke likely occurred in the brain's language centers (like Broca's or Wernicke's area) but did not damage the motor cortex, which controls movement. The long-term effects of a stroke are entirely dependent on where in the brain it happened.

faqs.question: It's been 6 months since my stroke, and my recovery seems to have plateaued. Will I ever get better, or is this it?
faqs.answer: Most rapid recovery happens in the first 3-6 months as brain swelling goes down and the brain rewires itself (neuroplasticity). While recovery may slow after 6 months, it does not stop. Slower, more gradual progress can continue for years, especially with consistent, targeted rehabilitation and therapy. It's important to set new, long-term goals and not get discouraged by the change in pace.

faqs.question: Why am I so exhausted and emotional all the time since my stroke? I cry for no reason. Is this depression or just part of the recovery?
faqs.answer: This is extremely common. It can be both. Post-stroke fatigue is a very real physical symptom from the brain's effort to heal. At the same time, post-stroke depression is also very common, partly as a psychological reaction to the event, but also as a direct chemical change in the brain caused by the injury itself. This is called emotional lability. You should speak to your doctor about this; it is a treatable side effect.

faqs.question: They told me to remember the acronym B.E. F.A.S.T. What does that stand for again?
faqs.answer: B.E. F.A.S.T. is an acronym to help you spot a stroke quickly. B for Balance (sudden loss of balance or coordination), E for Eyes (sudden blurred, double, or lost vision in one or both eyes), F for Face (one side of the face drooping), A for Arms (one arm drifting downward when trying to hold both up), S for Speech (slurred or strange speech, or unable to speak), and T for Time (Time to call 911 immediately, even if symptoms go away).

faqs.question: I lost a lot of weight, but my stretch marks are still here and look white. Why didn't they go away with the fat?
faqs.answer: Stretch marks (striae) are actually scars in the dermis, the middle layer of your skin. They happen when the skin stretches too fast (from weight gain, pregnancy, or a growth spurt), tearing the collagen and elastin. The initial red or purple color is from inflammation, but once they heal, they turn white or silvery. Because they are scars, they don't go away when the weight is lost. The scar tissue is permanent.

faqs.question: Do any of the expensive stretch mark creams or oils (like Bio-Oil or Mederma) actually work?
faqs.answer: This is a frustrating topic. There is very little scientific evidence that any topical cream or oil can remove existing stretch marks, especially white ones. However, keeping the skin well-hydrated with a thick moisturizer (whether it's an expensive cream or simple shea butter) can help improve the skin's texture and may slightly reduce the itchiness and redness of new (red/purple) stretch marks. For significant reduction, you'd need to see a dermatologist for treatments like laser therapy or microneedling.

faqs.question: I'm pregnant and using cocoa butter every day. Does this guarantee I won't get stretch marks?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, no. While keeping your skin moisturized is great and can help with itchiness, your likelihood of getting stretch marks is overwhelmingly determined by genetics and how quickly your skin stretches. If your mother got them, you are very likely to get them as well, regardless of what cream you use. Hydration helps skin elasticity, but it can't always overcome genetics.

faqs.question: I'm a teenage boy who doesn't work out, but I'm getting red stretch marks on my back. What's causing this?
faqs.answer: This is very common and almost certainly from a rapid growth spurt. During puberty, it's possible to grow several inches in a very short time. Your skin can't keep up with the new length of your skeleton, and it stretches, causing horizontal stretch marks on the back. They are not from weight gain and are not a sign of a problem; they are just a sign that you grew very quickly.

faqs.question: I leak a little pee every time I sneeze, laugh, or go for a run. It started after having kids. Is this just normal now?
faqs.answer: While it is extremely common after childbirth, it is not something you have to accept as normal for the rest of your life. This is classic stress incontinence. It's caused by a weakening of the pelvic floor muscles and the sling that supports your urethra. Childbirth is a major cause of this. The good news is that it is very treatable.

faqs.question: My doctor said to do Kegel exercises, but I'm not sure I'm doing them right. How do I know they're working?
faqs.answer: This is the most common problem with Kegels. To find the right muscles, try to stop your stream of urine mid-flow (don't do this regularly, just to identify the muscles). Those are your pelvic floor muscles. Squeeze them, hold for 3-5 seconds, and then fully relax for 3-5 seconds. You should feel a lift inside. Make sure you are not squeezing your glutes, thighs, or abs. A pelvic floor physical therapist can be a huge help, as they can use biofeedback to confirm you are isolating the correct muscles.

faqs.question: Are Kegels the only option? What if they don't work? Am I stuck with surgery?
faqs.answer: No, there are many steps between Kegels and surgery. A pelvic floor physical therapist is the best next step. They can teach you to do Kegels correctly and strengthen your entire core. Other non-surgical options include a pessary, a small silicone device inserted into the vagina to provide support for the urethra. For women after menopause, estrogen cream can also help improve tissue health. Surgery (like a sling procedure) is highly effective but is usually only considered after these other options have been tried.

faqs.question: I'm overweight. My doctor said losing weight might help my leakage. How are those two things related?
faqs.answer: Excess body weight, particularly in the abdomen, puts constant extra pressure on your bladder and pelvic floor muscles. This chronic pressure weakens the muscles over time, making it harder for the urethra to stay closed during a stress event like a cough or sneeze. Losing even 5-10% of your body weight can significantly reduce this pressure and dramatically improve or even resolve stress incontinence symptoms.

faqs.question: My shin pain is only in one tiny spot, and it hurts just to press on it. Is this a stress fracture or just bad shin splints?
faqs.answer: That focal or pinpoint tenderness is a classic sign of a stress fracture. Shin splints (medial tibial stress syndrome) are an inflammation of the muscle and its attachment to the bone, and the pain is usually more diffuse or spread along a larger area of the shin. A stress fracture is a tiny crack in the bone itself, so the pain is highly localized to that single spot. You should get it imaged.

faqs.question: I've been in a boot for 6 weeks for my stress fracture, and the new X-ray shows it's still not healing. Why isn't it getting better?
faqs.answer: This is called a nonunion or delayed union and can be very frustrating. Common reasons include: 1) Not resting it enough (walking on it too much, even in a boot). 2) Poor blood supply, especially in certain bones (like the 5th metatarsal). 3) A nutritional deficiency (not enough Vitamin D or calcium). 4) Smoking, which severely impairs your body's ability to heal bone. 5) Taking anti-inflammatory medicines (like ibuprofen), which can sometimes interfere with bone healing. Your doctor may need to order a CT scan or MRI.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a stress fracture in my navicular bone. Why is this one so much more serious than a shin splint?
faqs.answer: You have a high-risk stress fracture. The navicular is a bone in the midfoot that has a very poor, tenuous blood supply, especially in its center. Because healing bone requires good blood flow, fractures in this watershed area are notorious for not healing on their own (nonunion) and often require surgery (like putting a screw in) to stabilize them. This is treated much more aggressively than a low-risk fracture, like in the shin.

faqs.question: I'm a runner and I keep getting stress fractures. I've changed my shoes. What else am I doing wrong?
faqs.answer: This is likely a training error. The most common cause is too much, too soon—increasing your mileage or intensity too quickly for your bones to adapt. It could also be a biomechanical issue (like flat feet or overpronation) that a physical therapist can help correct with orthotics or exercises. For female runners, it's also critical to check for the female athlete triad: disordered eating, amenorrhea (loss of periods), and low bone density (osteoporosis), which makes you much more susceptible to fractures.

faqs.question: My throat is killing me, I have a fever, and my glands are swollen. But I don't have a cough. Is it strep or a virus?
faqs.answer: The absence of a cough is actually a strong indicator of strep throat. A bacterial strep infection typically causes a sudden, severe sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes in the neck, and white patches (exudate) on the tonsils. Symptoms like a cough, runny nose, and hoarseness are much more common with a viral infection. The only way to know for sure is to get a test.

faqs.question: The doctor did a rapid strep test and it was negative, but they still sent a throat culture to the lab. Why? Don't they trust the first test?
faqs.answer: The rapid strep test is very accurate when it's positive, but it can have false negatives (meaning it can miss an infection). A throat culture, where they try to grow the bacteria in a lab, is the gold standard. It's much more sensitive and can catch infections that the rapid test missed. Your doctor is being thorough, especially since untreated strep can (rarely) lead to complications like rheumatic fever.

faqs.question: I felt better after 2 days on antibiotics, so I stopped taking them. Is that okay?
faqs.answer: No, this is very important. You must finish the entire course of antibiotics (usually 7-10 days), even if you feel 100% better. Stopping early may not kill all the bacteria. The ones that survive can be the most resistant, leading to a relapse of your infection or contributing to antibiotic resistance. Finishing the course also ensures you're protecting against rare complications like rheumatic fever and kidney inflammation.

faqs.question: My son keeps getting strep throat over and over, like 4-5 times this year. Should his tonsils come out?
faqs.answer: This is called recurrent tonsillitis, and it's a very common reason to consider a tonsillectomy. While guidelines vary, surgery is often recommended if a child has a certain number of documented strep infections in a year (e.g., 7 times in one year, or 5 times per year for two years, or 3 times per year for three years) despite antibiotic treatment. You should see an ENT (Ear, Nose, and Throat) specialist to discuss the pros and cons.

faqs.question: Can I be a strep carrier? I feel fine, but my test was positive.
faqs.answer: Yes. A strep carrier is someone who has the strep bacteria in their throat but has no symptoms of infection. Their immune system is keeping it in check. Carriers are generally not contagious and do not need antibiotic treatment unless they or a close family member are having recurrent infections. It's often discovered when a whole family is tested because one child is sick.

faqs.question: I've had this gnawing, burning stomach pain and really bad heartburn for months. My antacids don't work anymore. Could this be more than just reflux?
faqs.answer: Yes, it absolutely could be, and you need to get it checked. Persistent stomach pain or heartburn that doesn't respond to standard treatment (like antacids or PPIs) is a major red flag. Vague symptoms that are easily dismissed—like nagging indigestion, a full feeling after eating only a small amount, or a nagging hunger that eating doesn't satisfy—can be the only early signs of stomach cancer. An upper endoscopy is needed to look.

faqs.question: My doctor found H. pylori in my stomach. I heard that's linked to cancer. Am I going to get stomach cancer?
faqs.answer: Having an H. pylori infection is the single biggest risk factor for stomach cancer, but it does not mean you will get it. Only a very small percentage of people with the infection develop cancer. The infection causes chronic inflammation (gastritis), which, over many decades, can lead to pre-cancerous changes. The most important thing is that you were diagnosed, and you can now be treated with a course of antibiotics to eradicate the bacteria. This will significantly lower your future risk.

faqs.question: What does linitis plastica mean? My doctor said this is a diffuse type of stomach cancer and it's hard to treat.
faqs.answer: Linitis plastica is a rare and very aggressive type of stomach cancer (adenocarcinoma). Unlike typical cancers that form a distinct lump or tumor, this type spreads diffusely throughout the entire stomach wall, making the wall thick, rigid, and leathery (like a leather bottle). It's often diagnosed late because it doesn't form a clear tumor that's easy to see on scans, and it's very difficult to treat with surgery.

faqs.question: My dad was diagnosed with stage 4 stomach cancer. The doctor said the 5-year survival rate is only 7%. Does this mean he only has a few months?
faqs.answer: Those statistics are an average based on thousands of people diagnosed at least 5 years ago. They are not a prediction for an individual. Your dad's prognosis depends on his overall health, where the cancer has spread (e.g., liver, lungs), and, most importantly, his cancer's specific biomarkers. Some stomach cancers (like those that are HER2-positive) can be treated with new targeted therapies, which can lead to much better outcomes than old statistics show. Focus on his specific treatment plan, not the general numbers.

faqs.question: I had an endoscopy for acid reflux, and my doctor found and removed stomach polyps. Should I be worried about cancer?
faqs.answer: In most cases, no. The vast majority of stomach polyps (also called gastric polyps) are benign (non-cancerous). The most common type, fundic gland polyps, have virtually no cancer risk, especially if you take acid-reducing (PPI) medications. Hyperplastic polyps are also common and non-cancerous. Your doctor removed them to be biopsied, which is the standard procedure.

faqs.question: Why did they remove them if they are probably harmless?
faqs.answer: While most are benign, some types can be precancerous. Adenomatous polyps (adenomas) are rare in the stomach, but they are the same type that can turn into cancer in the colon. They are considered precancerous and are always removed. Doctors remove all polyps they find to send them to a pathologist, who looks at them under a microscope to definitively tell what type they are and if there is any cancer risk.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have fundic gland polyps because I take Omeprazole (a PPI). Should I stop taking my medicine?
faqs.answer: This is a very common association. Long-term use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like Omeprazole is the most common cause of benign fundic gland polyps. These polyps are considered harmless. You should not stop your medication without talking to your doctor. The risks of uncontrolled acid reflux (like esophageal damage) usually far outweigh the presence of these harmless polyps. Your doctor will just monitor them.

faqs.question: The biopsy said I have an adenomatous polyp (adenoma) in my stomach. What does that mean for me?
faqs.answer: This is the one type of polyp that is taken very seriously. An adenoma is a precancerous growth. While it's not cancer yet, it has a high risk of developing into stomach cancer over time. Because it was found and removed, your doctor will want to do follow-up endoscopies (e.g., in one year) to make sure no new polyps have grown and to check for any other high-risk changes in your stomach lining (like intestinal metaplasia).

faqs.question: I just started a new seizure medicine (Lamotrigine) two weeks ago, and now I have a fever, and a painful, red rash is spreading all over my body. Could this be SJS?
faqs.answer: Yes. Stop taking the medication and go to an emergency room immediately. SJS is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction to a medication. It often starts 1-3 weeks after beginning a new high-risk drug (like Lamotrigine, Allopurinol, or certain antibiotics). It typically begins with flu-like symptoms (fever, sore throat) followed by a rapidly spreading, painful red or purplish rash that blisters and causes the top layer of skin to slough off. This is a medical emergency.

faqs.question: What's the difference between SJS and Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN)? My doctor used both terms.
faqs.answer: They are considered to be the same disease on a spectrum, differing only by severity. The distinction is made by how much of the skin surface is affected. If it involves less than 10% of the body surface, it's called SJS. If it involves more than 30%, it's called TEN. The overlap SJS/TEN category is between 10-30%. TEN is more widespread and has a higher mortality rate.

faqs.question: Why is this so dangerous? Isn't it just a bad rash?
faqs.answer: No, it's not just a rash. It's a systemic reaction where the skin and mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, genitals, lungs) essentially die and peel off. This is like having a severe burn over your whole body. The loss of the skin barrier leads to massive fluid loss, high risk of life-threatening infections (sepsis), and potential organ failure. Patients are almost always treated in an ICU or a burn unit.

faqs.question: I had SJS from an antibiotic. Does this mean I'm allergic to all antibiotics now?
faqs.answer: No, it means you are severely and permanently allergic to that specific drug and likely any other drugs in its exact same class. For example, if you reacted to a sulfa antibiotic, you must avoid all sulfa drugs. You will be labeled as having this allergy in all your medical records. It does not mean you are allergic to all other, unrelated classes of antibiotics (like penicillins or macrolides), but you will need to be extremely cautious with any new medication.

faqs.question: I have a painful, red, swollen bump on my skin that looks like a giant, deep pimple or spider bite. Could this be a staph infection?
faqs.answer: Yes, that is a classic description of a staph infection, particularly a boil (furuncle) or abscess. Staph bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus) are a common cause of skin infections. They often start in a hair follicle or small cut and create a painful, pus-filled lump. Many people mistake them for spider bites. It's important to not pop it yourself, as this can spread the infection.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a staph infection and MRSA?
faqs.answer: Staph (Staphylococcus) is the name of the bacteria. MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) is a specific type of staph. The key difference is that MRSA is resistant to the most common, first-line antibiotics (like methicillin, amoxicillin, and penicillin). This means a MRSA infection is not worse in terms of symptoms, but it is much harder to treat and requires different, more powerful antibiotics.

faqs.question: My boil is small. Can I just put hot compresses on it, or do I need to see a doctor for antibiotics?
faqs.answer: For a very small, minor boil, warm compresses applied for 10-15 minutes several times a day can help it come to a head and drain on its own. However, you should see a doctor if it is very large, extremely painful, on your face or spine, you develop a fever, or if you have underlying conditions (like diabetes). The doctor may need to incise and drain (I&D) it, and they will decide if you need oral antibiotics based on its severity and whether it's MRSA.

faqs.question: I'm a wrestler, and our team keeps getting these skin infections. How is it spreading so fast?
faqs.answer: Staph and MRSA are highly contagious and spread through direct skin-to-skin contact, which is constant in wrestling. It also spreads through contaminated surfaces (shared mats, benches, towels, or razors). A small, un-covered cut or mat burn is a perfect entry point for the bacteria. The key to stopping the spread is to cover all wounds with a secure bandage, shower immediately after practice, don't share any personal items, and ensure all mats are disinfected daily.

faqs.question: I was just diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer. My doctor told me the statistics aren't good. Am I just supposed to give up?
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. It's critical to remember that statistics are just averages from the past; they are not your personal story. A stage 4 diagnosis is not a single, hopeless category. Your treatment and prognosis depend enormously on factors like where it has spread (e.g., just to the liver vs. multiple organs), your overall health, and the specific genetic biomarkers of your tumor. Many people live for many years with stage 4 disease, managing it as a chronic condition with ongoing treatment.

faqs.question: My first chemotherapy (FOLFOX) stopped working, and the cancer is growing again. Is this the end? What are my options?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and expected part of the journey. This is not the end; it's the time for second-line therapy. The next step depends on what you had first and your tumor's genetics. Your oncologist will now discuss different chemotherapy drugs (like FOLFIRI) or, more likely, adding a targeted therapy. These are drugs like bevacizumab (Avastin) that cut off the tumor's blood supply, or drugs like cetuximab (Erbitux) that block a specific growth signal (if your tumor is KRAS wild-type). There are many more lines of treatment.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to test my tumor for biomarkers like KRAS, BRAF, and MSI. What is this, and why does it matter?
faqs.answer: This is the most important part of modern cancer care. Think of biomarkers as your tumor's instruction manual. These tests tell your doctor exactly what mutations are driving the cancer. This is crucial: If your tumor is KRAS wild-type (not mutated), it means it will likely respond to a powerful class of drugs (EGFR inhibitors like cetuximab). If it's mutated, those drugs won't work. If your tumor is MSI-High, it means it has a defect in its DNA-repair system. This makes it highly responsive to immunotherapy (like Keytruda), which can lead to dramatic, long-lasting remissions. These tests allow for personalized medicine instead of a one-size-fits-all approach.

faqs.question: My cancer has only spread to my liver. Why are they talking about surgery AND chemo?
faqs.answer: This is a very hopeful situation. When metastatic colon cancer is oligometastatic (meaning it has only spread to one or a few small spots in one organ, like the liver), you may be a candidate for a curative-intent approach. The plan is to use chemotherapy first to shrink the liver tumors as much as possible. Then, a specialized surgeon (a hepato-biliary surgeon) may be able to surgically remove all the tumors. This combination offers the best (and a very real) chance for long-term survival and even a cure.

faqs.question: How do I balance the side effects of chemo with my quality of life? I'm scared of being sick all the time.
faqs.answer: This is the central question, and it's your decision. Palliative care is not just end-of-life care; it's a specialized team that works with your oncologist to manage symptoms and side effects. Be completely honest with your team. If you are nauseous, fatigued, or have bad neuropathy (numbness), tell them. They can adjust dosages (chemo holidays are common), add supportive medications, and help you align the treatment goals with your life goals (like being well enough for a family wedding or a trip).

disease_name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

faqs.question: I have this scaly, red, crusty patch on my ear that won't heal. It bleeds sometimes. Is this a dangerous skin cancer?
faqs.answer: This sounds like a classic squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). It's the second most common skin cancer. While most SCCs are not as dangerous as melanoma, they are more aggressive than basal cell carcinoma. They can be dangerous if left untreated, as they have a small but real risk of growing deep into the tissues and spreading (metastasizing) to other parts of the body. You must have it biopsied.

faqs.question: My doctor said my SCC is in situ (Bowen's disease). What does that mean?
faqs.answer: In situ means in place. This is the earliest, most superficial form of SCC. It means the cancer cells are only in the very top layer of the skin (the epidermis) and have not invaded into the deeper layers (the dermis). This is excellent news, as it is 100% curable with a simple procedure like excision, scraping (curettage), or even a topical cream.

faqs.question: They want to do Mohs surgery for the SCC on my nose. Why not just cut it out?
faqs.answer: Mohs surgery is the gold standard for SCCs in high-risk areas like the nose, eyelids, ears, and lips. In Mohs, the surgeon removes a thin layer of the tumor, immediately takes it to an on-site lab, and checks 100% of the margins under a microscope. If they see any cancer roots, they go back and take only that specific spot. They repeat this until the margins are clear. This gives the highest possible cure rate (over 99%) while sparing the most normal, healthy tissue, which is critical on the face.

faqs.question: I'm an organ transplant recipient, and my dermatologist is very aggressive about checking me for SCC. Why am I at higher risk?
faqs.answer: The immunosuppressive drugs you take to prevent organ rejection are the cause. These drugs weaken your immune system's ability to police your skin and destroy early, damaged cells. This makes you dramatically more susceptible to skin cancers, especially SCC. Your risk can be 65-100 times higher than the general population, which is why you need very frequent, thorough skin checks.

faqs.question: I twisted my wrist, and it's swollen and hurts, but I can still move my fingers. Does this mean it's just a sprain and not broken?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Being able to move it is a good sign, but it doesn't rule out a fracture. A sprain is an injury to a ligament (the tape that connects bones), while a fracture is a break in the bone. A severe sprain (a torn ligament) can often hurt more and have more swelling than a minor fracture. The only way to know for sure is with an X-ray.

faqs.question: It's been 2 weeks since I sprained my ankle, and I'm still limping. How long is this supposed to take?
faqs.answer: People often underestimate sprain recovery. A mild Grade 1 sprain (stretched ligament) might feel better in 1-2 weeks. But a Grade 2 (partial tear) or Grade 3 (complete tear) sprain can easily take 6-12 weeks or more for the ligament to heal and for you to regain full strength and stability. If you're still limping, you likely have a more significant sprain and would benefit from physical therapy to prevent chronic instability.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a high ankle sprain. Why is that worse than a regular ankle sprain?
faqs.answer: A regular (lateral) ankle sprain damages the ligaments on the outside of your ankle. A high ankle sprain (syndesmotic sprain) damages the tough ligaments that hold your two leg bones (the tibia and fibula) together above the ankle. This is a much more serious injury because it makes the entire ankle-leg structure unstable. These sprains take significantly longer to heal (often twice as long) and are more likely to require a walking boot or even surgery.

faqs.question: Should I be using ice or heat on my sprained ankle? It's been 3 days.
faqs.answer: For the first 2-3 days (the acute phase), you should only use ice (15-20 minutes at a time, several times a day) to reduce swelling and numb the pain. After 3-4 days, when the initial swelling has peaked, you can start to use gentle heat (like a heating pad) before activity or stretching to warm up the tissues. You can also alternate ice and heat. But ice is still the best choice after activity to calm any new inflammation.

faqs.question: I rolled my ankle badly. How do I know if I need an X-ray? I don't want to go to the ER if it's just a sprain.
faqs.answer: Doctors use a guideline called the Ottawa Ankle Rules. You likely need an X-ray if you have pain in the malleolar zone (the bony bumps on either side of your ankle) AND you are unable to bear weight on it for 4 steps (both immediately after the injury and in the ER). If you can walk on it, even with a limp, it's less likely to be a fracture, but you should still see a doctor if the swelling is severe or doesn't improve.

faqs.question: My ankle isn't that painful, but it's hugely swollen and bruised all down the side. Is the swelling a bad sign?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. The lateral ankle ligaments on the outside of your ankle are very vascular (full of blood vessels). When they tear (a Grade 2 or 3 sprain), they bleed a lot, causing dramatic swelling and black-and-blue bruising that can track down into your foot and toes due to gravity. This often looks much worse than it is. The more important long-term sign is instability—a feeling that your ankle wants to give way or roll again.

faqs.question: It's been 6 weeks, and my ankle is still a bit swollen and feels weak. Why isn't it 100%?
faqs.answer: Ligament healing is slow. It takes 6-12 weeks for the scar tissue to form, and months for that tissue to remodel and get strong. The weak or unstable feeling is from damage to the proprioceptors in your ankle—nerves that tell your brain what position your joint is in. This is why physical therapy is so important. You don't just need to heal the ligament; you need to retrain your muscles and nerves to provide stability. This involves balance and strengthening exercises.

faqs.question: I keep spraining the same ankle over and over. What is going on?
faqs.answer: This is called chronic ankle instability. It means the ligaments from your first sprain never healed properly (they healed in a stretched-out position) or you never fully rehabbed your strength and proprioception. Every time you roll it, you're stretching those weak ligaments even more. This is a significant problem that can lead to arthritis. You need to see a physical therapist or an orthopedic specialist. You may need a brace for sports, and in some cases, surgery is needed to repair or tighten the ligaments.

faqs.question: I'm a 42-year-old woman, I'm fit, and I don't have high cholesterol. The ER said I had a SCAD heart attack. How is this possible?
faqs.answer: This is the classic profile for a SCAD. Unlike a typical heart attack (from plaque rupture), SCAD is a tear that forms inside the wall of a heart artery. This tear creates a false channel for blood, or a blood clot (hematoma) forms within the wall, which then compresses the artery and blocks blood flow. It is not related to traditional risk factors (smoking, cholesterol). It is the #1 cause of heart attacks in pregnant/postpartum women and is very common in young, healthy-seeming women.

faqs.question: They didn't put a stent in. My doctor said conservative management is better. Why wouldn't they prop the artery open?
faqs.answer: This is the standard, preferred treatment for SCAD, and it's different from a regular heart attack. The arteries in SCAD are extremely fragile and friable. Trying to place a stent can often worsen the tear, extend the dissection, or block off other vessels. Studies show that in most cases, if the patient is stable, the dissected artery will heal on its own over 4-6 weeks. Treatment is focused on medications (like beta-blockers) to reduce the stress on the heart while this healing happens.

faqs.question: I keep having chest pain, even after my SCAD. Am I having another one? I'm terrified to move.
faqs.answer: This is an extremely common and frightening part of SCAD recovery. Most patients (over 90%) experience chest pain after their SCAD. It's often non-cardiac (muscular, from the event) or from small vessel spasms. However, SCAD does have a recurrence risk (about 10-15% in the first few years). You must never ignore chest pain. Your doctor should give you a clear plan, which may involve taking nitroglycerin. If it's new, severe, or just like the first time, you must go back to the ER to get it checked out.

faqs.question: My doctor said I should be screened for FMD. What is that?
faqs.answer: FMD (Fibromuscular Dysplasia) is a vascular disease that causes abnormal cell growth in the walls of arteries, making them look beaded. It is not plaque. A very high percentage of SCAD patients (50-86%) are also found to have FMD in other arteries (like the ones going to your kidneys or brain). It is a strong associated condition. Because of this, it is now standard practice for all SCAD survivors to get a head-to-pelvis CT or MR angiogram to screen for FMD and aneurysms in other parts of their body.

faqs.question: My legs get incredibly heavy, numb, and painful after I've been walking for 5 minutes. But as soon as I sit or lean on a shopping cart, it gets better. What is this?
