faqs.answer: This is the classic sign of neurogenic claudication from lumbar spinal stenosis. Stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal canal, which pinches the nerves going to your legs. When you stand or walk, your spine extends, which worsens the narrowing and chokes the nerves, causing the pain. When you sit or lean forward (like on a shopping cart), you flex your spine, which opens up the canal and gives the nerves room, relieving the pain.

faqs.question: Is this the same as a slipped disc (herniated disc)?
faqs.answer: They are related but different. A herniated disc is a soft disc problem where the gel-like center of a disc pushes out and hits a nerve, which is common in younger people. Spinal stenosis is a hard problem, more common as we age. It's a narrowing of the bone itself, caused by a combination of bulging discs, thickened ligaments, and arthritis in the facet joints. It's an arthritic, degenerative process.

faqs.question: My doctor wants me to try physical therapy and injections. I'm in so much pain, shouldn't I just get the surgery to fix it?
faqs.answer: Surgery (a laminectomy) is very effective, but it's a major operation. For mild to moderate stenosis, a combination of physical therapy and epidural steroid injections is often very successful. PT can't widen the canal, but it can strengthen your core and glutes to de-load your spine and teach you to move in ways that don't cause pain. The injections can calm the inflammation of the pinched nerves, giving you a window of relief to make progress in therapy. Most doctors will only recommend surgery if these fail or your weakness is severe.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have cervical stenosis in my neck, but my main symptom is that I'm clumsy and my hands feel numb. Is that related?
faqs.answer: Yes, and this is a much more serious condition. Cervical stenosis is narrowing in your neck, which can compress the spinal cord itself (not just nerve roots). This is called myelopathy. Symptoms are not just pain; they are clumsiness in the hands (trouble buttoning shirts, bad handwriting), a weird gait (feeling like you're walking on cotton), and urgency with your bladder. This is a surgical diagnosis, as progressive compression of the spinal cord can lead to permanent paralysis.

faqs.question: I had an epidural (or spinal tap) two days ago, and now I have the worst headache of my life. It's fine when I lie flat, but as soon as I sit up, it's unbearable.
faqs.answer: This is the classic post-dural puncture headache, or spinal headache. It's caused by a tiny hole in the dura (the sac holding your spinal fluid) that is leaking fluid. When you lie flat, the pressure is stable. When you sit or stand, gravity causes the pressure to drop in your head, which pulls on your brain and causes this severe, positional headache. It is not dangerous, but it is miserable.

faqs.question: How do I get rid of this at home? I've been told to drink caffeine and lie flat.
faqs.answer: Lying flat is the #1 treatment. This stops the leak and allows your body to replenish the spinal fluid. Forcing fluids (water, electrolytes) and consuming caffeine (coffee, soda) can also help, as caffeine is a vasoconstrictor and may help reduce the headache pain. However, these are just to manage symptoms while the hole tries to heal on its own.

faqs.question: It's been 2 days and caffeine isn't working. My doctor mentioned a blood patch. What is that?
faqs.answer: An epidural blood patch is the definitive cure, and it works almost instantly. An anesthesiologist will perform another epidural, but instead of injecting medicine, they will inject a small amount of your own blood (drawn from your arm) into the epidural space. This blood clots over the hole and forms an immediate patch, stopping the leak and restoring the pressure in your head. The relief is often dramatic and immediate.

faqs.question: If I don't get the blood patch, will this ever go away on its own?
faqs.answer: Yes, most spinal headaches will resolve on their own, as the tiny hole will eventually scar over and heal. However, this can take 5-7 days, and sometimes as long as two weeks. Most people find the headache so severe and debilitating (being unable to sit or stand) that they opt for the blood patch to get immediate relief rather than toughing it out flat on their back for a week.

faqs.question: My MRI found a benign spinal tumor (like a meningioma). If it's not cancer, why are they saying I need surgery? Can't I just leave it alone?
faqs.answer: This is a key concept. In the spine, benign does not mean harmless. Your spinal cord is in a tight, bony canal with no extra room. A benign tumor, even if it's slow-growing and not cancerous, will still compress your spinal cord as it grows. This compression will cause permanent, irreversible nerve damage, leading to paralysis, numbness, and loss of bladder/bowel control. Surgery is often recommended to remove it before it causes permanent deficits.

faqs.question: What's the difference between an intradural and extramedullary tumor?
faqs.answer: This just describes the tumor's location. The spinal cord is covered by a tough sac called the dura. An intradural-extramedullary tumor, which is the most common type (e.g., meningiomas, schwannomas), means the tumor is inside the dural sac, but outside the spinal cord itself (growing next to the cord). These are often benign and easier to remove. In contrast, an intramedullary tumor is one growing inside the spinal cord tissue itself (e.g., ependymomas, astrocytomas). These are much rarer and more difficult to remove without damaging the cord.

faqs.question: What are the first symptoms? I have back pain, but my doctor is also asking about numbness in my saddle area.
faqs.answer: Back pain, especially pain that is worse at night when lying down, is a common first symptom. But because the tumor is pressing on nerves, the key symptoms are neurological. Your doctor is asking about saddle anesthesia (numbness in the parts of your body that would touch a saddle—inner thighs, groin, buttocks) because this is a major red flag for cauda equina syndrome, a surgical emergency caused by compression of the nerves at the very bottom of your spine.

faqs.question: The biopsy said I have an ependymoma. The surgeon said it's low-grade but that I'll need radiation. I'm confused.
faqs.answer: An ependymoma is the most common intramedullary tumor (inside the cord) in adults. They are often low-grade (slow-growing). The goal of surgery is gross total resection (getting it all out). If the surgeon is confident they got 100% of it, you may just be monitored. But if any small piece had to be left behind (because it was stuck to the cord), they will recommend radiation after surgery to sterilize the area and prevent that small piece from ever growing back.

faqs.question: My son had a complete injury at T10. The doctor said he won't walk. Is there any hope? What about new research?
faqs.answer: A complete injury means there is currently no detectable motor or sensory function below the level of the injury (the T10 level, around the navel). In this situation, the prognosis for walking is unfortunately poor. However, recovery means many things. The fastest functional return happens in the first 6 months, but improvements can continue for 1-2 years. Hope should be focused on maximizing independence with a wheelchair, learning new skills, and preventing complications. New research (like epidural stimulation) is very exciting but is still experimental and not yet a cure.

faqs.question: What is autonomic dysreflexia? They told me it's a medical emergency, and it can be triggered by a full bladder?
faqs.answer: This is a critical, life-threatening complication for anyone with an injury at T6 or above. Your autonomic nervous system (which controls blood pressure, etc.) is now disconnected. When a noxious (painful or irritating) stimulus happens below your injury level—like a full bladder, a kinked catheter, or even an ingrown toenail—your body sends a panic signal. This signal can't reach your brain, so it causes an uncontrolled, massive sympathetic response—your blood pressure can skyrocket to stroke levels (200/110+). The first step is to sit up, and then immediately find and fix the cause (e.g., drain the bladder).

faqs.question: It's been 5 years since my injury. Why am I suddenly having more muscle spasms (spasticity) and pain?
faqs.answer: This is very common. Late-onset complications can arise years later. Increased spasticity or new pain is often a sign that something else is wrong. It could be a non-noxious trigger like a bladder infection, a kidney stone, or a pressure sore you can't feel. It can also be a sign of a new problem in your spinal cord, such as a syrinx (a fluid-filled cyst) forming at the injury site. You should see your spinal cord specialist for a full workup.

faqs.question: What's the difference between tetraplegia and quadriplegia?
faqs.answer: They mean the exact same thing. Tetraplegia (using the Greek prefix tetra) is now the preferred medical term. Both words describe paralysis affecting—to some degree—all four limbs (arms and legs). This is the result of a cervical (neck) injury. Paraplegia is paralysis that affects the lower half of the body (legs) but not the arms. This is the result of a thoracic or lumbar (back) injury.

faqs.question: I'm having sudden, severe back pain and my legs are weak and numb. My doctor ordered an MRI for a spinal AVM. What is that?
faqs.answer: A spinal AVM is a rare, abnormal tangle of blood vessels in or on the spinal cord. Normally, high-pressure arteries feed into tiny capillaries, which then drain into low-pressure veins. In an AVM, the arteries connect directly to the veins. This high-pressure blood flow steals blood from the normal spinal cord tissue (causing weakness/numbness) and the fragile veins can burst, causing a stroke or hemorrhage in the spinal cord, which is a medical emergency.

faqs.question: How did I get this? Was I born with it?
faqs.answer: Most spinal AVMs are congenital, meaning you are born with them, but they often don't cause symptoms until you are an adult. The symptoms (like pain, weakness, or numbness) appear when the AVM starts to bleed, gets large enough to compress the spinal cord, or steals so much blood that the cord begins to suffer from a lack of oxygen.

faqs.question: They want to do an embolization. What does that mean? Is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: An embolization is a minimally-invasive procedure performed by a neuro-radiologist. They guide a tiny catheter from an artery in your groin all the way to the AVM in your spine. Then, they inject a special glue or tiny particles to block the abnormal arteries feeding the AVM. This is a very delicate procedure and has risks (like accidentally blocking a normal artery), but it is often the first-line treatment as it is less invasive than open spinal surgery. The goal is to de-activate the AVM.

faqs.question: What happens if they don't treat it? Can it just go away?
faqs.answer: No, an AVM will not go away on its own. The risk of leaving it untreated is very high. Each year, there is a significant risk that the AVM will bleed (hemorrhage). A bleed into the spinal cord is a catastrophic event that can cause sudden, permanent paralysis and loss of bladder/bowel function. Because the risk of a bleed is so high, treatment is almost always recommended if it is feasible.

faqs.question: I have this weird bulging feeling in my vagina, and it feels like something is falling out, especially when I stand for a long time. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic symptom of pelvic organ prolapse. An enterocele (small bowel prolapse) is when the small intestine and the lining of the pelvis (peritoneum) bulge down into the upper part of the vagina. It's caused by a weakening of the pelvic floor muscles and ligaments, often from childbirth, aging, or a hysterectomy. The bulging you feel is your small bowel pushing down.

faqs.question: Why did this happen after my hysterectomy? I thought that was supposed to fix things.
faqs.answer: This is a very common scenario. The uterus acts as a central support for the top of the vagina. When the uterus is removed, it can leave the vaginal vault (the top of the vagina) as a weak point. Over time, pressure from above (from your small bowel) can cause this area to collapse and prolapse. This is called a vault prolapse, and an enterocele is often part of it.

faqs.question: I don't want surgery. Can I use a pessary for this?
faqs.answer: Yes, for many women, a pessary is an excellent non-surgical option. A pessary is a small, silicone device (often shaped like a ring or cube) that is placed inside your vagina by your gynecologist. It acts as a scaffold to hold the vaginal walls and the prolapsed organs back up in place. It can relieve your symptoms completely. It needs to be removed and cleaned regularly, but it's a very effective way to manage prolapse without an operation.

faqs.question: My doctor said I need surgery and mentioned sacrocolpopexy. That sounds intense. What is it?
faqs.answer: Sacrocolpopexy is the gold standard surgical repair for severe vaginal vault prolapse and enterocele. It is an abdominal surgery (often done robotically) where the surgeon uses a piece of surgical mesh to lift the top of the vagina (the vault) and anchor it to a strong ligament on your sacrum (the bone at the base of your spine). This creates a very strong, durable suspension that restores the normal anatomy and prevents the small bowel from bulging down.

faqs.question: Why is small bowel cancer so rare and hard to find? I've had vague stomach pain and weight loss for a year, and doctors just found it.
faqs.answer: You are right; it is very rare and notoriously difficult to diagnose. This is for a few reasons: 1) The small intestine is over 20 feet long, so a small tumor has a lot of room to grow before it causes a blockage. 2) The symptoms are very vague (like cramping, nausea, fatigue, or anemia) and are easily mistaken for much more common problems like IBS, Crohn's disease, or ulcers. 3) It is very difficult to see. A regular upper endoscopy only sees the first few inches, and a colonoscopy only sees the very last inch.

faqs.question: How do they even find a tumor in the middle of 20 feet of intestine?
faqs.answer: It requires special tests. After a CT or MRI scan suggests a problem, the main tool is a video capsule endoscopy. You swallow a pill-sized camera that takes thousands of pictures as it tumbles through your entire small intestine, transmitting them to a recorder you wear on a belt. This allows the doctor to see the entire length of the small bowel. An alternative is a double-balloon enteroscopy, a specialized, long endoscope that is pleated through the intestine.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a carcinoid tumor in my small bowel. Is that the same as regular cancer (adenocarcinoma)?
faqs.answer: No, it's a different and more common type of small bowel tumor. Carcinoid is a type of neuroendocrine tumor (NET). These tumors grow from hormone-producing cells in the gut. They are often very slow-growing (indolent) compared to adenocarcinomas. However, they can spread to the liver, and they can release hormones (like serotonin) into the bloodstream, causing carcinoid syndrome (symptoms like flushing, diarrhea, and heart palpitations).

faqs.question: I have celiac disease, and now I have lymphoma in my small bowel. Are these related?
faqs.answer: Yes, there is a strong and direct link. In a very small subset of people with celiac disease, especially those who are diagnosed late or do not strictly follow a gluten-free diet, the chronic inflammation can lead to a rare but serious type of lymphoma called Enteropathy-Associated T-cell Lymphoma (EATL). This is a known, though uncommon, complication of celiac disease.

faqs.question: My husband has started sleepwalking as an adult. He never did this as a kid. Is this a sign of something serious?
faqs.answer: While adult-onset sleepwalking can just be from stress or severe sleep deprivation, it is more concerning than in childhood. It's often a sign of an underlying sleep disorder that is fragmenting the sleep and triggering the parasomnia. The most common culprit is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The brain is aroused from deep sleep briefly by the lack of oxygen, but not enough to fully wake up, which can trigger the sleepwalking. He should be evaluated by a sleep specialist.

faqs.question: I found my 10-year-old in the kitchen trying to make a sandwich, but he was completely asleep. Is it dangerous to wake him up?
faqs.answer: It is not dangerous in a medical sense, but it is highly disadvisable. A sleepwalker is in a very deep stage of sleep. If you wake them, they will be extremely disoriented, confused, and frightened. They may not recognize you and could react defensively, lashing out or trying to run. The safest thing to do is to not shout or shake them, but to gently and calmly guide them by the arm or shoulder back to their bed, speaking in a soft, reassuring voice. They will likely not remember it at all.

faqs.question: What can I do to keep my sleepwalking child safe?
faqs.answer: Safety is the #1 priority. You must treat it like baby-proofing for a much larger child. This includes putting locks or child-safety knobs high on all exterior doors, putting secure gates at the top of all staircases, making sure all windows are locked and secured, hiding sharp objects (like kitchen knives) and car keys, removing tripping hazards from the floor, and placing an alarm or bell on their bedroom door so you are alerted if they get up.

faqs.question: What is confusional arousal? My son will sit up in bed, eyes open, and mumble nonsense, but he's not walking.
faqs.answer: This is a disorder of arousal (or parasomnia) and is on the same spectrum as sleepwalking and sleep terrors. The brain is stuck between a deep sleep stage and being awake. This results in confused behavior, sitting up, muddled speech, or thrashing, but without actually getting out of bed. It's triggered by the same things (sleep deprivation, fever, stress) and is generally not harmful.

faqs.question: My toddler sits up screaming in the middle of the night, eyes wide open, but he seems to be looking right through me. He's terrified, but I can't comfort him. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is a classic sleep terror (or night terror). The most important thing to know is that your child is not awake. They are in a very deep stage of non-REM sleep. Their eyes are open, and they may scream or thrash, but they are not conscious, not having a nightmare, and cannot see you. This is why you can't comfort them; they are not present to be comforted.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this and a nightmare? The next morning, he doesn't remember a thing.
faqs.answer: That is the key difference. A nightmare is a bad dream that happens during REM (dreaming) sleep, usually in the second half of the night. A child will wake up from a nightmare, be scared, and seek comfort, and they will remember the dream. A sleep terror is a disorder of arousal that happens in the first third of the night, during deep sleep. The child does not wake up, is inconsolable, and has no memory of it the next day. It is much more frightening for the parent than for the child.

faqs.question: What am I supposed to do during an episode? Should I try to wake him up?
faqs.answer: No, do not try to wake him. Just like with sleepwalking, waking him will only lead to extreme confusion and fright, which can make the episode worse. Your only job is safety. Stay with him, speak calmly (even if he can't hear you), and make sure he cannot hurt himself by falling out of bed or hitting his head. The episode will pass on its own (usually in 5-15 minutes), and he will fall back into a normal sleep.

faqs.question: My son is having these 3-4 times a week. Is this normal? What's triggering them?
faqs.answer: While occasional sleep terrors are common, frequent ones often have a clear trigger. The #1 cause is being over-tired or having an inconsistent sleep schedule. A later bedtime or a missed nap can lead to a rebound of deep sleep, making a terror more likely. Other triggers include fever, stress, or an underlying sleep disorder like sleep apnea (if his breathing is being disrupted, it can trigger an arousal).

faqs.question: I sleep 8 hours every night, but I still wake up exhausted, like I haven't slept at all. What is wrong with me?
faqs.answer: This is the classic sign of poor sleep quality, even if your sleep quantity seems fine. You are likely not getting enough restorative deep sleep or REM sleep. The most common medical cause for this is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), where you are briefly stopping breathing all night, which forces your brain into a lighter stage of sleep. Other causes include restless legs syndrome (RLS) or periodic limb movements, which are fragmenting your sleep without you knowing it.

faqs.question: I'm so wired at night that I can't fall asleep for hours, and then I can't wake up in the morning. Is this insomnia?
faqs.answer: This sounds less like typical insomnia and more like a circadian rhythm disorder, specifically Delayed Sleep Phase Syndrome (DSPS). This is a body clock problem. Your internal clock is shifted later, so your body doesn't produce melatonin or feel sleepy until 2 or 3 a.m. This is very common in adolescents and young adults. Treatment involves chronotherapy, like strict sleep schedules, bright light therapy in the morning, and sometimes low-dose melatonin taken in the evening (not at bedtime) to pull your clock earlier.

faqs.question: I get an irresistible creepy-crawly feeling in my legs, but only at night when I'm trying to rest. The only thing that helps is getting up and walking. Am I going crazy?
faqs.answer: You are not going crazy. This is a perfect description of Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS). It's a neurological disorder characterized by an uncontrollable urge to move the legs, typically at night, which is temporarily relieved by movement. It's a major cause of insomnia because it's impossible to fall asleep. It is often linked to iron deficiency (even without anemia), so your doctor should check your ferritin (iron storage) levels.

faqs.question: I keep falling asleep in the middle of the day, sometimes even in the middle of a conversation. I'm not just tired, I'm sleepy. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS), and it's a major red flag for a sleep disorder. The most common cause is severe sleep apnea or narcolepsy. Narcolepsy is a neurological disorder where the brain cannot regulate sleep-wake cycles. Its classic symptom is sleep attacks (overwhelming sleepiness) and sometimes cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness triggered by strong emotion, like laughter). You need a formal sleep study immediately.

faqs.question: My wife says I'm snoring, and she's terrified because I stop breathing for 10-15 seconds and then gasp for air. I feel fine, but should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the cardinal sign of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The snoring is the sound of a narrowed airway; the silence is the moment your airway has completely collapsed and you are not breathing (an apnea). The gasp is your brain's panic response, partially waking you to take a breath. You may feel fine, but this is happening dozens or hundreds of times a night, fragmenting your sleep and, more importantly, dropping your blood oxygen levels, which puts an enormous strain on your heart and brain.

faqs.question: I hate my CPAP machine. The mask leaks, it dries out my nose, and I feel claustrophobic. Are there any alternatives?
faqs.answer: This is an extremely common complaint. First, many CPAP problems are fixable (a different mask style—like nasal pillows, a heated humidifier for dryness, or a ramp feature). But if you truly can't tolerate it, yes, there are alternatives. For mild-to-moderate apnea, a mandibular advancement splint (a custom dental appliance) that pulls your lower jaw forward can be very effective. Other options include positional therapy (keeping you off your back), surgical procedures (like UPPP), or newer treatments like hypoglossal nerve stimulation (Inspire).

faqs.question: My sleep doctor said I have central sleep apnea, not obstructive. What's the difference? CPAP isn't working.
faqs.answer: This is a key difference. Obstructive apnea is a plumbing problem: your throat is physically collapsing. Central apnea is a neurological problem: your brain is forgetting to send the signal to your diaphragm to breathe. This is why a regular CPAP might not work; it's holding your airway open, but your brain still isn't sending the breathe signal. Central apnea is often related to heart failure or opioid use, and it requires a different kind of machine, like a BiPAP or ASV (Adaptive Servo-Ventilation), which can prompt you to take a breath.

faqs.question: I'm not overweight, but I was diagnosed with sleep apnea. How is that possible?
faqs.answer: While excess weight (especially around the neck) is the #1 risk factor, it is not the only cause. Apnea is a problem of anatomy. You can be thin and still have bad anatomy for breathing. This includes having a retrognathic jaw (a lower jaw that is set back), a large tongue, large tonsils, or a narrow, high-arched palate. These structural issues can create a small airway that is prone to collapse, regardless of your weight.

faqs.question: My doctor says my skull base tumor is benign, so why are they recommending risky brain surgery?
faqs.answer: This is a great question. In this location, benign (not cancer) does not mean harmless. The skull base is an incredibly crowded and complex area. Even a slow-growing, benign tumor (like a meningioma) can press on critical nerves and the brainstem, causing serious problems like vision loss, hearing loss, or trouble swallowing. The surgery is risky because of the location, but the goal is to remove the tumor before it causes permanent, irreversible neurological damage.

faqs.question: I'm having vision problems and I've lost my sense of smell. How can a tumor be causing both?
faqs.answer: This combination of symptoms strongly points to a tumor in the anterior (front) part of the skull base, often an olfactory groove meningioma or a pituitary adenoma. The tumor is growing in the area right behind your eyes and nose, putting pressure on both the optic nerves (which control vision) and the olfactory nerves (which control smell) at the same time.

faqs.question: My surgeon wants to remove my pituitary tumor through my nose. How is that even possible?
faqs.answer: This is a modern, minimally invasive technique called the endoscopic endonasal approach. Your pituitary gland sits in a small, bony saddle (the sella turcica) that is located at the very back of your sinus cavity. Surgeons can pass a tiny, high-definition camera (an endoscope) and specialized tools through your nostrils to reach this area and remove the tumor, without making any external incisions or having to go through the brain itself.

faqs.question: They're recommending Proton Beam Therapy instead of regular radiation. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: Proton beam therapy is a very precise, advanced form of radiation. A standard X-ray (photon) beam enters the body, hits the tumor, but then continues through the body, exiting out the other side and hitting healthy tissue. A proton beam is different. It can be programmed to travel to an exact depth (the tumor) and stop, depositing almost all its energy there, with virtually no exit dose. This is critical in the skull base to protect vital structures like your eyes, brainstem, and hearing nerves.

faqs.question: The tumor is a vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma). They gave me the options of watchful waiting, radiation, or surgery. How do I choose?
faqs.answer: This is a common and difficult choice. 1) Watchful waiting is often for small, slow-growing tumors in older patients, where the risks of treatment outweigh the benefits. 2) Radiation (like Gamma Knife) is very good at stopping the tumor from growing, but it doesn't remove it and is best for smaller tumors. 3) Surgery is the only option that removes the tumor but has a higher risk of immediate facial weakness or total hearing loss. The choice depends on your age, your current hearing, the tumor's size, and your personal goals (e.g., preserving hearing vs. definitive removal).

faqs.question: I have this small, pearly, waxy-looking bump on my nose. It sometimes bleeds and scabs over, but never fully heals. I thought cancer was supposed to be dark?
faqs.answer: That is a classic description of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), which is the most common type of skin cancer. You're right that melanoma is dark, but BCCs and Squamous Cell Carcinomas (SCCs) are often pink, red, or skin-colored. The key warning sign you're seeing is the non-healing sore that bleeds easily. It needs to be biopsied.

faqs.question: My dermatologist wants to do Mohs surgery for the skin cancer on my ear. Why is this better than just cutting it out?
faqs.answer: Mohs surgery is the gold standard for cancers on the face, ears, hands, and other cosmetically sensitive areas. In a normal excision, the surgeon cuts it out and hopes the margins are clear. In Mohs, the surgeon removes a thin layer, immediately checks 100% of the margins under a microscope while you wait, and if any roots are left, they go back and take only that tiny spot. This gives the highest possible cure rate while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue.

faqs.question: I've had a mole my whole life, but it's suddenly become itchy, and the edges look blurry or smeared. Is this a sign of melanoma?
faqs.answer: Yes, any change in an existing mole is a major warning sign for melanoma. Remember the ABCDEs: Asymmetry (one half doesn't match the other), Border (irregular, scalloped, or blurry), Color (multiple colors like black, brown, red, or blue), Diameter (larger than a pencil eraser), and Evolving (any change in size, shape, color, or symptoms like itching/bleeding). An evolving or itchy mole needs to be seen by a dermatologist immediately.

faqs.question: I'm Black, and I found a dark, new stripe under my toenail that is spreading to the cuticle. I thought dark-skinned people didn't get melanoma?
faqs.answer: This is a dangerous myth. While people with more melanin have less risk of sun-related melanomas, they can (and do) get a specific type called Acral Lentiginous Melanoma. This type is not related to sun exposure and appears on the palms of the hands, the soles of the feet, or under the nails (as you described, called Hutchinson's sign). This is a very serious warning sign and needs to be biopsied urgently.

faqs.question: My biopsy came back as squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen's disease). How serious is this?
faqs.answer: In situ means in place. This is the earliest possible stage of squamous cell carcinoma, where the cancer cells are confined only to the very top layer of the skin (the epidermis) and have not invaded deeper. This is excellent news, as it means the cancer is not dangerous and is 100% curable with a simple removal procedure.

faqs.question: My eyes and mouth are incredibly dry, so my doctor ran blood tests and is sending me to a rheumatologist. How is dry eye an arthritis problem?
faqs.answer: That's because Sjogren's is a systemic autoimmune disease, not just a dryness problem. Your immune system is mistakenly attacking your own moisture-producing glands (tear and salivary). This same immune-system attack can also target other parts of your body, most commonly your joints, causing inflammation and pain very similar to rheumatoid arthritis. A rheumatologist specializes in these types of systemic autoimmune conditions.

faqs.question: My blood test was positive for SS-A and SS-B antibodies. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: SS-A (or Ro) and SS-B (or La) are autoantibodies—proteins made by your immune system that are specifically known to attack your own cells. Finding these antibodies in your blood is highly characteristic of Sjogren's syndrome and helps confirm the diagnosis. The SS-A antibody is also important as it can be associated with a higher risk of systemic symptoms (like lung or kidney issues) and can cause complications in pregnancy.

faqs.question: Honestly, the dry mouth is annoying, but the fatigue and brain fog are what's ruining my life. Is that really part of Sjogren's?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is one of the most common and debilitating systemic (whole-body) symptoms of Sjogren's. The profound, overwhelming fatigue and cognitive brain fog are not from the dryness. They are caused by the body-wide inflammation and the high levels of cytokines (inflammatory messenger proteins) that are part of the autoimmune attack. You are not lazy or crazy—it's a very real and primary part of the disease.

faqs.question: My doctor told me having Sjogren's means I have a higher risk of lymphoma. This is terrifying. How high is the risk really?
faqs.answer: It is very important to put this in perspective. While the relative risk is higher compared to the general population (meaning you are more likely to get it than someone without Sjogren's), the absolute risk is still very low. Only about 5-10% of Sjogren's patients ever develop lymphoma. Your doctor tells you this so you are aware of the warning signs (like new, persistent, swollen lymph nodes, fever, or night sweats) and report them, as it's highly treatable when caught early.

faqs.question: Can Sjogren's affect anything else? I've been having shortness of breath.
faqs.answer: Yes, it is a systemic disease. While joints are the most common non-glandular target, it can also affect the lungs (causing dryness, inflammation, or interstitial lung disease), kidneys (causing inflammation), nerves (causing neuropathy), and skin (causing dryness and rashes). You should absolutely report any new shortness of breath to your rheumatologist, as it could be a sign of lung involvement.

faqs.question: I get a horrible headache with pressure in my cheeks and forehead every time the weather changes or my allergies flare up. Is this a sinus headache?
faqs.answer: This is a very common complaint, but studies show that over 80% of people who think they have recurrent sinus headaches are actually experiencing migraines. A key difference is that migraines often come with other symptoms, like nausea or sensitivity to light and sound. If you get sinus headaches that are moderate-to-severe and happen regularly, you should be evaluated for migraines.

faqs.question: When is my sinus headache an actual sinus infection (sinusitis) that needs antibiotics?
faqs.answer: A true bacterial sinus infection has other, more specific symptoms, not just head pressure. You should suspect an infection if your symptoms last for more than 10 days without improving, or if you have thick, discolored (green or yellow) nasal discharge, a fever, pain in your upper teeth, and a feeling of facial fullness that is worse when you bend forward.

faqs.question: My sinus headache is only on one side of my face, it's severe, and it's making me nauseous. Why did my doctor give me migraine medicine for this?
faqs.answer: Because those symptoms—one-sided pain (unilateral) and nausea—are classic hallmarks of a migraine, not a typical sinus headache. Migraines can (and often do) cause pain and pressure in the sinus areas by activating the trigeminal nerve, which has endings in your face. If over-the-counter sinus meds (like Sudafed) don't work, but a migraine drug (like a triptan) does, that's a strong sign it was a migraine all along.

faqs.question: My CT scan of my sinuses was totally clear, but my face still hurts and feels full. What else could it be?
faqs.answer: A clear CT scan rules out chronic sinusitis. This means your pain is almost certainly not coming from your sinuses. The most likely causes are: 1) Migraine (as discussed). 2) Tension headache, which can cause a band-like pressure. 3) Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder, where clenching your jaw can refer pain to your cheeks and temples. 4) Trigeminal neuralgia, a nerve problem that causes sharp, electric-shock pain (less common).

faqs.question: My blood test showed I have sickle cell trait. Does this mean I have the disease? Will I get pain crises?
faqs.answer: No. Having sickle cell trait (SCT) means you are a carrier. You have one sickle gene and one normal gene. You do not have sickle cell disease (also called sickle cell anemia, or SS), which requires two sickle genes. People with trait almost never have pain crises or any symptoms of the disease. The only time it might cause issues is under extreme physical duress, like at very high altitude or during military boot camp. It is important for family planning, as you can pass the trait to your children.

faqs.question: What exactly is a pain crisis? My son has sickle cell, and he says it feels like his bones are breaking.
faqs.answer: That's a very accurate description. A pain crisis (or vaso-occlusive crisis) is the hallmark of the disease. It happens when the C-shaped sickle cells, which are hard and sticky, get stuck in small blood vessels. This creates a logjam that blocks blood flow. The tissues and organs downstream (especially in the bones, chest, and back) are starved of oxygen, which causes intense, throbbing pain, much like a heart attack in the bone. It is a true medical emergency.

faqs.question: What is acute chest syndrome? My daughter was admitted for a pain crisis, and now they're saying she has this and moving her to the ICU.
faqs.answer: Acute chest syndrome is a life-threatening complication and the leading cause of death for people with sickle cell disease. It's when a sickle cell logjam (like the one that causes a pain crisis) happens in the blood vessels of the lungs. This causes a new infiltrate on the chest X-ray, and the patient develops fever, chest pain, and a dangerously low oxygen level. It requires immediate, aggressive treatment, often including blood transfusions.

faqs.question: My doctor wants my child to start Hydroxyurea. I looked it up, and it's a chemotherapy drug. Why would you give that to a child for a blood disorder?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and understandable concern. Hydroxyurea is a chemo drug only at very high doses. At the very low, daily doses used for sickle cell, it works in a completely different and brilliant way. It tricks the bone marrow into producing more fetal hemoglobin (HbF)—the type of hemoglobin babies have. Fetal hemoglobin blocks the sickling process. It makes the red blood cells rounder, more flexible, and less sticky, leading to dramatically fewer pain crises and fewer episodes of acute chest syndrome.

faqs.question: When I go to the ER for a pain crisis, I'm terrified the staff will think I'm a drug seeker just trying to get narcotics. How should I handle this?
faqs.answer: This is a real and devastating problem for many with sickle cell. The best strategy is to be prepared. Have a pain plan or letter from your hematologist (your sickle cell specialist) that explains your diagnosis, your usual medications, and what works for you during a crisis. Present this calmly to the ER staff. Use I statements (I am in a sickle cell crisis, My pain level is a 9/10) rather than demanding a specific drug (I need Dilaudid right now).

faqs.question: I'm 70, and I've been getting very dizzy and lightheaded. My heart rate is sometimes really slow (in the 40s), but other times it suddenly races. My doctor says I have sick sinus syndrome?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic presentation. Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) means your heart's natural pacemaker (the sinus node) is getting old and not working reliably. It can fail to send out signals (causing a slow rate, or bradycardia), or it can get out of sync and let other, faster rhythms take over (like atrial fibrillation, or tachycardia). This combination of slow-and-fast is very common and is nicknamed tachy-brady syndrome.

faqs.question: My doctor says I need a pacemaker. Will that fix both the slow and the fast heart rates?
faqs.answer: This is a great question. The pacemaker only fixes the slow heart rate. It acts as a backstop—if your heart tries to beat too slowly, the pacemaker kicks in and keeps it at a safe, normal rate (e.g., 60 bpm). This allows your doctor to then safely treat your fast heart rate (the tachycardia) with medications (like beta-blockers). Without a pacemaker, those same medications would make your slow heart rate dangerously slow, so the pacemaker is the safety net that lets them treat the whole problem.

faqs.question: If my heart's natural pacemaker is failing, can't they just fix it instead of putting in an artificial one?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, no. Sick sinus syndrome is a disease of the wiring. The sinus node tissue itself is typically damaged by age-related scarring and fibrosis (hardening). This damage is microscopic and irreversible. There is no medication or procedure that can rejuvenate or fix this old tissue, which is why the only effective treatment for the symptoms (like fainting) is to bypass the problem with an artificial pacemaker that provides a new, reliable signal.

faqs.question: Is this a dangerous, life-threatening condition? I'm scared my heart will just stop.
faqs.answer: While it sounds terrifying, SSS is generally not immediately life-threatening. It's a very, very slow-progressing disease. The main danger is not from the heart suddenly stopping, but from the symptoms it causes—specifically, fainting (syncope) from a very slow heart rate, falling, and getting seriously injured (like a head injury or a broken hip). The pacemaker is put in to prevent these spells and improve your quality of life.

faqs.question: I had to have a large part of my small intestine removed (due to Crohn's). Now I have constant, watery diarrhea, and I'm losing weight. Is this short bowel?
faqs.answer: Yes, that is the definition of short bowel syndrome (SBS). Your small intestine is where you absorb almost all your nutrients and water. When a significant portion is removed, your body no longer has enough surface area to absorb what you eat and drink, leading to severe chronic diarrhea, dehydration, malnutrition, and weight loss, even if you are eating a lot of food.

faqs.question: My doctor said I'm not absorbing nutrients and wants to start TPN. Does this mean I'll be fed through an IV forever?
faqs.answer: TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) is a life-saving liquid nutrition given directly into a large vein, completely bypassing your gut. It may not be forever. It's often used as a bridge to let your remaining intestine rest and adapt. Over time, your doctor will work with you to slowly re-introduce special foods and liquids, and the goal is to reduce the TPN as your gut learns to absorb more.

faqs.question: Can my remaining intestine adapt and learn to absorb more?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the most important part of long-term recovery. It's a process called intestinal adaptation. Over a period of one to two years, the remaining intestine (especially the ileum) will slowly and structurally change. The tiny, finger-like villi that line the gut will get longer and thicker, dramatically increasing their surface area to try and compensate for the missing part. This process is complex but is the key to eventually getting off TPN.

faqs.question: They told me my ileum and ileocecal valve were removed and that this is a bigger problem. Why do those specific parts matter so much?
faqs.answer: Those are the most critical parts of the small intestine. The ileum (the final section) is the only place your body can absorb Vitamin B12 and bile acids (which are needed to digest fats). The ileocecal valve is the gateway between the (mostly sterile) small intestine and the (bacteria-filled) large intestine. Losing this valve allows bacteria to backwash into the small intestine, causing SIBO (Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth), which leads to even more malabsorption, gas, and bloating.

faqs.question: I have this incredibly painful, blistering rash in a band on one side of my chest. It doesn't cross the middle. Could this be shingles?
faqs.answer: That is the textbook description of shingles (herpes zoster). The virus (which also causes chickenpox) lies dormant in a single nerve root by your spine. When it reactivates, it travels down that one nerve, causing the rash only in the dermatome (the strip of skin) that nerve controls. This is why it almost never crosses the midline of your body and appears as a one-sided band.

faqs.question: I'm only 38. I thought shingles was an old person's disease? How could I get it?
faqs.answer: While the risk increases with age, anyone who has had chickenpox (even a mild case) can get shingles. The virus is reactivated when your immune system is distracted or weakened. In younger people, this is almost always triggered by a period of extreme stress, lack of sleep, a bad cold, or other physical or emotional duress that temporarily lowers your immune defenses.

faqs.question: My rash is on my forehead and near my eye. My doctor seemed very worried and sent me to an eye doctor immediately. Why is it so dangerous there?
faqs.answer: This is called herpes zoster ophthalmicus and is a medical emergency. The nerve that the virus is traveling down is the trigeminal nerve, which controls sensation for your face and your cornea (the front of your eye). The virus can cause a shingles rash on your cornea, leading to severe inflammation, scarring, and permanent vision loss or blindness. You need to be on antiviral pills and be seen by an ophthalmologist.

faqs.question: The rash and blisters are gone, but it's been 3 months, and the skin still burns and aches. The slightest touch from my shirt is unbearable. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the most feared complication of shingles, called Postherpetic Neuralgia (PHN). The shingles rash is gone, but the virus has damaged the nerve itself. The nerve is now misfiring and sending continuous, false pain signals to your brain. This nerve pain is notoriously difficult to treat and requires different medications (like gabapentin, pregabalin, or certain antidepressants) than a typical rash.

faqs.question: I have the shingles vaccine (Shingrix) on my calendar, but I'm healthy and I'm only 52. Is it really worth it?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. The CDC recommends Shingrix for all healthy adults 50 and older. The reason is that PHN (the chronic, burning nerve pain) is so debilitating and common, and the risk of getting it increases with age. The Shingrix vaccine is over 90% effective at preventing both the initial shingles rash and, most importantly, the long-term PHN.

faqs.question: I'm a new runner, and the inner, lower half of my shins is killing me. How do I know if it's shin splints or a more serious stress fracture?
faqs.answer: There are two main ways to tell. 1) The pain area: Shin splints (Medial Tibial Stress Syndrome) typically cause a general, dull ache over a larger area (a few inches) along the shin bone. A stress fracture is a tiny crack in the bone, and the pain is focal—you can usually point to one specific spot, the size of a fingertip, that is exquisitely tender. 2) The pain behavior: Shin splint pain is often bad at the start of a run, may fade as you warm up, and then returns after. Stress fracture pain starts mild and gets worse and worse as you run, and it often hurts to just walk around.

faqs.question: I've rested for two weeks, iced it, and as soon as I tried to run, the shin splints came right back. What am I doing wrong?
faqs.answer: This is a classic training error. Shin splints are an overuse injury from too much, too soon. Resting lets the inflammation cool down, but it doesn't fix the reason you got them. The most common cause is increasing your mileage or intensity too quickly. You have to return very gradually, and you also need to address the underlying cause, which is often weak hip/glute muscles or poor foot mechanics.

faqs.question: My physical therapist said my overpronation (flat feet) is causing my shin splints. How is my foot causing shin pain?
faqs.answer: Pronation is the natural inward rolling of your foot when you run. Overpronation means your foot rolls too far inward. This causes your entire lower leg, including your tibia (shin bone), to rotate inward too much. The tibialis posterior muscle, which runs along your inner shin, has to work overtime on every single step to try and pull your foot back and control this collapse. The shin splints are the pain from this muscle being chronically overworked and inflamed.

faqs.question: Can I just run through the pain? Will it go away on its own if I keep going?
faqs.answer: This is a very bad idea. Shin splints are the first warning sign of a bone-stress injury. The pain is from the muscle pulling on the bone, causing inflammation. If you keep running through that pain, you are not giving the bone a chance to repair. This inflammatory process will eventually lead to a full-blown stress fracture in the bone, which will force you to stop running completely for 6-8 weeks.

faqs.question: I have explosive, watery diarrhea that has turned bloody, and I have a high fever and stomach cramps. How is this different from E. coli or Salmonella?
faqs.answer: While all three cause food poisoning, that specific combination—especially the bloody diarrhea (dysentery) and high fever—is the hallmark of Shigella. Shigella is an invasive bacterium; it doesn't just irritate the gut, it actually invades and destroys the cells of the intestinal lining, which is what causes the blood and pus in the stool. It also takes a very small number of bacteria to make you sick, making it extremely contagious.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to just drink fluids and not to take anti-diarrhea medicine (like Imodium). Why can't I stop the diarrhea?
faqs.answer: This is critical advice. The diarrhea is your body's main defense mechanism for physically flushing the invasive, toxin-producing bacteria out of your system. If you take a medicine like Imodium (loperamide), you paralyze the gut. This traps the bacteria inside your intestines, giving them more time to multiply and invade the gut wall, which can make the infection much more severe and last longer.

faqs.question: My son's daycare said he has a Shigella infection. How does this spread so easily in a daycare setting?
faqs.answer: Shigella is spread through the fecal-oral route and is incredibly contagious—it can take as few as 10-100 bacteria to cause an infection. In a daycare, this is a perfect storm. It spreads rapidly through: 1) Staff changing an infected baby's diaper and not washing their hands perfectly before touching another child or a toy. 2) Toddlers who are not good at handwashing. 3) Any surfaces (like changing tables) that are not properly disinfected.

faqs.question: How can I tell if I'm dehydrated enough to need to go to the hospital?
faqs.answer: With shigellosis, you are losing a lot of fluid and electrolytes. The key danger signs of severe dehydration that require an IV are: inability to keep any liquids down (vomiting everything), feeling very dizzy, lightheaded, or woozy when you stand up, not urinating, or only producing a very small amount of dark, concentrated urine, and a rapid, thready pulse. If you are experiencing these, you should go to an ER.

faqs.question: I've eaten shrimp my whole life, and I'm 40. How can I suddenly develop a severe shellfish allergy as an adult?
faqs.answer: This is a key feature of shellfish allergy: it is the most common food allergy to develop in adulthood. Unlike peanut or milk allergies, which usually start in childhood, shellfish allergy often appears out of the blue in your 20s, 30s, or 40s. The reason is not fully understood, but your immune system can one day misidentify a protein in shellfish (tropomyosin) as a threat, and from that point on, you will have an allergic reaction.

faqs.question: I'm allergic to shrimp (a crustacean). Does this mean I am also allergic to scallops and clams (mollusks)?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily, but you need to be cautious. The allergy is class-specific. Crustaceans (like shrimp, crab, and lobster) share one set of allergenic proteins. Mollusks (like clams, scallops, oysters, and mussels) share a different set. Many people are allergic to one group but not the other. However, there is some cross-reactivity, so an allergist would likely recommend avoiding all shellfish until you can be properly tested.

faqs.question: I'm allergic to shellfish. My doctor wants me to get a CT scan with contrast. Isn't that made of iodine, which is in shellfish? Will I have a reaction?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and persistent myth. You are not allergic to iodine. A shellfish allergy is a reaction to a protein (tropomyosin) in the animal's muscle. It has absolutely nothing to do with iodine. The idea that shellfish and iodine contrast dye are related has been thoroughly disproven. You can safely receive IV contrast dye; just be sure to tell your doctor about your allergy history in general, not specifically the shellfish.

faqs.question: I was at a hibachi restaurant and the steam from the shrimp being cooked on the grill made my lips tingle and my throat itch. Is an airborne reaction real?
faqs.answer: Yes. For a highly sensitized person, this is a very real danger. The allergy-causing proteins in shellfish are heat-stable (not destroyed by cooking) and can be aerosolized in the steam. When you inhale these tiny protein particles, they can trigger an allergic reaction (like tingling, itching, or even asthma) just from breathing the air. This is why people with severe shellfish allergies must avoid places where it is being cooked.

faqs.question: Why is shaking a baby so much worse than bouncing them on my knee or an accidental fall? What's the difference?
faqs.answer: A baby's head is very large and heavy, and their neck muscles are extremely weak. Bouncing or a simple fall is a single-impact event. Shaking is a violent acceleration-deceleration injury. The head whips back and forth, causing the baby's brain to slam against the inside of the skull repeatedly. This rotational force shears and tears blood vessels (causing subdural hematomas) and nerve fibers in a way that a simple fall almost never does.

faqs.question: The doctor said my baby has retinal hemorrhages. How does shaking cause bleeding in the eyes?
faqs.answer: The same violent, back-and-forth whipping motion that causes the brain to slam against the skull also causes the vitreous (the jelly inside the eyeball) to slam back and forth. This pulls on the very delicate layers of the retina at the back of the eye, ripping the tiny blood vessels there. Widespread retinal hemorrhages are one of the classic triad of symptoms (along with brain swelling and subdural hematomas) that are highly specific to this kind of abusive head trauma.

faqs.question: My baby fell off the couch and has a skull fracture. Does this mean the hospital will think I shook him?
faqs.answer: This is a valid concern. Medical teams are trained to look for patterns. An accidental short fall (like from a couch) can cause a simple, linear skull fracture. What doctors look for in abuse are injuries that don't match the story. Shaken baby syndrome (or abusive head trauma) rarely causes a skull fracture; its classic signs are the internal injuries (brain bleeding, eye bleeding) from the rotational force, often without any external sign of trauma.

faqs.question: What are the long-term effects? If a baby survives, will they be normal?
faqs.answer: The prognosis is often devastating. The tearing of nerve fibers and brain bleeding can lead to a wide range of permanent disabilities. This includes cerebral palsy (loss of motor control), blindness (from the retinal damage), deafness, severe cognitive and learning disabilities, and a lifelong seizure disorder. Even in milder cases, the child may have significant behavioral and learning problems that are not apparent until they start school.

faqs.question: I'm a new dad, and my baby will not stop crying. I'm so frustrated and tired I'm scared I'll lose it. What do I do?
faqs.answer: This is a critical moment, and recognizing your frustration is the most important step. It is okay to walk away. If you have checked that the baby is fed, dry, and not in pain, and you are at your breaking point: 1) Put the baby safely in their crib on their back. 2) Walk out of the room, close the door, and take 10 minutes to breathe, call a friend, or listen to music. 3) Never, ever shake or toss a baby, no matter how frustrated you are. The crying is normal; the shaking is fatal. Call a parenting helpline if you feel overwhelmed.

faqs.question: I don't have any symptoms, but my new partner wants me to get tested. What does a full STD panel actually check for?
faqs.answer: This is a great question, as full panel means different things. A comprehensive panel should, at a minimum, include: 1) Blood tests for HIV, syphilis, and Hepatitis B & C. 2) A urine test for gonorrhea and chlamydia. 3) A physical exam and blood test for herpes (HSV-1/HSV-2). Note: There is no screening test for HPV in men, and in women, it's typically done with a Pap smear.

faqs.question: How long after a potential exposure should I wait to get tested for HIV for the result to be accurate?
faqs.answer: This is called the window period. The test accuracy depends on the type of test. 1) An Antibody/Antigen (4th Gen) Test, which is the standard lab blood test, is conclusive after 45 days (about 6 weeks). 2) A Rapid (Antibody) Test (finger prick) can take longer to be accurate, so a negative result is considered conclusive at 90 days (3 months). 3) A NAT test can detect the virus itself as early as 10-30 days but is very expensive and not used for routine screening.

faqs.question: My partner just tested positive for HPV, but I feel fine. What does this mean for me? Will I have it forever?
faqs.answer: HPV is the most common STD, and nearly every sexually active person will get it at some point. If your partner has it, you almost certainly have been exposed. The good news is that for over 90% of people (men and women), their immune system clears the virus on its own within 1-2 years. You will likely never have a symptom. The problem is the 10% of cases where the virus persists and can, over many years, cause cell changes that lead to cancer (cervical, anal, throat) or warts.

faqs.question: I've only had oral sex. Can I still get an STD?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Many STDs are transmitted very effectively through oral sex (giving or receiving). This includes: Herpes (HSV-1, or oral herpes, is a very common cause of genital herpes through oral sex), Syphilis (can cause a chancre in the mouth/throat), Gonorrhea (can cause throat gonorrhea), HPV (a leading cause of throat cancer), and HIV (low risk, but possible).

faqs.question: My screening test for herpes (HSV-2) came back positive, but I've never had a single symptom. Could this be a false positive?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a major problem with herpes blood tests (IgG tests). These tests, especially at the low-positive level (e.g., an index value between 1.1 and 3.5), have a very high rate of being false positives. They are detecting an antibody that looks like herpes but isn't. You should not accept this as a diagnosis. The gold standard is a Western Blot blood test, which is much more specific and can confirm or deny the first test.

faqs.question: Right at the moment of orgasm, I get an explosive, thunderclap headache. It's the worst pain I've ever felt. Am I having a stroke or an aneurysm?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of a primary sexual headache (or orgasmic headache). While it is terrifying, in most cases it is benign (harmless). However, because a thunderclap headache is also the #1 warning sign of a ruptured brain aneurysm (a subarachnoid hemorrhage), you must go to the emergency room immediately the first time this happens. They will need to do a CT scan and possibly a spinal tap to rule out a life-threatening bleed.

faqs.question: My headache is different. It's a dull, aching pain in my head and neck that builds up with sexual excitement. Is this the same thing?
faqs.answer: This is the other type of primary sexual headache, called a pre-orgasmic headache. It's thought to be caused by the progressive tensing of the neck and jaw muscles during arousal. It's considered benign and is a different mechanism from the explosive thunderclap headache.

faqs.question: My brain scan was clear and my doctor said it's benign. I'm so scared it will happen again that I'm avoiding sex. How can I prevent it?
faqs.answer: This is very common. The fear of the pain is a major issue. For prevention: 1) Some people find that taking an over-the-counter pain reliever (like Indomethacin or an NSAID) an hour before sexual activity can prevent it. 2) If they happen frequently, your doctor may prescribe a daily preventative medicine, like a beta-blocker (propranolol), which lowers blood pressure and is very effective.

faqs.question: Why does this even happen? Is it a blood pressure thing?
faqs.answer: The exact cause isn't known. The dull type is from muscle tension. The explosive (orgasmic) type is thought to be a vascular issue—a rapid, temporary vasospasm (clamping down) and then rebound dilation (opening up) of blood vessels in the brain, triggered by the sudden spike in blood pressure and heart rate that happens at orgasm.

faqs.question: I'm confused. I thought SARS was that disease from 2003. Is it the same as COVID-19?
faqs.answer: They are in the same family, but they are not the same. Think of them as cousins. The 2003 outbreak was caused by a virus called SARS-CoV-1. The current pandemic (COVID-19) is caused by a different virus, SARS-CoV-2. Both are coronaviruses, and both likely originated in bats. The name SARS-CoV-2 was chosen because it is so genetically similar to the original 2003 virus.

faqs.question: Was the original SARS (2003) more or less deadly than COVID-19?
faqs.answer: The original SARS-CoV-1 was significantly more deadly. It had a much higher case fatality rate (CFR) of about 10-15% (meaning 1 in 10 infected people died). COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) is less deadly, with a much lower CFR (well under 1% in most places now), but it is dramatically more infectious and spreads far more easily.

faqs.question: If SARS-1 was so deadly, how did it just disappear in 2003, while COVID-19 spread everywhere?
faqs.answer: This is the most critical difference between the two viruses. SARS-CoV-1 was only contagious when a person was already very sick (had a high fever and symptoms). This made it easy to control with simple, old-fashioned public health measures: fever screening at airports, and contact tracing and quarantine of sick people. It was contained. COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) is the opposite: it spreads before you have symptoms (pre-symptomatic and asymptomatic spread), making it impossible to contain.

faqs.question: What were the symptoms of the 2003 SARS? Was it like a cold?
faqs.answer: No, it was much more severe than a cold. It almost always started with a high fever (over 100.4°F or 38°C). This was followed a few days later by a dry cough, shortness of breath, and severe body aches (myalgia). It quickly progressed to pneumonia, and many patients developed Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) and required a ventilator.

faqs.question: Where did the original SARS come from?
faqs.answer: It was traced to civet cats (a small mammal) being sold in live-animal wet markets in Guangdong, China. It is believed the virus jumped from a bat (its natural host) to the civet cat, and then from the civet cat to the first human handlers, kicking off the 2003 outbreak.

faqs.question: I just started an antidepressant (an SSRI) two weeks ago, and my doctor also just gave me a migraine medicine (a triptan). Now I feel really agitated, I'm sweating, and my heart is racing. Is this serotonin syndrome?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a very real possibility and you should call your doctor or pharmacist immediately. Mixing an SSRI/SNRI with a triptan is one of the most common ways to trigger serotonin syndrome. You have two medications that are both increasing your serotonin levels, and it may be overloading your system. The agitation, sweating (diaphoresis), and racing heart (tachycardia) are classic early warning signs.

faqs.question: Can I get this just from taking one drug, or does it only happen when you mix them?
faqs.answer: It can happen from a single drug, but it's rare and usually only happens in cases of an intentional or accidental overdose of one serotonergic drug (like an SSRI). The vast majority of cases are like yours—they happen when you combine two or more drugs that all affect serotonin (e.g., an SSRI + a triptan + a cough medicine with Dextromethorphan + St. John's Wort).

faqs.question: What's the difference between this and just normal side effects? My doctor said I might feel agitated when I started my SSRI.
faqs.answer: This is about degree and combination. Normal start-up side effects are usually mild and fade over time (e.g., mild jitteriness). Serotonin syndrome is a toxic state that gets worse. The key red flags that point to the syndrome and not just side effects are the combination of mental changes (agitation, confusion), autonomic changes (sweating, fever, racing heart, large pupils), and neuromuscular changes (muscle twitching, tremors, and especially clonus—a rhythmic, tapping foot when your doctor checks your reflexes).

faqs.question: My doctor said I have clonus in my leg. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Clonus is a key diagnostic sign of serotonin syndrome. It's a type of involuntary, rhythmic muscle spasm. Your doctor likely had you relax your leg and then quickly flexed your foot upward. In a person with serotonin syndrome, this will often trigger the foot to beat or tap rhythmically on its own. It's a sign of hyperactive reflexes caused by the serotonin overload.

faqs.question: If I have this, am I in danger? How quickly does it go away?
faqs.answer: A mild case is not dangerous if it's caught. A severe, untreated case can progress to high fever, seizures, and death, so it is taken very seriously. The good news is that for mild-to-moderate cases, the treatment is simple: stop the offending medications. The syndrome resolves very quickly, almost always within 24-48 hours of stopping the drugs, as your body clears the excess serotonin.

faqs.question: I woke up and my knee is incredibly swollen, bright red, hot to the touch, and I can't put any weight on it. I also have a fever. Is this just a bad arthritis flare-up?
faqs.answer: No, this is a medical emergency. A single, hot, swollen joint that you cannot move or bear weight on, especially with a fever, is septic arthritis (an infected joint) until proven otherwise. A normal arthritis flare-up does not typically cause a high fever or this level of acute pain. You need to go to an emergency room immediately.

faqs.question: I'm in the ER, and they want to stick a huge needle in my knee right now to drain it. Why the hurry?
faqs.answer: The hurry is because the pus inside your joint is toxic. Pus is full of bacteria and enzymes from your own white blood cells. This toxic soup starts to digest and destroy your cartilage (the smooth lining of the joint) within hours. Draining the joint (an arthrocentesis) is the only way to: 1) Relieve the pressure, 2) Get a fluid sample to confirm the diagnosis, and 3) Start washing the toxic material out. Any delay can lead to permanent joint destruction.

faqs.question: How did I even get an infection inside my knee joint? I don't have a cut on my leg.
faqs.answer: This is called hematogenous spread. It means you had a different infection somewhere else in your body (like a UTI, a skin boil, or even a dental infection) that got into your bloodstream. The bacteria then seeded or landed in your joint, which is a nutrient-rich area with no real immune defenses, and set up a new, major infection.

faqs.question: They said I need IV antibiotics and a surgical washout (I&D). Why isn't draining it once with a needle enough?
faqs.answer: A septic joint is an abscess in a closed space. The pus is often too thick to be fully removed by a needle. A surgical washout (or incision and drainage) is an operation where a surgeon goes into the joint (often with a camera) and power-washes the entire joint with sterile saline, flushing out all the bacteria, pus, and debris. This is far more effective. The IV antibiotics are crucial to kill the bacteria in your bloodstream and in the joint lining itself.

faqs.question: What happens if this isn't treated fast enough? What's the long-term damage?
faqs.answer: The long-term damage is severe, permanent osteoarthritis. As mentioned, the pus destroys the cartilage. If treatment is delayed by even a day or two, you can lose that smooth, protective lining. The repaired joint will be bone-on-bone (or bone-on-scar-tissue), leading to chronic pain, stiffness, and a high likelihood of needing a full joint replacement in the future.

faqs.question: My elderly mom had a simple UTI, and now she's in the ICU with sepsis and is very confused. How did this happen so fast?
faqs.answer: This is a classic and very dangerous progression, especially in the elderly. Sepsis is not just an infection. It is your body's overwhelming and life-threatening response to that infection. Her immune system, in trying to fight the UTI, has triggered a body-wide firestorm of inflammation. This inflammation causes leaky blood vessels, leading to a drop in blood pressure, and her organs (like her brain, causing the confusion) are not getting enough blood or oxygen.

faqs.question: The doctor keeps using the term septic shock. Is that different from sepsis?
faqs.answer: Yes. Think of it in stages. Infection is the bug (like the UTI). Sepsis is the body's overwhelming response to that bug. Septic Shock is the most severe, life-threatening stage of sepsis. It means the inflammation is so severe that your blood pressure has crashed to a dangerously low level, and it will not come back up even with large amounts of IV fluids. This is the stage where organs begin to shut down.

faqs.question: Why are they giving her pressors (like norepinephrine)? Her blood pressure is still low even after bags of IV fluids.
faqs.answer: This is the definition of septic shock. The body-wide inflammation has caused all her blood vessels to dilate (open up), so her blood pressure plummets. Pressors are powerful medications that are a last resort to chemically squeeze the blood vessels, which presses the blood pressure back up to a level that is high enough to pump blood to her brain and kidneys.

faqs.question: If my dad survives sepsis, will he just go back to normal?
faqs.answer: Not always. Surviving sepsis is a major, traumatic medical event. Many survivors (up to 50%) suffer from Post-Sepsis Syndrome. This is a long-term condition that can include severe fatigue, brain fog and cognitive difficulties, new joint or muscle pain, anxiety, and PTSD from the ICU experience. Recovery can be very slow, and he may have new, long-term health problems.

faqs.question: What are the early warning signs I can look for at home? How do I know if it's just a fever or sepsis?
faqs.answer: This is the key to survival. Look for a combination of symptoms. The acronym TIME is helpful: T - Temperature: Higher or lower than normal; I - Infection: Signs of an infection (like a cough, painful urination, or a red wound); M - Mental Decline: New confusion, sleepiness, or being difficult to wake up; and E - Extremely Ill: Severe I feel like I'm going to die feeling, severe pain, or shortness of breath. If you see these, especially the mental decline or extreme illness, it's a medical emergency.

faqs.question: My 8-year-old has a meltdown every morning before school, crying and saying he's sick. Is this just school refusal, or is it separation anxiety disorder?
faqs.answer: The two are very closely linked, but there's a key difference in the fear. School refusal is often a fear of something at school (like a bully, a test, or social anxiety). Separation Anxiety Disorder is a fear of what will happen to YOU (the parent/caregiver) while he is gone. A child with the disorder will have persistent, catastrophic fears that you will get in a car crash or get sick and die while they are at school. The stomach ache is a very real physical symptom of this intense panic.

faqs.question: My 3-year-old cries when I leave him at daycare. Is this the disorder?
faqs.answer: No, that is normal. Crying when a parent leaves is a standard, healthy, and expected part of development for toddlers (it's called separation anxiety). It becomes a disorder when it is developmentally inappropriate (e.g., still happening in an 8 or 10-year-old), when the distress is extreme (e.g., full-blown panic attacks), and when it interferes with their life (e.g., refusing to go to school, sleepovers, or playdates for months).

faqs.question: How do I help him? My instinct is to coddle him and let him stay home, but I'm told I have to be tough. What's the right way?
faqs.answer: Coddling (avoidance) makes the anxiety worse in the long run. Being tough (ignoring it) can be traumatizing. The middle path is empathy with a firm boundary. 1) Empathize: I know you're scared I won't come back, and that feeling is awful. 2) Reassure: I will be here at 3:00 to pick you up. My job is to always come back. 3) Be Firm: Your job is to go to school. I will walk you to the door. This is the basis of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which is the primary treatment.

faqs.question: Can adults have this? I'm 30, and I feel genuine panic and dread when my partner leaves for a business trip, and I can't stop texting them.
faqs.answer: Yes. While it's most common in children, Adult Separation Anxiety Disorder is a real and recognized condition. It involves the same core fear—an unrealistic and persistent worry that something terrible will happen to your attachment figure (your partner, your child, or your parent) when they are not with you. This can lead to checking behaviors (constant texting) or refusing to travel or be alone. It is treatable with therapy (CBT).

faqs.question: I found out my daughter is cutting. My first instinct is to panic and search her room and take away all sharp objects. Is this the right thing to do?
faqs.answer: This is a very common and understandable first reaction. However, it's often not helpful. While removing immediate means is a short-term safety step, a sweep of her room can feel like a punishment and a violation of trust, making her more secretive. The most important first step is to stay calm, control your own fear, and talk to her non-judgmentally. Your relationship is the most important tool you have.

faqs.question: Why is my son doing this? He swears he's not suicidal. If he doesn't want to die, why is he hurting himself?
faqs.answer: This is the most critical distinction to understand. For the vast majority, non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI) is not a suicide attempt. It is a coping mechanism. They are experiencing an overwhelming emotional pain (like depression, anxiety, or worthlessness) that feels unbearable. The physical pain of cutting acts as a release; it provides a focal point for the pain, snaps them out of a feeling of numbness (dissociation), and provides a (very) temporary sense of control. They are doing it to feel better, not to die.

faqs.question: I want to say, Just stop it! or Promise me you'll never do it again. But I'm scared that's the wrong thing. How do I even start this conversation?
faqs.answer: You're right, those approaches will likely fail. Just stopping is not possible without a new coping skill. Instead, try a script that is non-judgmental and curious: I saw the marks on your arm, and I am so incredibly worried about you because I know that means you are in a lot of pain. I'm not mad. I love you. Can you tell me what was going on today that made you feel like you needed to do that?

faqs.question: Is this just a phase or a cry for attention?
faqs.answer: No. This is a dangerous myth. While it is a sign that they need attention (as in, help and support), it is not attention-seeking in a manipulative way. Most people who self-injure are deeply ashamed and go to great lengths to hide it. It is a sign of severe emotional distress and a lack of healthy coping skills. It is not a phase and must be taken seriously as a sign of an underlying mental health issue.

faqs.question: What kind of therapy actually works for this? Just talk therapy?
faqs.answer: The gold standard treatment, especially for self-injury, is Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT). While standard talk therapy (CBT) is helpful, DBT is specifically designed to teach people concrete skills to replace the self-injury. It focuses on four modules: 1) Mindfulness (being present), 2) Distress Tolerance (how to survive a crisis without making it worse), 3) Emotion Regulation (understanding and changing emotions), and 4) Interpersonal Effectiveness (how to ask for help).

faqs.question: My doctor did a blood panel and said I have selective IgA deficiency. I feel fine. What does this even mean?
faqs.answer: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency. IgA (Immunoglobulin A) is an antibody that is your body's first line of defense in your mucous membranes (like your nose, sinuses, lungs, and gut). You are selectively missing this one type of antibody. The reason you feel fine is that this is the most common scenario—most people with IgA deficiency are completely asymptomatic and never know they have it. Your body's other immune components (like IgG and IgM) often compensate.

faqs.question: I'm not fine. I keep getting sinus infections, bronchitis, and pneumonia over and over again. Could this be the reason?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the other side of IgA deficiency. For a significant minority of people, the compensation isn't enough. Because you're missing that first-line defense in your mucus, bacteria and viruses can more easily set up shop in your sinuses, lungs, and GI tract, leading to recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections. This is the classic symptom.

faqs.question: If I'm missing part of my immune system, can it be replaced?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, no. Unlike other immunodeficiencies where you can get IVIG (infusions of antibodies), standard IVIG contains very little IgA, so it doesn't help. There is no replacement for IgA. Treatment is proactive—managing the recurrent infections with antibiotics, staying up-to-date on all vaccines (to boost your other antibodies), and, in severe cases, taking a low prophylactic (preventative) dose of an antibiotic.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to wear a medical alert bracelet because of this. Why? I'm not allergic to anything.
faqs.answer: This is a rare but critical safety issue. Because your body has never seen IgA, a small percentage of people with this deficiency have developed anti-IgA antibodies. If you were to get a blood transfusion (which contains normal plasma with IgA), your body could see that IgA as a foreign invader and mount a severe, life-threatening anaphylactic reaction to the blood product.
