The bracelet is to warn doctors to use special washed (IgA-free) blood products if you ever need a transfusion.

faqs.question: I have this, and I also have celiac disease and allergies. Are they all related?
faqs.answer: Yes, there is a very strong link. People with selective IgA deficiency are 10-20 times more likely to also have celiac disease. The link to other autoimmune diseases (like lupus, rheumatoid arthritis) and allergic conditions (like asthma and eczema) is also much higher than in the general population. It's believed that the lack of IgA in the gut lining allows more foreign substances (like gluten) to pass through, which can trigger these other immune-system overreactions.

faqs.question: My 7-year-old son keeps zoning out for 10-15 seconds. He just stares blankly, and sometimes his eyelids flutter, then he's back and has no idea it happened. His teacher says he's just daydreaming.
faqs.answer: This is not daydreaming. This is the classic description of an Absence Seizure (formerly petit mal). A daydreamer can be snapped out of it if you call their name. A child in an absence seizure cannot—they are gone for those 10 seconds. This is a type of generalized seizure, and you need to see a pediatric neurologist. The good news is that it is typically very treatable with medication.

faqs.question: I had one seizure (a grand mal), but my EEG and MRI are both normal. Does this mean I don't have epilepsy?
faqs.answer: This is a common and confusing situation. Epilepsy is a diagnosis of a tendency to have recurrent, unprovoked seizures. Having one seizure does not mean you have epilepsy. It could have been provoked (by alcohol withdrawal, low blood sugar, or a medication). Furthermore, a single EEG or MRI can be normal even in someone with epilepsy, as the test is just a snapshot in time. Your doctor will likely watch and wait. A second unprovoked seizure is what usually leads to the diagnosis of epilepsy.

faqs.question: What is an aura? I get a weird smell (like burning rubber) and a deja vu feeling right before I have a seizure.
faqs.answer: That aura is the seizure. It's a focal aware seizure (or simple partial seizure) that is starting in one tiny part of your brain. The weird smell means it's starting in your temporal lobe near the olfactory center. The deja vu means it's starting near the memory centers. For many people, this aura then spreads to the rest of the brain, causing the larger, convulsive seizure. This is an incredibly important warning sign that gives you a few seconds to get to a safe place.

faqs.question: I'm terrified my husband will swallow his tongue during a convulsion. What am I supposed to do? Should I put a wallet in his mouth?
faqs.answer: This is the most important seizure first-aid myth. It is physically impossible to swallow your tongue. NEVER put anything in the mouth of someone having a seizure. You cannot help them, and you will break their teeth, damage their jaw, or get your fingers bitten. The only thing to do is: 1) Ease them to the floor, 2) Turn them gently onto their side (this lets saliva drain and keeps the airway clear), 3) Put something soft under their head, 4) Time the seizure. Do not restrain them. Call 911 if it's their first seizure or lasts over 5 minutes.

faqs.question: What are common triggers? I have epilepsy, and I'm scared to drink coffee or use my computer.
faqs.answer: For most people, everyday things like coffee or computer use are not triggers. The single biggest and most common trigger for a breakthrough seizure in someone with epilepsy is lack of sleep. Other major triggers include missed medication, illness/fever, and heavy alcohol use (or withdrawal). A very small, rare subset of people do have photosensitive epilepsy, where flashing lights (like a strobe light or video game) can be a trigger, but this is not the norm.

faqs.question: I'm 32, I'm thin, I exercise, I eat well, and my blood pressure is 180/100. My doctor says this might be secondary hypertension. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: It means your high blood pressure is secondary to (caused by) another, specific medical problem. The normal high blood pressure (Primary Hypertension) is a slow, gradual disease of aging and lifestyle. When a young, healthy person like you has sudden, severe hypertension, it's a huge red flag that something else is wrong. Your blood pressure is a symptom, not the disease.

faqs.question: My doctor is ordering tests on my kidneys and thyroid for my blood pressure. How are these related?
faqs.answer: These are the most common secondary causes. 1) Kidneys: Your kidneys are the master regulators of blood pressure. If the artery to your kidney is narrowed (renal artery stenosis), the kidney thinks your whole body's blood pressure is low, so it releases hormones (renin) that tell your body to clamp down, skyrocketing your pressure. 2) Thyroid/Adrenal Glands: Glands like your thyroid or adrenals can develop small, benign tumors that overproduce hormones like adrenaline (a pheochromocytoma) or aldosterone. These hormones put your body in a constant fight or flight state, and your blood pressure will be dangerously high.

faqs.question: Could my severe snoring and sleep apnea be the cause of my high blood pressure?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. This is one of the most common and under-diagnosed causes of secondary hypertension. When you stop breathing at night (an apnea), your blood oxygen level plummets. Your brain panics and floods your body with stress hormones (like adrenaline) to wake you up. When this happens hundreds of times a night, your blood vessels are in a constant state of clamping down, leading to severe high blood pressure all day long.

faqs.question: If we find and fix the secondary cause (like the kidney artery), will my blood pressure go back to normal? Can I be cured?
faqs.answer: This is the good news about secondary hypertension. If a single, treatable cause (like a narrowed renal artery or a hormone-producing tumor) is found, then yes, you can potentially be cured. For example, stenting the renal artery or surgically removing the adrenal tumor can cause the blood pressure to return completely to normal, and you may be able to come off all blood pressure medications.

faqs.question: I'm 55, and I'm getting these waxy, crusty, stuck-on brown spots all over my back. They look disgusting. Are they cancerous?
faqs.answer: These are almost certainly Seborrheic Keratoses (SKs), and they are completely benign (non-cancerous). They are an extremely common, harmless part of aging. Your doctor may have jokingly called them barnacles of aging or wisdom spots. They are not related to sun damage and not related to melanoma.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this, a mole, and a wart?
faqs.answer: A mole is a growth of your pigment cells (melanocytes) and is in the skin. An SK is a stuck-on growth on top of the skin, made of excess skin cells (keratinocytes), which is why it often has a waxy, pasted-on look. A wart is a rough growth caused by a virus (HPV), is contagious, and is more common on hands and feet.

faqs.question: One of the spots on my back is always getting red, itchy, and irritated by my bra strap. Can I have it removed?
faqs.answer: Yes. While they don't need to be removed for medical reasons, they are very commonly removed for cosmetic reasons or, in your case, because they are in a high-friction area and get irritated. A dermatologist can easily and quickly remove it in the office, usually by freezing it (cryotherapy) or lightly scraping it off (curettage).

faqs.question: I've had these for years, but suddenly, in the last 2 months, I've had an explosion of hundreds of them all over my body. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: No. This is not normal and is a medical red flag. The sudden eruption of many seborrheic keratoses is a paraneoplastic sign known as the Sign of Leser-Trélat. This can be an external warning sign of an internal cancer, most commonly stomach cancer (adenocarcinoma). You need to see your doctor for a full workup, including an upper endoscopy, to check for an underlying malignancy.

faqs.question: I have the worst dandruff of my life. It's in my scalp, my eyebrows, and even in the greasy folds by my nose. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is a classic description of Seborrheic Dermatitis. It's a very common, chronic inflammatory skin condition. The dandruff you're seeing is not just dry skin—it's an inflammatory reaction to a yeast (a fungus called Malassezia) that lives on everyone's skin. In people with this condition, the skin over-reacts to this yeast, especially in oily (sebaceous) areas, causing the redness, itching, and greasy, yellowish flakes.

faqs.question: Why does it seem to get so much worse in the winter and when I'm under a lot of stress?
faqs.answer: These are the two most common triggers. 1) Winter: The cold, dry air outside and the hot, dry air inside are thought to irritate the skin barrier, making flares more likely. 2) Stress: Stress causes a release of cortisol (the stress hormone), which can dysregulate your immune system and ramp up the inflammatory response, leading to a bad flare-up.

faqs.question: My regular dandruff shampoo (like Head & Shoulders) isn't working anymore. What's the next step?
faqs.answer: Head & Shoulders (zinc pyrithione) is a good start, but when it's not enough, you need to rotate your active ingredients. The next step is a shampoo containing Ketoconazole (like Nizoral A-D), which is an antifungal that directly kills the Malassezia yeast. You can also try shampoos with Selenium Sulfide (Selsun Blue) or Coal Tar (T/Gel). For the face, your doctor might prescribe a mild topical steroid or antifungal cream for a few days.

faqs.question: I'm a man with a beard and mustache, and the skin underneath my facial hair is always red, flaky, and itchy. Is this the same thing?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is an extremely common location for seborrheic dermatitis. The facial hair traps oil and moisture, creating a perfect environment for the Malassezia yeast to thrive. The best way to treat it is to use an antifungal shampoo (like Nizoral) as a beard wash 2-3 times a week. Lather it in, let it sit on the skin for 3-5 minutes, and then rinse it out.

faqs.question: I had what I thought was a stye (or chalazion) on my eyelid, but it keeps coming back in the exact same spot. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a major red flag and you should see an ophthalmologist. A recurrent stye or chalazion in the same location is the classic presentation for sebaceous carcinoma, which is an aggressive cancer of the oil glands (sebaceous glands) in the eyelid. It is often called a great mimicker because it looks like a benign stye, leading to a delayed diagnosis.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have Muir-Torre syndrome and now I have this skin cancer. Are the two related?
faqs.answer: Yes, they are very strongly related. Muir-Torre syndrome is a genetic condition that gives you a high risk for internal cancers (especially colon cancer) and also for sebaceous (oil gland) tumors, including sebaceous carcinoma. Finding a sebaceous carcinoma, especially one not on the eyelid, is often the key skin finding that leads to the diagnosis of Muir-Torre.

faqs.question: They want to do Mohs surgery to remove the cancer on my eyelid. Isn't that for skin cancer on the nose?
faqs.answer: Mohs surgery is the gold standard for skin cancers in high-risk, cosmetically sensitive areas, and the eyelid is a perfect example. Because sebaceous carcinoma is aggressive and can spread, Mohs gives the highest possible cure rate (by checking 100% of the margins) while sparing the maximum amount of healthy eyelid tissue, which is critical for your eye to function properly after.

faqs.question: Is this type of cancer dangerous? I thought skin cancer was no big deal if it wasn't melanoma.
faqs.answer: This is not a no big deal skin cancer. Unlike the more common basal cell or squamous cell types, sebaceous carcinoma is an aggressive, high-risk cancer. It has a significant potential to spread (metastasize) to nearby lymph nodes and even to distant organs, which can be life-threatening. It requires prompt and aggressive treatment.

faqs.question: I'm not depressed, but every year around October, I get exhausted, I crave carbs, and I just want to hibernate. When spring comes, I'm fine. Is this SAD?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of SAD. It's not just the winter blues; it's a predictable, recurrent major depressive episode. The key symptoms are atypical—not sadness, but overwhelming fatigue (hypersomnia), intense craving for carbohydrates, weight gain, and a loss of interest in things you normally enjoy. The fact that it resolves completely in the spring is the defining feature.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to buy a light box. How can staring at a light possibly fix my mood? It sounds like a gimmick.
faqs.answer: It's not a gimmick; it's a first-line, evidence-based treatment. The leading theory for SAD is that the lack of sunlight in winter disrupts your circadian rhythm (your body clock). A 10,000-lux light box mimics the sun. By using it for 20-30 minutes first thing in the morning, you are tricking your brain into resetting your body clock, which helps regulate the production of serotonin and melatonin, leading to improved mood and energy.

faqs.question: Why does my doctor insist I use the light box in the morning? Does the time of day really matter?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is the most important part of the treatment. The goal is to anchor your day and tell your brain the sun is up. Using it in the morning pulls your body clock earlier. If you used it at night, it would be like telling your brain it's noon at 10 p.m., which would shift your clock the wrong way and cause severe insomnia, making the SAD worse.

faqs.question: I live in a sunny state like Florida, but I work in a windowless office. Can I still get SAD?
faqs.answer: Yes. While it's more common in northern latitudes, SAD is about the change in your personal sun exposure. If your sun-up to sun-down exposure is dramatically reduced in the winter (e.g., you commute in the dark and stay inside all day), your brain can still experience the light-deprivation trigger, even if it's sunny outside.

faqs.question: Is it possible for SAD to be part of bipolar disorder? I get depressed in the winter, but in the spring I get too happy and energetic.
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a critical distinction. For many people, SAD is actually a seasonal pattern of Bipolar II Disorder. They experience predictable depressive episodes in the fall/winter and hypomanic (energetic, wired, too good) episodes in the spring/summer. It's very important to tell your doctor this, because treating this with only an antidepressant (an SSRI) can be dangerous and trigger a manic episode.

faqs.question: I found a lump in my scrotum. It's not on my testicle, but behind it, and it feels like a bag of worms. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic textbook description of a varicocele. It is a collection of varicose (enlarged) veins in the scrotum. It is almost always on the left side, is benign (non-cancerous), and is generally harmless, though it can sometimes cause a dull ache or be a significant cause of infertility.

faqs.question: I have a small, hard, pea-sized lump that is on my testicle, and it's painless. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. You must see a urologist immediately. Any hard, painless, fixed lump on the testicle itself is testicular cancer until proven otherwise. Unlike other masses, this is a true medical urgency. Do not wait to see if it goes away. An ultrasound will be ordered immediately.

faqs.question: My entire testicle is suddenly swollen, red, and extremely painful, and I have a fever. What is happening?
faqs.answer: This is a medical emergency. The two most likely causes are: 1) Epididymitis, an infection of the epididymis (the tube behind the teste), which is treated with antibiotics. OR 2) Testicular Torsion, where the testicle has twisted on its own spermatic cord, cutting off its blood supply. Torsion is a surgical emergency that requires you to be in an operating room within 6 hours, or the testicle will die.

faqs.question: I have a small, smooth, movable lump that's separate from my testicle. My doctor called it a spermatocele. Is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: No, this is a very common and benign (harmless) finding. A spermatocele (or epididymal cyst) is a small, fluid-filled sac that forms on the epididymis (the sperm-collecting tube). It is not cancer and has no risk of turning into cancer. They are only treated (surgically removed) if they grow to be very large and cause pain or discomfort.

faqs.question: I got stung by a scorpion. It hurts, burns, and is tingling, but the pain is only in my hand. Am I in danger?
faqs.answer: In the vast majority of cases in the UnitedSstates, the sting is from a non-dangerous species. This causes severe local pain, burning, and tingling at the site, but it is not life-threatening. The main danger is from the Arizona Bark Scorpion. You must go to the ER if you develop systemic (whole-body) symptoms.

faqs.question: What are the danger signs of a serious sting that mean I need to go to the ER?
faqs.answer: You must go to the ER immediately if you or your child develop any of these systemic neurotoxic symptoms: blurry vision, roving or jerky eye movements, drooling or slurred speech, a feeling of a thick tongue, or widespread, random muscle twitching (fasciculations).

faqs.question: My child was stung, and now their eyes are twitching and jerking all over the place. What's happening?
faqs.answer: This is the classic red flag sign of a severe, neurotoxic envenomation from a dangerous scorpion (like the Arizona Bark Scorpion). Children are much more susceptible to the venom than adults. This is a medical emergency. You need to get them to an emergency room immediately for observation and possible treatment with antivenom.

faqs.question: Why does the sting tingle so much? And why does it shoot up my arm when I tap on it?
faqs.answer: This is because the venom is a neurotoxin that works by propping open sodium channels in your nerves, making them hyperexcitable. The tingling (paresthesia) is the nerve misfiring. When you tap on the nerve (a Tinel's sign), it sends a jolt along the irritated nerve, confirming the venom's effect.

faqs.question: My 12-year-old daughter's doctor said her shoulders are uneven and one shoulder blade sticks out when she bends over. Is this scoliosis?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the classic finding from the Adam's Forward Bend Test. The uneven shoulder and the rib hump (the shoulder blade or scapula sticking out) are hallmark signs of a rotational curve in the spine, which is the definition of scoliosis. She will need a standing X-ray to confirm it and measure the Cobb angle (the severity of the curve).

faqs.question: Her X-ray shows a 30-degree curve. Her doctor wants to put her in a brace. Will this fix the curve?
faqs.answer: This is a critical point: a brace does not fix or straighten the existing 30-degree curve. The only goal of the brace is to stop the curve from getting worse while she is still growing. This is a moderate curve, and the main risk is that it will progress (get worse) during her adolescent growth spurt. The brace holds the spine in place to prevent that.

faqs.question: Can't I just take her to a chiropractor or physical therapist to fix this instead of the brace?
faqs.answer: A chiropractor cannot fix a structural curve. For a moderate (25-40 degree), progressive curve in a growing child, a brace is the only non-surgical treatment proven to halt its progression. Physical therapy (like the Schroth Method) is excellent and should be done, but it's used as an adjunct to bracing, not as a replacement for it.

faqs.question: Her curve is now 50 degrees, and they're talking about spinal fusion surgery. What does that involve?
faqs.answer: Curves over 45-50 degrees are considered severe and will often continue to get worse even after she stops growing. Spinal fusion is a major surgery where an orthopedic surgeon straightens the spine with metal rods and screws, and then fuses (grows together) the vertebrae in that section into one solid, straight bone. This provides a permanent correction but does mean that section of her back will no longer be flexible.

faqs.question: I'm 60, and I've always had a slight curve. Now I have terrible back pain and sciatica. Is this related?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is adult degenerative scoliosis. The old, pre-existing curve creates an unbalanced spine. Over decades, this leads to faster wear-and-tear (arthritis), bone spurs, and spinal stenosis (pinching of the nerves) on the concave side of the curve, which is what is causing your new sciatica (leg pain).

faqs.question: My CT scan for my bad stomach pain showed a misty mesentery and my doctor says I have sclerosing mesenteritis. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is a rare inflammatory disease. The mesentery is the fan-like tissue that holds your intestines in place and contains their blood supply. Misty mesentery on a CT scan means this tissue is inflamed. Sclerosing (or fibrosing) means it can progress to forming scar tissue, which is the more serious form of the disease.

faqs.question: Is this cancer? My doctor said it can look like lymphoma on the scan.
faqs.answer: It is not cancer. It is a benign inflammatory and fibrotic (scarring) process. However, it is famous for mimicking cancer on a CT scan, which is why a biopsy is almost always needed to tell the difference and make a definitive diagnosis. In very rare cases, it can be associated with lymphoma, but the condition itself is not malignant.

faqs.question: What causes this? Did I do or eat something to cause it?
faqs.answer: We do not know the cause. It is idiopathic (of unknown origin). It's thought to be some form of autoimmune or inflammatory response, but it is not caused by your diet, an injury, or anything you did. It's just a rare, unlucky inflammatory condition.

faqs.question: What is the long-term danger? Can the scarring hurt my intestines?
faqs.answer: Yes. In the fibrosing or sclerosing stage, the scar tissue can become so thick and hard that it constricts the intestines (causing a bowel obstruction) or, more dangerously, it can strangle and cut off the blood supply to the bowel, which is a surgical emergency (bowel ischemia).

faqs.question: How is this treated? My doctor wants to try a steroid (Prednisone) or Tamoxifen.
faqs.answer: Because it's an inflammatory disease, the first-line treatment is to suppress the inflammation. This is often done with steroids (like Prednisone) or other anti-inflammatory/anti-fibrotic medications (like Tamoxifen) to try and calm down the inflammation and stop it from progressing to the dangerous sclerosing (scarring) phase.

faqs.question: My fingers are always freezing and turn white, blue, and then red in the cold. Now my skin feels tight and shiny. My doctor says this is scleroderma.
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation. The cold, color-changing fingers are Raynaud's phenomenon. Scleroderma (hard skin) is a chronic, autoimmune disease where your body attacks its own tissue, causing an overproduction of collagen (scar tissue). This leads to the tight, shiny skin (sclerodactyly) and can also affect your internal organs.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have limited scleroderma, or CREST syndrome. Does that mean it's not serious?
faqs.answer: Limited is a misleading name. It means the skin-hardening is limited to your hands, arms, and face (not your trunk). However, the internal organ involvement can be very serious. CREST stands for Calcinosis (calcium deposits), Raynaud's, Esophageal dysmotility (severe heartburn), Sclerodactyly (tight fingers), and Telangiectasia (red spots). The biggest danger in this form is Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH), which is high blood pressure in the lungs and is life-threatening.

faqs.question: What's the diffuse type, and how is it different from limited?
faqs.answer: Diffuse scleroderma is more aggressive. The skin-hardening happens rapidly and affects the entire body (trunk, back, etc.), not just the hands and face. More importantly, this type has a high, early risk of different organ problems, specifically Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) (scarring of the lungs) and Scleroderma Renal Crisis (sudden, severe high blood pressure and kidney failure).

faqs.question: I have constant, terrible heartburn, and I feel like food gets stuck in my chest. Is this related?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the E in CREST (Esophageal dysmotility), and it happens in almost all scleroderma patients. The scarring process has hardened the smooth muscle of your esophagus, so it can't push (peristalsis) food down properly. It also weakens the valve at the bottom, allowing acid to flow back up constantly. This can lead to severe damage (Barrett's esophagus) if not treated.

faqs.question: My blood test came back positive for an Anti-Scl-70 (or topoisomerase) antibody. What does that tell my doctor?
faqs.answer: These antibodies are diagnostic markers. Having the Anti-Scl-70 antibody is highly specific for the Diffuse form of scleroderma. It confirms your diagnosis and tells your doctor that you are at a very high risk for developing Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) (lung scarring). They will now need to screen you regularly with breathing tests (PFTs) and chest CT scans.

faqs.question: I have a shooting, electric pain that starts in my buttock and goes all the way down the back of my leg to my foot. It's not just back pain. What is this?
faqs.answer: That is the definition of sciatica. It's not a disease itself, but a symptom with a specific pattern. It means something in your lower back (lumbar spine) is pinching or compressing your sciatic nerve, the large nerve that runs from your buttock down your leg. The pain you feel is referred pain from that pinched nerve root.

faqs.question: What is pinching the nerve? My doctor said it's probably a herniated disc.
faqs.answer: This is the most common cause (90% of cases), especially in younger adults. The gel-like center of one of your spinal discs (usually L4/L5 or L5/S1) has bulged or ruptured (herniated) out of its tire and is physically pressing on the nerve root as it tries to exit the spine.

faqs.question: The pain is bad, but now my foot feels numb and I'm tripping over it (I can't lift my toes). Is this a bad sign?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a red flag and is much more serious than just pain. Pain is a sensory signal. Numbness, and especially weakness (like foot drop, where you can't lift your foot), means the nerve is so pinched that the motor signal is being blocked. You need to see a doctor or surgeon urgently, as this nerve damage can become permanent if not decompressed (fixed).

faqs.question: When should I go to the ER for sciatica?
faqs.answer: You must go to the ER immediately if you have sciatica and you develop saddle anesthesia (numbness in your groin, inner thighs, and buttocks—the parts that would touch a saddle) or any new loss of bowel or bladder control. This is Cauda Equina Syndrome, a surgical emergency where all the nerves at the base of your spine are being crushed, and it can lead to permanent paralysis if not treated in hours.

faqs.question: My doctor wants me to get an epidural steroid injection. How does that help? It doesn't un-pinch the nerve, does it?
faqs.answer: You are exactly right, it doesn't. The herniated disc is causing pain in two ways: 1) It's mechanically pinching the nerve, and 2) It's leaking inflammatory chemicals that are chemically irritating the nerve. The injection doesn't fix the pinch, but it delivers a powerful anti-inflammatory steroid (like cortisone) directly to the inflamed nerve root, washing away the chemicals and calming the severe inflammation. This can give you dramatic pain relief.

faqs.question: My MRI found a schwannoma. Is this a brain tumor? Is it cancer?
faqs.answer: A schwannoma is a tumor of a nerve, not the brain (though it can be on a nerve inside your skull). It grows from the Schwann cells that form the insulating sheath (myelin) around a nerve. The most important thing is that they are almost always benign (not cancer) and very slow-growing.

faqs.question: The most common one is an acoustic neuroma (or vestibular schwannoma). What symptoms does that cause?
faqs.answer: This is a schwannoma on the 8th cranial nerve (the hearing and balance nerve). Its classic symptoms are one-sided (unilateral) hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in one ear), and dizziness or balance issues (vertigo). Any of these one-sided symptoms requires an MRI to rule this out.

faqs.question: If it's benign and slow-growing, why would I have surgery? Can't I just watch it?
faqs.answer: Observation (watchful waiting with yearly MRIs) is a very common option, especially if it's small or you're an older adult. However, because it's in a tight, bony space (like the skull base or spinal canal), even a benign tumor will eventually grow large enough to compress critical structures (like your brainstem or spinal cord), causing permanent, irreversible damage. Surgery is often done to remove it before it causes this.

faqs.question: Can they remove the tumor without destroying the nerve it's on?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the primary goal of the surgery. Unlike other tumors that invade the nerve, a schwannoma typically grows from the sheath and displaces or pushes the nerve fibers to the side. A skilled neurosurgeon can often find the plane between the tumor and the nerve and shell out the tumor while preserving the function of the nerve fibers.

faqs.question: I've had several schwannomas removed. My doctor now says I have Schwannomatosis. Is this the same as Neurofibromatosis (NF)?
faqs.answer: It is the third type of NF. It's related to, but different from, NF1 and NF2. NF1 causes cafe-au-lait spots and neurofibromas. NF2's hallmark is bilateral (both sides) vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas). Schwannomatosis is characterized by multiple schwannomas everywhere else in the body (spine, peripheral nerves), but typically without the vestibular ones.

faqs.question: My main symptom is just pain. Horrible, chronic, burning pain, even from small tumors. Why?
faqs.answer: This is the primary and most debilitating feature of schwannomatosis, and what truly makes it different from NF2. The tumors themselves (even if small) are often intensely painful, causing chronic, neuropathic (nerve) pain that is very difficult to treat. Management is often focused on pain, not just tumor removal.

faqs.question: If I have this, will my kids get it? It's not on my NF2 gene.
faqs.answer: You are right, the NF2 gene is usually normal. Schwannomatosis is caused by a different gene (like SMARCB1 or LZTR1). It can be familial (inherited, with a 50% risk to children) or sporadic (a new mutation just in you). Genetic testing can help clarify your specific type and the risk to your family.

faqs.question: Is the treatment just whack-a-mole, cutting out tumors when they appear?
faqs.answer: This is a common and frustrating reality. Because you have a genetic tendency to form new tumors, surgery is not a cure for the disease. Surgery is reserved only for tumors that are causing focal problems (like weakness or compression of the spinal cord) or those that are causing intractable pain. The rest of the disease is managed by a pain specialist.

faqs.question: My family says I'm just eccentric. I'm not schizophrenic, I don't hear voices, but I do have magical thinking, I'm very suspicious, and I'm very awkward in social situations. Is this schizotypal?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description. Schizotypal Personality Disorder is on the schizophrenia spectrum. It's not psychosis, but it shares negative symptoms (social withdrawal, flat affect) and cognitive symptoms (magical thinking, odd beliefs, paranoid ideas of reference). It's a personality disorder—a stable, lifelong pattern of this behavior.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this and Schizoid personality disorder? They both sound like loners.
faqs.answer: This is a key distinction. A person with Schizoid PD is a loner and is indifferent to social contact; they genuinely prefer to be alone. A person with Schizotypal PD is also a loner, but it's because they are terrified of social interaction, deeply paranoid, and have social anxiety. They are anxious and suspicious of people, not indifferent to them.

faqs.question: What are ideas of reference? My therapist says I have these.
faqs.answer: This is a core symptom. It's the feeling that random, neutral events are secretly related to you. For example, believing that a news report is a coded message just for you, or that two strangers laughing across the street are definitely laughing at you and talking about you.

faqs.question: If I have this, am I going to become schizophrenic?
faqs.answer: This is a major concern, but it is not a guarantee. A small percentage (about 10-15%) of people with schizotypal PD may go on to develop full-blown schizophrenia. It is considered a prodromal (pre-symptom) risk factor, but most people with the disorder do not.

faqs.question: How is this even treated? Is it medication or therapy?
faqs.answer: It is primarily treated with long-term psychotherapy (talk therapy) to help you learn to test reality, improve your social skills, and manage your anxiety. Because it's on the schizophrenia spectrum, sometimes a very low dose of an antipsychotic medication is used, not to treat psychosis, but to help turn down the volume on the paranoia and magical thinking, making therapy more effective.

faqs.question: My 21-year-old son has become withdrawn, his grades collapsed, and he's now saying the FBI is spying on him through the TV. Is this a first psychotic break?
faqs.answer: This is a very classic prodrome and first break scenario. Schizophrenia often emerges in the late teens/early 20s. It starts with negative symptoms (withdrawal, apathy, flat emotions, drop in function) and then the positive symptoms (the psychosis) appear. Paranoid delusions (like the FBI) and hallucinations (like hearing voices) are the hallmarks.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a delusion and a hallucination?
faqs.answer: A Hallucination is a false sensory experience (e.g., hearing voices that aren't there, seeing things, or feeling bugs on the skin). A Delusion is a fixed, false belief that is not based in reality (e.g., believing you are a god, believing you are being poisoned), even when shown evidence to the contrary.

faqs.question: What are negative symptoms? My doctor talks about them more than the voices.
faqs.answer: This is a core, and often misunderstood, part of the illness. Positive symptoms (hallucinations) are added experiences. Negative symptoms are deficits or things that are taken away. This includes: Avolition (no motivation to do anything), Alogia (poverty of speech), Anhedonia (no pleasure in anything), and Flat Affect (no emotional expression). These negative symptoms are often what cause the most long-term disability.

faqs.question: Will my son have to be on antipsychotic medication forever? The side effects (like weight gain) are awful.
faqs.answer: Schizophrenia is a chronic, lifelong brain illness, like diabetes. The antipsychotic medication (which controls the psychosis) is the cornerstone of treatment and is almost always lifelong. While the side effects (like weight gain and high blood sugar from atypical antipsychotics) are serious and must be managed, stopping the medication almost guarantees a relapse of the psychosis, which is very dangerous and damaging to the brain.

faqs.question: My brother's diagnosis is schizophrenia, but his main symptom is that he doesn't make any sense when he talks. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is a cognitive or disorganized symptom, often called disorganized speech or thought disorder. The links between his thoughts are broken. This can sound like word salad (random words), tangentiality (going off on tangents), or loose associations (jumping from topic to topic illogically). This is a hallmark sign that the processing part of the brain is affected.

faqs.question: I've been a loner my whole life. I don't have friends, I don't want friends, and I'd rather just be alone. Am I schizoid?
faqs.answer: This is the core of Schizoid Personality Disorder (PD). It's not social anxiety. It's a profound, lifelong detachment from social relationships and a strong preference for solitary activities. People with this disorder are often seen as cold or aloof because they have a very flat affect and seem indifferent to praise, criticism, or human contact.

faqs.question: Is this the same as Asperger's/Autism (ASD)?
faqs.answer: No, but they can look similar and are often confused. A person on the autism spectrum may struggle with social skills but often has a deep desire for connection that they can't express or navigate. A person with Schizoid PD has no desire for connection. Their internal world is often rich, but they have no motivation to share it or engage with others.

faqs.question: Does this mean I'm schizophrenic?
faqs.answer: No. Schizoid PD is not a psychotic disorder. You are fully in touch with reality. It shares the schizo- prefix because it shares the negative symptoms (flat affect, social withdrawal) of schizophrenia, but it does not have the positive symptoms (hallucinations, delusions).

faqs.question: Is there any treatment for this? I don't feel bad, but my family is worried.
faqs.answer: This is the paradox of Schizoid PD. Most people with it do not seek treatment because they are not distressed by their condition (it's ego-syntonic). Therapy is usually sought later in life due to co-morbid depression or pressure from family. The treatment is not to make you social, but rather a form of psychotherapy (like CBT) to help you navigate the social world you are forced to live in and manage any associated depression.

faqs.question: My diagnosis is schizoaffective disorder. My doctor said it's like schizophrenia and bipolar. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: That's the simplest way to put it. To be diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder, you must meet the full criteria for schizophrenia (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) and also meet the full criteria for a major mood disorder (either Bipolar Disorder or Major Depression).

faqs.question: How is this different from Bipolar with psychotic features? I get confused.
faqs.answer: This is the key distinction. In Bipolar with psychosis, the psychosis (hallucinations) only happens during a mood episode (mania or depression). When the mood is normal, the psychosis goes away. In Schizoaffective Disorder, the psychosis is persistent—you must have a baseline of psychotic symptoms (like voices) even when your mood is stable and normal.

faqs.question: So do I have the Bipolar Type or the Depressive Type?
faqs.answer: This is the subtype of your diagnosis. You have the Bipolar Type if you have ever had a manic or hypomanic episode. You have the Depressive Type if you have only ever had major depressive episodes (but never mania).

faqs.question: What is the treatment? Is it just one pill?
faqs.answer: No, the treatment is complex because it must target both problems. This almost always requires a mood stabilizer (like Lithium or Valproate) to control the mood (bipolar) part, and an antipsychotic (like Paliperidone or Olanzapine) to control the psychotic (schizophrenia) part. Paliperidone (Invega) is one of the few drugs approved to treat schizoaffective disorder as a monotherapy (single drug).

faqs.question: My 6-year-old has a high fever, a bright red strawberry tongue, and a sandpaper rash all over his body. Is this scarlet fever?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the exact classic triad of scarlet fever. It's important to know that this is not a separate, mystical disease; it is strep throat with a rash. The Group A Strep bacteria is releasing a toxin (an erythrogenic toxin) that causes the diffuse, sandpaper rash, the strawberry tongue, and Pastia's lines (bright red lines in the armpits and groin).

faqs.question: My son gets strep all the time. Why did he get this rash this time?
faqs.answer: Because he was infected with a strain of Group A Strep that produces the toxin. Not all strep bacteria make this toxin. It's also possible to be immune to the toxin from a previous exposure, so you could get strep throat again from a toxin-producing strain but not get the rash.

faqs.question: Is this dangerous? It sounds like an old-fashioned, Victorian disease.
faqs.answer: It is dangerous only in the sense that untreated strep is dangerous. The rash itself is not. The underlying strep infection must be treated with a full 10-day course of antibiotics (like Penicillin or Amoxicillin) to prevent the rare but very serious complications, like rheumatic fever (which permanently damages the heart valves) or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (kidney disease).

faqs.question: He has the rash, but his rapid strep test was negative. How is that possible?
faqs.answer: The rapid test is a good screening test, but it has a false negative rate. Your doctor, seeing the classic scarlet fever rash, is making a clinical diagnosis (which is very reliable in this case) and is correctly treating the strep. They likely sent a throat culture (the gold standard test) as well, which will probably come back positive in a few days.

faqs.question: I am unbearably itchy, and it's so much worse at night that I can't sleep. I have a pimply rash in my finger webs and on my wrists. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the absolute classic presentation of scabies. The intense (pruritus) that is worse at night is the #1 hallmark. Scabies is an infestation by a microscopic mite that burrows under your skin to lay its eggs. The finger webs, wrists, waistline, and groin are its favorite spots. The itch is an allergic reaction to the mite, its eggs, and its feces.

faqs.question: I'm a very clean person and I shower every day! How did I get this?
faqs.answer: Scabies has nothing to do with personal hygiene. You cannot wash it off. It is spread by prolonged, direct skin-to-skin contact (like holding hands, sleeping in the same bed, or sexual contact). You get it from another person who has it. It's very common in dorms, nursing homes, and daycares, regardless of cleanliness.

faqs.question: My doctor gave me a permethrin cream. How do I use it, and will it work right away?
faqs.answer: This is the gold standard treatment. You must apply the cream everywhere on your body from the neck down (even places that don't itch) and leave it on for 8-14 hours (usually overnight), then wash it off. You must also treat your entire household (and any sexual partners) at the exact same time, even if they don't itch, or you will just pass it back and forth.

faqs.question: I used the permethrin cream a week ago, and I'm still itchy. Did it not work?
faqs.answer: This is normal and very common. The cream kills the live mites. But your skin is still having an allergic reaction to all the dead mites and their feces stuck in your skin burrows. This post-scabies itch can last for 2-4 weeks. Your doctor can give you a steroid cream to help calm the allergic component of the itch while your skin sheds the dead mites.

faqs.question: What is crusted or Norwegian scabies? My doctor said my grandfather in the nursing home has this.
faqs.answer: This is a rare, severe hyper-infestation of scabies. A normal case involves 10-15 mites. Crusted scabies involves millions of mites. It only happens to people with a severely weakened immune system (like the elderly, or people with AIDS or on chemo), because their body cannot fight back or feel the itch. It's not itchy, but looks like thick, warty crusts on the skin, and it is extremely contagious to others.

faqs.question: I have a large, deep lump in my thigh. It's not painful. I thought cancer was supposed to hurt?
faqs.answer: This is the most dangerous myth about sarcomas. Soft-tissue sarcomas (cancers of muscle, fat, or connective tissue) are almost always painless in their early stages. They are often found when they are already large (e.g., bigger than a golf ball). Any new, deep, growing, painless lump must be evaluated by a doctor, preferably with an MRI, not just watched.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have a GIST. Is that a sarcoma?
faqs.answer: Yes. A Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) is a specific type of sarcoma that grows in the wall of your stomach or intestines. It's a cancer of the interstitial cells of Cajal (the pacemaker cells of the gut). It is not stomach cancer (which is adenocarcinoma) and is treated very differently, often with a targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) drug like Imatinib (Gleevec).

faqs.question: My son has Ewing's sarcoma. I thought this was a bone cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes, sarcoma can mean bone sarcoma or soft-tissue sarcoma. The most common bone sarcomas are Osteosarcoma (common in teens, near the knee) and Ewing's sarcoma (common in children/teens, often in the long bones or pelvis). Both are very aggressive and are treated with a combination of intense chemotherapy first, followed by surgery and/or radiation.

faqs.question: My biopsy said liposarcoma. Does that mean it's just a cancerous fatty lump (lipoma)?
faqs.answer: A lipoma is a benign, harmless lump of fat. A liposarcoma is a malignant (cancerous) tumor of fat cells. While some are very low-grade (atypical lipomatous tumor), many are aggressive (dedifferentiated) and can spread (metastasize), most often to the lungs. They are not the same, and the liposarcoma needs to be removed by a surgical oncologist.

faqs.question: Why did my doctor say this sarcoma is spindle cell? What type is that?
faqs.answer: Spindle cell describes what the cancer looks like under the microscope. It's not a type of sarcoma, but a description or grade. Many different sarcomas (like leiomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma) are made of these spindle-shaped cells. It's often used when the tumor is high-grade or undifferentiated, which means it's aggressive.

faqs.question: I've had a dry cough for months, I'm exhausted, and my X-ray showed hilar lymphadenopathy (big lymph nodes in my chest). My doctor says it's sarcoidosis. What is that?
faqs.answer: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory, autoimmune disease of unknown cause. Its hallmark is the formation of granulomas (tiny, microscopic clumps of inflammatory cells) in your organs. The lungs and the lymph nodes in the chest (hilar nodes) are the most common (90%+) place for this to happen, which is what your X-ray showed.

faqs.question: I also have these painful, red, hot bumps on my shins, and my ankles are swollen. Are they related?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a classic acute sign. This rash is called Erythema Nodosum, and it's a reactive inflammation. When it appears with the swollen lymph nodes in the chest and joint pain, it's called Löfgren's syndrome, which is an acute, good-prognosis form of sarcoidosis that often resolves on its own.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to check my ACE level and my calcium. How are those related to my lungs?
faqs.answer: 1) ACE: The granulomas (the inflammatory clumps) are like little factories that produce the ACE enzyme, so a high ACE level in your blood is a marker of the total-body granuloma burden. 2) Calcium: For the same reason, the granulomas also over-activate Vitamin D, which causes your body to absorb too much calcium from your diet, leading to hypercalcemia (high blood calcium), which is dangerous.

faqs.question: My lung doctor said I don't need treatment and to watch and wait. Why wouldn't we treat it if it's in my lungs?
faqs.answer: Because for over 60% of people (especially Stage 1 or Löfgren's syndrome), the inflammation resolves on its own within 2-3 years without any treatment. The treatment (high-dose steroids like Prednisone) has serious side effects, so it's reserved only for people who have severe symptoms (like can't breathe), high calcium, or progressive disease that is moving toward the scarring stage (pulmonary fibrosis).

faqs.question: Can this affect my heart? My doctor wants me to get an EKG.
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the most dangerous, though less common, form. Cardiac sarcoidosis is when the granulomas form inside the heart muscle. This can block the heart's electrical system (causing heart block and needing a pacemaker) or weaken the heart muscle (causing heart failure).

faqs.question: I ate some chicken 2 days ago, and now I have horrible diarrhea, fever, and stomach cramps. Is this Salmonella?
faqs.answer: This is the classic scenario. Salmonella is a bacterial food poisoning. The key is the incubation period—it takes 12-72 hours after eating the contaminated food (often undercooked chicken, eggs, or produce) to cause watery diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps. It's not immediate.

faqs.question: How is this different from a stomach flu (Norovirus)?
faqs.answer: Norovirus (the stomach bug) is very fast—it hits you 12-24 hours after exposure and is characterized by violent, projectile vomiting and watery diarrhea. Salmonella takes longer to incubate (24-72 hours) and is less about vomiting and more about high fever and watery (sometimes bloody) diarrhea.

faqs.question: My doctor just told me to drink fluids and not to take antibiotics. Why? I have a fever and I'm miserable.
faqs.answer: For a simple salmonella (gastroenteritis) in a healthy person, antibiotics are not recommended. They don't shorten the illness by much, and they can increase the risk of you becoming a chronic carrier (still shedding the bacteria in your stool for weeks). The antibiotics can also damage your good gut flora, which are needed to fight the infection. Treatment is just supportive care (fluids/electrolytes).

faqs.question: When would I need antibiotics for Salmonella?
faqs.answer: Antibiotics are reserved only for severe or invasive disease. This includes: 1) You are immunocompromised (e.g., on chemo), 2) You are very old or a newborn, or 3) The salmonella has escaped your gut and gotten into your bloodstream (bacteremia), which can cause a life-threatening, sepsis-like illness.

faqs.question: I had typhoid fever years ago in another country. Is that related to Salmonella?
faqs.answer: Yes. Typhoid fever (or enteric fever) is a severe, life-threatening form of salmonella, caused by a specific strain (Salmonella Typhi). This strain is not a simple food poisoning; it's an invasive bacteremia (bloodstream infection) that causes a very high, sustained fever and can be fatal. This is not the same as the salmonella you get from undercooked chicken in the US.

faqs.question: I have a painless, slow-growing lump in my cheek, right in front of my ear. What could this be?
faqs.answer: This is the exact location and description of a parotid gland tumor. The parotid is your largest salivary gland. The vast majority (80%) of these tumors are benign (not cancer). The most common type is a Pleomorphic Adenoma, which is benign but should be removed.

faqs.question: Why does my surgeon keep talking about my facial nerve? He said it's the main risk of the surgery.
faqs.answer: This is the #1 risk of parotid surgery. The facial nerve (which controls all the muscles on that side of your face—eye-closing, smiling) exits your skull and directly enters and branches inside the parotid gland. A surgeon must dissect and peel the nerve fibers off the tumor. Temporary weakness from stretching the nerve is common; a permanent cut (paralysis) is rare with a skilled surgeon.

faqs.question: If it's benign, can't I just leave it alone? I'm terrified of the nerve damage.
faqs.answer: This is not recommended. 1) Benign pleomorphic adenomas have a malignant transformation risk—over many years (10-15), they can turn into an aggressive cancer. 2) The larger the tumor gets, the more the facial nerve is stretched over it, and the higher the risk of damaging the nerve during surgery. It is much safer to remove them when they are small.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this parotid tumor and a submandibular tumor? I have a lump under my jaw.
faqs.answer: The submandibular is the gland under your jaw. A lump there is a different story. While parotid tumors are 80% benign, lumps in the submandibular gland are a 50/50 shot (50% benign, 50% cancerous). Because the cancer risk is much higher, these are almost always removed.

faqs.question: My lump is painful and it hurts when I eat. Is that a tumor?
faqs.answer: That is less likely to be a tumor. Pain, especially pain that worsens when you think about or start to eat, is the classic sign of a salivary stone (sialolithiasis) or an infection (sialadenitis). The stone is blocking the duct, and when your gland squeezes to release saliva, it causes a painful back-up. This is a much more common (and less serious) problem.

faqs.question: I have this deep, aching pain in my low back/buttock area. It's not my spine, it's off to the side. My doctor says it's my SI joint. What is that?
faqs.answer: Your Sacroiliac (SI) joint is the shock-absorber joint that connects your spine (the sacrum) to your pelvis (the ilium). Sacroiliitis is inflammation of that joint. It causes a deep, achy pain in the buttock/low back area that is often mistaken for disc pain or sciatica.

faqs.question: Why is my pain so much worse in the morning? It takes me 30 minutes to loosen up.
faqs.answer: This is the hallmark of inflammatory back pain, as opposed to mechanical back pain. The inflammation in the joint causes stiffness and pain that is worse with rest (i.e., sleeping) and better with activity (i.e., moving around). Mechanical pain (like a muscle strain) is the opposite (better with rest).

faqs.question: My doctor tested me for the HLA-B27 gene and wants me to see a rheumatologist. Why?
faqs.answer: Because inflammatory sacroiliitis is the cardinal, first sign of a family of autoimmune diseases called Spondyloarthropathies. The classic one is Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS). The HLA-B27 gene is a genetic marker that makes you highly susceptible to developing AS. The rheumatologist needs to see if this is the first stop on the way to AS.

faqs.question: I'm 35 and pregnant, and this SI joint pain is unbearable. Is this Ankylosing Spondylitis?
faqs.answer: Unlikely. This is the other common cause. During pregnancy, your body releases hormones (like relaxin) that loosen all your pelvic ligaments to prepare for childbirth. This makes the SI joint hypermobile and unstable, which can cause severe mechanical pain. This is mechanical SI joint dysfunction, not inflammatory sacroiliitis, and it's treated with physical therapy and a pelvic belt.

faqs.question: Sometimes my heart just suddenly starts racing—like 160 bpm—for no reason. It feels like a light switch was flipped. Is this a panic attack or my heart?
faqs.answer: That light switch (abrupt on/off) is the classic sign of a re-entrant tachycardia, like SVT (Supraventricular Tachycardia). A panic attack usually ramps up and ramps down. SVT is caused by an extra wire or short circuit in your heart's electrical system.

faqs.question: When it happens, I get lightheaded and feel like I'm going to pass out. Is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: For most young, healthy people, SVT is benign but bothersome. The lightheaded feeling (pre-syncope) is because the heart is beating so fast that it doesn't have time to fill with blood, so your blood pressure drops. The main danger is fainting (syncope) and hitting your head.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to bear down like I'm having a bowel movement. How does that stop my heart?
faqs.answer: This is a vagal maneuver. By bearing down, you are stimulating your vagus nerve. This nerve acts as the brake pedal for your heart. Stimulating it can slow the electrical conduction in your heart enough to break the short circuit and stop the SVT.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this SVT and Atrial Fibrillation (A-Fib)?
faqs.answer: SVT is a fast but REGULAR rhythm (like a perfect drumroll: rat-tat-tat-tat). A-Fib is a fast and IRREGULARLY IRREGULAR rhythm (like a drumroll where the drummer is having a seizure: rat-tat...tat...rat-tat-tat...tat). A-Fib is much more serious as it carries a high risk of stroke.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned a cardiac ablation to cure this. What is that?
faqs.answer: An ablation is a procedure to fix the short circuit. They thread catheters (wires) through a vein in your leg up to your heart. They map the electricity to find the extra wire, and then they use radiofrequency (heat) or cryo (cold) to destroy that tiny, problematic spot. It's over 95% curative.

faqs.question: I had a concussion 3 months ago. I didn't black out, but I'm still having headaches, brain fog, and I get irritable for no reason. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is Post-Concussion Syndrome (PCS). A concussion is a mild TBI. You don't have to lose consciousness to have one. While most people recover in a few weeks, 10-20% of people will have persistent symptoms (headache, fog, dizziness, irritability) that last for months or even a year.

faqs.question: What is second impact syndrome? My son wants to go back to football, but I'm scared.
faqs.answer: This is the most dangerous risk for athletes. If you get a second concussion before your first concussion has fully healed, your brain (which is in a vulnerable, swollen state) can lose its ability to autoregulate its blood flow. This can lead to massive, catastrophic brain swelling and even death. This is why you cannot return to play until you are 100% symptom-free.

faqs.question: My husband had a severe TBI. He's awake, but he's not himself. He's impulsive, angry, and has no filter. Will my old husband ever come back?
faqs.answer: This is the hardest, most painful part of a TBI. The frontal lobes (which control personality, judgment, and impulse control) are the most commonly injured part of the brain in a TBI. The person you knew was their frontal lobe function. This type of personality change (disinhibition, irritability) is often the most permanent and difficult-to-treat outcome of the injury. It requires intense cognitive rehab and family counseling.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a subdural and an epidural hematoma?
faqs.answer: Both are bleeds, and it's about location and speed. An Epidural bleed (common from a skull fracture, like at a ski accident) is an arterial bleed on top of the dura. It's high-pressure and causes rapid decline (the talk and die patient). A Subdural bleed (common in elderly falls) is a venous bleed under the dura. It's slow and low, and symptoms (like confusion) can take days or weeks to appear.

faqs.question: The ER doctor said I just have a concussion and my CT scan was normal. Why do I feel so awful if my scan is normal?
faqs.answer: A CT scan is a structural test. It's only good for finding macro (big) problems, like a bleed, a fracture, or a stroke. A concussion is a functional or metabolic injury. It's a bruise on the axons (the wires), causing a short-circuit at a microscopic level. Your wiring is fizzled, but your structure is fine, so the CT scan will always be normal. This does not mean your injury isn't real.

faqs.question: I was fine, and then over a few days, my legs got numb and weak, and I couldn't pee. The MRI showed inflammation in my spinal cord. They're calling it Transverse Myelitis.
faqs.answer: This is the exact definition. Myelitis = inflammation of the spinal cord. Transverse = it goes across a level or segment of the cord. This inflammation blocks all the nerve signals from the brain to the body (causing weakness/paralysis) and from the body to the brain (causing a sensory level or numbness) below that spot.

faqs.question: What caused this? Was it a virus?
faqs.answer: It's often post-infectious. The most common trigger is a normal viral infection (like a cold or flu). Your immune system, in trying to fight the virus, gets confused and cross-reacts, launching an autoimmune attack against your own spinal cord. It's not the virus in your spine; it's your immune system's response to the virus.

faqs.question: They're treating me with massive doses of IV steroids. How does that help?
faqs.answer: The goal is to shut down the autoimmune attack as fast as possible. High-dose IV solu-medrol (steroids) is a sledgehammer to your immune system, which stops the inflammation. If that doesn't work, the next step is often Plasmapheresis (PLEX), a procedure that filters the attacking antibodies out of your blood.

faqs.question: Now my doctor is saying this might be my first attack of Multiple Sclerosis (MS). How is this related?
faqs.answer: This is a critical distinction. Transverse Myelitis can be a one-and-done event (monophasic). Or, it can be the first clinical attack of a demyelinating disease, most commonly MS (if the brain MRI shows lesions) or NMO (Neuromyelitis Optica) (if a specific Aquaporin-4 antibody is in your blood). You will need follow-up MRIs to see if new, different lesions appear over time, which would confirm MS.

faqs.question: Will I be paralyzed forever? What's the prognosis?
faqs.answer: Recovery varies wildly. About 1/3 of people recover fully, 1/3 have moderate deficits (like a limp or numbness), and 1/3 have severe deficits (wheelchair-bound). Recovery is slow—it happens over months to years. Good recovery is heralded by a rapid start of the treatment (steroids/PLEX).

faqs.question: My baby was born and looked fine, but a few hours later, he turned blue (cyanotic), and they said he has TGA. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: This is a congenital (born with) heart defect. Transposition means swapped. Your baby's two main arteries (the great arteries) are swapped. The aorta (which should go to the body) is attached to the blue-blood pumping chamber, and the pulmonary artery (which should go to the lungs) is attached to the red-blood pumping chamber. This creates two separate circles—blue blood just goes to the body, and red blood just goes to the lungs. It is fatal if not treated.

faqs.question: If the blood isn't mixing, how is he alive at all?
faqs.answer: He is only alive because of the holes that babies are supposed to have before birth: the PFO (a hole between the atria) and the PDA (a duct between the arteries). These shunts are allowing a tiny bit of red and blue blood to mix. The doctors will immediately give him a drug (Prostaglandin) to keep the PDA hole open.

faqs.question: They said he needs a balloon atrial septostomy right now. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is an emergency bridge procedure. They are giving him Prostaglandin to keep the PDA open, but they also need to make the other hole bigger. They will thread a catheter to his heart and use a balloon to rip the PFO hole (the septum) wider. This allows more red and blue blood to mix, which will turn him pink and keep him stable enough for the main surgery.

faqs.question: What is the arterial switch operation? Is that the final fix?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is the fix. It is a major open-heart surgery done in the first few weeks of life. The surgeon will literally cut the aorta and pulmonary artery off the heart, un-swap them, and sew them back onto the correct pumping chambers (the correct ventricles). It is a highly complex, but now very successful, operation that cures the defect.

faqs.question: After the arterial switch, will he be a normal kid? What are the long-term effects?
faqs.answer: Yes, for the most part, the arterial switch is a full anatomic repair, and he will grow up, play sports, and live a normal life. He will, however, need to see a cardiologist for the rest of his life for check-ups, as there can be long-term issues (like the sutures in the arteries narrowing down, or the coronary arteries being re-implanted) that need to be monitored.

faqs.question: My doctor said I had a mini-stroke or TIA. Does this mean I'm safe now, or am I going to have a real stroke?
faqs.answer: A TIA is a very serious warning sign. While it doesn't cause permanent brain damage itself, your risk of having a full, disabling stroke is extremely high, especially in the first 48 hours and following days. You must get a medical evaluation immediately to find the cause and start prevention.

faqs.question: How can I tell the difference between a TIA and a full stroke while it's happening?
faqs.answer: You can't, and you shouldn't try. The symptoms are identical: sudden numbness or weakness (especially on one side), trouble speaking, vision loss, or dizziness. The only difference is that TIA symptoms are temporary. You must call emergency services immediately, even if the symptoms go away.

faqs.question: My TIA symptoms are all gone. Why do I still need to be in the hospital and take blood thinners?
faqs.answer: The hospital evaluation is to find why the TIA happened. Doctors will use CT or MRI scans to look for blockages or check your heart. The medications (like aspirin or other antiplatelets) are to prevent another, larger clot from forming and causing a permanent, devastating stroke.

faqs.question: I had a TIA. Does this mean I have to change my whole life?
faqs.answer: Very likely. A TIA is a wake-up call to manage your stroke risk factors. This usually means controlling high blood pressure, lowering cholesterol, stopping smoking, managing diabetes, eating a healthier diet, and exercising regularly.

faqs.question: Did I have a TIA because of stress?
faqs.answer: While stress can contribute to high blood pressure (a major risk factor), TIAs are physically caused by a temporary blockage of a blood vessel in the brain. The most common causes are a blood clot that travels from the heart (especially with atrial fibrillation) or a narrowing of an artery in your neck due to cholesterol plaque.

faqs.question: My dad suddenly got confused and kept asking where he was, over and over. A few hours later, he was fine but doesn't remember it. The ER said transient global amnesia. Is this a stroke?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of transient global amnesia (TGA). It's a sudden, temporary episode of memory loss where the person cannot form new memories and may repeat the same questions. While frightening, TGA is considered benign and is not the same as a TIA or stroke, though doctors run tests to rule those out.

faqs.question: Does having TGA mean my mom is getting Alzheimer's?
faqs.answer: No. TGA is an isolated, temporary event. It does not appear to be a risk factor for developing Alzheimer's or other forms of dementia. The memory function returns to normal after the episode.

faqs.question: What triggers TGA? My husband had an episode after we had an intense argument.
faqs.answer: The exact cause isn't known, but TGA is often reported after a specific trigger. Common triggers include sudden emotional stress (like an argument or bad news), physical exertion, sudden immersion in cold or hot water, medical procedures, or even sexual intercourse.

faqs.question: Now that my wife has had one episode of TGA, is she likely to have another one?
faqs.answer: The risk of recurrence is low. Most people (over 90%) who experience TGA only have one episode in their lifetime.

faqs.question: How do doctors diagnose this if all the tests (CT, MRI) come back normal?
faqs.answer: Diagnosis is clinical, meaning it's based on the classic story and by ruling out other, more serious conditions. The criteria include: a witness confirming the memory loss, the person being alert and aware of their identity, no other neurological symptoms (like paralysis), and the episode resolving within 24 hours.

faqs.question: I heard trachoma is an infection. How do you actually get it? Is it like pink eye?
faqs.answer: Trachoma is a specific bacterial infection (caused by Chlamydia trachomatis) that is highly contagious. Unlike common pink eye, it's spread through contact with eye and nose discharge from an infected person (on hands, clothes, or towels) and also by certain types of flies that feed on eye discharge.

faqs.question: My doctor said trachoma can cause blindness. How does an eye infection do that?
faqs.answer: The blindness isn't from the initial infection. Trachoma is a disease of repeated infections over many years. Each infection causes scarring on the inside of the eyelid. This scarring eventually pulls the eyelid inward, causing the eyelashes to turn in and rub directly on the cornea. This constant rubbing (called trichiasis) is painful and slowly scratches and clouds the cornea, leading to irreversible blindness.

faqs.question: What are the first signs? Would I know if my child had it?
faqs.answer: In the early stages, it looks like a severe, persistent form of bacterial pink eye (conjunctivitis), especially in children. You'd see red, irritated, and watery eyes, discharge, and swelling of the eyelids.

faqs.question: Can trachoma be cured with antibiotics?
faqs.answer: Yes, the active bacterial infection can be cured with antibiotics (like a single dose of azithromycin). The bigger challenge is preventing re-infection, which requires community-wide strategies involving antibiotics, promoting facial cleanliness, and improving access to clean water.

faqs.question: My grandmother's lashes are rubbing her eye from old trachoma. Is it too late for her?
faqs.answer: It's not too late to prevent blindness. While antibiotics can't reverse the old scars, a simple surgery can be performed to rotate the eyelid outward, moving the eyelashes away from the cornea. This procedure stops the painful rubbing and saves her vision from further damage.

faqs.question: My baby makes a high-pitched, rattling noise when he breathes out, especially when he's crying. My doctor mentioned tracheomalacia. Is this serious?
faqs.answer: This is a very common description. Tracheomalacia is a weakness of the trachea (windpipe) cartilage. Instead of staying open, the airway collapses partially when breathing out, causing that rattling or high-pitched vibrating sound (stridor).

faqs.question: It sounds like a terrible cough or croup. How is this different from asthma?
faqs.answer: It's often misdiagnosed as severe asthma or recurrent croup. The key difference is the cause: asthma is inflammation in the small airways, while tracheomalacia is a structural collapse of the large airway. Inhalers used for asthma often don't help the noise from tracheomalacia.

faqs.question: Will my child have this forever? Will they need surgery?
faqs.answer: In many mild to moderate cases, the cartilage gets stronger as the child grows, and the symptoms resolve on their own, usually by age 2 or 3. Surgery is typically reserved for severe cases where the collapse causes blue spells (cyanosis) or life-threatening choking episodes.

faqs.question: What can I do to help my baby when the breathing gets really noisy?
faqs.answer: Often, just changing your baby's position (like picking them up or laying them on their stomach) can help open the airway and quiet the breathing. Keeping them calm is also important, as crying makes the collapse worse. It's also crucial to treat respiratory infections (like colds) quickly.

faqs.question: My son with tracheomalacia gets bronchitis all the time. Are the two related?
faqs.answer: Yes, they are often linked. Because the airway collapses, it's harder for your son to cough effectively and clear mucus from his lungs. This trapped mucus can lead to more frequent and severe respiratory infections like bronchitis or pneumonia.

faqs.question: I'm pregnant and I have a cat. My friend said I have to get rid of it or my baby could have birth defects. Is this true?
faqs.answer: This is a common and frightening myth. You do not need to get rid of your cat. The parasite is spread through feces, but it only becomes infectious 1 to 5 days after being passed. The safest thing to do is to have someone else change the litter box daily. If you must do it, wear gloves and wash your hands thoroughly.

faqs.question: If I don't have a cat, can I still get toxoplasmosis?
faqs.answer: Yes. In fact, you are more likely to get it from other sources. The most common ways to get infected are by eating undercooked or raw contaminated meat (especially pork, lamb, and venison) or by gardening without gloves (the parasite can live in soil contaminated by cat feces).

faqs.question: What does a new toxoplasmosis infection feel like? I'm worried I have it.
faqs.answer: For most healthy people, a new toxoplasmosis infection feels like a mild flu. You might have swollen lymph nodes, muscle aches, and a fever, or you might have no symptoms at all and never know you were infected.

faqs.question: I'm pregnant and my blood test says I was infected with toxoplasmosis in the past. Is my baby at risk?
faqs.answer: No. If a blood test shows you were infected many months or years before your pregnancy, you are considered immune, and your baby is protected by your antibodies. The danger is only from a new, active infection acquired just before or during pregnancy.

faqs.question: I'm immunocompromised (e.g., HIV or chemo). Should I be worried about the toxoplasmosis I had years ago?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a very important situation. If you are severely immunocompromised, a past (latent) toxoplasmosis infection can reactivate and cause severe disease, most often in the brain (toxoplasmic encephalitis). Your doctor will monitor you and may prescribe preventive medication.

faqs.question: I heard TSS is from tampons. I use a menstrual cup. Am I completely safe?
faqs.answer: No, not completely. While TSS is famously linked to high-absorbency tampons left in too long, it can also be caused by menstrual cups, diaphragms, or birth control sponges left in for extended periods. The syndrome is caused by toxins from staph or strep bacteria, which can grow on these devices.

faqs.question: Can you get TSS even if you're not menstruating? Can men get it?
faqs.answer: Yes. Toxic shock syndrome can affect anyone, including men and children. Non-menstrual causes are common and include infected skin wounds, surgical incisions, burns, or even a recent viral infection (like the flu) that leads to a secondary bacterial infection.

faqs.question: What are the first signs? How is it different from a bad flu?
faqs.answer: The onset is very sudden and severe. Key signs include a high fever (over 102°F), low blood pressure (causing faintness or dizziness), vomiting or diarrhea, and a diffuse, flat red rash that looks like a sunburn, especially on the palms and soles. It's a life-threatening emergency, unlike the flu.

faqs.question: I had TSS once before. Am I more likely to get it again?
faqs.answer: Yes, unfortunately, you are at a higher risk of recurrence. Many doctors advise that if you've had TSS, you should avoid using internal vaginal products like tampons or menstrual cups altogether.

faqs.question: How long is too long to leave a tampon in?
faqs.answer: You should change your tampon at least every 4 to 8 hours. Always use the lowest absorbency tampon that's appropriate for your flow. To further reduce risk, you can alternate between tampons and pads and avoid using tampons continuously overnight.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have toxic hepatitis from a natural weight-loss supplement. How can a supplement cause liver damage?
faqs.answer: This is a dangerous misconception. Natural does not mean safe. Many herbal supplements (like kava, comfrey, or high-dose green tea extract) are well-known to be toxic to the liver in some people. Your liver has to process everything you ingest, and some substances can be directly poisonous to its cells.

faqs.question: I only take Tylenol (acetaminophen) when I have a headache. Could that really be the cause?
faqs.answer: Yes, if taken in large doses. Acetaminophen is the most common cause of acute liver failure. The danger often comes from unintentional overdose—for example, taking the maximum dose for a headache while also taking a cold medicine that also contains acetaminophen. The combined dose can easily exceed the safe daily limit.

faqs.question: My doctor told me to stop taking the medication that caused it. Will my liver go back to normal?
faqs.answer: In many cases, yes. The liver has a remarkable ability to regenerate. If the condition is caught early and the offending toxin is removed, your liver function and symptoms often go away completely.

faqs.question: Can this damage be permanent?
faqs.answer: Yes. Severe or prolonged exposure can cause permanent, irreversible scarring of the liver (cirrhosis). In the most severe cases, it can lead to acute liver failure, which is a life-threatening emergency that may require a liver transplant.

faqs.question: How would I even know I have liver damage? I just felt tired and nauseous.
faqs.answer: The symptoms are often vague and can be mistaken for the flu: fatigue, nausea, and loss of appetite. The most specific sign is jaundice—a yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes. Dark-colored urine and pale stools are also red flags.

faqs.question: My son just got diagnosed with Tourette's. Is he going to start shouting curse words in public?
faqs.answer: This is the biggest and most damaging misconception about Tourette's. The involuntary shouting of obscene words is called coprolalia, and it's actually rare, affecting only about 10-15% of people with the disorder. It is not a required symptom for diagnosis.

faqs.question: So what are the symptoms? My child just blinks hard and clears his throat a lot.
faqs.answer: That is the classic presentation. Tourette's is defined by having at least two motor tics (like eye blinking, head jerking, nose twitching) and at least one vocal tic (like throat clearing, sniffing, grunting, or tongue clicking) for more than a year.

faqs.question: Will the tics get worse as he gets older? Will he have this for his whole life?
faqs.answer: Tics often wax and wane, meaning they get better and worse in cycles. They typically are at their worst in the early teen years and then, for many people, significantly improve or even disappear by early adulthood.

faqs.question: The doctor also mentioned ADHD and OCD. Are these related to Tourette's?
faqs.answer: Yes, very strongly. Most people with Tourette's (over 80%) have at least one other co-occurring condition. The most common are ADHD and OCD. In fact, many families find the symptoms of ADHD or OCD to be more disruptive to daily life than the tics themselves.

faqs.question: It looks like my daughter can hold in her tics for a little while. Does this mean she's faking it or can control it if she tries?
faqs.answer: No, she is not faking it. Many people can suppress their tics for short periods, but it takes immense concentration. The urge builds up like the need to sneeze, and eventually, it must be released, often resulting in a burst of tics afterward.

faqs.question: My newborn baby is blue and having trouble breathing. The doctor said it's a heart defect called TAPVR. What is happening?
faqs.answer: In a normal heart, oxygen-rich blood comes from the lungs to the left side of the heart. In TAPVR, a defect causes that oxygen-rich blood to return to the right side of the heart instead. This means oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor blood get mixed, and the blood going to the body doesn't have enough oxygen, which is why your baby looks blue (cyanotic).

faqs.question: They are talking about open-heart surgery on my tiny baby. Is this the only option?
