If both parents are carriers (have the trait), there is a 1-in-4 (25%) chance with each pregnancy that the child could inherit two trait genes, resulting in thalassemia major—a severe, life-threatening form of anemia that requires lifelong blood transfusions.

faqs.question: What's the difference between alpha and beta thalassemia?
faqs.answer: Hemoglobin is made of alpha chains and beta chains. Alpha thalassemia is when you're missing alpha genes (common in Southeast Asian populations). Beta thalassemia is when you're missing beta genes (common in Mediterranean populations). The concept of trait and major applies to both.

faqs.question: What is thalassemia major like?
faqs.answer: This is a very serious disease. The body cannot produce functional hemoglobin, leading to severe anemia. To survive, a person with thalassemia major needs to receive blood transfusions every 2-4 weeks for their entire life. This leads to a dangerous buildup of iron, which must be chelated (removed) with daily medication.

faqs.question: My newborn was just diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The name sounds so scary. What is it, exactly?
faqs.answer: Tetralogy means four. TOF is a combination of four heart defects: 1) A large hole between the ventricles (VSD), 2) A blockage of blood flow to the lungs (pulmonary stenosis), 3) An overriding aorta (it sits over the VSD), and 4) A thickening of the right ventricle wall.

faqs.question: My baby sometimes turns blue and goes limp after crying hard. The doctor called this a tet spell. What's happening?
faqs.answer: A tet spell is a life-threatening emergency. Crying can cause a spasm that makes the blockage to the lungs (the pulmonary stenosis) even tighter. This forces all the oxygen-poor (blue) blood to go through the hole (VSD) and out to the body, causing the baby to turn blue (cyanotic). The fix is to pull the baby's knees to their chest, which helps redirect blood to the lungs.

faqs.question: They are scheduling his full repair surgery at 3-6 months old. What does this surgery fix?
faqs.answer: The open-heart surgery does two main things: 1) It closes the hole (VSD) with a patch. 2) It removes the blockage to the lungs by cutting away muscle and often placing a patch to widen the pulmonary artery. This forces all the blue blood to go to the lungs, as it should.

faqs.question: After the surgery, is he cured? Or will he have heart problems for life?
faqs.answer: The surgery is a repair, not a cure. He will always have a special heart and will need to be followed by a congenital cardiologist for his entire life. The repair is excellent, but it creates new issues that must be monitored.

faqs.question: What new issues? The surgeon said his pulmonary valve will be leaky after the repair.
faqs.answer: This is the most common long-term issue. To relieve the blockage, the surgeon often has to cut open the pulmonary valve, which makes it very leaky (pulmonary regurgitation). This is fine for a while, but over 10-20 years, that leak can stretch out the right ventricle. Most people with TOF will need at least one more surgery as a teen or adult to replace that leaky valve.

faqs.question: I stepped on a rusty nail. My mom is panicking about tetanus. Do I really need to get a booster shot?
faqs.answer: Yes. Stepping on a rusty nail is the classic scenario, but it's not the rust itself that's the problem. The danger is that a deep puncture wound (like from a nail) is a perfect, low-oxygen environment for the Clostridium tetani bacteria (which lives in soil and dust) to grow. If your last booster was over 5 years ago, you need one now.

faqs.question: So it's not just rusty metal? What if I got a deep cut from a clean kitchen knife or a splinter from gardening?
faqs.answer: Correct. The bacteria live in soil, dust, and manure. A clean knife is low risk, but a deep puncture wound from gardening, a wood splinter, or an animal bite are all high-risk wounds. The rust is just a sign that the object has been outside and is likely contaminated with soil.

faqs.question: What does lockjaw actually mean? What are the symptoms?
faqs.answer: The bacteria produce a toxin that attacks the nervous system, causing extreme muscle spasms. The first symptom is often a stiffening or locking of the jaw muscles, making it hard to open your mouth or swallow. This then progresses to severe, painful, full-body muscle spasms that can be strong enough to break bones.

faqs.question: I can't remember the last time I had a tetanus booster. It's probably been 15 or 20 years. How often am I supposed to get one?
faqs.answer: The standard recommendation is to get a Tdap (Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis) or Td (Tetanus, Diphtheria) booster shot every 10 years. If you get a dirty wound (like a puncture), you should get a booster if it's been more than 5 years since your last one.

faqs.question: Is tetanus treatable? Or is it always fatal?
faqs.answer: There is no cure for tetanus once you have it. Treatment involves managing the symptoms in a hospital ICU (with muscle relaxants and a ventilator) while your body waits for the toxin to wear off. It is still fatal in 10-20% of cases, even with modern medicine. This is why prevention with the vaccine is so critical.

faqs.question: My son woke up with sudden, extreme pain in his testicle. The ER doctor said it's torsion and he needs surgery right now. How serious is this?
faqs.answer: This is a 10 out of 10 surgical emergency, as serious as a heart attack. Torsion means the testicle has twisted on its own spermatic cord, cutting off its entire blood supply. There is a very short window, usually about 4 to 6 hours, to surgically untwist it before the testicle dies from lack of oxygen.

faqs.question: What if we are outside the 6-hour window? Does this mean he will definitely lose his testicle?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily, but the risk increases dramatically. The 6-hour window is a guideline. The surgeon will untwist it and see. If the testicle pinks up (blood flow returns), they will save it. If it remains black and is non-viable, they will have to remove it (an orchiectomy).

faqs.question: Will my son be sterile or infertile if he loses one testicle?
faqs.answer: No. A healthy, remaining testicle is perfectly capable of producing enough testosterone and sperm for a normal life, including having children. His fertility should not be affected.

faqs.question: The surgeon said they are going to stitch the other testicle in place during the surgery. Why? Is it at risk too?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a critical and standard part of the procedure. The underlying cause of torsion is often a genetic trait (called a bell clapper deformity) where the testicles are not well-anchored. This trait is almost always in both testicles. So, to prevent this from ever happening to the other side, the surgeon will place a few stitches to anchor it to the scrotal wall.

faqs.question: My teenager had some pain yesterday, but it went away. Now it's back. Could it still be torsion?
faqs.answer: Yes, this could be intermittent torsion, where the testicle twists and then untwists on its own. This is a major warning sign. Each time it twists, it can cause damage, and the next time it may not untwist. He needs to be seen by a urologist immediately.

faqs.question: I found a lump on my testicle. It's hard like a pebble and doesn't hurt. Should I be worried, or is it just a cyst?
faqs.answer: You need to see a doctor immediately. While it could be a cyst, the classic sign of testicular cancer is a painless, hard lump in the testicle. Unlike other issues, pain is not a common early symptom. You must have an ultrasound to get a clear answer.

faqs.question: My doctor says I have testicular cancer and they have to remove my testicle. Isn't there any way to just remove the lump?
faqs.answer: No. Unlike other cancers, it is considered unsafe to biopsy or shell out the lump because cutting into the testicle could spread the cancer cells. The standard, life-saving treatment is to remove the entire testicle (a radical inguinal orchiectomy).

faqs.question: I'm 28. If I lose a testicle and need chemotherapy, will I ever be able to have kids?
faqs.answer: This is a major concern, and you must address it before treatment. Removing one testicle will not make you infertile. However, chemotherapy can cause temporary or permanent infertility. Because of this, it is strongly recommended that you bank your sperm (cryopreservation) before you start chemotherapy, just in case.

faqs.question: Will I look different in the locker room? Will I stop being a man if my testicle is removed?
faqs.answer: A single testicle produces all the testosterone you need, so you will not lose your sex drive, facial hair, or muscle mass. For cosmetic concerns, you have the option of getting a saline prosthetic implant, which is a fake testicle that looks and feels natural, so no one would know.

faqs.question: Is this a good or bad cancer to get? I'm terrified.
faqs.answer: It is completely normal to be terrified. However, testicular cancer is one of the most curable cancers that exists, even if it has spread. The 5-year survival rate is over 95%. The treatments are highly effective, but the key is to not delay.

faqs.question: I get a headache almost every afternoon. It feels like a tight band or vise around my head. I'm worried I have a brain tumor. How can I tell?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of a tension headache. Brain tumor headaches are typically worse in the morning, get progressively more severe over time, and are often accompanied by other neurological signs (like vomiting, vision changes, or seizures). A dull, pressure-like headache caused by stress, eye strain, or poor posture is almost always a tension headache.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a tension headache and a migraine? My headache is really bad, but I don't get an aura.
faqs.answer: Migraines are usually throbbing or pounding and are often one-sided. They are also made worse by activity and are typically joined by nausea, vomiting, or extreme sensitivity to light and sound. A tension headache is a dull, steady pressure on both sides and, while painful, doesn't usually stop you from your daily activities.

faqs.question: Can stress or sitting at my computer all day really cause a headache every single day?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is called chronic tension headache. Poor posture (like tech neck), clenching your jaw, eye strain from a screen, lack of sleep, and chronic stress can cause your neck, scalp, and shoulder muscles to be in a constant state of contraction, which triggers the daily headaches.

faqs.question: I take Tylenol or Advil almost every day to cope. Is this dangerous?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is a major problem. Overusing pain relievers (more than 2-3 times a week) can lead to medication-overuse headaches or rebound headaches. The medication itself starts causing the headache when it wears off, creating a vicious cycle. You must speak to your doctor about breaking this cycle.

faqs.question: What can I do to stop them besides taking pills?
faqs.answer: The best treatments are non-medication. This includes physical therapy to correct posture and release neck muscle knots, stress management (like exercise or meditation), getting regular sleep, and ensuring your eyeglass prescription is up to date.

faqs.question: I have terrible pain on the outside of my elbow, but I've never played tennis in my life. How did I get tennis elbow?
faqs.answer: This is very common. Tennis elbow (or lateral epicondylitis) is just a name. It's a repetitive strain injury. It's caused by any activity that involves forceful, repetitive gripping and wrist extension. This is common in plumbers, painters, carpenters, or even from using a computer mouse or screwdriver.

faqs.question: What's the difference between tennis elbow and golfer's elbow?
faqs.answer: The location. Tennis elbow is pain on the outside (lateral) part of the elbow. Golfer's elbow is pain on the inside (medial) part of the elbow. They are both types of tendinitis, just affecting different tendons.

faqs.question: It's been hurting for months and just won't get better. Why is it taking so long to heal?
faqs.answer: This is because it's often not just inflammation (tendinitis), but a degenerative problem (tendinopathy). Every time you use your hand, you are re-injuring the damaged, frayed tendon. It's very hard to rest it enough. Treatment focuses on eccentric exercises to slowly strengthen and remodel the tendon, which takes time.

faqs.question: My doctor suggested a counterforce brace. How does that strap on my forearm help my elbow?
faqs.answer: The brace (which looks like a strap) is worn just below the elbow. It works by changing the angle of force on the tendon. It offloads the pressure from the painful spot on the elbow bone and redirects the strain to the strap, allowing the inflamed area to rest and heal.

faqs.question: I've tried rest, braces, and physical therapy. Now my doctor is offering a cortisone shot. Will this fix it?
faqs.answer: A cortisone (steroid) injection can provide excellent short-term pain relief by reducing inflammation. However, it does not fix the underlying tendon damage. The pain often returns, and repeated shots can weaken the tendon. It's best used to cool down the pain so you can perform your physical therapy exercises.

faqs.question: I was told I had tendinitis for months, but it never got better. Now a new doctor says it's tendinopathy. What's the difference?
faqs.answer: This is a critical distinction. Tendinitis implies the problem is purely inflammation (the -itis). Tendinopathy (or tendinosis) means the tendon's structure itself is damaged and degenerated (the -opathy). The cells are disorganized, and the tendon is weak. This is why anti-inflammatories (like ibuprofen) stop working.

faqs.question: Why did my tendinopathy happen? I'm not a serious athlete.
faqs.answer: It's an overuse injury that happens slowly. It's caused by loading the tendon more than it can handle, repeatedly, without enough time to repair. This can be from a new exercise, a repetitive job, poor posture, or even just wear and tear as we age.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have to do eccentric exercises. They seem to make the pain worse at first. Am I doing it right?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the cornerstone of treating tendinopathy. An eccentric exercise is when you lengthen the muscle under load (e.g., lowering your heel off a step for Achilles tendinopathy). It's normal to feel some discomfort (but not sharp pain). This specific type of exercise is what stimulates the tendon to lay down new, organized collagen and heal.

faqs.question: Will I need surgery? I've had this pain for almost a year.
faqs.answer: Surgery is the very last resort. The vast majority of tendinopathies (like in the Achilles, patella, or elbow) can be healed with a dedicated, months-long physical therapy program focusing on eccentric loading. Surgery is only considered if this fails.

faqs.question: Should I be using ice or heat? I'm so confused.
faqs.answer: For an acute injury (tendinitis, in the first 48 hours), ice is helpful to reduce inflammation. For a chronic problem (tendinopathy), heat is often more beneficial. Applying heat before your exercises increases blood flow to the tendon, which can aid in the healing process and make the stretches feel better.

faqs.question: I went on a long hike and now my Achilles tendon is swollen and hurts. Is this tendinitis or did I tear it?
faqs.answer: It's most likely acute tendinitis—you've inflamed the tendon from sudden overuse. An Achilles rupture (a full tear) is usually a sudden, gunshot or pop feeling, and you would be unable to stand on your tiptoes. Tendinitis is pain and stiffness that's worse after rest (like in the morning).

faqs.question: My doctor just said R.I.C.E. (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation). Is that really all I can do?
faqs.answer: For an acute tendinitis (a new, hot, swollen injury), R.I.C.E. is the most important treatment. The goal is to calm down the inflammation. You can also take over-the-counter anti-inflammatories (like ibuprofen). The rest part is key—you have to stop the activity that caused it.

faqs.question: How long should I rest? I'm afraid of losing my fitness.
faqs.answer: You need relative rest, which means avoiding the specific high-impact activity (like running) until the pain is gone. This could be a few days or a few weeks. You can cross-train with activities that don't load the tendon, like swimming or cycling.

faqs.question: I feel better, but as soon as I try to run again, the pain comes right back. Why?
faqs.answer: This is because you haven't fixed the reason you got tendinitis. It's often due to an underlying issue like weak glute muscles, poor running form, or tight calves. If you just rest and don't correct the cause with physical therapy, you will just re-injure it.

faqs.question: Is it true that I shouldn't stretch a tendon when it's inflamed?
faqs.answer: This is a good point. For an acute, inflamed tendon, aggressive stretching can sometimes pull on the inflamed fibers and make it worse. Gentle range of motion is fine, but you should wait for the acute pain to calm down before starting a more focused stretching or strengthening program.

faqs.question: I took a new medication, and now I have a rash, blisters, and my skin is peeling off in sheets. The ER said TEN. What is this?
faqs.answer: TEN is a rare, life-threatening emergency. It's a severe allergic reaction (usually to a medication) that causes your skin (epidermis) to die and separate from your body. You are essentially burning from the inside out. You must be treated in a burn unit.

faqs.question: They said it was caused by my new antibiotic (or seizure med). How can a common drug do this?
faqs.answer: It's not a side effect; it's a rare, unpredictable, severe hypersensitivity reaction. The most common triggers are antibiotics (like sulfa drugs), anti-seizure medications (like lamotrigine), and allopurinol (for gout). The first step in treatment is to immediately stop the suspected drug.

faqs.question: What's the difference between this and Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)?
faqs.answer: They are the same disease, just on a spectrum of severity. It's called SJS if less than 10% of the body's skin is affected. It's called SJS/TEN overlap if 10-30% is affected. It is called TEN if over 30% of the body's skin is peeling. TEN is the most severe form.

faqs.question: Will I survive this? What are the long-term effects?
faqs.answer: TEN has a high mortality rate (up to 30%) because of the high risk of infection (from the lost skin) and dehydration. Survival depends on getting to a burn unit quickly. If you survive, the skin will grow back, but you may have permanent scarring, skin discoloration, and chronic eye, mouth, or genital problems.

faqs.question: I also have blisters in my mouth, eyes, and throat. Is this part of it?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a key feature of SJS/TEN. It's not just the skin; the mucous membranes (lining of the eyes, mouth, throat, and genitals) are almost always involved. This can cause severe pain and long-term scarring (like blindness if the eyes are badly affected).

faqs.question: Sometimes I get a really weird rising feeling in my stomach, a strange smell (like burning rubber), and a strong feeling of deja vu. Am I going crazy, or is this a seizure?
faqs.answer: You are not going crazy. This is the classic description of a focal aware seizure (or aura) originating in the temporal lobe. The temporal lobe controls memory, emotions, and smell, which is why the seizure causes these very specific, strange, psychic symptoms.

faqs.question: Can I be awake during this? I remember the whole thing.
faqs.answer: Yes. This is called a focal aware seizure. Focal means it starts in one part of the brain (your temporal lobe), and aware means you are conscious and remember it. If the seizure spreads, you might then lose awareness, but the aura itself is a seizure you are awake for.

faqs.question: My wife says I sometimes zone out for a minute. She says I lip-smack and pick at my clothes, but I don't remember it. Is this related?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the next stage. This is a focal impaired awareness seizure. The seizure has spread from the first aura stage and is now affecting your consciousness. The lip-smacking and picking (called automatisms) are classic, unconscious behaviors during this type of seizure.

faqs.question: I had one of these strange spells and then I had a full-blown grand mal (tonic-clonic) seizure. Are they connected?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is called a focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizure. It started as a focal seizure in your temporal lobe (the aura) and then spread to involve the entire brain, causing the convulsive seizure. Knowing it starts in the temporal lobe is critical for your doctor to choose the right medication.

faqs.question: My EEG was normal. Does this mean I don't have epilepsy?
faqs.answer: No. An EEG only records your brain's electrical activity during the test. If you don't have a seizure while hooked up, the test can be normal. A normal EEG does not rule out epilepsy, especially temporal lobe epilepsy, where the seizure activity can be deep in the brain and hard to detect.

faqs.question: My dentist says I'm grinding my teeth, but I'm sure I don't. How would I even know if I'm doing it in my sleep?
faqs.answer: Your dentist can see the evidence. They will see wear facets (flat, shiny spots) on your teeth that shouldn't be there. Other signs are: waking up with a dull headache, a sore/tight jaw, or pain in your ear/face muscles. Your partner might also hear you grinding.

faqs.question: I'm so stressed at work. Is stress the only reason I'm doing this?
faqs.answer: Stress and anxiety are the biggest causes of clenching and grinding. It's a subconscious way your body handles tension. However, it can also be caused by an abnormal bite (misaligned teeth), a new filling that's too high, or as a side effect of some medications (like antidepressants).

faqs.question: My dentist wants me to buy a $500 custom night guard. Can't I just get a boil-and-bite one from the pharmacy?
faqs.answer: A custom guard from a dentist is made of a hard, durable material that is precisely fitted to balance your bite. A soft, over-the-counter guard can sometimes make things worse. Your jaw may interpret the squishy material as food and you may chew on it all night, strengthening your grinding muscles.

faqs.question: Will a night guard stop me from grinding, or does it just protect my teeth?
faqs.answer: This is a key point. For most people, a night guard primarily protects the teeth from wear and damage. It acts as a shield. It may reduce the grinding behavior by relaxing the muscles, but the urge to grind (from stress) may still be there. It's a treatment, not a cure.

faqs.question: Can I really wear my teeth down to nothing if I don't do anything?
faqs.answer: Over decades, yes. Severe, untreated bruxism can wear the enamel completely off, exposing the yellow dentine layer. This can lead to severe sensitivity, cracked teeth, and the need for expensive crowns or root canals on all your teeth.

faqs.question: My 15-year-old son is so irritable and angry all the time. He just stays in his room. I thought depression was about being sad?
faqs.answer: This is a critical difference in teens. While adults with depression often appear sad, in teenagers (especially boys), depression often manifests as irritability, anger, and hostility. Withdrawing from the family and losing interest in things they used to love are also major red flags.

faqs.question: How can I tell the difference between normal teen moodiness and real depression?
faqs.answer: Moodiness is temporary—they might be upset about a grade but bounce back and have fun with friends later. Depression is a persistent (lasting 2+ weeks) dark cloud that affects everything—their grades, their friendships, their sleep, their eating, and their ability to feel joy.

faqs.question: My daughter's doctor suggested an antidepressant. I'm terrified of those black box warnings about suicide. Are they safe?
faqs.answer: This is a valid and serious concern. The FDA black box warning states that antidepressants can increase the risk of suicidal thoughts (not actions) in a small number of people under 25, especially in the first few weeks. This is why it is critical that the teen is monitored very closely by you and their doctor when starting medication. For many, the medication is life-saving.

faqs.question: Isn't therapy the best option? Why jump to pills?
faqs.answer: For mild to moderate depression, therapy (like Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, or CBT) is the recommended first-line treatment. For moderate to severe depression, the proven, most effective treatment is a combination of therapy and medication. The medication helps lift the fog so the teen has the energy and clarity to do the hard work in therapy.

faqs.question: My son says he doesn't want to talk to a shrink. How can I force him to go to therapy?
faqs.answer: You can't force a teen to talk, but you can set a non-negotiable boundary about attending. Frame it as a health check-up, just like for their body. Let them interview the therapist. If they hate the first one, let them shop for one they connect with. The fit between the teen and the therapist is the most important factor.

faqs.question: I've had this persistent, itchy, scaly rash for years that doctors kept treating as eczema or psoriasis. Now a biopsy says it's Mycosis Fungoides. What is that?
faqs.answer: Mycosis Fungoides (MF) is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL). This means it is a very slow-growing cancer of the T-cell (a white blood cell) that lives in the skin. It is notorious for being misdiagnosed as eczema for years because in its early patch stage, it looks identical.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have lymphoma. Am I going to die? Do I need chemotherapy?
faqs.answer: This is not like the lymphoma you see in movies (like Hodgkin's). MF is typically indolent, meaning extremely slow-growing. Most people live a normal, full lifespan with the disease. It's treated as a chronic skin condition. Systemic chemo is only used for very advanced, rare cases.

faqs.question: What is the treatment like if it's not chemo? My rash is just getting thicker.
faqs.answer: The treatment is skin-directed. This means it targets only the skin. The most common treatments are: potent topical steroids, light therapy (phototherapy or PUVA) in a dermatologist's office, or a topical nitrogen mustard (a type of skin chemo gel).

faqs.question: My diagnosis is Peripheral T-cell Lymphoma, NOS. My doctor seems much more serious about this. Is this different from the skin kind?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a completely different and much more serious disease. Peripheral T-cell Lymphoma (PTCL) is a systemic cancer inside your lymph nodes and body. It is rare, aggressive, and requires immediate, intensive chemotherapy. It is not the same as the slow-growing cutaneous (skin) type.

faqs.question: Is it true that T-cell lymphomas are worse or harder to treat than B-cell lymphomas?
faqs.answer: As a general rule, yes. Systemic T-cell lymphomas (like PTCL-NOS) are rarer and generally have a poorer prognosis than the more common B-cell lymphomas (like diffuse large B-cell). The standard chemo regimens are often less effective, and relapse is more common.

faqs.question: My baby was developing normally, but now at 6 months, he's regressing and has a cherry-red spot in his eye. The doctor said Tay-Sachs. What does this mean?
faqs.answer: This is the devastating, classic presentation of infantile Tay-Sachs. It is a rare, inherited genetic disorder where the baby lacks an enzyme (Hex-A). Without this enzyme, a fatty substance builds up in the brain and nerves, destroying them. The regression (losing skills like sitting up) and the cherry-red spot in the eye are hallmark signs.

faqs.question: What is the prognosis? Can this be treated?
faqs.answer: This is a heartbreaking diagnosis. There is currently no cure or effective treatment for Tay-Sachs. The disease is progressive and relentless. The treatment is palliative—managing symptoms like seizures and feeding difficulties. Tragically, children with classic infantile Tay-Sachs rarely live past the age of 4 or 5.

faqs.question: My partner and I are both of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. We were told we should get carrier screening. Why?
faqs.answer: Tay-Sachs is an autosomal recessive disorder, meaning a child can only get it if both parents are carriers. The carrier state is far more common in certain populations, including Ashkenazi Jews, French-Canadians, and Cajuns. Carrier screening is a simple blood test to see if you and your partner carry the gene.

faqs.question: We found out that my husband and I are both carriers. What does this mean for our pregnancy?
faqs.answer: If both parents are carriers, there is a 1-in-4 (25%) chance with each pregnancy that the child will have Tay-Sachs disease. There is a 2-in-4 (50%) chance they will be a carrier (like you), and a 1-in-4 (25%) chance they will be completely unaffected.

faqs.question: What options do we have if we are both carriers and want to have children?
faqs.answer: You have several options. You can get pregnant naturally and have prenatal testing (CVS or amniocentesis) to see if the fetus is affected. Your other option is to do In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) with preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD). This allows doctors to test the embryos and only implant the ones that are not affected by Tay-Sachs.

faqs.question: I'm horrified. I saw what looks like white rice or pasta segments in my stool. Is this a tapeworm?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the most common way a tapeworm is diagnosed. You are seeing proglottids, which are the egg-filled segments of the tapeworm that break off and are passed in the stool. You should see a doctor; they will ask for a stool sample to confirm.

faqs.question: How did I even get this? I'm a very clean person.
faqs.answer: It has nothing to do with personal hygiene. You get a tapeworm by eating the cysts. The two most common sources are eating undercooked or raw pork (Taenia solium) or undercooked/raw beef (Taenia saginata). The fish tapeworm (Diphyllobothrium) is from eating raw freshwater fish, like in some sushi.

faqs.question: Will I feel it moving inside me? Am I going to waste away and lose all my weight?
faqs.answer: This is a common myth. The vast majority of people with an adult tapeworm in their intestine have no symptoms at all. You will not feel it move. The idea that it causes wasting is rare; most people have no weight loss. The fish tapeworm is the exception, as it can sometimes cause a Vitamin B12 deficiency.

faqs.question: What is the treatment? Is it hard to get rid of?
faqs.answer: No, it's actually very easy to treat. The treatment is a single dose of an anti-parasitic pill (like Praziquantel). The pill kills the tapeworm's head (scolex) where it's attached to your intestine. Once the head detaches, the whole worm will be passed in your stool.

faqs.question: My friend said the pork tapeworm is dangerous and can go to your brain. Is that true?
faqs.answer: This is a critical distinction. Eating undercooked pork gives you the intestinal tapeworm. The dangerous condition, cysticercosis, happens if you accidentally ingest the eggs of the pork tapeworm (from fecal contamination). In this case, the larvae can form cysts in your muscles and, most dangerously, your brain, causing seizures. This is a different disease.

faqs.question: My doctor had trouble getting a blood pressure in my left arm and said my pulse was weak. Now they're sending me to a specialist. What's going on?
faqs.answer: This is the hallmark sign of Takayasu's arteritis. It's a rare form of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels) that attacks the aorta and its main branches (like the subclavian artery to your arm). The inflammation causes the artery to thicken and narrow, which reduces blood flow to your arm, making the pulse weak or absent.

faqs.question: I'm a 30-year-old woman and I'm just so tired, with a low fever and joint pain. My doctor thinks it's this. I thought it was just stress.
faqs.answer: This is the Stage 1 or systemic phase. Before the blood vessel plumbing problems start, the disease often presents as a vague, inflammatory illness with fatigue, fever, night sweats, and joint pain. It's often misdiagnosed as lupus or just being run-down.

faqs.question: Is this an autoimmune disease? What causes it?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is an autoimmune disease. Your body's immune system is mistakenly attacking your own large arteries. The exact cause or trigger is not known, but it almost exclusively affects women, typically under the age of 40.

faqs.question: What is the treatment? My doctor mentioned steroids and immunosuppressants.
faqs.answer: The main goal is to stop the inflammation to prevent your arteries from closing. The cornerstone of treatment is a high dose of a steroid (like Prednisone). Because the disease is chronic, you will also be put on a steroid-sparing immunosuppressant (like methotrexate) to keep the disease in remission so you can lower the steroid dose.

faqs.question: Can I have a healthy pregnancy if I have Takayasu's?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can, but it is a high-risk pregnancy that must be co-managed by your rheumatologist and a high-risk OB. It is critical to plan the pregnancy when your disease is in remission. The main risk is developing severe high blood pressure during the pregnancy, which can be dangerous for both you and the baby.

faqs.question: How is ulcerative colitis (UC) different from Crohn's disease? They sound the same.
faqs.answer: They are both types of IBD, but the main difference is location and depth. UC only affects the large intestine (the colon) and only affects the innermost lining. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the GI tract (from mouth to anus) and affects the entire thickness of the bowel wall.

faqs.question: I'm in a flare and have bloody diarrhea 10-15 times a day. Is this my life now? Will I ever be normal again?
faqs.answer: A severe flare is a terrible and frightening experience. It is not your new normal. The goal of treatment (with steroids, 5-ASA drugs, or biologics) is to get you into remission. Many people with UC spend years in remission, living completely normal, symptom-free lives.

faqs.question: My doctor said UC puts me at a higher risk for colon cancer. How much higher, and what do I do?
faqs.answer: Yes, chronic inflammation does increase your risk. This is why it's essential that you get screening colonoscopies much earlier and more often than other people. Instead of starting at age 45, you will likely start 8-10 years after your diagnosis and get one every 1-2 years to look for pre-cancerous changes.

faqs.question: My medicines aren't working. The doctor is talking about surgery. Does this mean I'll have an ostomy bag for the rest of my life?
faqs.answer: This is a major fear, but not always the case. The surgery for UC (a total colectomy) cures the disease because the colon is the only organ it affects. You have two main options: 1) A permanent ileostomy (an external bag). OR 2) A J-pouch surgery, where the surgeon creates a new rectum out of your small intestine inside your body, so you can still use the bathroom normally. The J-pouch is the more common goal.

faqs.question: What foods should I avoid? I'm afraid to eat anything.
faqs.answer: This is very individual, but food does not cause UC. During a flare, you should avoid high-residue foods: raw vegetables, nuts, seeds, and corn. Stick to a low-residue, bland diet (like white bread, rice, bananas, cooked vegetables). When you are in remission, you can and should slowly reintroduce foods to find your personal triggers.

faqs.question: I woke up with a very painful, red eye, and I'm suddenly extremely sensitive to light. My doctor said uveitis and gave me steroid drops. Is this just pink eye?
faqs.answer: No, this is not pink eye (conjunctivitis). Pink eye is an infection of the outer surface. Uveitis is a serious inflammation inside the eye, in the middle layer (the uvea). The extreme light sensitivity and deep, aching pain are classic signs. It is much more serious than pink eye.

faqs.question: My doctor said my uveitis might be from my autoimmune disease (like my Ankylosing Spondylitis / Rheumatoid Arthritis). How are they related?
faqs.answer: This is very common. The eye is an immune-privileged site. In many systemic autoimmune diseases, the same inflammation that attacks your joints (in AS or RA) or skin (in psoriasis) can also attack the inside of your eye, causing uveitis. For many people, uveitis is the first sign of their underlying disease.

faqs.question: Can this make me blind? I'm really scared.
faqs.answer: If left untreated, yes, uveitis can cause permanent complications like glaucoma, cataracts, and scarring, which can lead to blindness. This is why it's treated so aggressively with steroid eye drops. With prompt treatment, the inflammation can be controlled and vision can be saved.

faqs.question: The steroid drops are making my vision blurry. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: The drops themselves (and the dilating drops often given with them) can cause temporary blurry vision. However, the inflammation itself also makes vision blurry. You must be monitored closely by your eye doctor, as long-term steroid use can also cause glaucoma or cataracts, so they need to check your eye pressure.

faqs.question: I keep getting these floaters in my vision. Is this part of the uveitis?
faqs.answer: Yes. Floaters are a hallmark sign of intermediate or posterior uveitis (inflammation in the middle or back of the eye). The floaters you see are inflammatory cells floating in the jelly (vitreous) inside your eye. This type is less painful but just as serious.

faqs.question: I have this heavy, dragging feeling in my pelvis, and it feels like a ball is sitting in my vagina, especially at the end of the day. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of a uterine prolapse (or other pelvic organ prolapse). The ball you are feeling is your uterus, which is prolapsing or dropping down into the vaginal canal because the pelvic floor muscles and ligaments that support it have been weakened.

faqs.question: I'm 60. Is this from having my kids all those years ago?
faqs.answer: Yes. The biggest risk factors are vaginal childbirth (especially large babies or long labors) and menopause. Childbirth stretches and weakens the supports, and then the loss of estrogen during menopause causes those tissues to thin and weaken further, allowing the prolapse to appear.

faqs.question: My doctor wants me to try a pessary. What is that? Is it uncomfortable?
faqs.answer: A pessary is a non-surgical device, usually made of silicone, that is placed inside your vagina to prop up and support your uterus. It's like a bra for your pelvic organs. When fitted correctly, you should not feel it at all, and it can provide complete relief from the bulge feeling.

faqs.question: Do Kegel exercises actually work, or am I wasting my time?
faqs.answer: For mild prolapse, pelvic floor physical therapy (which includes Kegels) can be very effective at strengthening the muscles and reducing symptoms. For a severe prolapse (where the ball is at or past the vaginal opening), Kegels will not be enough to fix it, but they are still important for supporting a pessary or a surgical repair.

faqs.question: Do I have to have a hysterectomy to fix this? I don't want such a big surgery.
faqs.answer: No. A hysterectomy (removing the uterus) is one option, but there are also uterine-sparing surgeries. A surgeon can use stitches or surgical mesh to suspend your uterus back up into its normal position (a sacrohysteropexy). This is an excellent option if you wish to keep your uterus.

faqs.question: My doctor found a polyp in my uterus. I'm postmenopausal and I had some light bleeding. Does this mean I have cancer?
faqs.answer: Any bleeding after menopause must be investigated. A polyp is a common cause. The vast majority of uterine (endometrial) polyps are benign (non-cancerous). However, there is a small risk (about 3-5% in postmenopausal women) that a polyp can be cancerous or pre-cancerous, which is why your doctor must remove it for a biopsy.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a polyp and a fibroid? They sound the same.
faqs.answer: They are made of different tissue. A fibroid is a benign muscle tumor that grows from the wall of the uterus. A polyp is an overgrowth of the lining of the uterus (the endometrium). They can both cause heavy bleeding, but polyps are more often associated with postmenopausal bleeding and have a small cancer risk, whereas fibroids are almost never cancerous.

faqs.question: I'm having trouble getting pregnant. Could a polyp be the cause?
faqs.answer: Yes, it's possible. A polyp, especially if it's large or near the fallopian tubes, can act like an IUD—it can interfere with the sperm reaching the egg or prevent a fertilized embryo from implanting in the uterine wall. Many doctors will recommend removing polyps before fertility treatments.

faqs.question: How do they remove a polyp? Is it a big surgery?
faqs.answer: No, it's a very minor, outpatient procedure called a hysteroscopy. A surgeon inserts a tiny camera (hysteroscope) through your cervix into your uterus (no incisions). They can see the polyp and remove it with a small grasping tool or shaving device. You are usually home the same day.

faqs.question: Can uterine polyps just go away on their own?
faqs.answer: Sometimes. Small polyps (less than 1 cm) can sometimes regress or be shed during your period, especially in premenopausal women. However, if a polyp is causing symptoms (like heavy bleeding or infertility) or if you are postmenopausal, it should be removed.

faqs.question: My periods are so heavy, I'm flooding through pads, and I'm anemic. My doctor says it's fibroids. Do I have to have a hysterectomy?
faqs.answer: Absolutely not. A hysterectomy (removing the uterus) is the only 100% cure, but it is not your only option. There are many uterus-sparing treatments, including hormonal IUDs (to reduce bleeding), medications, Uterine Fibroid Embolization (to shrink them), and myomectomy (a surgery to remove only the fibroids).

faqs.question: I have several fibroids, but they don't cause any symptoms. My doctor said we can just watch and wait. Is this safe?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is the standard of care for asymptomatic fibroids. Fibroids are benign (non-cancerous) muscle tumors. If they are not causing heavy bleeding, pain, or pressure, there is no medical need to remove them. Your doctor will just monitor them to make sure they aren't growing rapidly.

faqs.question: I want to get pregnant, but my doctor found a submucosal fibroid. Is this going to cause infertility?
faqs.answer: This is a key concern. The location of the fibroid is what matters. Fibroids on the outside of the uterus (subserosal) usually don't affect pregnancy. But a submucosal fibroid (one that bulges into the uterine cavity) can prevent an embryo from implanting, leading to infertility or miscarriage. Most surgeons recommend removing these before trying to conceive.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a myomectomy and a hysterectomy?
faqs.answer: A myomectomy is a surgery that removes only the fibroids, leaving your uterus in place. This is the choice for women who still want to have children. A hysterectomy is a surgery that removes the entire uterus (with the fibroids). This is a definitive cure for the bleeding, but you can no longer get pregnant.

faqs.question: I'm 52 and approaching menopause. Will my fibroids shrink on their own?
faqs.answer: Yes, most likely. Fibroids are fed by estrogen. After menopause, your estrogen levels drop dramatically, which causes most fibroids to stop growing and, in many cases, to shrink significantly. If your symptoms are manageable, waiting for menopause is a very common strategy.

faqs.question: I just started a new multivitamin, and now my pee is neon or radioactive yellow. Is this normal?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is completely normal and harmless. It's caused by excess Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin). Your body can't store it, so it excretes what it doesn't need, and it happens to be a very bright, fluorescent-yellow compound.

faqs.question: My urine looks dark brown or tea-colored. I'm not eating anything weird. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a red flag. Dark brown or tea-colored urine can be a sign of severe dehydration. It can also be a sign of a serious liver problem (like hepatitis), as it's caused by excess bilirubin spilling into the urine. You should drink water and see a doctor.

faqs.question: I ate a bunch of beets, and now my urine is pink/red. I'm panicking, is this blood or the beets?
faqs.answer: This is almost certainly the beets. It's a very common and harmless phenomenon called beeturia. A large amount of red pigment from beets can pass through your system and stain both your urine and your stool. If it continues for a day after you stop eating beets, or if you're not sure, then you should see a doctor to rule out blood.

faqs.question: My urine looks foamy or bubbly in the toilet. Is this a bad sign?
faqs.answer: A little bit of foam is normal. But if you notice your urine is consistently foamy, like the head on a beer, it is a significant warning sign. It can mean you are spilling protein into your urine (proteinuria), which is a key indicator of kidney disease and needs to be checked immediately.

faqs.question: What does very dark, syrupy urine mean after a really intense workout or if I fell?
faqs.answer: This is a medical emergency. This could be rhabdomyolysis—a condition where extreme muscle damage causes muscle protein (myoglobin) to flood your blood. This protein is toxic to the kidneys and turns the urine dark. You need to go to an ER for IV fluids to prevent kidney failure.

faqs.question: I have all the symptoms of a UTI (burning, frequency), but my urine test came back negative. Am I imagining this?
faqs.answer: No, you are not. This is very common. You could have an early infection where the bacteria count isn't high enough yet. More often, it's urethritis (inflammation of the urethra, not the bladder) or interstitial cystitis (bladder pain syndrome), which feels exactly like a UTI but isn't caused by bacteria.

faqs.question: I always get a UTI after sex. What am I doing wrong?
faqs.answer: You're not doing anything wrong. It's a very common mechanical issue. The act of sex can push bacteria from the vaginal area up into the urethra. The best prevention is to urinate immediately after intercourse to flush out any bacteria that may have entered the urethra before they can multiply.

faqs.question: Does drinking cranberry juice really cure a UTI?
faqs.answer: No. Cranberry (pills or juice) does not cure an active UTI. You need antibiotics for that. Cranberry may help prevent future UTIs in some people, as a compound in it (A-type proanthocyanidins) can make it harder for bacteria to stick to the bladder wall.

faqs.question: I'm a man, and my doctor said I have a UTI. I thought only women got these?
faqs.answer: It is much rarer for men to get UTIs due to their longer urethra, but it is not impossible. When a man does get a UTI (especially a recurrent one), it's considered complicated and needs a full urology workup. It often points to an underlying problem, like an enlarged prostate (BPH) or a kidney stone.

faqs.question: My UTI symptoms are gone, but now I have a high fever, chills, and bad pain in my back/flank. What is happening?
faqs.answer: This is a medical emergency. This is a sign the UTI has traveled up from your bladder to your kidneys. This is a kidney infection (pyelonephritis), which is much more serious. You need to see a doctor immediately, as you may need IV antibiotics.

faqs.question: Ever since I had kids, I leak a little urine when I cough, sneeze, laugh, or jump. Is this just my new normal?
faqs.answer: It is extremely common, but it is not normal and you do not have to live with it. This is stress incontinence. It's caused by a weakening of the pelvic floor muscles that support your bladder. A referral to a pelvic floor physical therapist can be life-changing, as they can teach you to strengthen these muscles.

faqs.question: My problem is different. I get a sudden, desperate urge to pee and I can't make it to the bathroom in time. What is that?
faqs.answer: This is urge incontinence, also known as overactive bladder. It's a signal problem. Your bladder muscle is contracting and sending a GOTTA GO NOW signal to your brain even when it's not full. This is often treated with bladder training exercises (from a PT) or medications to calm the bladder muscle.

faqs.question: I'm a man, and I've started dribbling after I urinate. Is this incontinence?
faqs.answer: This is overflow incontinence or post-void dribbling. In men, this is very often not a bladder problem, but a plumbing problem. It's a classic sign of an enlarged prostate (BPH) that is blocking the urethra, preventing your bladder from emptying completely. You should see a urologist.

faqs.question: Are pads my only option? I feel old and embarrassed.
faqs.answer: No. Pads are just a coping mechanism; they don't treat the problem. For stress incontinence, physical therapy or a minor surgical sling can cure it. For urge incontinence, medication or even bladder Botox can stop the spasms. You have many options.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a sling surgery and a bladder lift?
faqs.answer: A bladder lift (or prolapse repair) is a surgery to fix a cystocele—when your bladder itself has prolapsed (dropped) into the vagina. A sling is a surgery specifically for stress incontinence. It's a small piece of mesh or your own tissue placed under the urethra to give it back-stop support, like a hammock, so it doesn't open when you cough.

faqs.question: I'm a man, and my urine stream has become very weak. Sometimes it splits or sprays. It's getting harder to empty my bladder. What's wrong?
faqs.answer: This is the classic sign of a urethral stricture. It's a kink or scar in the urethra (the pee tube) that is narrowing the channel, like stepping on a garden hose. The most common cause is an old injury (like falling on a bike frame) or a past infection.

faqs.question: How is this different from an enlarged prostate (BPH)? The symptoms sound the same.
faqs.answer: They are very similar, but the location of the blockage is different. BPH is a squeezing of the urethra at the bladder neck by the prostate. A stricture is a scar further down the urethra. A urologist will do tests (like a uroflow test or cystoscopy) to see where the blockage is.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to dilate the stricture in the office. Is this a permanent fix?
faqs.answer: Dilation (using rods to stretch the scar) can provide immediate relief, but it is often not a permanent fix. Because a stricture is scar tissue, stretching it often just re-injures it, and the scar can come back even tighter. It's a temporary maintenance for many people.

faqs.question: If dilation doesn't work, what's the real fix? Am I looking at major surgery?
faqs.answer: The real fix is a surgery called a urethroplasty. This is a specialized operation where a surgeon cuts out the narrow, scarred section of the urethra and then either re-connects the healthy ends or uses a graft (often tissue from the inside of your cheek) to rebuild that section. This has a very high, permanent success rate.

faqs.question: I keep getting prostatitis or UTIs. Could my stricture be the cause?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Because the stricture prevents you from emptying your bladder completely, stale urine is left behind. This is a perfect breeding ground for bacteria, leading to recurrent urinary tract infections or prostatitis.

faqs.question: I have terrible, radiating flank pain, just like a kidney stone. But the CT scan didn't show a stone. What else could be blocking my ureter?
faqs.answer: The ureter is the tube from the kidney to the bladder. While a stone is the most common cause, it can be blocked by other things. This includes a blood clot, a kink or scar from a past surgery, or (more ominously) extrinsic compression—something outside the ureter (like a tumor or swollen lymph node) that is pushing it closed.

faqs.question: My ultrasound report says I have hydronephrosis. What does that mean, and is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: Hydronephrosis means water on the kidney. It's not a disease itself; it's the result of your ureteral obstruction. Because urine is backed up, the kidney and ureter swell up with fluid, like a water-balloon. If left untreated, this back-pressure can permanently damage and kill the kidney.

faqs.question: My baby was diagnosed with a UPJ obstruction on a prenatal ultrasound. How can this be fixed?
faqs.answer: A UPJ (ureteropelvic junction) obstruction is a common congenital (from birth) blockage where the kidney connects to the ureter. If it's severe, a pediatric urologist will perform a surgery called a pyeloplasty to cut out the narrow, blocked segment and re-attach the ureter to the kidney, creating a wide-open funnel.

faqs.question: How do they fix the blockage? My doctor mentioned a stent.
faqs.answer: A stent is a quick fix to relieve the hydronephrosis and save the kidney. It's a thin, plastic tube that goes inside the ureter (past the blockage) to force the channel open and let urine drain. This is not a permanent solution; it's a band-aid that buys time while your doctor figures out how to fix the actual blockage (e.g., with surgery).

faqs.question: Is a ureteral stent painful? I've heard horror stories.
faqs.answer: Stents are notorious for being uncomfortable. While they save the kidney, many people experience a pulling or burning feeling in their flank or bladder every time they urinate. It can also cause a constant, annoying urge to pee. It's a trade-off to protect your kidney.

faqs.question: I have blood in my urine (no pain), and my doctor said the cancer is in my ureter, not my bladder. Is that better or worse?
faqs.answer: This is upper tract urothelial carcinoma (UTUC). It's the same type of cancer cell as bladder cancer, but it's in a much more difficult location (the ureter). It is rarer than bladder cancer and is generally considered more difficult to treat because the ureter wall is so thin, making it easier for the cancer to escape.

faqs.question: My doctor is saying they need to remove my entire kidney and my entire ureter for this. Why so much for a small tumor?
faqs.answer: This is the gold standard surgery, called a nephroureterectomy. The reason is that urothelial cancer is multifocal—it has a very high risk of seeding or re-seeding itself along the entire urinary tract. If they just remove the tumor, the chance of it recurring in the kidney or the stump of the ureter is very high.

faqs.question: I'm a heavy smoker. Did this cause my ureteral cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes. Smoking is the number one risk factor for all urothelial cancers (bladder, ureter, and kidney pelvis). The carcinogens you inhale are filtered by your kidneys and then sit in your urine, where they bathe the lining of your entire urinary tract (ureter included) for hours, causing DNA damage and cancer.

faqs.question: Is there any way to save my kidney? I only have one good one.
faqs.answer: In very specific cases (e.g., you only have one kidney, or the tumor is low-grade and small), a specialist surgeon may be able to perform a segmental resection (cutting out just that piece of the ureter) or use a laser through a scope to burn the tumor. However, this is risky and has a high recurrence rate.

faqs.question: I had my kidney and ureter removed. What's my follow-up like? Am I cured?
faqs.answer: You are not done. Because the entire lining of your urinary tract is at risk, you now have a very high risk of developing a new tumor in your bladder. You will need surveillance cystoscopy (a camera in your bladder) every 3-6 months for many years to catch any new bladder tumors early.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have UPS. Is this related to sarcoma? I've never heard of it.
faqs.answer: Yes. UPS stands for Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma. It is a rare type of cancer known as a soft-tissue sarcoma. Undifferentiated and pleomorphic are terms that describe how the cells look under a microscope—they are highly abnormal and don't resemble any normal, healthy tissue.

faqs.question: My diagnosis used to be malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH), and now it's UPS. Why did it change?
faqs.answer: This is a common point of confusion. MFH was an older wastebasket term used for many high-grade sarcomas. As genetic and molecular testing has improved, doctors have been able to reclassify these. UPS is now the correct, modern diagnosis for this specific high-grade sarcoma that cannot be otherwise classified.

faqs.question: How did I get this? I don't have any risk factors.
faqs.answer: For the vast majority of UPS cases, the cause is unknown. It is not an inherited disease and is not linked to lifestyle factors. It is thought to be the result of a spontaneous, random genetic mutation in a single cell that causes it to grow uncontrollably.

faqs.question: I just have a large, painless lump in my thigh. How can something that doesn't hurt be a high-grade cancer?
faqs.answer: This is the most dangerous and deceptive feature of soft-tissue sarcomas. They often grow large and deep in the muscle, pushing normal tissues aside without causing pain. Pain is not a reliable indicator of how serious a sarcoma is. Any new, unexplained, or growing deep lump should be evaluated.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to do surgery, then radiation. Why both?
faqs.answer: This is the standard of care for a high-grade sarcoma. The goal of surgery is to remove the entire tumor with a wide margin of healthy tissue. Because UPS is aggressive, radiation is then used to mop up and kill any microscopic cancer cells that might have been left behind, which dramatically reduces the chance of the cancer coming back in that spot.

faqs.question: My newborn son only has one testicle in his scrotum. The doctor says to wait and see. Is it going to drop on its own?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is very common, especially in premature babies. The testicles develop in the abdomen and descend in the last few months of pregnancy. In many cases, an undescended testicle will complete its journey and drop into the scrotum on its own by the time the baby is 3 to 6 months old.

faqs.question: My son is 9 months old and it's still not down. Now the doctor wants to do surgery. Is this really necessary?
faqs.answer: Yes. If the testicle has not descended by 6 months, it will not descend on its own and surgery (orchiopexy) is necessary. A testicle that stays in the body is too warm, which can damage its ability to make sperm. The surgery is done to bring the testicle into the scrotum where it can develop normally.

faqs.question: If we don't do the surgery, will my son be infertile?
faqs.answer: If both testicles are undescended, yes, he will almost certainly be infertile. If only one is undescended, his other, healthy testicle will likely make enough sperm for him to be fertile. However, the surgery is still done to maximize his fertility and for another, more important reason.

faqs.question: What other reason? The doctor mentioned cancer risk.
faqs.answer: This is the primary reason for the surgery. A testicle that remains in the abdomen or groin has a significantly higher risk of developing testicular cancer later in life. The surgery does not lower this risk, but it moves the testicle to a place (the scrotum) where it can be easily felt, so that any lumps (the first sign of cancer) can be detected early.

faqs.question: What is the recovery like for an orchiopexy surgery?
faqs.answer: It's a very common and safe pediatric surgery. It's often done as an outpatient procedure, so your son will go home the same day. He will have a small incision in the groin and on the scrotum. You'll need to limit his straddle or rough play for a few weeks, but recovery is generally very quick.

faqs.question: My newborn's belly button pops out when she cries. It looks like a balloon! Is this dangerous?
faqs.answer: This is the classic look of an umbilical hernia. It's a small hole in the abdominal muscle under the belly button. When your baby cries or strains, a little bit of intestine or fat pops through. In babies, this is not dangerous and is almost always painless.

faqs.question: My grandmother said we should tape a coin over it to push it back in. Is this a good idea?
faqs.answer: No, this is an old wive's tale and should not be done. Taping a coin or belly band on it does not help the muscle heal any faster and can cause a skin rash or infection. The best treatment is to just leave it alone.

faqs.question: Will my child have this outie belly button forever? Will it need surgery?
faqs.answer: Almost certainly not. Over 90% of umbilical hernias in babies close on their own as the child's abdominal muscles get stronger. This usually happens by age 2, but doctors will often watchfully wait until age 4 or 5 before ever considering surgery.

faqs.question: When should I worry? What are the signs of an emergency?
faqs.answer: An emergency is extremely rare in children. The danger sign is incarceration—when the intestine gets stuck in the hole. You should go to the ER if the hernia becomes hard, swollen, dark/red, and you can't gently push it back in, or if your child is vomiting and in severe pain.

faqs.question: I'm an adult and I think I just got one after my pregnancy. Is this different than a baby's?
faqs.answer: Yes. An umbilical hernia in an adult is very different. It will not go away on its own and has a much higher risk of incarceration. Adult-onset umbilical hernias almost always require a simple surgical repair to stitch the muscle hole closed (often with mesh).

faqs.question: I have pain on the pinky side of my wrist, especially when I use a mouse or twist a doorknob. Is this carpal tunnel?
faqs.answer: No, this is a common confusion. Carpal tunnel causes pain, numbness, and tingling on the thumb side of the hand. Pain on the pinky side is ulnar-sided wrist pain. It's a different set of problems, often related to the TFCC, a cartilage structure in the wrist.

faqs.question: My doctor mentioned I might have a TFCC tear. What is that?
faqs.answer: The TFCC (Triangular Fibrocartilage Complex) is a small piece of cartilage in your wrist that acts like the meniscus in your knee. It provides cushioning and support. You can get a wear-and-tear (degenerative) tear over time, or an acute tear from falling on an outstretched hand.

faqs.question: I work on a computer all day. Can my desk setup be causing this pain?
faqs.answer: Yes. A non-ergonomic setup can put your wrist in an unnatural, bent position (ulnar deviation) to reach the mouse. This can compress and inflame the ulnar side of the wrist. Using an ergonomic vertical mouse or a trackball can often provide significant relief by keeping your wrist in a neutral handshake position.

faqs.question: What's the press test my doctor did?
faqs.answer: The ulnar fovea sign or press test is a key diagnostic move. The doctor presses on the soft spot on the ulnar side of your wrist. Sharp pain in this spot is highly indicative of a TFCC tear or ulnar-sided inflammation.

faqs.question: Will this require surgery? My doctor suggested a splint first.
faqs.answer: For most degenerative tears or inflammation, a splint or wrist widget (a special TFCC brace) combined with rest and anti-inflammatories is the first-line treatment. Surgery (arthroscopy) to clean up or repair the cartilage is only considered if conservative treatment fails to relieve the pain.

faqs.question: I'm 16 and I've never had a period. My doctor did an ultrasound and said I don't have a uterus. How is this possible?
faqs.answer: This is the classic presentation of a condition called MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser) syndrome. It's a congenital condition, meaning you were born this way. In MRKH, the vagina and uterus (womb) are undeveloped or absent, but your ovaries are present and you have normal female chromosomes (46,XX).

faqs.question: If I have ovaries, does this mean I'm still female? Will I go through puberty?
faqs.answer: Yes, you are 100% female. Because your ovaries are normal, they produce female hormones (estrogen). This means you will develop normal, healthy breasts, pubic hair, and all other secondary sexual characteristics. You are just missing the uterus and vaginal canal.

faqs.question: Will I ever be able to have sex? Do I need surgery to create a vagina?
faqs.answer: You can absolutely have a normal, pleasurable sex life. The primary, first-line treatment is non-surgical. It's a technique called vaginal dilation. Using a set of smooth, tube-shaped dilators, you apply gentle, daily pressure to stretch the tissue and create a vaginal canal. This is highly effective.

faqs.question: What if dilation doesn't work for me? What is the surgery like?
faqs.answer: If dilation fails, there are surgical options called vaginoplasty. There are several techniques, but the goal is to create a new vaginal canal. This can be done using a skin graft or even a segment of your own intestine. This is a more complex procedure, which is why dilation is always tried first.

faqs.question: If I don't have a uterus, does this mean I can never have my own children?
faqs.answer: This is one of the most difficult parts of the diagnosis. You cannot carry a pregnancy yourself. However, because your ovaries are normal, they do produce healthy eggs. This means you can have a child who is 100% genetically yours by using IVF (to retrieve your eggs) and a gestational surrogate (a woman who carries the pregnancy for you).

faqs.question: It hurts to have sex, insert a tampon, or even sit on a bike. It's a burning, raw feeling at the entrance of my vagina. My doctor says I'm fine. What is this?
faqs.answer: This sounds like vulvodynia, specifically vestibulodynia (pain at the vestibule, or entrance). It is chronic pain without a clear, visible cause (like an infection). Your doctor is wrong to dismiss you; this is a very real, neurologic pain condition. You are not fine, and it's not in your head.

faqs.question: How is this different from vaginismus? My muscles also get really tight.
faqs.answer: They are often related. Vulvodynia is the pain—the raw, burning, neurologic discomfort. Vaginismus is the muscle response—the involuntary, tight clenching of your pelvic floor muscles in anticipation of that pain. You've learned that touch hurts, so your body tenses up to protect you.

faqs.question: I've had yeast infections for years. Could they have caused this?
faqs.answer: This is a very common link. While the pain isn't an active infection, having recurrent yeast infections can piss off and re-wire the nerve endings in the vulva, making them hypersensitive. They start firing pain signals from a normal touch, even after the infection is long gone.

faqs.question: What kind of doctor even treats this? My gynecologist seems lost.
faqs.answer: While some gynecologists specialize in this, the best treatment often comes from a pelvic floor physical therapist. They are trained to treat both the muscle component (vaginismus) and the nerve component (vulvodynia) with manual therapy, desensitization exercises, and relaxation techniques.

faqs.question: What other treatments are there? I can't even wear jeans.
faqs.answer: Treatment is multi-faceted. It includes: 1) Topical numbing lidocaine jelly to use before sex. 2) Pelvic floor PT. 3) Low-dose nerve-calming medications (like amitriptyline or gabapentin) that you take orally to turn down the volume on the overactive nerves.

faqs.question: I have this one spot on my vulva that constantly itches. It's not a yeast infection. Now the skin looks thick and white. Should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes. This is a major warning sign. An intractable itch (one that doesn't go away) in one specific spot is the most common symptom of vulvar cancer. A white, thick, or raised patch (called leukoplakia) must be biopsied by your gynecologist.

faqs.question: Is vulvar cancer caused by HPV, like cervical cancer?
faqs.answer: It depends on the type. There are two main types. One type is HPV-related and is often seen in younger, premenopausal women. The other type is non-HPV-related and is more common in older, postmenopausal women. This second type is often associated with a chronic skin condition called lichen sclerosus.

faqs.question: I was just diagnosed with lichen sclerosus. Does this mean I am going to get cancer?
faqs.answer: No. Having lichen sclerosus does not mean you will get cancer. However, it does put you at a higher lifetime risk (about 3-5%). This is why it's critical that you use your steroid ointment as prescribed (to control the inflammation) and get checked by your GYN every 6-12 months for life, even if you have no symptoms.

faqs.question: What does vulvar cancer look like? Is it a lump?
faqs.answer: It can be. It can present as a lump or wart-like growth, a sore or ulcer that won't heal, or a discolored patch (red, white, or dark) that is different from the skin around it. Any new, persistent skin change on the vulva needs to be seen by a doctor.

faqs.question: How is vulvar cancer treated? Will surgery be disfiguring?
faqs.answer: The main treatment is surgery to remove the cancer. In the past, this was a very radical, disfiguring surgery. Today, for early-stage cancers, the surgery is much more conservative, removing only the tumor and a margin of healthy skin. This preserves function and appearance as much as possible.

faqs.question: I've had heavy, gushing periods my whole life. I also get terrible nosebleeds and I bruise if you look at me wrong. Is this normal, or could it be a bleeding disorder?
faqs.answer: This is not normal, and it is the classic presentation of Von Willebrand disease (vWD) in women. It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Many people (especially women) are misdiagnosed for years as just having bad periods or being clumsy.

faqs.question: My doctor wants to do blood tests. Can't they just check my clotting time like they do for other people?
faqs.answer: Standard clotting tests (like PT and PTT) are often completely normal in Von Willebrand disease. You need a specialized vWD panel that specifically measures the amount of Von Willebrand factor (VWF) in your blood and, more importantly, how well it works (its activity).

faqs.question: My son has hemophilia. Is this the same thing?
faqs.answer: No, they are different. Hemophilia is an X-linked (passed from mother to son) disorder where you are missing a clotting factor (Factor VIII or IX). vWD is not X-linked (it affects men and women equally) and is a problem with the glue (Von Willebrand factor) that helps the platelets and Factor VIII stick together. vWD is generally much milder.

faqs.question: Can I take Aspirin or Ibuprofen (Advil) for my period cramps?
faqs.answer: You should never take Aspirin. Aspirin works by making platelets less sticky, which is exactly what you don't want. You should also be very cautious with NSAIDs (like Ibuprofen/Advil) as they can also increase bleeding risk. You must ask your hematologist what is safe for you.

faqs.question: I'm scared to have surgery. How do they stop me from bleeding?
faqs.answer: This is very manageable! Before any surgery or major dental work, you will be pre-treated by your hematologist. For mild vWD, you may get a nasal spray called DDAVP, which squeezes your body's stored VWF into your bloodstream. For more severe types, you will get an IV infusion of actual Von Willebrand factor.

faqs.question: I'm a teacher, and by the end of the day, my voice is gone. It's hoarse and it hurts. Is this just laryngitis?
faqs.answer: This is a functional voice disorder, likely muscle tension dysphonia. You are straining your voice (like an athlete pulling a muscle) from overuse. Laryngitis is typically from an infection. Your problem is from vocal fatigue and misuse. A speech-language pathologist (SLP) can teach you vocal hygiene to fix this.

faqs.question: My voice is hoarse, but it also sounds breathy and weak. I'm not a teacher. What could this be?
faqs.answer: A breathy or weak voice often means your vocal cords are not closing completely. This can be caused by a vocal cord nodule or polyp (a benign growth on one cord) or vocal cord paralysis (where one cord isn't moving), which is allowing air to escape.

faqs.question: I haven't been able to sing for months. I can talk, but I've lost my upper range. What's wrong?
faqs.answer: This is a major red flag for a vocal cord lesion—a polyp, cyst, or nodule. These growths act like a lump on the vocal cord, preventing it from vibrating correctly at high frequencies (your high notes). You need to see an ENT doctor, who will use a camera (stroboscopy) to look at your vocal cords.

faqs.question: My voice sounds shaky or trembly, especially when I try to hold a note. I'm embarrassed to talk.
faqs.answer: This sounds like spasmodic dysphonia or an essential tremor of the voice. This is a neurological voice disorder, not a damage problem. It's caused by involuntary spasms or tremors in the laryngeal muscles. This is often treated with Botox injections into the vocal cords to calm the spasms.

faqs.question: My doctor just said acid reflux (LPR) is causing my hoarseness. How can stomach acid hurt my voice?
faqs.answer: This is Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (LPR). At night, silent reflux (which you may not feel as heartburn) can travel all the way up your esophagus and spill onto your vocal cords, which are right at the top. This acid bathes and inflames your vocal cords all night, making them swollen and hoarse in the morning.

faqs.question: My voice suddenly became extremely breathy and weak. I run out of air when I try to talk. What happened?
faqs.answer: This is the classic sign of a unilateral (one-sided) vocal cord paralysis. The nerve that tells one of your vocal cords to move has been damaged. The paralyzed cord is stuck in an open position, so your two cords can't meet. All the air you're pushing leaks through the gap, creating the weak, breathy sound.

faqs.question: I just had thyroid (or neck/chest) surgery, and now my voice is gone. Did my surgeon mess up?
faqs.answer: This is the most common cause. The recurrent laryngeal nerve that controls your vocal cord runs right through the neck, near the thyroid and chest. It is very delicate. It can be bruised or stretched during surgery, even when the surgeon is being extremely careful. This is a known and common risk of these surgeries.

faqs.question: My doctor said my paralysis is idiopathic. What does that mean?
faqs.answer: Idiopathic means we don't know the cause. In many cases, it's assumed to be caused by a virus (like a bad cold) that has inflamed and damaged the nerve. It can also be caused by a tumor in the chest that is pressing on the nerve, so a CT scan is always done.

faqs.question: Will my voice be stuck like this forever?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Nerves can heal, but it's very slow. Doctors will usually wait and see for 6-12 months to see if the nerve recovers and the voice returns on its own. During this time, a speech therapist can help you use your good cord more effectively.

faqs.question: It's been a year, and my voice is still weak. What can be done now?
faqs.answer: You have excellent options. The goal is to move the paralyzed cord to the middle so the good cord can meet it. This can be done with a bulk injection (injecting a filler, like fat, into the paralyzed cord) or a thyroplasty (a surgery to insert a small shim into the voice box that physically pushes the cord over).

faqs.question: I'm getting these bleached white patches of skin on my hands and around my mouth. They don't itch or hurt. What is this?
faqs.answer: This is the classic description of vitiligo. It is an autoimmune disease, not an infection. Your own immune system is mistakenly attacking and destroying your melanocytes—the cells that produce pigment (color) in your skin.

faqs.question: Is this going to spread and cover my whole body?
faqs.answer: This is the number one fear, and it's unpredictable. In some people, it stays as a few small segmental patches. In others (non-segmental vitiligo), it can be progressive and spread. It most commonly appears on sun-exposed areas (hands, face) and in body folds (armpits, groin).

faqs.question: Is it true that this is linked to other autoimmune diseases?
faqs.answer: Yes. People with vitiligo have a much higher rate of other autoimmune conditions, especially thyroid disease (like Hashimoto's or Grave's). Your doctor must run a blood test (a thyroid panel) to check your thyroid function, as this is a very common comorbidity.

faqs.question: Can I get my color back? Is there a cure?
faqs.answer: There is no cure, but there are treatments to re-pigment the skin. The goal is to calm down the immune system in that area. This is done with: 1) Potent steroid creams or a new JAK inhibitor cream (Opzelura), and 2) Phototherapy (narrow-band UVB light), which stimulates the pigment cells to wake up and migrate back into the white patches.

faqs.question: Will tanning help blend the spots?
faqs.answer: No, tanning will make it look worse. The white vitiligo patches have no pigment and cannot tan—they will only burn. The normal skin around them will get darker, which makes the white spots stand out even more. The most important thing you can do is wear sunscreen to protect the white patches and lessen the contrast.

faqs.question: I'm exhausted, dizzy, and my tongue feels sore and beefy red. My doctor said I have B12 deficiency. What causes this?
faqs.answer: A sore, red tongue (glossitis) and pins and needles (neuropathy) are classic signs of B12 deficiency anemia. The most common cause is not your diet, but an autoimmune condition called pernicious anemia. Your body creates antibodies that destroy the intrinsic factor in your stomach, which is essential for you to absorb B12 from your food.

faqs.question: I'm a strict vegan. Am I at high risk for B12 deficiency?
faqs.answer: Yes, you are at extremely high risk. Vitamin B12 is only found naturally in animal products (meat, milk, eggs). If you are a strict vegan, you must supplement with B12 (either in pills or fortified foods) to prevent this anemia and the serious, irreversible nerve damage it can cause.

faqs.question: My doctor said I have folate deficiency anemia. How is this different from B12?
faqs.answer: Both B12 and Folate (Vitamin B9) are needed to make healthy red blood cells. A deficiency in either one causes megaloblastic anemia (large, immature red blood cells). Folate deficiency is often from diet (not eating green, leafy vegetables) or from heavy alcohol use. A key difference is that folate deficiency does not cause the neurological/nerve symptoms that B12 deficiency does.

faqs.question: If I have pernicious anemia, can't I just take B12 pills?
